From jeme at brelin.net  Sun Jun  1 02:32:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sun Jun  1 02:32:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux compatibility check on these parts...
In-Reply-To: <1054448670.27614.30.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1054419190.27621.9.camel@goose.robinson-west.com> 
 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0305312056550.26256@shaft.bitmine.net>
 <1054448670.27614.30.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306010225350.29940@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sat, 31 May 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> Well, it's very unlikely that I'm going to have to worry about a case.

That was a joke.

> As far as homework, the answers to the questions I've been posing for
> the most part are relevant to just about everyone where even attempting
> to answer them isn't likely to cause pain or hardship.

Well, I was just pointing out that the effort it would take any of us to
go through your hardware list and look up the driver availability is the
same effort you could forward yourself.  I just mean that you're asking
others to do something you could just as easily do yourself.

> The problem I see in the tech sector is job security, I don't have it
> and I'll bet that most of the people on this list don't either.

Job security isn't for wage earners anymore.  Low job security keeps wages
down and prevents workers from asking too much of their employers.  In the
modern jargon this is called "job market flexibility" and it means that
your job can be filled by a dozen or two unemployed people so your
position is "flexible".

Until something serious changes in the economy or society (like a new
industry is created that everyone thinks they need much like we saw with
the automobile and the internet or a new labor movement sweeps the nation
or a plague wipes out a significant chunk of the population), this is just
how things are going to be.

> It's sad that I'm trying to offer a disclaimer I've seen so many
> complain about.

I'm not quite sure what you mean by this last sentence, but I'm pulling
for you, sir.  I sincerely hope you find a way to get by without losing
too much of your self or your happiness.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org



From hapibeli at attbi.com  Sun Jun  1 10:58:02 2003
From: hapibeli at attbi.com (Dirk Ouellette)
Date: Sun Jun  1 10:58:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] export LD_ASSUME_KERNEL=2.2.5
Message-ID: <1054490200.1250.5.camel@localhost.localdomain>

To get Realplayer8 to work in RH9,I put the line export
LD_ASSUME_KERNEL=2.2.5 into  my /etc/profile as follows;

export PATH USER LOGNAME MAIL HOSTNAME HISTSIZE INPUTRC
export LD_ASSUME_KERNEL=2.2.5
for i in /etc/profile.d/*.sh ; do
    if [ -r "$i" ]; then
        . $i
    fi

Was this the correct way to do this?
Dirk



-- 
"Quality is Insurance", Wes Revell, 2002




From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Sun Jun  1 11:00:03 2003
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Sun Jun  1 11:00:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Scalable and esthetic Perl
In-Reply-To: <mailman.1054407082.5641.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
References: <200305301632.h4UGWl506875@gate.daniloff.com> <mailman.1054407082.5641.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <868ysl4r2u.fsf_-_@red.stonehenge.com>

The following message is a courtesy copy of an article
that has been posted to plug.plug as well.

>>>>> "Ron" == Ron Braithwaite <ron at nutriware.com> writes:

Ron> And this brings us to the final point about *my* preference for Java
Ron> over Perl. And that is syntax. I very much like Java's syntax and I very
Ron> much dislike Perl's. This point of view is a personal thing, but
Ron> something I am very willing to defend. But over beer and not on this
Ron> list and not at the risk of starting some sort of flame war.

Uh, you don't get to say "I'm taking the last shot now" and make
statements that would undermine an industry. :)

Ron> I like Java. It is a truely high level, object oriented language.

It's a hybrid OO language, like C++ or Perl.  For *truly* OO, you have
to go to Smalltalk or Eiffel or Ruby.

Ron> My problem with Perl is actually, my problem with C++, only more so. The
Ron> absolute unesthetic code that is produced in Perl drives me mad.

Let's rephrase this in a way we can all agree:

    1) You've seen unesthetic code written in Perl
    2) Perhaps you've produced said code

But I need to add point 3 for balance:

    3) It's also practical and reasonable to produce nice looking Perl
    code that is maintainable and scalable

Perhaps you either haven't seen examples of #3, or you can't
personally produce #3, and therefore blast the whole area.  Too bad.
I won't let that stand.

Ron> But, just like Forth, Perl doesn't scale. I cannot imagine a project
Ron> where 15-20 programmers share a Perl code base. I cannot imagine a
Ron> project with a million lines of Perl code.

You have a very limited imagination.  Again, I think this says more
about you than about Perl.

I've seen the discipline it takes for *any* code base to get to be
workable for 10 programmers and 100K lines of code.  There's nothing
in particular that Perl does to hinder those strategies.  Only bad
project managers. :)

Ron> We can disagree based on our preferences, while still respecting each
Ron> other's abilities. The mark of an adult is the ability to disagree
Ron> without disparaging the other's choice.

Then be sure to phrase your future observations as contextual, rather
than absolute.  I can agree when you make them "in my observation".
But not when you say things that are broad-sweeping like "Perl doesn't
scale" -- that would come as quite a surprise to the people creating
slashcode, ticketmaster.com, cbs-sportsline.com, and hundreds of
others of huge installed Perl code bases.

-- 
Randal L. Schwartz - Stonehenge Consulting Services, Inc. - +1 503 777 0095
<merlyn at stonehenge.com> <URL:http://www.stonehenge.com/merlyn/>
Perl/Unix/security consulting, Technical writing, Comedy, etc. etc.
See PerlTraining.Stonehenge.com for onsite and open-enrollment Perl training!

to go to Smalltalk or Eiffel or Ruby.

Ron> absolute unesthetic code that is produced in Perl drives me mad.

From ron at nutriware.com  Sun Jun  1 14:45:02 2003
From: ron at nutriware.com (Ron Braithwaite)
Date: Sun Jun  1 14:45:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Scalable and esthetic Perl
In-Reply-To: <868ysl4r2u.fsf_-_@red.stonehenge.com>
References: <200305301632.h4UGWl506875@gate.daniloff.com> <mailman.1054407082.5641.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org> <868ysl4r2u.fsf_-_@red.stonehenge.com>
Message-ID: <3EDA73B3.2060802@nutriware.com>

Randal L. Schwartz wrote:
>>>>>>"Ron" == Ron Braithwaite <ron at nutriware.com> writes:
> 
> 
> Ron> And this brings us to the final point about *my* preference for Java
> Ron> over Perl. And that is syntax. I very much like Java's syntax and I very
> Ron> much dislike Perl's. This point of view is a personal thing, but
> Ron> something I am very willing to defend. But over beer and not on this
> Ron> list and not at the risk of starting some sort of flame war.
> 
> Uh, you don't get to say "I'm taking the last shot now" and make
> statements that would undermine an industry. :)

Heh. Of course. :)

> Ron> I like Java. It is a truely high level, object oriented language.
> 
> It's a hybrid OO language, like C++ or Perl.  For *truly* OO, you have
> to go to Smalltalk or Eiffel or Ruby.

Err. I suppose. But as a hybred language, it is much closer to OO than 
C++ is.

> Ron> My problem with Perl is actually, my problem with C++, only more so. The
> Ron> absolute unesthetic code that is produced in Perl drives me mad.
> 
> Let's rephrase this in a way we can all agree:
> 
>     1) You've seen unesthetic code written in Perl
>     2) Perhaps you've produced said code

Definitely 1). I tend to be a little obsessive about writing nice code, 
so I think 2) isn't true. When I write code, I am writing a form of 
poetry and I always treat it as such.

> But I need to add point 3 for balance:
> 
>     3) It's also practical and reasonable to produce nice looking Perl
>     code that is maintainable and scalable

You know, I think you are probably right as long as it is someone like 
you and me writing the code (I think my Perl has always been very 
clean). Its just that I have seen way too much code from others that 
wasn't maintainable and probably wasn't scalable.

> Perhaps you either haven't seen examples of #3, or you can't
> personally produce #3, and therefore blast the whole area.  Too bad.
> I won't let that stand.

And you shouldn't. I had some other stuff happening all around me when I 
wrote that note and I was basically venting far beyond what I would have 
normally.

> Ron> But, just like Forth, Perl doesn't scale. I cannot imagine a project
> Ron> where 15-20 programmers share a Perl code base. I cannot imagine a
> Ron> project with a million lines of Perl code.
> 
> You have a very limited imagination.  Again, I think this says more
> about you than about Perl.
> 
> I've seen the discipline it takes for *any* code base to get to be
> workable for 10 programmers and 100K lines of code.  There's nothing
> in particular that Perl does to hinder those strategies.  Only bad
> project managers. :)

Ah yes, and that hits the nail on the head. Without technically 
competent technical management, everything will always go to hell.

Too many project managers spec'd Ada hoping that it would do their job 
for them, rather than on any virtues of that language.

Neither Forth nor Perl do anything to hinder strategies for 
maintainability or scalability, per se. But they also don't encourage 
it, either. At least, not to any extent that I am aware of.

But I must say that my imagination isn't limited so much as my 
experience is. I have encountered a great many Perl programs and most of 
them have left me a little upset. You are quite right in saying that 
Perl doesn't limit anyone's ability to write good code. But...

> Ron> We can disagree based on our preferences, while still respecting each
> Ron> other's abilities. The mark of an adult is the ability to disagree
> Ron> without disparaging the other's choice.
> 
> Then be sure to phrase your future observations as contextual, rather
> than absolute.  I can agree when you make them "in my observation".
> But not when you say things that are broad-sweeping like "Perl doesn't
> scale" -- that would come as quite a surprise to the people creating
> slashcode, ticketmaster.com, cbs-sportsline.com, and hundreds of
> others of huge installed Perl code bases.

And you are right and I humbly apologize for my hasty words. The very 
fact that there are large successful projects in Perl means that 
somewhere there must be some technical management that is capable of 
setting and enforcing coding and QA standards that work. Something I 
have encountered far too seldom in my career.

But, what I was trying to say still holds true though: When it gets 
right down to it, my preference for Java over Perl is mostly a matter of 
personal taste and style. And I believe the same is probably true for 
your preferences as well.

Peace,
-Ron

-- 
"It was much better to imagine men in some smoky room somewhere, made 
mad and cynical by privilege and power, plotting over the brandy. You 
had to cling to this sort of image because if you didn't you would have 
to face the fact that ordinary people, the kind who brushed the dog and 
told their children bed time stories, were capable of then going out and 
doing horrible things to other ordinary people. It was so much easier to 
blame it on "them." It was bleakly depressing to think that they were 
"us." If it was "them" then nothing was anyone's fault. If it was "us" 
then what did that make "me?"  After all, I am one of "us." I have 
certainly never thought of myself as one of "them." No one ever thinks 
of themselves as one of "them." We are always one of "us." It's always 
"them" that does the bad things." - from "Jingo" by Terry Pratchett




From judah at opusnet.com  Sun Jun  1 17:56:02 2003
From: judah at opusnet.com (Aaron Baer)
Date: Sun Jun  1 17:56:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] export LD_ASSUME_KERNEL=2.2.5
In-Reply-To: <1054490200.1250.5.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1054490200.1250.5.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1054515282.16672.5.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Sun, 2003-06-01 at 10:56, Dirk Ouellette wrote:
> To get Realplayer8 to work in RH9,I put the line export
> LD_ASSUME_KERNEL=2.2.5 into  my /etc/profile as follows;
> 
> export PATH USER LOGNAME MAIL HOSTNAME HISTSIZE INPUTRC
> export LD_ASSUME_KERNEL=2.2.5
> for i in /etc/profile.d/*.sh ; do
>     if [ -r "$i" ]; then
>         . $i
>     fi
> 
> Was this the correct way to do this?
> Dirk

You can open a terminal and test it with  echo $LD_ASSUME_KERNEL

My only concern is wether or not that would force every application to
use the older threading all the time. Which would defeat some of the
purpose of running an rh9 kernel. It sucks but I would rather do it
myself in a terminal until real releases a player that supports the new
threads. They have to eventually because it's the way 2.6 is going to
be. I would hope they'd fix it in the next 8 months or so. Just my
thoughts. I would hope the same fix is it the pipes for Oracle. They're
java implementation is based off of a jre that doesn't support the new
threads libraries. Suns 1.4 and above is the only release that supports
them. I've been using the beta for a while now with no problems in every
day use.

A-
-- 
----
Aaron Baer
judah at opusnet.com
http://www.cat.pdx.edu/~baera/

> ----
> Aaron Baer
> judah at opusnet.com
> http://www.cat.pdx.edu/~baera/
> 
Of course you are saying to put a wrapper around your realplay
executable, like: realplayer where realplayer is a shell script with:
#!/bin/bash
export LD_ASSUME_KERNEL=2.2.5
/usr/X11R6/bin/realplay $@

chmod 755 realplayer

move it to a directory in your path, like /usr/local/bin.

Then when you want to use realplay*, execute the shell script
realplayer.

Ken
CAD2CAM.COM

* This is he location where realplay is put in RedHat 8.0.  Don't know
where it is in 9.0, but could guess it is there.




From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Sun Jun  1 20:59:06 2003
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Sun Jun  1 20:59:06 2003
Subject: [PLUG] C.R.I.M.E. meeting 06/10/2003 @ 10AM @ Verizon
Message-ID: <1054526403.21215.5052.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

CRIME meeting Tuesday 06/10/2003 @ 10AM @ Verizon

Speaker: Dr. Crispin Cowen, of WireX, and OGI

Topic:  ?Defcon Capture the Flag:  Defending Vulnerable Code from
Intense Attack?

Presentation Abstract: Defcon's Capture the Flag (CtF) game is the
largest open computer security hacking game.  Last year's CtF had rules
that made it particularly difficult to be a successful defender.  We
entered an Immunix server, comprised of five years of DARPA-funded
technologies, to see whether this system could survive sustained attack
from determined experts.  We describe our experience surviving Defcon
CtF.


C.R.I.M.E. meets in the Verizon (Airtouch) Cellular building (Take I-5
South to Carmen Drive. The building is on the West side [Tigard side] of
the Freeway). The meeting room is in the back of the building. The talk
begins at 10:00 a.m.The street address is 15575 Sequoia Pkwy, Tigard. 
Lunch generally follows the meeting.


http://crime.whiteknighthackers.com/meetings.php3.


-- 
Zot O'Connor

http://www.ZotConsulting.com
http://www.WhiteKnightHackers.com




From holger at selover.net  Mon Jun  2 09:00:02 2003
From: holger at selover.net (Holger Stephan)
Date: Mon Jun  2 09:00:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mail abuse problem
In-Reply-To: <1054526403.21215.5052.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
References: <1054526403.21215.5052.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
Message-ID: <1054569549.27315.44.camel@halo>

Here is a mail security question:

A few days ago I received a message that contained a .pif file,
obviously a virus infected mail. I'm using Evolution on RH, so I just
deleted it. 

Today the webmaster of one of the domains on my server received an
undeliverable notification from the AOL postmaster, with a virus message
attached. In other words: it seems my webmaster sent out this virus
message:

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
From: 	webmaster at bd-4.org
To: 	sclark3650 at aol.com
Subject: 	Re: Application
Date: 	02 Jun 2003 08:13:55 +0000	
Please see the attached file.

<<Attachment: DOS/Windows program attachment (approved.pif)>>
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

I'm using AUTH for SMTP. There is nothing in the maillog. The only two
people using email with bd-4.org are both on Linux. There are others on
Windows using other domains on the same server. Mail retrieving is with
ipop3/pop3s on the other domains and on bd-4.org only imaps. 

I'm concerned that my mail server is used to spread virus mails. Should
I move to something safer than AUTH with its clear password transfer?
Any ideas? Thanks!

Holger




From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Jun  2 09:12:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Mon Jun  2 09:12:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mail abuse problem
In-Reply-To: <1054569549.27315.44.camel@halo>
References: <1054526403.21215.5052.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
	 <1054569549.27315.44.camel@halo>
Message-ID: <1054570259.1177.5955.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Mon, 2003-06-02 at 08:59, Holger Stephan wrote:

> I'm concerned that my mail server is used to spread virus mails. Should
> I move to something safer than AUTH with its clear password transfer?
> Any ideas? Thanks!

SMTP-SSL with AUTH?

It's probably just a virus like Klez that fakes the sender's address,
based on something in the infected user's addressbook or browser cache.

Wil

Topic:  ?Defcon Capture the Flag:  Defending Vulnerable Code from

Intense Attack?

 

Presentation Abstract: Defcon's Capture the Flag (CtF) game is the

largest open computer security hacking game.  Last year's CtF had rules

that made it particularly difficult to be a successful defender.  We

entered an Immunix server, comprised of five years of DARPA-funded

technologies, to see whether this system could survive sustained attack

from determined experts.  We describe our experience surviving Defcon

CtF.

 

 

C.R.I.M.E. meets in the Verizon (Airtouch) Cellular building (Take I-5

South to Carmen Drive. The building is on the West side [Tigard side] of

the Freeway). The meeting room is in the back of the building. The talk

begins at 10:00 a.m.The street address is 15575 Sequoia Pkwy, Tigard. 

Lunch generally follows the meeting.

 

 

http://crime.whiteknighthackers.com/meetings.php3.

From svanhoosen at yahoo.com  Mon Jun  2 09:18:02 2003
From: svanhoosen at yahoo.com (Scott Van Hoosen)
Date: Mon Jun  2 09:18:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mail abuse problem
In-Reply-To: <1054569549.27315.44.camel@halo>
Message-ID: <20030602161627.39343.qmail@web40803.mail.yahoo.com>

Viruses such as Klex will scan the infected Windows
user's Outlook address book and sends itself to all of
those receipients, then addresses the email FROM
someone from that same address list. That way, you
can't easily tell who actually sent the email, as it
looks like it was sent from someone else. I would bet
that in your situation, someone had that webmaster
email in their address book, then their infected
computer blamed its email blast on them.

-Scott

--- Holger Stephan <holger at selover.net> wrote:
> Here is a mail security question:
> 
> A few days ago I received a message that contained a
> .pif file,
> obviously a virus infected mail. I'm using Evolution
> on RH, so I just
> deleted it. 
>

> Date: 	02 Jun 2003 08:13:55 +0000

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jun  2 09:23:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon Jun  2 09:23:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mail abuse problem
In-Reply-To: <1054569549.27315.44.camel@halo>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306020917170.8621-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On 2 Jun 2003, Holger Stephan wrote:

> Today the webmaster of one of the domains on my server received an
> undeliverable notification from the AOL postmaster, with a virus message
> attached. In other words: it seems my webmaster sent out this virus
> message:

  I've received a few messages supposedly from legitimate domains (e.g.,
aol.com -- and that's not a troll) reporting that a Microsoft-virus was sent
by me to someone at that domain. Because there's no way I can originate (or
pass on) a Microsoft e-mail virus I look in the logs. Nothing there. Then I
traced the IP address from which the message arrived here and I found that
it did not match the supposed domain name.

  Depending on the mood I'm in I either delete them or report them as spam.
There's no way I could have sent that message.

Rich

From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Jun  2 10:14:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon Jun  2 10:14:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mail abuse problem
In-Reply-To: <1054573081.27316.52.camel@halo>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306021002360.15344-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On 2 Jun 2003, Holger Stephan wrote:

> No SSL on SMTP, but it's planned now. 

Hah! That's what you think. :-) Take a good look at your mail log, 
you'll see plenty of entries that show you're already doing SSL on 
SMTP:

  Jun  1 05:03:33 servername sendmail[30187]: STARTTLS=server, 
  relay=franklin.cse.ogi.edu [129.95.40.9], version=TLSv1/SSLv3,
  verify=NO, cipher=EDH-RSA-DES-CBC3-SHA, bits=168/168

So franklin.cse.ogi.edu, the main mail server for the CSE dept at
OGI/OHSU, negotiated a 168-bit key exchange with your server. And,
sure enough, you can use the openssl binary (0.9.7 or higher) to
verify that:

  [heinlein]$ openssl s_client -connect servername:25 -starttls smtp
  CONNECTED(00000003)

Just make sure you substitute your real server name for 'servername.' 
:-) Grep your sendmail.cf for '/ssl/' to get all the references.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

On Mon, 2003-06-02 at 10:13, Paul Heinlein wrote:
    On 2 Jun 2003, Holger Stephan wrote:
    
    > No SSL on SMTP, but it's planned now. 
    
    Hah! That's what you think. :-) Take a good look at your mail log,

From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Jun  2 11:23:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon Jun  2 11:23:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mail abuse problem
In-Reply-To: <1054576820.27316.63.camel@halo>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306021107550.15344-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On 2 Jun 2003, Holger Stephan wrote:

> OK, Paul, SSL on SMTP is enabled but probably only used by you.

Actually, it's not used by me. It was a server-to-server transaction,
completely devoid of user interaction. Newer sendmail installations,
properly configured, will do STARTTLS to try to negotiate an SSL
connection, bumping back down to plain text if SSL is unavailable.

> A question: when setting the hostname, is there a solution for
> multiple domains?

Sadly, no. If your users' mail clients do the sort of cert-checking 
they should be doing, then they'll have to send mail using the 
hostname (CN) embedded in the cert:

  cd /usr/share/ssl/certs
  openssl x509 -in sendmail.pem -noout -subject | cut -d/ -f6

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From montagne at boora.com  Mon Jun  2 12:17:02 2003
From: montagne at boora.com (Michael Montagne)
Date: Mon Jun  2 12:17:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] imap retrieval
Message-ID: <20030602191718.GA1646@boora.com>

I need to automate the download of messages from an Exchange Mail folder
(or two).  I tried to use fetchmail but there are numerous incorrect
headers (these are spam messages) that cause fetchmail to not downlaod
anything.  This is documented on their mailing list as an issue, but
since messages with this problem are usually spam, they are not
concerned.  So I need to find a way to retrieve the mails and put them
in a mailbox on a linux machine.  I need these so I can run sa-learn on
them, therefore the headers should be unaltered.  

-- 
  Michael Montagne  http://www.themontagnes.com  503.226.1575

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Jun  2 12:22:01 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)

Subject: [PLUG] imap retrieval

On Mon, 2003-06-02 at 12:17, Michael Montagne wrote:
> I need to automate the download of messages from an Exchange Mail folder
> (or two).  I tried to use fetchmail but there are numerous incorrect
> headers (these are spam messages) that cause fetchmail to not downlaod
> anything.  This is documented on their mailing list as an issue, but
> since messages with this problem are usually spam, they are not
> concerned.  So I need to find a way to retrieve the mails and put them

You might try writing your own client in Perl or Python.  Both have
modules for speaking IMAP.  A couple hours with RFC 2060 and the man
pages and you should be good to go.

Wil

From pundit at teleport.com  Mon Jun  2 12:43:01 2003
From: pundit at teleport.com (Ken Barber)
Date: Mon Jun  2 12:43:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mail abuse problem
In-Reply-To: <1054569549.27315.44.camel@halo>
References: <1054526403.21215.5052.camel@kat.zotnet.com> <1054569549.27315.44.camel@halo>
Message-ID: <200306021241.54712.pundit@teleport.com>

On Monday 02 June 2003 08:59, Holger Stephan wrote:
> Here is a mail security question:

> Today the webmaster of one of the domains on my server received
> an undeliverable notification from the AOL postmaster, with a
> virus message attached. In other words: it seems my webmaster
> sent out this virus message:

It's Sobig.c.  It hit over the weekend.  I got several copies of 
its predecessor last week.

It installs an SMTP server in 'doze machines and then mass-mails 
itself with forged email headers, some of which claim to come 
from Bill Gates himself.  It didn't come from the AOL postmaster;  
It came from some clueless loser still endangering his/her safety 
and privacy by running 'doze on an Internet-connected machine.

Configuring your SMTP server to reject SMTP requests from hosts 
that fail a reverse DNS lookup will help stop some of these.  But 
not all of them.

The SANS security news browser --

http://www.sans.org/snb/csec.htm

-- does an excellent job of keeping folks up-to-the-minute with 
breaking security news.

Ken



From holger at selover.net  Mon Jun  2 13:04:01 2003
From: holger at selover.net (Holger Stephan)
Date: Mon Jun  2 13:04:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mail abuse problem
In-Reply-To: <200306021241.54712.pundit@teleport.com>

Message-ID: <1054584200.27316.80.camel@halo>

Thank you Ken.

I know it didn't come from the AOL postmaster, the AOL postmaster just
rejected one of the virus mails because the recipient didn't exist.

As much as I appreciate your efforts around open source, I don't think
calling unsuspecting Windows users 'clueless losers' helps our case.
Most of those I know in this matter connect through dial-up to exchange
their mail and don't have DSL or cable. Being in their 60s they are
happy to have mastered that - something they learned late in their life.
The system is and will always be servicing unsuspecting people. It's the
system we need to change, not the retirees.

Holger

From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Jun  2 13:24:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Mon Jun  2 13:24:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mail abuse problem
In-Reply-To: <200306021241.54712.pundit@teleport.com>
References: <1054526403.21215.5052.camel@kat.zotnet.com> <1054569549.27315.44.camel@halo>
 <200306021241.54712.pundit@teleport.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306021320510.24341@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 2 Jun 2003, Ken Barber wrote:
> Configuring your SMTP server to reject SMTP requests from hosts that
> fail a reverse DNS lookup will help stop some of these.  But not all of
> them.

Excuse my ignorance here, but wouldn't this reject mail from virtual
domains?

If I have a server with one IP address that relays mail for foo.net,
bar.org, and baz.biz and I sent mail to you from xyzzy at baz.biz, would your
SMTP agent reject it because the IP reverses as mail.foo.net?

And if not, don't most folks put their dynamic pool IPs in DNS with names
like "dialup-123.isp.org"?

I don't see how this practice doesn't hurt you a lot and fail to help just
as much.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org



From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Jun  2 13:40:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Mon Jun  2 13:40:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mail abuse problem
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306021320510.24341@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <1054526403.21215.5052.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
	 <1054569549.27315.44.camel@halo> <200306021241.54712.pundit@teleport.com>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306021320510.24341@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <1054586146.838.30.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Mon, 2003-06-02 at 13:23, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> On Mon, 2 Jun 2003, Ken Barber wrote:
> > Configuring your SMTP server to reject SMTP requests from hosts that
> > fail a reverse DNS lookup will help stop some of these.  But not all of
> > them.
> 
> Excuse my ignorance here, but wouldn't this reject mail from virtual
> domains?
> 
> If I have a server with one IP address that relays mail for foo.net,
> bar.org, and baz.biz and I sent mail to you from xyzzy at baz.biz, would your
> SMTP agent reject it because the IP reverses as mail.foo.net?

No.  The hostname in EHLO/HELO doesn't have to match the domain, just be
resolvable.  The same for looking up the domain name of the sender's
address (these are usually rejected with a temporary 4XX error, in case
DNS isn't working correctly at the moment).

> And if not, don't most folks put their dynamic pool IPs in DNS with names
> like "dialup-123.isp.org"?
> 
> I don't see how this practice doesn't hurt you a lot and fail to help just
> as much.

The idea is that most poorly-configured networks don't have reverse DNS
setup, and that well-configured networks will be more vigilant against
spammers.  The sets aren't exactly equal, but close enough that it's
rarely a problem and that it blocks lots of spam.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *
*     Tired of spam and viruses in your e-mail?  Get the     *
* Naked Ape Mail Defender! http://nakedape.cc/r/maildefender *

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Mon Jun  2 13:55:03 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Mon Jun  2 13:55:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mail abuse problem
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306021320510.24341@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <1054526403.21215.5052.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
	<1054569549.27315.44.camel@halo>
	<200306021241.54712.pundit@teleport.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.52.0306021320510.24341@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <86r86cyzgz.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Jeme" == Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:

Ken> Configuring your SMTP server to reject SMTP requests from hosts
Ken> that fail a reverse DNS lookup will help stop some of these.  But
Ken> not all of them.

Jeme> Excuse my ignorance here, but wouldn't this reject mail from
Jeme> virtual domains?

Jeme> If I have a server with one IP address that relays mail for
Jeme> foo.net, bar.org, and baz.biz and I sent mail to you from
Jeme> xyzzy at baz.biz, would your SMTP agent reject it because the IP
Jeme> reverses as mail.foo.net?

I think you are okay as long as your message from xyzzy at baz.biz is
forwarded through mail.foo.net and *it's* IP reverse lookups resolve
"correctly".  It isn't a question of what the From: line says.

Jeme> And if not, don't most folks put their dynamic pool IPs in DNS
Jeme> with names like "dialup-123.isp.org"?

Then you (and your recipient) are screwed, or you forward through your
ISP or some other helpful host that doesn't fail the reverse lookup.


--

seniorr at aracnet.com       whole earth.  But not forever!  I tell you, the day

                          the world has never heard before.'' -- Ben Hur

On Mon, 2 Jun 2003, Alex Daniloff wrote:

> I would be very happy if somebody on this list can provide some
> information on .NET vs other technology, preferably open sourced.

Alex,

  Check the Linux World and Linux Journal Web sites. I believe it was on one
or the other where I read a very comprehensive critique of .NET that found
not even Microsoft understood what it was supposed to be or do (based on
conflicting statements they've issued). It is also a collection of failed or
obsolete technology (according to the review) that did not work as
individual pieces so they've all been thrown together in the hope that some
magic synergy would make a silk purse from a sow's ear.

  I'm sure google will turn something up.

Rich

view of how your performance will be.

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Mon Jun  2 17:19:02 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Mon Jun  2 17:19:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] resovl.conf
In-Reply-To: <20030603000511.GB3141@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>
References: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCIEMNCLAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
	 <20030603000511.GB3141@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <1054599514.1101.1427.camel@main>

On Mon, 2003-06-02 at 17:05, Rogan Creswick wrote:
> On Tue, Jun 03, 2003 at 07:57:54AM +0800, Billy Dimaculangan wrote:
> >    I change something in my resolv.conf file, what do I need to do in order
> >    for changes to take effect..?
> 
> AFAIK, that's all you have to do.
> 
> Someone (please!) correct me if I'm wrong.
> 
> -Rogan
> 

I agree, I have been doing a lot of it these days and have not ran into
a problem yet. As root you can do an `/etc/init.d/network restart` if
you so desire but if your not getting the results from the resolv.conf
changes that you expect than you might revisit the file looking for a
typo.

From techmage at aracnet.com  Mon Jun  2 17:20:03 2003

>Sorry, I'm not in a position to ask him such a question. 
>You know all this corporate politic, subordinance and other things.
>All I can do is to present him with evidences that .NET is a not
>worthy technology to standardize upon.
>I would be very happy if somebody on this list can provide some
>information on .NET vs other technology, preferably open sourced.

>Alex

Hi Alex,
I'm studying .net towards my degree and my take from instructors and
such is it's MS attempt at Java, since they won't use Java. I'm
unimpressed, and the last unofficial I heard is it's stopped being
pushed do to security leaks and that industry is not inclined to adopt
it based on it's bugginess and failure to be able to port to all
platforms as promised. Google will be your best shot for "Official"
information though. My personal on it is it's VB in a new coat and
pair of shoes and the shoes are too big and the coat too small.
I long for a school that actually TEACHES unix systems. Mike and Ed
are great, but the school sucks as far as *nix. I even hear that PSU
is going to be dropping it's *nix stuff too, which leaves me trying to
decide where to live to get the education I want.

Good luck and if your boss doesn't go for it, take heart, the market
is changing and you may be replacing him sooner than he thinks.

Harry

knit one
Perl Two
knit one 
Perl 5.5

From svanhoosen at yahoo.com  Mon Jun  2 17:21:02 2003
From: svanhoosen at yahoo.com (Scott Van Hoosen)
Date: Mon Jun  2 17:21:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Samba/Winbind with NT Domain
In-Reply-To: <20030602161627.39343.qmail@web40803.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20030603002027.32011.qmail@web40810.mail.yahoo.com>

I'm working on joining a Red Hat Samba server to our
NT Domain, using winbind. It seems to finally be
working, but many of our Domain groups have spaces in
them. I can't seem to find a way to add these to my
smb.conf file, is it uses spaces to separate shares. I
have tried enclosing them in quotes and escaping the
spaces with a leading \ but nothing seems to work.

Is there an easy way to do this, or must I rename all
of my groups (groan)?

-Scott

From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Jun  2 17:35:03 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon Jun  2 17:35:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] resovl.conf
In-Reply-To: <1054599514.1101.1427.camel@main>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306021733090.15344-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On 2 Jun 2003, Steven A. Adams wrote:

> As root you can do an `/etc/init.d/network restart`

If you're running nscd, you might think about restarting it too:

  /etc/init.d/nscd restart

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From stevea at nwtechops.com  Mon Jun  2 18:03:02 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Mon Jun  2 18:03:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] resovl.conf
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306021733090.15344-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

	 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306021733090.15344-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <1054602166.1103.1434.camel@main>

On Mon, 2003-06-02 at 17:34, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On 2 Jun 2003, Steven A. Adams wrote:
> 
> > As root you can do an `/etc/init.d/network restart`
> 
> If you're running nscd, you might think about restarting it too:
> 
>   /etc/init.d/nscd restart
> 

Very true, good catch. Most of my installs use file dns for host
resolution in nsswitch and it seems to have no effect in that case.

Steve




From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Mon Jun  2 18:20:02 2003
From: josh at emediatedesigns.com (Josh Orchard)
Date: Mon Jun  2 18:20:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] .NET technology on Linux or a good substitution?
In-Reply-To: <200306022127.h52LR4H11095@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <86n0h0yz3g.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> 
     <200306022127.h52LR4H11095@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <1843.134.244.174.75.1054603162.squirrel@sautez.com>

>> Alex> web environment?
>>
>> Flippant reply (not informed by any actual experience with .NET
>> whatsoever) follows:
>>
>>   Ask him if he wants his company to turn a profit or piss all the
>>   revenue away solving stupid unproductive problems.
>
> Sorry, I'm not in a position to ask him such a question.
> You know all this corporate politic, subordinance and other things.
> All I can do is to present him with evidences that .NET is a not
> worthy technology to standardize upon.
> I would be very happy if somebody on this list can provide some
> information on .NET vs other technology, preferably open sourced.
>
> Thanks in advance.
>

Alex,

I actually do some work with .NET.  Not directly mind you, but being that
my job is to begin to understand it and be an authority on .NET and
JSP/Servlet Enterprise solutions I would like to give a bit of overview.

The .NET which has gone through some confusion changes in marketing names.
 As you may have heard MS changed their new server name from .NET server
to Server 2003 to avoid some of the confusion.  MS approached the
marketing side of the technolgy all wrong.  The concept of .NET is based
on current technologies using SOAP/XML and other 'standards'.  I'll quote
the standards as all the standard commitees always seem to be writing more
specs then actually doing work.  So, MS, IBM, SUN, and any other company
that wants to make a living and provide solutions for today's needs take
some liberties in their coding practices.

What you need to understand is why the request is being made?  Without
that knowing that first, you can't make a decision on the use of .NET and
what it offers verses other solutions.  My daily development is with
JSP/Servlet technology because I support many different platforms.  But
another part of my company and collegues I work daily with are developing
.NET solutions for huge coorporate clients of ours.  We are working
together to find solutions and both technologies can provide a solution. 
.NET has a better security then java applets.  It uses C# (C-sharp) as the
base language which is MS version of java with many different approaches
to how one may have improved java.  They allow certain abilities that java
wouldn't allow.  This gives more flexibility but at the same time is a
limit in other ways. Every decision gives you good and bad results. 
Personally, I think if you are going to write an applet or C# small client
then you might as well write a full C client.  That is a better solution.

The .NET techology is really a way of saying web services.  You should
review what web services are and how they work and see if that is
something that would provide a solution for your company.  Then look at
how java provides those services.  Compare the good and bad.  My company
has hired consultants to analys the pros and cons between java and .NET
and I've seen huge presentations comparing them.

I have determine that the orginally question needs to be answered.  What
are you tring to solve?  Web services are not the end all solution and
give flexibility and restrictions just like any other solution.  If you
like, I could find some of the presentations and see if they are not
confidential and email them to you.  They do not try to say one is better
but compare java and .NET as a web services solution.  That was our focus.

The other issue may be that the boss is hearing the phrase and perhaps
confused on what was .NET and what is .NET now.  They are constant
evolving solutions and some times very difficult to describe.  I do think
it is getting better and has some advantages over other solutions.  But is
that solution what you need?  Even if you can't talk to the boss that
aksed the question you still can ask your boss and present to him/her with
all the possibilites as a solution.  I work on a Tomcat/JSP/Servlet
solution and we have similar solutions on .NET for other customers.  Each
had advantages that each client needed to leverage into existing
infrastructures.

You can contact me off list if you want to discuss this further.  Again,
I'll look for the presentations tomorrow and let you know if I can share
the results.  Unfortunately, I may not be able to share them with you.  I
could perhaps summerize them a bit.

Good luck with the research.  I know that asking or convincing a boss of a
technology solution is sometimes a difficult task.  I have fought for open
source solutions to redistribute and it has been a long hard battle and in
many ways my little office has done things that have other offices
jealous.  At the same time, I do see the other commercial solutions we use
as some nice technology I would like to try.

Josh

put that off till the last in my education to avoid costly
recertification.  My dream is to ignore Microsoft altogether.  I wonder
who's responsible for the push towards Microsoft at PCC and PSU where it
is clear that Microsoft has failed to duplicate the quality of the
alternatives at a reasonable price?

a comprehensive book on the tool kit.  Unfortunately, I don't have a
month to learn how the functions work by going to the source.

can't comment very wisely on what should and should not be done about
it.

A networking book from their bookstore is focused on Linux's advanced
routing capabilities so from that standpoint the institution looks 
promising as a PSU alternative.

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Mon Jun  2 23:47:04 2003
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Mon Jun  2 23:47:04 2003
Subject: [PLUG] C.R.I.M.E. meeting moved to wednesday! 06/11/2003 @ 10AM @ Verizon
Message-ID: <1054622898.21232.5123.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

NOTE:  The CRIME meeting has moved to Wednesday the 11th of June.

CRIME meeting Tuesday 06/11/2003 @ 10AM @ Verizon

Speaker: Dr. Crispin Cowen, of WireX, and OGI

Topic:  ?Defcon Capture the Flag:  Defending Vulnerable Code from
Intense Attack?

Presentation Abstract: Defcon's Capture the Flag (CtF) game is the
largest open computer security hacking game.  Last year's CtF had rules
that made it particularly difficult to be a successful defender.  We
entered an Immunix server, comprised of five years of DARPA-funded
technologies, to see whether this system could survive sustained attack
from determined experts.  We describe our experience surviving Defcon
CtF.


C.R.I.M.E. meets in the Verizon (Airtouch) Cellular building (Take I-5
South to Carmen Drive. The building is on the West side [Tigard side] of
the Freeway). The meeting room is in the back of the building. The talk
begins at 10:00 a.m.The street address is 15575 Sequoia Pkwy, Tigard. 
Lunch generally follows the meeting.


http://crime.whiteknighthackers.com/meetings.php3.

Zot O'Connor

Message-ID: <20030603170109.GB22224@boora.com>

>On about 02/06/03, Wil Cooley was heard to proclaim:

> On Mon, 2003-06-02 at 12:17, Michael Montagne wrote:
> > I need to automate the download of messages from an Exchange Mail
> folder
> > (or two).  I tried to use fetchmail but there are numerous incorrect
> > headers (these are spam messages) that cause fetchmail to not downlaod
> > anything.  This is documented on their mailing list as an issue, but
> > since messages with this problem are usually spam, they are not
> > concerned.  So I need to find a way to retrieve the mails and put them
> > in a mailbox on a linux machine.  I need these so I can run sa-learn
> on
> > them, therefore the headers should be unaltered.  
> 
> You might try writing your own client in Perl or Python.  Both have
> modules for speaking IMAP.  A couple hours with RFC 2060 and the man
> pages and you should be good to go.
> 
> Wil

That was so easy.  Thanks for the tip!!

From michael at robinson-west.com  Tue Jun  3 10:50:02 2003

Date: Tue Jun  3 10:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Taxes for contract work...
Message-ID: <1054662154.13817.19.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

I'm new at this.  I earned $689.85 in my last check and since I
guess the limit for not reporting is $500 that I am responsible
for the taxes.  Is fica really %10.5 for everyone?  I'm a 23 year
old dependent with $500 of outstanding subsidized stafford loan
to pay off @ $50/month, I owe darn near everything I've earned 
so far.  One thing I wonder about is if amounts earned below the 
minimum tax level will be reported by my employer, i.e. if I get 
a $200 check after two under hour weeks will I have to pay taxes 
on that amount?  Is $10.50/hour reasonable for a person with a 
general studies degree from PCC?  Can anyone guess my income tax?

I wish I could get a job with stable hours, benefits, better pay, 
and Linux training.

     --  Michael C. Robinson





From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Jun  3 11:06:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue Jun  3 11:06:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Taxes for contract work...
In-Reply-To: <1054662154.13817.19.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306031101510.13226-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On 3 Jun 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote:

> I'm new at this.  I earned $689.85 in my last check and since I guess the
> limit for not reporting is $500 that I am responsible for the taxes.  Is
> fica really %10.5 for everyone?  I'm a 23 year old dependent with $500 of
> outstanding subsidized stafford loan to pay off @ $50/month, I owe darn
> near everything I've earned so far.  One thing I wonder about is if
> amounts earned below the minimum tax level will be reported by my
> employer, i.e. if I get a $200 check after two under hour weeks will I
> have to pay taxes on that amount?  Is $10.50/hour reasonable for a person
> with a general studies degree from PCC?  Can anyone guess my income tax?

  I'm not an accountant so I recommend that you contact one for definitive
answers. If you're self employed you need to file quarterly tax returns to
the IRS and state. You also need to pay other taxes, depending on the
jurisdiction in which you live. The least expensive way to find out is to
call an accountant for advice specific to your situation. I can give you the
telephone number of my accountant if you wish. She charges only $65/hour;
exceptionally reasonable.

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

                       Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
            2404 SW 22nd Street | Troutdale, OR 97060-1247 | U.S.A.
 + 1 503-667-4517 (voice) | + 1 503-667-8863 (fax) | rshepard&#64;appl-ecosys.com

From danielx.j.petcher at intel.com  Tue Jun  3 11:19:02 2003
From: danielx.j.petcher at intel.com (Petcher, Danielx J)
Date: Tue Jun  3 11:19:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Taxes for contract work...
Message-ID: <7D6F4CF55743264F8B23E20353705EEC0A8F1A@orsmsx408.amr.corp.intel.com>

Talk to the IRS and your state's revenue department if you want ACURATE
and FREE tax advice. They're happy to help, especially if you call some
other time than mere days before the end of a fiscal quarter.

If you want technical help with Linux or even just interesting
conversation with a Linux theme, you've come to the right place.

If you want anecdotal information that could land you beaucoup bucks in
penalties, fees, and interest, we might just be able to help you there,
too.

To put it more kindly, I wouldn't recommend trusting tax advice that
didn't come from an accountant, a lawyer, or the government itself. Your
livelihood, and even your liberty (should your ignorance result in
fraud) are at stake here!

-djp
http://folding.stanford.edu - the brain you save may be your own!

From dpool at hevanet.com  Tue Jun  3 11:36:01 2003
From: dpool at hevanet.com (david pool)
Date: Tue Jun  3 11:36:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Taxes for contract work...
References: <7D6F4CF55743264F8B23E20353705EEC0A8F1A@orsmsx408.amr.corp.intel.com>
Message-ID: <3EDCEA63.6060702@hevanet.com>

Petcher, Danielx J wrote:

>If you want anecdotal information that could land you beaucoup bucks in
>penalties, fees, and interest, we might just be able to help you there,
>too.
>

For example, one might suggest that if you're earning less than 10,000 a 
year you could blow off quarterly filings your first year and talk to an 
accountant at the end of the year to see how it's going. The anecdote 
would say the IRS doesn't impose fines in such cases because it's not 
cost effective for them. But then, they can and they certainly might.

d

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Jun  3 13:18:01 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue Jun  3 13:18:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] .pdf ???
In-Reply-To: <1054604902.1252.35.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1054604902.1252.35.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306031316200.9124@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 2 Jun 2003, Dirk Ouellette wrote:
> I've got a supposed .pdf that came in an evolution email, but I can't
> send it as an attachment. it is in
> /tmp/evolution-500-1218/evolution.wMmFq8/Forms_Legal_.PDF
>
> Is this some kind of virtual .pdf that is only printable and not
> forwardable as an attachment?

Well, think about it.  You're on a unix-like system and you run evolution
as a regular privileged user.  What could anyone do to a file that would
make it so that you couldn't copy the bits into an email attachment?

Try `file /tmp/evolution-500-1218/evolution.wMmFq8/Forms_Legal_.PDF` and
see that it's really a PDF (or at least appears to be one by the rules of
magic).  Make a copy of it.  Try to delete the original.  Open it with a
PDF reader.  There are lots of things you can do to assure yourself that
it's just a file and bits are bits.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org



From deansuhr at carpedis.com  Tue Jun  3 14:02:02 2003
From: deansuhr at carpedis.com (Dean Suhr)
Date: Tue Jun  3 14:02:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Getting Started - Hardware Choices
In-Reply-To: <3EDCF726.3010406@linuxlink.com>
Message-ID: <BB025A98.3AC9F%deansuhr@carpedis.com>

Good Afternoon,

I was just thrust into the support role at my work to repair a hacked
corporate web server.  I wiped out the hard drive, installed RH Linux v9 and
had a great Linux experience. So I am now motivated to consider Linux for
another project ... I found this group and I thought I'd seek some advice.

I have an  original iMac (OS X/Unix) running as a server at home that needs
to be migrated to different hardware and I am considering options and would
like some advice.  I am serving for a foundation that I run along with a
dozen or so other non-profit organizations on a DSL line (UPS, local
backups, etc.).  I need good reliability and decent uptime - but the server
load is very light overall hundreds of visits per week - all static pages.
I would like to be serving streaming video in the coming months (when the
upstream DSL bandwidth is increased) - for perhaps 2 or 3 users at a time.

I will run Apache, Mailman, an e-mail server and DNS - that's about it. No
file sharing, no local user on this machine.

The question I have surrounds hardware. My only real requirement is decent
reliability with >99% uptime, and USB so I can KVM with my desktop hardware.
What would you suggest and why? A few things I am pondering (target cost is
$200-$300):

* I have found a commercial grade server with dual PIII-500's in it for
$275.  128Mb, 9Gb This seems like the best deal to me - but, can I install a
PCI card to get the USB interface that I want to run the system
post-configuration with USB keyboard and mouse?.

* Fry's has a P4-1.1G or so for $229

* I could build a box - what processor would you suggest - do I need P4 or
would PIII do the job?  Any special power supply or motherboard
requirements?

* A slew of Dell machines on eBay for $100-$300 that are used desktops -
most with PIII 500+

Or would a slower machine work as well?

* I have a PowerComputing PowerTowerPro box that is server grade with a
PowerPC processor in it.  I am game to try a Debian install (even though a
try about two years ago was fruitless) - but this box does not have USB
(would use a PCI add-in and I am concerned that the ease-of-use of Red Hat's
one-click software up to date process would not be available).
 
Thanks!

Dean
West Linn, OR




From mikedela at ipns.com  Tue Jun  3 14:21:01 2003
From: mikedela at ipns.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Tue Jun  3 14:21:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Getting Started - Hardware Choices
In-Reply-To: <BB025A98.3AC9F%deansuhr@carpedis.com>
Message-ID: <KE8LKXVA6VPEBBA64YUICB0ISRVSTO.3edd1116@mike>

6/3/03 2:00:56 PM, Dean Suhr <deansuhr at carpedis.com> wrote:

>and USB so I can KVM with my desktop hardware.

Are you familiar with the excellent capabilities that ssh and 
other applications can provide you? I have a server less than 
5 feet away from me that does not have a monitor or keyboard 
on it. It is very simple to manage and use Linux without 
being a local user.

Mike De La Mater
mikedela at ipns.com
503-702-6749 






From pundit at teleport.com  Tue Jun  3 15:30:03 2003
From: pundit at teleport.com (Ken Barber)
Date: Tue Jun  3 15:30:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Getting Started - Hardware Choices
In-Reply-To: <BB025A98.3AC9F%deansuhr@carpedis.com>
References: <BB025A98.3AC9F%deansuhr@carpedis.com>
Message-ID: <200306031528.34134.pundit@teleport.com>

On Tuesday 03 June 2003 14:00, Dean Suhr wrote:

> * I have a PowerComputing PowerTowerPro box that is server
> grade with a PowerPC processor in it.  I am game to try a
> Debian install (even though a try about two years ago was
> fruitless) - but this box does not have USB (would use a PCI
> add-in and I am concerned that the ease-of-use of Red Hat's
> one-click software up to date process would not be available).

RedHat doesn't make a product that runs on PPC so you'll have 
trouble using their one-click update process anyway.

However, Yellow Dog Linux 3.0 is basically a re-compile of RedHat 
8.0 for the PPC processor.  They don't use RedHat's UpToDate 
product, obviously, but they do have a couple of their own 
updaters:  apt-get and yum.  Neither is "clickable" since they're 
CLI apps, but yum ran pretty flawlessly for me the one time I 
tried it, and the first thing that came to my mind was, "hey, 
I'll bet I could script this, and just run it in a cron job!"

Ken

From sandy at herring.org  Tue Jun  3 16:08:02 2003
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Tue Jun  3 16:08:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Getting Started - Hardware Choices
In-Reply-To: <BB0271F7.3ACF5%deansuhr@carpedis.com>
References: <KE8LKXVA6VPEBBA64YUICB0ISRVSTO.3edd1116@mike> <BB0271F7.3ACF5%deansuhr@carpedis.com>
Message-ID: <20030603230750.GA19928@kippered.herring.org>

Dean,

I've not (yet) used it, but I believe VNC (Virtual Network Computing) is
what you want...

    http://www.uk.research.att.com/vnc/

It is part of the RH linux distros...

[bigfish at kippered bigfish]$ apropos vnc
Xvnc                 (1)  - a VNC server
vncconnect           (1)  - connect a VNC server to a VNC viewer
vncpasswd            (1)  - set password for VNC server
vncserver            (1)  - start a VNC server application
vncviewer            (1)  - VNC client application

FWIW, my web server is an ancient Pentium Pro-S (SMP with matched CPUs w/512
KB cache) w/256Mb RAM running RH7.3 and Apache 1.3.27. It does yeoman's
duty, though it also has a relatively light load...

    http://herring.org/usage/
    
Availability > 99% (as long as PGE isn't mucking about)...

  4:05pm  up 102 days,  9:15, 10 users,  load average: 0.28, 0.38, 0.39

You don't need a lot of beef for linux (although I can't speak to what
streaming video may require).

cheers,
Sandy

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Tue Jun  3 16:23:02 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Tue Jun  3 16:23:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] O'Reilly Open Source Convention
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306031617060.5544-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

I'm about to send out a couple postings relating to O'Reilly Open
Source Convention, but first I want to remind people that

           O'Reilly Open Source Convention

                      will be

                    July 7-11, 2003
                         at
              The Portland Marriott Downtown
                 1401 SW Naito Parkway
                   Portland, OR 97201

Monday and Tuesday will have special tutorials.
Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday will have the general sessions
The vendor exhibition will be Wednesday and Thursday.
Check http://conferences.oreillynet.com for details.

Like most professional conferences, this conference is expensive.
Get your employer to send you if at all possible.
We want O'Reilly to make money on this conference and bring more
events to the Oregon Open Source Community.

If you do sign up to attend, you can probably still get a 30% discount
by admitting that you are a member of the Portland Linux/Unix Group
and giving the secret but widely published code "os03pug"; and remember
"You are a member of the Portland Linux/Unix Group if you say you
are a member of the Portland Linux/Unix Group".

If you can not afford to attend, you can:

       -  Attend the vendor's exhibit on Wednesday and Thursday.
          I'm not sure how much this costs at the event.
          It may be as much as $100.00.  However, an Exhibit Only
          Pass is FREE if you register on-line at
                    http://conferences.oreillynet.com.

       -  Volunteer to work at the conference.
          PLUG has negotiated 20 positions.
          More on this in a later posting.

                                          Sincerely,
                                          David Mandel
                                          Chief Activist
                                          Portland Linux/Unix Group
                                          1440 NE 59th
                                          Portland, Oregon 97213

O'Reilly needs 20 volunteers to help with the O'Reilly Open Source
Convention on July 7-11, 2003.  Actually, they need ten volunteers
to work on Wednesday and ten volunteers to work on Thursday; and
they will give all 20 volunteers passes to the main conference
(Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday exhibits and sessions).
To sign up:

       -  READ the rest of this posting.
          I have appended O'Reilly's invitation to this posting
          which describes everything involved in helping them.

       -  If you still want to volunteer, email me at dmandel at pdxLinux.org
          with:

          Name:           (First and Last name)

          Day you want to work:
              options are "Wednesday, July  9th" and Thursday, July 10th"

          Thursday's PLUG meeting in Portland.

information to O'Reilly.  If we get more than 20 volunteers, I will
build a stand-by list and see if I can find other opportunities.

                             Volunteering at OSCON

    O'Reilly & Associates would like to extend a special invitation
    to all Portland Linux/Unix Group members to attend the O'Reilly
    Open Source Convention Sessions for FREE (Wednesday - Friday,
    July 9th - 11th) -- a value of $1095 -- in exchange for one full
    day of your volunteered time and service at the Convention.


                                   Details

    We are currently looking for a total of 20 volunteers to help us
    out by monitoring session rooms and verifying attendee badges on
    the days of Wednesday, July 9th and Thursday, July 10th .  We need
    ten committed volunteers per day (for a total of 20), and space is
    available on a first-come, first-serve basis.
    (Email address required for volunteer instructions and verification.)

    Only one full day of volunteering is required to gain free access
    to the convention sessions.  Volunteering does not require any heavy
    labor or special skills.  On your chosen day of service, you will be
    required to work from 9:00 am until 5:30 pm.  A one hour lunch break
    (on your own) is included in the work day, along with two 15-minute
    breaks.  Your free convention pass will include all events during
    the Convention (Wednesday - Friday) including entrance into the
    Exhibit Hall and all Exhibit Hall events.

    This offer *does not* include any tutorials (Monday - Tuesday).
    However, if you are interested in purchasing a tutorial pass to
    attend a day or two of tutorials, you may use this discount code
    to receive 30% your tutorial fees.  Discount Code: os03pug

    Sign up on the attached volunteer sign-up sheets to confirm which day
    you will commit to volunteering your time.  You may want to visit our
    "At-a-Glance" schedule online to review which sessions you want to
    attend before scheduling your work day.
    http://conferences.oreillynet.com/pub/w/23/oscon_grid.html

    We look forward to working with you at OSCON!
    - O'Reilly Conference Team

Hours:  9:00 AM to 5:30 PM
Check in at Registration at 9:00 AM

From: bmdimaculangan at bhpi.com.ph (Billy Dimaculangan)
Date: Tue Jun  3 17:19:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] HTTP 404 - File not found
Message-ID: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCCEOCCLAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>

We have 2 boxes here. The mail server and web server. Recently our ISP is
hosting our web server and the mail server stays with us. Until we changed
ISP and now we both have our web and mail server with us.  The web server is
up and running which we setup and configure after we've change ISP.  The
problem since then is our mail server, we cannot access the web mail, but we
can send and receive email using MS outlook through POP3.  We've advised the
ISP for the IP address that we've used and properly configured gateway
address that they've given. Using another dialup account, sending ping
request to the IP address of the mail server seems to be no problem but
sending ping request to the hostname of the mail server was unsuccessful.
Accessing through web browser the IMP web mail with the hostname or the ip
address gives an HTTP 404 - file not found error. I've already checked the
logs and still nothing new.  What configuration are we missing?

TIA
---
Billy





From drl at drloree.com  Tue Jun  3 18:32:01 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Tue Jun  3 18:32:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] HTTP 404 - File not found
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCCEOCCLAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
References: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCCEOCCLAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <1054690288.27359.107.camel@toshi>

On Tue, 2003-06-03 at 17:14, Billy Dimaculangan wrote:
> We have 2 boxes here. The mail server and web server. Recently our ISP is
> hosting our web server and the mail server stays with us. Until we changed
> ISP and now we both have our web and mail server with us.  The web server is
> up and running which we setup and configure after we've change ISP.  The
> problem since then is our mail server, we cannot access the web mail, but we
> can send and receive email using MS outlook through POP3.  We've advised the
> ISP for the IP address that we've used and properly configured gateway
> address that they've given. Using another dialup account, sending ping
> request to the IP address of the mail server seems to be no problem but
> sending ping request to the hostname of the mail server was unsuccessful.

This means that your DNS change hasn't caught up with you.  Did you have
someone change the DNS setup?

> Accessing through web browser the IMP web mail with the hostname or the ip
> address gives an HTTP 404 - file not found error. I've already checked the
> logs and still nothing new.  What configuration are we missing?

This could be because the client isn't capable of sending the hostname. 
Fix your DNS before mucking around with the server.

Good Luck

Derek Loree





From sandy at herring.org  Tue Jun  3 18:43:01 2003
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Tue Jun  3 18:43:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Getting Started - Hardware Choices
In-Reply-To: <20030603230750.GA19928@kippered.herring.org>
References: <KE8LKXVA6VPEBBA64YUICB0ISRVSTO.3edd1116@mike> <BB0271F7.3ACF5%deansuhr@carpedis.com> <20030603230750.GA19928@kippered.herring.org>
Message-ID: <20030604014235.GA21113@kippered.herring.org>

On Tue, 03 Jun 2003, Sandy Herring wrote: 
> Dean,
> 
> I've not (yet) used it, but I believe VNC (Virtual Network Computing) is
> what you want...
> 
>     http://www.uk.research.att.com/vnc/

Okay... I've used it now... thanks for asking the question, Dean - it
incented me to try it. One tip I learned along the way... if you're going to
use gnome as your desktop /and/ you already have an instance of gnome
running, you will want to modify ~/.vnc/xstartup to unset your
SESSION_MANAGER environment variable...

    #!/bin/sh

    # Red Hat Linux VNC session startup script
    unset SESSION_MANAGER
    exec /etc/X11/xinit/xinitrc

Also, if you want to see the Nautilus panel, run vncviewer full screen.

Very cool stuff.

cheers,
Sandy
--

From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Jun  3 21:25:02 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue Jun  3 21:25:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] PCI/AGP Graphics Board Problem
In-Reply-To: <20030520230018.9081.qmail@station173.com>
References: <20030520230018.9081.qmail@station173.com>
Message-ID: <20030604042420.GA15278@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* plug <plug at ardware.net> [2003-05-20 16:01]:
> So from what I can figure, as soon as the kernel kicks in, it fails to
> send any output to the graphics board.  I can rebuild the kernel 
> because the system boots, but don't
> have any idea where to start to solve the problem.  

A co-worker of mine was having difficulty with X on a ATI PCI Radeon
7000 today. 

The fix was to comment out the "dri" line in the XF86Config file. "dri"
is only used with AGP cards (or so I'm told). 

-- 
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

Top post? http://www.caliburn.nl/topposting.html

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Tue Jun  3 23:08:02 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Tue Jun  3 23:08:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] busted AGP slot? ... evidently not!
In-Reply-To: <86bs0qwao6.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <OIFAA783JEOLWRFE42WTA9FB963YC0EB.3e659844@miked>
	<86bs0qwao6.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <86adcyqswm.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Russell" == Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com> writes:

>>>>> "Mike" == Mike De La Mater <mikedela at ipns.com> writes:

Mike> IIRC, 1) We verified that the card was good in another system

Russell> Yes.

Mike> 2) We used a different AGP card in the slot, and it worked fine

Russell> Not exactly.  We removed the AGP card, which reenabled the
Russell> onboard AGP graphics.  We did this on two motherboards (same
Russell> part number) and got identical behavior.  The second
Russell> motherboard was brand new.

Mike> 3) We removed the drivers for the card and COMPLETELY
Mike> reinstalled it

Russell> It isn't even beeping during the power-on-self-tests.  There
Russell> is no video _of_ the power-on-self-tests, screen black, not
Russell> even a blinking cursor.  AFAICT, it hasn't even looked to see
Russell> if there is a hard disk attached, much less caring about an
Russell> OS, so it seems to me that "drivers" are irrelevant here.

Russell> This is an Intel D845GBVL, a P4 motherboard.

Russell> I did try upgrading the BIOS from P09 to P13.  No diff.

Just a followup:

After returning the second ATI card and getting a third ATI card (they
said the second one tested fine for them), we had the same behavior.
I was ready to just box up a motherboard (we had two afterall) _and_
the /sbin/fsck'ing card and ship them both to ATI and ask them to
figure out what was going wrong.

As a last thing to try before _really_ trying to hold the vendors feet
to the fire, I checked and found yet another BIOS upgrade available
from Intel (ATI doesn't have flashable firmware as far as I could ever
tell ... never got a hint otherwise in correspondence).  I read the
release notes and there was nothing that remotely seemed to address
our problem, but I installed it anyway (when status quo isn't working,
change for the sake of change is good).  Lo and behold, it suddenly
works.  All I can figure is that there was some firmware conflict that
got the box wedged _really_ early on and that the latest Intel BIOS
either accidentally or on purpose fixed it.

In all the time we were trying to figure out what might be going
wrong, we got no really useful advice.  We got some whacky ideas from
the gamer community, mostly disregarding all of the information that I
had provided.  My father even boxed up his system and took it in to
some PC repair outfit in Beaverton (not mentioning any names, but
they've got an ad in the yellow pages) and got some _really_ voodoo
explanation that the video card was toasted (he reportedly couldn't
get it to work in any of his systems even though ATI said there was
nothing wrong with it when they got it back) and that any motherboard
it was placed in would be permanently toasted too, and vice versa, ad
infinitum.  He said in order to free ourselves from this vicious cycle
we'd have to replace both the motherboard and video card at the same
time.  Sorry, my stick-pins are all away at the cleaners.  I'll stick
to Planet Earth were the laws of physics apply, thanks!

As far as I know the video card is still working.  But since I took
the phone off the hook and am filtering my dad's email off to
/dev/null, how would I discover otherwise?  ;-)


--

seniorr at aracnet.com       whole earth.  But not forever!  I tell you, the day

                          the world has never heard before.'' -- Ben Hur

distributions but have no first hand information.  You can always
compile it from source.

From mhopcroft at seraphimguard.com  Wed Jun  4 02:21:02 2003

Subject: [PLUG] I can;t go to meetings, but....

    My work schedule prohibits me from going to meetings, but I could use some help. I have a 1GHz Athlon with two very large hard drives (100GB main drive, 160GB secondary drive). My bios will only allow Windows to formayt 128GB of that second drive. 
    I want to crate a dual-boot system with Windows residing on the C: dirve (the 100GB) and Linux splitting the 160GB drive into two 80GB drives. (I hope the BIOS allows me to do this). I want to eventually use the Linux part of the system to do all my business (Internet, publishing, etc.) and use the Windows part of the system for recreational uses, eventually migrating everything over to Linux if possible. I also want to transfer my work documents (which include images, .doc files and dozens of PDF files) to the Linux part of the system (so I hope that whatever distribution I get includes both openOffice,org and Acrobat Reader for Linux). I've also heard about some of the various
    Is there anyone who can help me with my system? I'm more concerned with things like RealOne Player; I don;t know if there is a Linux version and it's the only way I can use the account I have with Major league baseball that lets me listen to live and archived games. Finally, I have a whole bunch of source files that I'm going to want to transfer to the Linux system (I may have already mentioned this -- it's lkate) incluidng all my MP3s, my work documents, and a collection of about a hundred electronic RPG books that I want to read intact.    SSC, publisher of Linux Journal, recently announced the launch of a
   new on-line publication, WorldWatch:
   http://WorldWatch.LinuxGazette.com. WorldWatch offers readers a
   comprehensive daily digest of articles from publications around the
   world about topics concerning Linux and open-source software. These
   topics are generally non-technical and offer big-picture perspectives
   regarding the implementation of the Linux operating system around the
   world and the resulting societal effects.




From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Jun  4 06:24:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)

  Red Hat Linux release 9 (Shrike)
  [heinlein]$ rpm -q XFree86
  XFree86-4.3.0-2

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Jun  4 06:34:03 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Jun  4 06:34:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] versions of XFree86
In-Reply-To: <1054709055.13817.24.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306040626340.31786-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On 3 Jun 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote:

> How does determine the version of 4.x being used...

That's semi-tricky. You can run xdpyinfo and get the version of 
XFree86 that's serving up your local display:

  xdpyinfo | head

Getting X info from a remote host is harder. The intuitive thing would 
be to ssh into a remote machine and use xdpyinfo -- but will still 
report your *local* info.

On a remote machine, you'll either have to poke around /var/log or use 
the package manager (rpm, apt) to figure out what's there.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From barryb at proaxis.com  Wed Jun  4 07:32:02 2003
From: barryb at proaxis.com (Bill Barry)
Date: Wed Jun  4 07:32:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] I can;t go to meetings, but....
In-Reply-To: <001501c32a7a$8a32fd40$1f7cadcf@ao.lop.com>
References: <001501c32a7a$8a32fd40$1f7cadcf@ao.lop.com>
Message-ID: <20030604141659.GA11049@edge>

On Wed, Jun 04, 2003 at 02:20:24AM -0700, Michael P Hopcroft wrote:
>        My work schedule prohibits me from going to meetings, but I could
>    use some help. I have a 1GHz Athlon with two very large hard drives
>    (100GB main drive, 160GB secondary drive). My bios will only allow
>    Windows to formayt 128GB of that second drive.
> 
>        I want to crate a dual-boot system with Windows residing on the C:
>    dirve (the 100GB) and Linux splitting the 160GB drive into two 80GB
>    drives. (I hope the BIOS allows me to do this). 

I suggest putting 3 partitions on the 100GB drive, a 50-100M boot
partition, the ~98.5GB windows partition and a ~1GB (depends on your
memory size) linux swap partition. This way all your boot information
is on one disk, and when your running linux from disk2, the swap will
be on a separate disk.

>    I want to eventually use the Linux part of the system to do all
>    my business (Internet, publishing, etc.) and use the Windows part
>    of the system for recreational uses, eventually migrating
>    everything over to Linux if possible. I also want to transfer my
>    work documents (which include images, .doc files and dozens of
>    PDF files) to the Linux part of the system (so I hope that
>    whatever distribution I get includes both openOffice,org and
>    Acrobat Reader for Linux). I've also heard about some of the
>    various 

You can leave your work documents on the windows partitions and still
access them from Linux, but not the other way around, so it's probably
best during the migration to leave the documents on the windows side.
Several distributions include openOffice and the include pdf readers
such as xpdf.  You can get Acrobat Reader for Linux directly from the
Adobe website if you need it.

>    Is there anyone who can
>    help me with my system? I am expecting to get DSL soon (I"m on
>    dialup now) and while my ISP is going to be Qwest/MSN, I hope
>    that isn;t all that relevant to my ability to use Libux to
>    control my Internet connection. I'm more concerned with things
>    like RealOne Player; I don;t know if there is a Linux version and
>    it's the only way I can use the account I have with Major league
>    baseball that lets me listen to live and archived games. 

Realplayer 8 is the latest version on Linux. I have never come across
any realmedia that Realplayer 8 could not handle, but that doesn't
mean there isn't any. Maybe the guys at Thursday's meeting can answer
this.

>    I'm also
>    concerned about the Windows sports sims I play -- if I can play
>    them using a Windows emulator I'll be very happy. Finally, I have
>    a whole bunch of source files that I'm going to want to transfer
>    to the Linux system (I may have already mentioned this -- it's
>    lkate) incluidng all my MP3s, my work documents, and a collection
>    of about a hundred electronic RPG books that I want to read
>    intact. (I"m an e-publisher by profession, so it;'s important
>    that i maintain compatibility with the people whgo are seniding
