From jkeroes at eli.net  Wed Jun  4 11:05:03 2003
From: jkeroes at eli.net (Joshua Keroes)
Date: Wed Jun  4 11:05:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [Portland Perl Mongers Meeting] 11 June 2003
Message-ID: <20030604180445.GD20025@eli.net>

There's an overlap in the Portland Perl Mongers meeting and the PLUG
interests this month so I thought a cross-post might be appreciated.
Cross-posting won't be a common occurrence so if you're interested in
Perl, join our list: http://mail.pm.org/mailman/listinfo/pdx-pm-list .

Note: this info is also on http://portland.pm.org/ . The website has
      links and pictures, too.


== Upcoming: Portland Perl Mongers Technical Meeting ==

We have a full evening of events planned for the Wed, 11 June 2003
meeting. This is an all-O'Reilly evening, starting with books and ending
with modules plus food along the way.


== Agenda ==

7:00 - 8:30ish
    Rael Dornfest and Rob Flickenger talk about their Hacks series at Powell's Tech.

8:45
    Walk to House of Louie, order pu-pu platters and agar pudding

9:00 - 10:00
    chromatic on Mail::SimpleList
    portland.pm t-shirts for sale! Buy one, impress you; buy two, impress me too!


== Gory Details ==

Powell's Technical Books
33 NW Park Ave.
Map: http://snurl.com/1ify

Rael Dornfest and Rob Flickenger, authors of O'Reilly's best-selling
Hacks series (Google Hacks, Linux Server Hacks and Mac OS X Hacks), talk
about their top-rated tomes, answer questions, and reveal a few of the
private hacks that didn't make the series.

Powell's will be giving away a Hacks book with any O'Reilly book
(excluding Pocket References) purchased all day June 11.

---

House of Louie
331 NW Davis St.
Map: http://snurl.com/1ig0

Walk over to House of Louie. It's about 5 or 6 blocks away.

---

House of Louie

This month's Perl Mongers meeting will be held at House of Louie, in the
back, in the banquet room. Please support our local business by ordering
some food or drink! If this proves to be a good venue, we'd like to be
welcomed back with open arms.

First: announcements, banter, witty banter, unwitty banter, social time,
t-shirts for sale ($9.99 + $0.01 S/H)

Next, chromatic talks about Mail::SimpleList:

    You've used Perl at work. You've programmed for other people before.
    How do you take a project from idea to execution? How can you add
    new features to your own projects without going crazy?

    Mail::SimpleList is a simple-but-effective project written in
    Perl. chromatic will demonstrate how he wrote it, from ideas to
    design to tests to implementation and explaining how
    Mail::SimpleList works, why he made the design choices he did and
    what he learned all along the way.

    chromatic will touch on mail filtering, object orientation,
    test-driven development, customer testing, deployment, refactoring
    and the normal ups and downs of any type of software development.

See you there!
-J

_______________________________________________
Pdx-pm-list mailing list
Pdx-pm-list at mail.pm.org
http://mail.pm.org/mailman/listinfo/pdx-pm-list



From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Jun  4 11:43:02 2003

from anything other than the hard disk.  It has some version of Mandrake
installed and poorly configured.

I set up the network interface and inserted the Debian boot CD I needed,
but I can't seem to find a baseconfig executable that'll allow me to just
do the installation from the CDROM without actually booting the CD.

Does someone have a suggestion?  I'll keep pluggin' away at it.

From danielx.j.petcher at intel.com  Wed Jun  4 11:50:03 2003
From: danielx.j.petcher at intel.com (Petcher, Danielx J)
Date: Wed Jun  4 11:50:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Making a Mandrake system usable (installing Debian)
Message-ID: <7D6F4CF55743264F8B23E20353705EEC089248@orsmsx408.amr.corp.intel.com>

Did you double-check the obvious?

Is the BIOS set to prefer booting from a CD before booting from the hard
drive? Can you boot Knoppix or some other CD-based distro to verify
CD-ROM bootability? Some ancient CD-ROMs weren't El-Torito compatible
(bootable).

-djp
http://folding.stanford.edu - the brain you save may be your own!

From michael at robinson-west.com  Wed Jun  4 12:10:03 2003
From: michael at robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Wed Jun  4 12:10:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] I can;t go to meetings, but....
In-Reply-To: <20030604141659.GA11049@edge>
References: <001501c32a7a$8a32fd40$1f7cadcf@ao.lop.com> 
	<20030604141659.GA11049@edge>
Message-ID: <1054753339.22718.59.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

On Wed, 2003-06-04 at 07:16, Bill Barry wrote:
> On Wed, Jun 04, 2003 at 02:20:24AM -0700, Michael P Hopcroft wrote:
> >        My work schedule prohibits me from going to meetings, but I could
> >    use some help. I have a 1GHz Athlon with two very large hard drives
> >    (100GB main drive, 160GB secondary drive). My bios will only allow
> >    Windows to formayt 128GB of that second drive.
> > 
> >        I want to crate a dual-boot system with Windows residing on the C:
> >    dirve (the 100GB) and Linux splitting the 160GB drive into two 80GB
> >    drives. (I hope the BIOS allows me to do this). 
> 
> I suggest putting 3 partitions on the 100GB drive, a 50-100M boot
> partition, the ~98.5GB windows partition and a ~1GB (depends on your
> memory size) linux swap partition. This way all your boot information
> is on one disk, and when your running linux from disk2, the swap will
> be on a separate disk.
> 
> >    I want to eventually use the Linux part of the system to do all
> >    my business (Internet, publishing, etc.) and use the Windows part
> >    of the system for recreational uses, eventually migrating
> >    everything over to Linux if possible. I also want to transfer my
> >    work documents (which include images, .doc files and dozens of
> >    PDF files) to the Linux part of the system (so I hope that
> >    whatever distribution I get includes both openOffice,org and
> >    Acrobat Reader for Linux). I've also heard about some of the
> >    various 
> 
> You can leave your work documents on the windows partitions and still
> access them from Linux, but not the other way around, so it's probably
> best during the migration to leave the documents on the windows side.
> Several distributions include openOffice and the include pdf readers
> such as xpdf.  You can get Acrobat Reader for Linux directly from the
> Adobe website if you need it.
> 
> >    Is there anyone who can
> >    help me with my system? I am expecting to get DSL soon (I"m on
> >    dialup now) and while my ISP is going to be Qwest/MSN, I hope
> >    that isn;t all that relevant to my ability to use Libux to
> >    control my Internet connection. I'm more concerned with things
> >    like RealOne Player; I don;t know if there is a Linux version and
> >    it's the only way I can use the account I have with Major league
> >    baseball that lets me listen to live and archived games. 
> 
> Realplayer 8 is the latest version on Linux. I have never come across
> any realmedia that Realplayer 8 could not handle, but that doesn't
> mean there isn't any. Maybe the guys at Thursday's meeting can answer
> this.
> 
> >    I'm also
> >    concerned about the Windows sports sims I play -- if I can play
> >    them using a Windows emulator I'll be very happy. Finally, I have
> >    a whole bunch of source files that I'm going to want to transfer
> >    to the Linux system (I may have already mentioned this -- it's
> >    lkate) incluidng all my MP3s, my work documents, and a collection
> >    of about a hundred electronic RPG books that I want to read
> >    intact. (I"m an e-publisher by profession, so it;'s important
> >    that i maintain compatibility with the people whgo are seniding
> >    me art and text files).  > Does anyone know what I should, or
> >    can, do in this situation?
> 
> I don't know about the RPG books, maybe somebody else on the list has
> experience with RPG books under linux.
> 
> Bill Barry
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

Why not distribute an open replacement format for RPG that is
universal?  Docbook may be a good place to look.  I have never
understood why restricted documentation formats are so ubiquitous,
isn't publishing about communicating information to others in mass?
Perhaps you can publish an RPG book that teaches your customers how
to migrate to a format that is friendly to both Linux and Windows.

     --  Michael

On Wed, 4 Jun 2003, Petcher, Danielx J wrote:
> Did you double-check the obvious?

If it was obvious to me, I checked it.

> Is the BIOS set to prefer booting from a CD before booting from the hard
> drive? Can you boot Knoppix or some other CD-based distro to verify
> CD-ROM bootability? Some ancient CD-ROMs weren't El-Torito compatible

I think it's some odd combination of the BIOS (a Dell monstrosity) and the
onboard SCSI controllers (Adaptec 7880).  I can't seem to boot from the
floppy or the cdrom.

I tried pulling the filesystem images off the Debian CD and mounting them
as loopbacks and then running `chroot /mnt/point linuxrc` and that got me
MOST of the way there, but then, of course, I got all these warnings about
repartitioning a mounted disk and I couldn't screw myself completely, now
could I?

So there it is.

Hmm.  I don't know the hairy details, but you could try loop mounting
the floppy images, look in /etc/inittab.  There is a dbootstrap
mentioned in the docs, but I didn't find it in a brief search.  Ah,
yeah.  Loopback mount root.bin and look in its /sbin/dbootstrap.

cdrom?

From svanhoosen at yahoo.com  Wed Jun  4 22:27:02 2003
From: svanhoosen at yahoo.com (Scott Van Hoosen)
Date: Wed Jun  4 22:27:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Knoppix - restarting X
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306041757340.15092@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <20030605052558.58610.qmail@web40812.mail.yahoo.com>

I played with Knoppix for the first time today, on
three different computers, and I was quite impressed.
I can see a lot of uses for this distro, for fixing
screwed up Linux or Windows machines, introducing
people to Linux, firing up an ssh session from
someone's house who doesn't have Linux, etc.

My only problem was on my wife's computer it
mis-identified her monitor, and tries to run it at
1280x1024, which it can't handle. It goes all fuzzy of
course, but I can get in with Ctrl-Alt-+ to lower the
res, but it uses that wacky virtual desktop size
thing. I tried fixing the settings in XF86Config
manually, and also by using one of the wizards (I
think it was Configuration Panel, Peripherals,
Display, or something like that). Problem is, I need
to restart X for the changes to take effect, but this
just restarts Knoppix again, and it forgets my
changes.

Is there a way to restart X in Knoppix without
rebooting?

-Scott

I suspect all your 'G stuff is useless in linux.  It would appear that 
there is no driver support now or even on the horizon.  Do a search at 
http://groups.google.com for your above pci card and linux and see the 
negative responses pile up.






From pem at nellump.net  Thu Jun  5 00:26:02 2003
From: pem at nellump.net (Paul Mullen)
Date: Thu Jun  5 00:26:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Scalable and esthetic Perl
In-Reply-To: <3EDA73B3.2060802@nutriware.com>
References: <200305301632.h4UGWl506875@gate.daniloff.com> <mailman.1054407082.5641.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org> <868ysl4r2u.fsf_-_@red.stonehenge.com> <3EDA73B3.2060802@nutriware.com>
Message-ID: <20030603070720.GA332@nellump.net>

On Sun, Jun 01, 2003 at 02:44:19PM -0700, Ron Braithwaite wrote:
> Randal L. Schwartz wrote:

> >But I need to add point 3 for balance:
> >
> >    3) It's also practical and reasonable to produce nice looking Perl
> >    code that is maintainable and scalable
> 
> You know, I think you are probably right as long as it is someone like 
> you and me writing the code (I think my Perl has always been very 
> clean). Its just that I have seen way too much code from others that 
> wasn't maintainable and probably wasn't scalable.

It always seemed to me [1] that programming in Perl is a bit like playing
the guitar: it's an instrument that requires little effort to become
passably mediocre at, but it's damned tough to master. Then again, pretty
much any programming language will be tough to master, and once you master
one, you usually can move on to the others with significantly less effort.

[1] NB: This is my opinion, and is not meant to be construed as fact. :-)


Paul

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Thu Jun  5 00:59:02 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Thu Jun  5 00:59:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Knoppix - restarting X
In-Reply-To: <20030605052558.58610.qmail@web40812.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306041757340.15092@shaft.bitmine.net> <20030605052558.58610.qmail@web40812.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20030605075849.GB5172@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

On Wed, Jun 04, 2003 at 10:25:58PM -0700, Scott Van Hoosen wrote:
> My only problem was on my wife's computer it
> mis-identified her monitor, and tries to run it at
> 1280x1024, which it can't handle. It goes all fuzzy of
> course, but I can get in with Ctrl-Alt-+ to lower the

Have you tried any of the kerenel boot params? Knoppix has a host of
things you can tell it at boot time that can fix that sort of thing.

Explore the F-keys when you are at the boot prompt, I think you want
something like "screen=1024x768" or whatever.

-Rogan

From launi at zaramyth.net  Thu Jun  5 07:36:03 2003
From: launi at zaramyth.net (Launi)
Date: Thu Jun  5 07:36:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Making a Mandrake system usable (installing Debian)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306041140520.10900@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <002f01c32b6f$219df4b0$cb00a8c0@dpixi.net>


  >-----Original Message-----
  >From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org 
  >[mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Jeme A Brelin
  >Sent: Wednesday, June 04, 2003 11:43 AM
 >I have this system here on my desk (at work) that I can't 
  >really make boot from anything other than the hard disk.  It 
  >has some version of Mandrake installed and poorly configured.
  >
  >I set up the network interface and inserted the Debian boot 
  >CD I needed, but I can't seem to find a baseconfig 
  >executable that'll allow me to just do the installation from 
  >the CDROM without actually booting the CD.
  >
So if you have a SCSI CD on the system I would suggest opening the case and
temporarily putting an IDE CD ROM for the install.  The assumption is that
you BIOS can handle booting from CD.  If this fails use a floppy to boot
from.

Lonnie





From judah at opusnet.com  Thu Jun  5 09:31:03 2003
From: judah at opusnet.com (Aaron Baer)
Date: Thu Jun  5 09:31:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] WMP54G Wireless on Debian
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306042307420.9218-100000@antares.mpcu.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306042307420.9218-100000@antares.mpcu.com>
Message-ID: <1054830648.5961.14.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Wed, 2003-06-04 at 23:11, Keith Morse wrote:
> On Wed, 4 Jun 2003, Roman Robinson wrote:
> 
> > <quote>
> > 
> > The PCI card is a Linksys WMP54G <http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/tg/detail/-/B000085BD8/002-8424496-0623230> and
> > the router is Linsys's 4port + Wireless DSL/Cable Router..
> > 
> > </quote>
> 
> 
> I suspect all your 'G stuff is useless in linux.  It would appear that 
> there is no driver support now or even on the horizon.  Do a search at 
> http://groups.google.com for your above pci card and linux and see the 
> negative responses pile up.
> 
> 

The router you ordered will not be a total loss for your network. This
is because 802.11g routers will also talk 802.11b and you can connect to
them using those cards at the traditional "11mb" speeds. 802.11b has a
wide amount of support under linux. I would suggest that your best
support is going to be a card with a Prism2 chipset, however there is
also great support for the cisco 340 and cisco 350 cards (the 350 is
100mW card and is fantastic) or the Orinoco Silver or Gold 802.11b cards
from Avaya. 

Here's a list of some Prism2 cards.
http://www.personaltelco.net/index.cgi/Prism2Card

Also http://www.netgate.com has one of the best prism2 cards out there
with a 200mW antenna.. Sweet.. but at tad pricey compared to some of the
30mW cards out there. And here's a dirty little secret. The Microsoft
Branded cards are Prism2 cards with 30mW antennas. 

Hopefully there will be 11g driver support for Linux eventually. The
technology is not going away any time soon.


A-

-- 
----
Aaron Baer
judah at opusnet.com
http://www.cat.pdx.edu/~baera/

Paul Mullen <pem at nellump.net> wrote:

> Now it works. Bitchin'!  Any ideas why the "-keystroke" option doesn't

Did you try it with two hyphens (--keystroke)?  That would be the
convention for long option names, I believe.

--Jason



From russell-evans at uswest.net  Thu Jun  5 09:59:02 2003
From: russell-evans at uswest.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Thu Jun  5 09:59:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Making X Disappear the Mouse Pointer
In-Reply-To: <20030605113500.0ac8926e.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20030526022754.GA1050@nellump.net><E19KLUZ-0000t1-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org><20030531195910.GB518@nellump.net><E19MJZX-0000bC-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org><20030603070803.GB332@nellump.net>
    <20030605113500.0ac8926e.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <E19Ny4l-0000Qs-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

unclutter: usage:
	-display <display>
	-idle <seconds> 	time between polls to detect idleness.
	-keystroke		wait for keystroke before idling.
	-jitter <pixels>	pixels mouse can twitch without moving
	-grab			use grabpointer method not createwindow
	-reset			reset the timer whenever cursor becomes
					visible even if it hasn't moved
	-root			apply to cursor on root window too
	-onescreen		apply only to given screen of display
	-visible		ignore visibility events
	-noevents		dont send pseudo events
	-not names...		dont apply to windows whose wm-name begins.
				(must be last argument)


Thank you
Russell

Thus spoke Jason Van Cleve <jason at vancleve.com>
( Thu, 5 Jun 2003 11:35:00 -0500 ):

> Did you try it with two hyphens (--keystroke)?  That would be the
> convention for long option names, I believe.

Not for unclutter, actually.  It doesn't use the GNU getopts syntax,
preferring its own [one hyphen][full option name] syntax.

It had been in the back of my mind to look for a progam like this, so
I just installed.  It works nicely except for the -keystroke option.

From mikedela at ipns.com  Thu Jun  5 11:38:02 2003
From: mikedela at ipns.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Thu Jun  5 11:38:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] xmms button font size
Message-ID: <1054838251.14597.8.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>

I'm really enjoying my 4 gigs of mp3s lately. I own and have all of the
original music. My problem is the tiny little font that comes with the
playlist buttons. I've manipulated the font of the list itself so I can
read it, but the "add" "del" "sel" "opt" and "list" buttons have tiny
fonts on them, as are the menus that they pull up. I've resorted to a
very ugly high-contrast skin to be able to read them, but I'd like to
change their size.

I'm familiar with the double size option, but that only works on the
main player window.

Has anyone encountered/overcome this issue?


-- 
Mike De La Mater
Small Business Networks and Consulting
503-702-6749
mikedela at ipns.com





From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Thu Jun  5 11:39:02 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Thu Jun  5 11:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Making a Mandrake system usable (installing Debian)
References: <002f01c32b6f$219df4b0$cb00a8c0@dpixi.net>
Message-ID: <001601c32b91$8b741a00$1901a8c0@madcat>

There is a bootloader that used to come with Slackware - basically it
emulated the bios function of "boot from device" - you write this image to a
floppy and boot to it - it will then come up with a spiffy menu that allows
you to choose from all the differnet detected devices in your system (i.e.
individual partitions, CD-ROMs, floppys, etc..) I used this to install from
a CD on an old laptop that would not allow me to boot from the CDROM.. I'm
sorry, I don't remember the name of this utility or the name of the
download.. I just know it was on an older distro of Slack..

Can anyone else remember? I want to know again now as well -- it was
helpful! :-)

Thanks,
Matt

For me the double size works as I generally only have the main window

From dpool at hevanet.com  Thu Jun  5 17:58:01 2003
From: dpool at hevanet.com (david pool)
Date: Thu Jun  5 17:58:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] State Government Leaders at Grant HS
Message-ID: <3EDFE6DE.6050307@hevanet.com>

Senator Brown pointed me to the opportunity to address Portland's 
Eastside legislators all gathered together in order to hear from the 
people (that's us). It looks sweet:

SPECIAL COMBINED TOWN HALL MEETING
***
12  East Portland Legislators,
Plus: Senate President Peter Courtney, and
Senate Ways & Means Co-Chair Kurt Schrader
***
Monday, June 9th
7:00 PM - 9:00 PM
Grant High School - 2245 NE 36th Ave., Portland



SENATE LEADERS TO JOIN EAST PORTLAND LEGISLATORS AT A SPECIAL COMBINED
TOWN HALL MEETING JUNE 9TH 

PORTLAND - Leaders of the state Senate and House will join legislators
representing North, Northeast, and Southeast Portland and East Multnomah
County for a rare combined town hall meeting on June 9th at 7:00 PM at
Grant High School.

Senate President Peter Courtney and Senator Kurt Schrader, co-chair of
the Ways and Means committee, will be the featured guests. They will be
joined by: 

Sen. Kate Brown 				Rep. Deborah Kafoury
   Senate Democratic Leader 		   House Democratic Leader
Sen. Margaret Carter 			Rep. Jeff Merkley
Sen. Avel Gordly 				Rep. Laurie
Monnes-Anderson
Rep. Jackie Dingfelder			Rep. Diane Rosenbaum 
Rep. Gary Hansen				Rep. Mike Schaufler
Rep. Steve March				Rep. Carolyn Tomei

The legislators said their goal is to bring the Legislature to the
community, since few citizens have the time to travel to Salem during
the week. "This is their Legislature and their government.  We want to
hear from them," Brown said.


SPECIAL COMBINED TOWN HALL MEETING
***
12  East Portland Legislators,
Plus: Senate President Peter Courtney, and
Senate Ways & Means Co-Chair Kurt Schrader
***
Monday, June 9th
7:00 PM - 9:00 PM
Grant High School - 2245 NE 36th Ave., Portland

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Thu Jun  5 23:10:02 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Thu Jun  5 23:10:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] httpd dead
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCGEAICMAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
References: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCGEAICMAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <1054879763.1295.22.camel@main>

On Thu, 2003-06-05 at 22:23, Billy Dimaculangan wrote:
> "httpd dead but pid file exists." Erorr message while displaying the httpd
> status. and got this error upon displaying the httpd fullstatus
> 

Check in the localstatedir (I normally set this to /var but your install
may differ) for httpd.pid. Either mv the file to a different name or rm
it.

From russell-evans at uswest.net  Thu Jun  5 23:47:02 2003
From: russell-evans at uswest.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Thu Jun  5 23:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] xmms button font size
In-Reply-To: <1054838251.14597.8.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <1054838251.14597.8.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <E19OB05-0005cv-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

right click on	right side of main window > options > preferences > font tab >
playlist > choose something large
 or
control-p > font tab > playlist > choose something large

Thank you
Russell

>  >  read it, but the "add" "del" "sel" "opt" and "list" buttons have tiny
>  >  fonts on them, as are the menus that they pull up. I've resorted to a
>  >  very ugly high-contrast skin to be able to read them, but I'd like to
>  >  change their size.
>  >  
>  >  I'm familiar with the double size option, but that only works on the
>  >  main player window.
>  >  
>  >  Has anyone encountered/overcome this issue?




From mikedela at ipns.com  Fri Jun  6 00:14:02 2003

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Fri Jun  6 00:30:03 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Fri Jun  6 00:30:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] XMMS playlist button size
Message-ID: <20030606072904.GA6855@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

Bust open ~/.xmms/Skins/<your_skin>.whatever with the appropriate
decompressor, then work on pledit.bmp to your hearts desire :).

pledit.bmp contains all the buttons for the playlist editing
functions, you can make them look like anything you want. (well, I
cant, because I lack the artistic ability, but you get my drift :).

If you work in a directory inside the Skins directory, then your
modified skin will appear in the skin browser with out any additional
work.

HTH,
-Rogan


ps: Sorry for fubaring everyone's threading with this message. I
accidentally deleted the thread a min. ago.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Jun  6 06:33:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Jun  6 06:33:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] httpd dead
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCGEAICMAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306060626480.24152-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Fri, 6 Jun 2003, Billy Dimaculangan wrote:

> "httpd dead but pid file exists." Erorr message while displaying the
> httpd status. and got this error upon displaying the httpd
> fullstatus
> 
> /usr/sbin/apachectl: line 78: links: command not found

First, find and delete your httpd.pid file. As root, try

  /bin/rm -i $(find /var -name 'httpd\.pid' 2>/dev/null)

Second, install the links program. For Red Hat, install the elinks 
rpm. For Debian, install the links package.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From buchholz at easystreet.com  Fri Jun  6 08:14:02 2003
From: buchholz at easystreet.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Fri Jun  6 08:14:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Hard drive messages.
References: <3EDCF726.3010406@linuxlink.com>
Message-ID: <3EE0AFB6.4050306@easystreet.com>

I don't think I'd worry about it.  If there are no corresponding messages
in /var/log/messages for /dev/sda, then you're probably not having any
hardware problems.

It looks like the partitions were created specifying a block count for
partition size rather than entering cylinder values.  What I don't under-
stand is why the physical and logical size difference messages are being
printed.


mike wrote:

> Is anything wrong with this drive?  None of my others give this error.
>
> Thanks.
>
> fdisk -l
>
>
>
> Disk /dev/sda: 255 heads, 63 sectors, 14467 cylinders
> Units = cylinders of 16065 * 512 bytes
>
>
>
>    Device Boot    Start       End    Blocks   Id  System
> /dev/sda1   *         1         4     30712+  83  Linux
> Partition 1 does not end on cylinder boundary:
>      phys=(60, 15, 63) should be (60, 254, 63)
> /dev/sda2             4      3829  30719808   83  Linux
> Partition 2 does not end on cylinder boundary:
>      phys=(1023, 15, 63) should be (1023, 254, 63)
> /dev/sda3          3829      6378  20480040   83  Linux
> Partition 3 does not end on cylinder boundary:
>      phys=(1023, 15, 63) should be (1023, 254, 63)
> /dev/sda4          6378     14590  65956464    f  Win95 Ext'd (LBA)
> Partition 4 does not end on cylinder boundary:
>      phys=(1023, 15, 63) should be (1023, 254, 63)
> /dev/sda5          6378      8928  20480008+  83  Linux
> /dev/sda6          8928      9565   5120104+  83  Linux
> /dev/sda7          9565      9820   2047720+  82  Linux swap
> /dev/sda8          9820     10075   2047720+  83  Linux
> /dev/sda9         10075     10203   1024096+  83  Linux

From drl at drloree.com  Fri Jun  6 11:13:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Fri Jun  6 11:13:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Hard drive messages.
In-Reply-To: <3EE0AFB6.4050306@easystreet.com>
References: <3EDCF726.3010406@linuxlink.com>
	 <3EE0AFB6.4050306@easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <1054923318.3267.7.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Fri, 2003-06-06 at 08:13, Don Buchholz wrote:
> I don't think I'd worry about it.  If there are no corresponding messages
> in /var/log/messages for /dev/sda, then you're probably not having any
> hardware problems.
> 
> It looks like the partitions were created specifying a block count for
> partition size rather than entering cylinder values.  What I don't under-
> stand is why the physical and logical size difference messages are being
> printed.
> 
I'm not sure if this makes sense, but it looks like the partition was
created with a 16 head scheme, and the kernel is trying to read it with
a 255 head scheme.  Did you move the drive to a different controller
after you partitioned it?  Most modern drives will simulate either
scheme, so it isn't fatal, but it looks like the kernel is missing the
ends of the primary partitions.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree
> 
> mike wrote:

From drl at drloree.com  Fri Jun  6 11:22:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Fri Jun  6 11:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] WMP54G Wireless on Debian
In-Reply-To: <3EDEABB5.601@attbi.com>
References: <3EDEABB5.601@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1054923857.3274.15.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Wed, 2003-06-04 at 19:32, Roman Robinson wrote:
> Here's my post on a few forums, I hope it has enough info.. If you
> need more details, please reply! I really really really need some ASAP
> help!
> <quote>
> Okay, so I just ordered all my wireless networking equipment. I
> thought that being I will need my server as soon as we go wireless so
> getting it ready early would be nice :-)
> 
> The PCI card is a Linksys WMP54G
> <http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/tg/detail/-/B000085BD8/002-8424496-0623230> and the router is Linsys's 4port + Wireless DSL/Cable Router..
> 
> Can someone please help with making my Debian system work wirelessly?
> Thanks!

My advise is to take the Linksys stuff back, get a prism 2 or 2.5 PCI
card and set that up as your access point on your debian box, no need
for the extra device.  I've found the NetGear MA311 to be reasonable,
but you need to install the hostap drivers.  If you're running debian
stable, you'll need to go to http://hostap.epitest.fi/.  If you're
running debian unstable, just install the hostap package, then follow
the instructions in the readme.  You'll need kernel headers to be
available, because the package creates kernel modules.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

From dgc at easystreet.com  Fri Jun  6 17:44:02 2003

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Fri Jun  6 19:03:02 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Fri Jun  6 19:03:02 2003
Subject: Answers -- Re: [PLUG] I still can't go to meetings, but I still need help.
In-Reply-To: <E19OPLW-0003tY-00@bridget.jatol.com>
References: <E19OPLW-0003tY-00@bridget.jatol.com>
Message-ID: <20030607020241.GA7434@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

On Fri, Jun 06, 2003 at 05:06:02PM -0500, Michael Hopcroft wrote:
> Hopefully someone can come over here and help me get my system sorted
> out. I especially want to find a way to get at the .doc, .pdf and .mp3
> files on my spare drive. I also need to know how to play video files and
> how to get them onto my hard drive from CD.


If your spare drive is NTFS you will have to use some other media
(either a separate computer, floppy, cd, ...). NTFS support isn't at a
useable state in linux yet.

>From here on I'm assuming your spare drive is fat32 (vfat).

1) Make a mount point.

	Mountpoints are just directories. Usually they are empty but
	they don't have to be. 

   $ mkdir /mnt/spare

2) Determine the device entry for your spare drive.

	(Most) devices in Linux are accessed through an entry in
	/dev. IDE Hard disks are accessed through /dev/hdX, where X
	is determined by the device location. For example, /dev/hda
	refers to the first drive on the first controller (the Primary
	Master in BIOS speak), /dev/hdb is the Primary Slave, c would
	be the Secondary Master and so on..

	To access a partition, a number is appended to the drive device:
	/dev/hda1 is the first partition on the Primary Master. You
	can use cfdisk to see the partitions on a drive:

   $ cfdisk /dev/hda
	
	Be carefull that you don't make any changes, unless you
	understand the consequences.

	I'll assume your spare drive / partition is /dev/hdb1
	(this is the first partition on the Primary Slave drive)

3) Mount the spare drive:

   $ mount /dev/hdb1 /mnt/spare

	This may not work. The most likely error will say something
	like: "specify a filesystem type". If that is the case, try
	this:

   $ mount -t vfat /dev/hdb1 /mnt/spare

4) Once the filesystem is mounted you will be able to see the files on
that partition by looking in /mnt/spare (or where ever you mounted
it). You can copy files from here to somewhere else, or use them in
place. You may need to be root to work in this filesystem. (This can
be changed, but I don't know how off the top of my head.)

5) You may want to have this drive mounted all the time, to do that
you need to make an entry in /etc/fstab (the mount point will persist
untill you delete it, unless it is in a ramdrive or some volatile
storage, or in a /tmp partition. Most likely it will persist).

Add this line to the end of your /etc/fstab:

/dev/hdb1	/mnt/spare	auto	defaults	0	2

Now this drive will be mounted each time you reboot.


Video:

mplayer and xine are both good video players. Knowing what distro you
use will help me explain how to get them / install them if you can't
figure it out.


.doc files can be opened with openoffice.org's writer and a few others.

.pdf files can be viewed with a host of things, if you don't have any
aversion to using non-free, closed source software, you can download
Acrobat Reader for Linux from the adobe site. Otherwise look into
xpdf, or just search for "pdf viewer" (or similar) on freshmeat.net.

.mp3's can be played by many, many things. The most popular is
probably xmms. It is virtually indestinguishable from winamp. Freeamp,
mgp123 and mp3blaster are some others.

Your distro probably set up your cd already, put a disk in and look in
/cdrom or /mnt/cdrom (this location is distro dependant). If one of
thoes two directories exists and is empty, try this:

$ mount /cdrom

or

$ mount /mnt/cdrom

and check it again. If you had to use mount to see the files you will
have to use umount before the cdrom will open to take the disk out.

$ umount /cdrom   (or /mnt/cdrom...)

You cannot umount a drive that is in use (if you have a shell that is
in that directory, that counts as "in use").


Hope this helps.

-Rogan


	



From pem at nellump.net  Fri Jun  6 19:43:02 2003
From: pem at nellump.net (Paul Mullen)
Date: Fri Jun  6 19:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Getting Started - Hardware Choices
In-Reply-To: <BB025A98.3AC9F%deansuhr@carpedis.com>

On Tue, Jun 03, 2003 at 02:00:56PM -0700, Dean Suhr wrote:
> 
> * I have a PowerComputing PowerTowerPro box that is server grade with a
> PowerPC processor in it.  I am game to try a Debian install (even though a
> try about two years ago was fruitless) - but this box does not have USB

I have Debian PPC on an old Umax S900 (PowerMac 9600 clone), which is
about the same era as your PowerTower Pro. Installation wasn't too
difficult, but you do have to understand the hardware (no click-n-drool
install interface). Everything seems to work OK, though I haven't tested
it out too rigorously.


Paul

To put it at its simplest, I have a spare hard drive physically inside
my computer but not attached to my system. It is full on a
non-functioning Windows XP professional and about 50GB of files that it
created when it worked. I don't care about most of the programs
(although it would be nice if I could run some of the games under an
emulator), but I have about 300 document files, 100+ PDF files, and 300+
MP#s that I'd really like to be able to run under Linux. the directories
are too big to copy onto a single CD (or even a single CD each) and I
can;t access the files at all right now. I'm not entirely sure what type
of formatting the hard drive was done on, but I'm, pretty sure the only
real solution (plugging the drive into a Windows system with a CD/RW and
backing up the My Documents directory onto multiple CDs, then loaing all
the CDs  contents into my Linux system, wiping the hard drive, and
plugging it back into my system mounted and formatted for Linux) would
be at least a full-day job.

I have other problems. My printer is a USB-based lexmark Z65. Lovely
printer -- great quality and very fast. problem is there's no Linux
driver for it that I know of.It was literally build with windows XP in
mind exclusively -- I'm not sure it would even work with a Mac. I need
to find a printing solution and some way to mount the pritner (and i'm
not entirely sure how USB works in Red Hat 9 anyway).

Then there are my CD drives. One of them is a DVD-ROM drive, and it
would be very nice to be able to play DVDs on it. I knpow my sound card
and speakers work in red Hat, I just don't knwo if Red hat recognizes
DVD drives as such, would recognize a DVD if I put it in, or if there is
software that could play it.

I'm sure there's more, but I don;t want to be too verbose or I'll never
finish the note.

Oh, one more thing -- I'm writing this with webmail because I can't get
evolution to recognize my mail server password, and i have the same
problem with Mozilla mail.

From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Sat Jun  7 06:53:01 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Sat Jun  7 06:53:01 2003
Subject: Answers -- Re: [PLUG] I still can't go to meetings, but I still need help.
References: <E19OPLW-0003tY-00@bridget.jatol.com> <20030607020241.GA7434@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <001201c32cf8$cec0a8b0$1901a8c0@madcat>

> If your spare drive is NTFS you will have to use some other media
> (either a separate computer, floppy, cd, ...). NTFS support isn't at a
> useable state in linux yet.

Umm.. ok.. If he want's "access" (i.e.readable access) to an NTFS partition
then this is built into the kernel (as long as it was compiled in or as a
module.. With Redhat I can almost guarantee it is..) I have been using the
NTFS module to read my XP partition for quite a while - at least two years
or so (but back then it was a 2000 partition).. Mandrake has a utility to
resize an NTFS partition.. Perhaps "NTFS write support is not in a stable
state on linux yet" is what you meant to say?

M

From chaz at bctonline.com  Sat Jun  7 14:34:01 2003
From: chaz at bctonline.com (Chaz)
Date: Sat Jun  7 14:34:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Red Hat 9 - syslog - iptables - console messages
Message-ID: <279250-2200366721381116@bctonline.com>

Red Hat 9
Use of the LOG target in iptables causes the log message to appear on
the console as well as in /var/log/messages.
The netfilter docs say that iptables logs at the 'warning' level via
syslog.
I've tried setting the kernel console logging in syslog.conf to 'err'
(and every other level above warning) but the messages still appear
on the screen.

syslog.conf
   orig:  #kern.*		    /dev/console
   new:   kern.err		    /dev/console

I'm assuming that since the console line was originally commented
out, that syslog must default to copying it's output to the console
screen.

Please advise on how to prevent the iptables messages from apearing
on the console.  It's very disruptive because the firewall blocks
(and logs) a lot of packets.

I've also sent this to Red Hat...

-chaz
Charles L. Sliger
chaz at bctonline.com




From michael at robinson-west.com  Sat Jun  7 14:52:01 2003
From: michael at robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Sat Jun  7 14:52:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Problem getting motherboard on a Linux compatibility list...
Message-ID: <1055022279.27931.61.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

Considering Linux started on an Intel 386 it is ironic that I am having
a hard time finding a 100% compatible Pentium 4 board but that is
exactly what I'm running into.  According to http://www.xfree86.org the
845G would be a good choice but so far the closest I have seen to that
is the 845GE which does something strange when you ask it to disable the
onboard video according to Intel's specs.  Does Intel sell a motherboard
without integrated video, lan, and sound or other Windoze only
components anymore?  Potentially they could be disabled, but Windows
98SE needs to go on the board I get where 98 has a bad habit of trying
to fix disabled devices.  Intel has no shame if it doesn't offer a good
Linux choice in a Pentium 4 board.  My VA503+ machine has been nice
because there isn't a single part that causes problems with 98SE or
Linux.  If it weren't for hard drive failure and the fact that 333 mhz
is way to slow these days I'd want to stay with it.

Under 98 all I have left is Warcraft II and TI-92 software for a usb
uplink.

Is there any business in the Portland, Scappoose, St. Helens area that
understands I will only go with a 100% Linux compatible board and that
I want to be as current as possible?  Preferably Pentium 4, although 
a 1 gig PIII is a good minimum guideline.  100% compatible means that
no devices on the board need to be disabled to use it with 
Linux.

As far as ASUS, etc., what's the best Intel alternative these days?

     --  Michael C. Robinson

  Apparently I've not followed this thread closely. However, a few months
ago I went to EMU (on NE 122nd Ave.) with a rough idea of what I wanted for
a replacement for my main server/workstation. I hit a slow time and was able
to speak with them about my needs and the initial components I had selected.
Based on their advice I bought a different motherboard and a faster speed
AMD processer (a 1.8G model). Anyway, I ended up with a complete system
(minus the tape deck and cd-rw I'll take from the existing system) for $500
and it's at least 6 times faster than the system it will replace. Amazing!

  I've decided to go with AMD rather than Intel and the components I bought
are all well supported by linux.

Subject: [PLUG] Samba/Winbind with NT Domain
In-Reply-To: <20030603002027.32011.qmail@web40810.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030602161627.39343.qmail@web40803.mail.yahoo.com> <20030603002027.32011.qmail@web40810.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20030608031234.GA2682@edge>

On Mon, Jun 02, 2003 at 05:20:27PM -0700, Scott Van Hoosen wrote:
> I'm working on joining a Red Hat Samba server to our
> NT Domain, using winbind. It seems to finally be
> working, but many of our Domain groups have spaces in
> them. I can't seem to find a way to add these to my
> smb.conf file, is it uses spaces to separate shares. I
> have tried enclosing them in quotes and escaping the
> spaces with a leading \ but nothing seems to work.
> 

> Is there an easy way to do this, or must I rename all
> of my groups (groan)?
> 

In the  WHATS NEW IN Samba 3.0.0 beta1
http://www.samba.org/samba/whatsnew/samba-3.0.0beta.html
there is this note.

10) Support for migrating from a Windows NT 4.0 domain to a Samba 
    domain and maintaining user, group and domain SIDs

which might solve your problem. 

Bill Barry



From stever at woo-hoo.com  Sat Jun  7 20:44:02 2003
From: stever at woo-hoo.com (Steven Raymond)
Date: Sat Jun  7 20:44:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix whitelist?
Message-ID: <40875.209.210.31.8.1055043787.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>

Well, I still haven't been able to get this to work.  Here's what my
main.cf looks like:

smtpd_recipient_restrictions =
        permit_mynetworks,
        check_client_access hash:/etc/postfix/badip,
        check_client_access hash:/etc/postfix/badaddr,
        check_sender_access hash:/etc/postfix/badaddr,
        check_recipient_access hash:/etc/postfix/access,
        reject_maps_rbl,
        reject_unknown_sender_domain,
        reject_unauth_pipelining,
        reject_unknown_recipient_domain,
        reject_non_fqdn_sender,
        reject_non_fqdn_recipient,
        reject_non_fqdn_hostname,
        reject_unknown_sender_domain,
        reject_unknown_hostname,
        check_relay_domains

body_checks = regexp:/etc/postfix/body_checks
header_checks = regexp:/etc/postfix/header_checks

smtpd_client_restrictions =
        permit_mynetworks,
        reject_maps_rbl,
        check_client_access hash:/etc/postfix/access,
        permitsmtpd_helo_required = yes
smtpd_helo_restrictions =
        permit_mynetworks,
        reject_maps_rbl,
        check_helo_access hash:/etc/postfix/access,
        reject_non_fqdn_hostname,
        reject_unknown_sender_domain,
        reject_unknown_hostname,
        reject_invalid_hostname,
        permit

smtpd_sender_restrictions =
        permit_mynetworks,
        reject_maps_rbl,
        check_sender_access hash:/etc/postfix/access,
        reject_non_fqdn_hostname,
        reject_invalid_hostname,
        reject_non_fqdn_sender,
        reject_unknown_sender_domain,
        reject_unknown_hostname,
        permit

Here's the /etc/postfix/badip and badaddr files (and I did run 'postmap
badip' then 'postmap badaddr' which generates the .db files)
[root at sparky postfix]# cat badip
12.129.211.145                  OK
[root at sparky postfix]# cat badaddr
ipowerweb.com                   OK

Still get a rejection like below:
Jun  7 20:24:16 sparky postfix/smtpd[19754]: connect from
host45.ipowerweb.com[12.129.211.145]
Jun  7 20:24:16 sparky postfix/smtpd[19754]: 956E87E80E8:
client=host45.ipowerweb.com[12.129.211.145]
Jun  7 20:24:17 sparky postfix/cleanup[19755]: 956E87E80E8:
message-id=<E19OqnT-000662-00 at host45.ipowerweb.com>
Jun  7 20:24:17 sparky postfix/cleanup[19755]: 956E87E80E8: reject: body
You are receiving this email because you have (or someone pretending to
be you has) requested a new password be sent for your account on
ClubCivic.com. If you did not request this email then please ig;
from=<nobody at host45.ipowerweb.com> to=<clubcivic at woo-hoo.com>: Message
content rejected
Jun  7 20:24:22 sparky postfix/smtpd[19754]: disconnect from
host45.ipowerweb.com[12.129.211.145]

I presume that the "Message content rejected" is due to the body_checks
filters.  Is it something easy I'm screwing up, like the order of
appearance of the filter checks in main.cf?  I've done a 'service
postfix restart' in between each change- that should get it to reload
main.cf I'm sure.

Any other ideas?  This is driving me nuts!

Thanks


> On Tue, 27 May 2003, Steven Raymond wrote:

From stever at woo-hoo.com  Sat Jun  7 20:52:01 2003
From: stever at woo-hoo.com (Steven Raymond)
Date: Sat Jun  7 20:52:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix whitelist?
In-Reply-To: <40875.209.210.31.8.1055043787.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
References: <40875.209.210.31.8.1055043787.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Sat Jun  7 21:06:01 2003
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Sat Jun  7 21:06:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Unexpected Spam
In-Reply-To: <1055033860.20107.609.camel@lana>
References: <1055033860.20107.609.camel@lana>
Message-ID: <200306072114.09642.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

On Saturday 07 June 2003 5:57 pm, Jon Jacob wrote:
> I use sendmail on my machine to serve my mail and today, for the first
> time, got an email addressed to someone else -- an non-existent user --
> on my domain.
>
> The mail was addressed to L.Davis at lana.manymoons.net and landed in my
> inbox at jon at manymoons.net.
>
> How could this have happened?

Probably a dictionary-style attack, a lucky guess, a random shot in the dark. 
Spammers (AKA loathesome execremental bipeds who do not deserve to live) do 
not care how much of their spew is wasted. They live to spew. If you haven't 
experienced spam attacks on your domain name, you've been lucky. 

Also take a good look at the headers, if jon at manymoons.net is not your default 
"catchall" account, it could be they spammed 'jon at manymoons.net', using the 
other address in a forged header.

-- 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Carla Schroder
www.tuxcomputing.com
this message brought to you
by Libranet 2.7 and Kmail
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

    mozart
    starb528
    carbuncle

to name but a few of the recent attempts. I've even gotten bounces and AV
auto-acks due to spammers who forged phony users at herring.org in the From:
header. Scumbags. /dev/null them and don't lose any sleep over it.

From stever at woo-hoo.com  Sun Jun  8 00:46:02 2003
From: stever at woo-hoo.com (Steven Raymond)
Date: Sun Jun  8 00:46:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix whitelist? - RESOLVED
In-Reply-To: <40996.209.210.31.8.1055044313.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
References: <40875.209.210.31.8.1055043787.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
        <40996.209.210.31.8.1055044313.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
Message-ID: <44314.209.210.31.8.1055058320.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>

Okay, finally my Postfix whitelisting problems.  It only took all night :)
My most recent problem was that despite how many "OK"s you have for an IP
address or domain name, header_checks and body_checks appear to be run no
matter what, on all mail, even if it was previously accepted or "OK"ed. 
Not exactly what I was looking for, but now I understand it and can live
with it.  While I haven't been able to completely test the rest of my
whitelists, I conclude that Ed's original suggestion in this thread about
creating a separate map file will be completely successful.
Here is an excellent 3-part article that thoroughly explains a lot about
Postfix's UCE controls and is easy to understand:
http://www.securityfocus.com/infocus/1593
To answer Wil's query along the way:
 "At present, specifying a header pattern with OK serves no useful
        purpose. A rule ending in OK affects only the header being
        matched. The next header may still result in a REJECT match,
        causing the mail still to be rejected."
The above applies only to the contents of header_checks & body_checks.  In
other words, the "OK" stops checking (and order is important) and will
accept the email if specified prior to header_ or body_checks.  I
concluded that the only way to stop a rejection occuring in header_ or
body_checks is to comment that line out.
Thanks for the help along the way!


> Funny note, I could not even _send_ this email to PLUG outbound through
> my mail server because it contained the phrase "You are receiving this
> email because you..." is blocked by the body_checks file.  I had to
> temporarily disable it for the mail to be relayed.
> Doesn't that sound like I have a real misconfiguration somewhere?  I did
> not think that anything in mynetworks was subject to the spam filters on
> outgoing mail, just inbound from the world.
> Thanks

Supposedly Intel P4's have a faster bus speed. but if the memory isn't
any faster than the AMD Athlon chip, I'm guessing that this is an
irrelevant fact.  I was told that AMD's and Intel's chip are price
matched so that there is no cost advantage to AMD.  I've also been told
that AMD is a poor compatability choice.  Needless to say, my old AMD
386 and my K6-III have been very good systems.  As far as a reliable
general benchmark, I wonder if the AMD outperforms the Pentium 4.

It's hard to get Habas to talk about AMD, in fact he wouldn't do
research into Linux compatability despite there being good ways
to do it at no cost insisting I make do instead with the 865GE or
some other unlisted Intel chipset.  ColumbiaPC in St. Helens does
sell Athlon XP systems, but basically I'd guess you have to know 
what you want and say you want to buy it explicitly, because Habas
currently has a different idea about what his customers should buy.
Habas won't advertise Athlon XP right now because he thinks that 
Intel P4 systems cost the same also believing that Pentiums 
are a better deal than an Athlon.

He's better than Preheim's in Scappoose, that guy will not refund bad
parts doing exchanges only.  Incompatabilities are not considered  
a valid reason for exchange there or there is no credit.  I Ended up
getting stuck with a Fujitsu drive that Linux for some strange reason
can't partition into any less than a single primary volume.
Picked up a case that ended up costing $90 even though
it probably should have cost $59.  It also surprised me that even
though I asked for an ATX case that there was a usb 2.0 connector
cut into the side leaving me wondering if the case really was ATX
and if it would work at all.  Needless to say, his one non custom case
should have been cheaper, but wasn't.  This case fiasco was only maybe a
month or so back.

ColumbiaPC is only eight miles away from me and it's better than an
picking up an E-Bay wonder, the potluck can be a bad scene sometimes.  
I also figure it's better than Fry's as Habas will take faulty hardware
back and Fry's won't, especially if you don't know you have faulty
hardware until after the return deadline.  Habas orders what you want,
it's a shame he only MCSE certifies though from what I've seen.

His email is habas at columbiapc.com

     --  Michael C. Robinson

Having a book on sendmail, unlike qmail, I wonder how it's going with
the supposed security problems that are supposed to be intractable in
sendmail?  I have a better chance of configuring sendmail well with
spam and virus filters than the chance I have of accomplishing this
under qmail.  One change I want to make to qmail is to teach it not
to accept a mail transfer if it determines that the return to address
is unusable.  The latter trick would cut all the spam I'm getting so
far.  The other fix I want to do is I want to allow anyone to send mail
to my domain while maintaining the rule that only my local users can 
use my MTA to send mail outside my domain.  The security I have now is
tighter than that and it is causing me trouble, I have to have every
domain I want to be able to receive mail from listed in rcpthosts.

My other curiosity with qmail is how to give a user another email
address without adding a Linux login account while maintaining
a seperate Maildir for that other address and the option
to forward mail to the original email account.

I ran sendmail at first, but I didn't know enough about maintaining it
or it got cracked because it just got slower and slower and broke at
one point.  I still using sendmail for a null client on one of my
servers. 

     --  Michael

Subject: [PLUG] Sendmail Problems
Message-ID: <20030608094815.2a141929.paul@lankow.net>

You can add Yahoo! to the list of domains that discriminate against us cable customers who send email. They don't reject us like AOL, but anything sent by us goes directly to recipient's bulk mail folder.

I created a mailertable file to tell sendmail to use smtp.comcast.net to transport mail destined for Yahoo. The 12.225.234.96 is the IP assigned to me by the cable company. Mail that I send directly out goes OK, I only get the time-out error when I pass the email off to smtp.comcast.net. Anyone know why this happens?

Jun  8 08:39:06 prj sendmail[6759]: h58Fd5EM006759: from=<paul at lankow.net>, size=414, class=0, nrcpts=2, msgid=<20030608083906.26bebbf7.paul at lankow.net>, proto=SMTP, daemon=MTA, relay=fred.lankow.net [192.168.1.1]
Jun  8 08:40:06 prj sendmail[6760]: h58Fd5EM006759: to=<pflnetws at yahoo.com>, ctladdr=<paul at lankow.net> (1001/1001), delay=00:01:00, xdelay=00:01:00, mailer=smtp, pri=60590, relay=mail.lankow.net. [12.225.234.96], dsn=4.0.0, stat=Deferred: Connection timed out with mail.lankow.net.

>point for Linux Internet software in general?

I look here:
http://rpmfind.net/
http://www.linux.org/
http://freshmeat.net/
http://sourceforge.net/

In that order. None are comprehensive (that I know of) but I've found a lot of 
stuff that way. If I get stuck, I ask the PLUG list.

Mike De La Mater
Small business networks and technology consulting

mikedela at ipns.com

worth of mail a day.

server? Since it doesn't work with two different programs, I don't think
it will work with any of the e-mail programs I have on my computer.

From judah at opusnet.com  Sun Jun  8 14:00:02 2003
From: judah at opusnet.com (Aaron Baer)
Date: Sun Jun  8 14:00:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Having trouble collecting email in Evolution
In-Reply-To: <E19P6a9-0000e4-00@bridget.jatol.com>
References: <E19P6a9-0000e4-00@bridget.jatol.com>
Message-ID: <1055105944.20662.30.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Sun, 2003-06-08 at 13:16, Michael Hopcroft wrote:

> Whenever I try to access mail.seraphimguard.com, I get a
> Username/Password mismatch error. Since the password works fine with
> Webmail I have no idea what's up. My web host's tech support hasn't been
> able to tell me anything this weekend.
> 

In the mail preferences for that account check the 'Receiving Mail' tab
in the Authentication type:

You can click the "Check for supported types" button and it will check
the mail server to see what the proper type is.. You can also choose
from the drop down.. 

Try checking there first.. 

A-

-- 
----
Aaron Baer
judah at opusnet.com
http://www.cat.pdx.edu/~baera/




From sean at fork.com  Sun Jun  8 17:33:02 2003
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Sun Jun  8 17:33:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Laptop Recommendations
Message-ID: <200306081256.52594.sean@fork.com>

I am considering a new career change soon which will require a lot of coding, 
presentations, documentation and traveling.  So it looks like a new laptop 
will be in order.

My partner says a Apple Ti-book is out, so what I'm looking for is x86 
recommendations.

Im assuming that win2k will work on just about all x86 if I have to install 
it, but what I'm really interested in is a laptop that is very linux 
comatible from one of the major vendors (Compaq/HP, Dell, Gateway).  It 
should supports at least 1400x1050 display, long battery, DVD (a writer would 
be a plus) built in ethernet/modem (built in wireless (802.11a) a plus), usb, 
serial, audio out, blah, blah, blah and something that works great with Linux 
power management, modem, video, sound.  Touch pads are good, finger sticks 
are bad....  I've spent the last year fighting with my Compaq Evo 600n trying 
to get it to work.  As long as it isn't on battery it works fine.

For a reasonable price (under $1000 great, under $1500 ok).  Laptops change so 
fast now adays I gave up trying to keep up years ago.  Anyone have any recent 
positive experiences?  Or should I slashdot this question.....


Sean

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Sun Jun  8 20:49:02 2003
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Sun Jun  8 20:49:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Laptop Recommendations
In-Reply-To: <200306081256.52594.sean@fork.com>
References: <200306081256.52594.sean@fork.com>
Message-ID: <200306082057.16934.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

On Sunday 08 June 2003 12:56 pm, Sean Whitney wrote:
> I am considering a new career change soon which will require a lot of
> coding, presentations, documentation and traveling.  So it looks like a new
> laptop will be in order.
>
> My partner says a Apple Ti-book is out, so what I'm looking for is x86
> recommendations.
>
> Im assuming that win2k will work on just about all x86 if I have to install
> it, but what I'm really interested in is a laptop that is very linux
> comatible from one of the major vendors (Compaq/HP, Dell, Gateway).  It
> should supports at least 1400x1050 display, long battery, DVD (a writer
> would be a plus) built in ethernet/modem (built in wireless (802.11a) a
> plus), usb, serial, audio out, blah, blah, blah and something that works
> great with Linux power management, modem, video, sound.  Touch pads are
> good, finger sticks are bad....  I've spent the last year fighting with my
> Compaq Evo 600n trying to get it to work.  As long as it isn't on battery
> it works fine.
>
> For a reasonable price (under $1000 great, under $1500 ok).  Laptops change
> so fast now adays I gave up trying to keep up years ago.  Anyone have any
> recent positive experiences?  Or should I slashdot this question.....
>
>
> Sean

Sony Vaio GRX series, many Dells, and most Thinkpads support Linux well. The 
tricky bits are built-in modems and sound. Power management is a big fat pain 
in Linux, because it is still a work in progress at the kernel level, but I 
hear tell some folks get ACPI going OK. See the IBM store on Ebay for good 
deals on last year's models. For example, they have some A31s with wifi and 
CDRW for $1499. Forget bidding, some dork always bids too high, so IMO it's a 
waste of time. http://www.stores.ebay.com/id=23983696&ssPageName=CompLaptpTS

See http://www.linux-on-laptops.com/ for the complete dish on what works.

-- 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Carla Schroder
www.tuxcomputing.com
this message brought to you
by Libranet 2.7 and Kmail
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~



From sandbox at pacifier.com  Sun Jun  8 21:26:02 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Sun Jun  8 21:26:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Laptop Recommendations
References: <200306081256.52594.sean@fork.com> <200306082057.16934.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <3EE40C21.6000701@pacifier.com>

Carla Schroder wrote:
> On Sunday 08 June 2003 12:56 pm, Sean Whitney wrote:
> 
>>I am considering a new career change soon which will require a lot of
>>coding, presentations, documentation and traveling.  So it looks like a new
>>laptop will be in order.
>>
>>My partner says a Apple Ti-book is out, so what I'm looking for is x86
>>recommendations.

I can tell you what doesn't work, though they're both older.  Toshiba 
1715xcds is pretty miserable.  Toshiba in general has a good track record 
with Linux but this was a very low-end model that wasn't made by them and 
they probably wish they never put their name on it.

The other, a IBM (excellent Linux record) ThinkPad 600e.  Mostly okay, no 
wheel action with an external mouse.  Hopefully, IBM has changed the chip 
that breaks an external mouse.  Good keyboard feel (hate the layout though) 
and overall build quality.  Power management is not perfect but lots better 
than the oem'ed Toshiba.

In short, check out IBM and don't automatically dismiss Toshiba based on one 
model.  Compare machines side-by-side if for nothing else to evaluate the 
display quality.  If you're gonna code on the thing, it better be bright and 
sharp--large doesn't hurt either.

Cheers,
Kyle Accardi

From mhopcroft at seraphimguard.com  Sun Jun  8 23:54:01 2003
From: mhopcroft at seraphimguard.com (Michael Hopcroft)
Date: Sun Jun  8 23:54:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Having trouble collecting email in Evolution
In-Reply-To: <E19P6a9-0000e4-00@bridget.jatol.com>
References: <E19P6a9-0000e4-00@bridget.jatol.com>
Message-ID: <1055141549.4358.8.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Sun, 2003-06-08 at 13:16, Michael Hopcroft wrote:
> Ximian Evolution 1.2.2, which i got in my Red had 9 distro, is not
> collecting my e-mail. neither is Mozilla mail, for that matter, but
> that's beside the point.

Believe it or not, I was able to solve my own problem. It was on the
server side, in the settings. My server wanted the full e-mail address
as the user name. I tried that and it worked like a charm. My inbox in
Evolution now has the 1000+ messages that were on the server and I won;t
lose any mail after all.

I feel brilliant now.

Michael Hopcroft 




From mhopcroft at seraphimguard.com  Sun Jun  8 23:57:02 2003
From: mhopcroft at seraphimguard.com (Michael Hopcroft)
Date: Sun Jun  8 23:57:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] I solved my own e-mail problem
Message-ID: <1055141798.4358.12.camel@localhost.localdomain>

	One of the things every Linux user needs is the resourcefulness to
solve some of their own problems. Well, I managed to get my e-mail
problem in Evolution straightened out by the simple expedeint of using
my entire e-mail address as my user name.

	I wonder what I'll do for my next trick....

	Michael Hopcroft




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jun  9 06:39:03 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon Jun  9 06:39:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Laptop Recommendations
In-Reply-To: <200306082057.16934.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306090631330.12057-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Sun, 8 Jun 2003, Carla Schroder wrote:

> Sony Vaio GRX series, many Dells, and most Thinkpads support Linux well. The 
> tricky bits are built-in modems and sound. Power management is a big fat pain 
> in Linux, because it is still a work in progress at the kernel level, but I 
> hear tell some folks get ACPI going OK.

  I've had two Toshibas -- the latest the four-year-old Portege 3025CT which
is the finest notebook I've owned. It's run only linux and the power saving
features (apm) work just fine for me.

  One factor that I suggest be carefully considered is weight. My Portege
weighs about 2 pounds. With AC power brick it's still a reasonable weight to
carry through airports, meetings and all sorts of backing-and-forthing. My
original laptop -- a Gateway in 1992 -- was about 7 pounds by itself. That
got old very fast as I hauled it everywhere. Much better than the original
Compaq suitcase luggables and still better than the Kaypro-2000s, but heavy
as a lead brick.

  When I need the external ports or floppy drive I take those along.
Otherwise I carry the stripped down version with only the Ethernet and
modem/serial pcmcia cards and I've never missed the weight of hardware not
needed.

  So consider the trade of weight for components that you won't need on a
constant basis.

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

            2404 SW 22nd Street | Troutdale, OR 97060-1247 | U.S.A.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Jun  9 09:45:03 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon Jun  9 09:45:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
In-Reply-To: <20030609162354.21999.qmail@web40812.mail.yahoo.com>

On Mon, 9 Jun 2003, Scott Van Hoosen wrote:

> They say they'll post instuctions for manual settings next month for
> Linux users. Does anyone know the new Comcast pop3, smtp and
> newsgroup server settings?

Don't know about news/nntp, but here are some mail hosts:

  [heinlein]$ host smtp.comcast.net
  smtp.comcast.net has address 24.153.64.2
  [heinlein]$ host imap.comcast.net
  imap.comcast.net has address 24.153.64.69
  [heinlein]$ host pop3.comcast.net
  pop3.comcast.net has address 24.153.64.3

There's also a mail.comcast.net that points to the pop3 server.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

responded with "It does many things. You must run it!". I made the mistake
of telling this person that I dual boot (thus effectively admitting that I
COULD run it but chose not to.) He then said "You have to!" I told him I
refused to install it. This was then implied:

If I did not run this software...

1. My internet connection would die
2. My email account would go away
3. My emails would go someplace else since the attbi domain won't be there
anymore and someone else would read them.
4. I would be breaking the rules and thus liable for some sort of damage.
5. I was a moron

Maybe the last one is right.... But still..!! :-o It wasn't until this
thread that I was entirely certain of what the software did - and since I
don't use my attbi account I found it a complete waste of time...

Qwest has a great deal on DSL, 4M up/ 1M down.. $160 month...... I need a
raise..!!

Matt

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Jun  9 11:26:01 2003

Message-ID: <1055183100.4708.2.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Mon, 2003-06-09 at 11:11, Brent Rieck wrote:
> Hello,
>   I was wondering how to determine the total amount of physical memory
> on a FreeBSD machine - The method I use under Linux is to run top and it
> just tells me the total amount of ram, FreeBSD isn't so forthcoming on
> it's top display.  Does anybody know a way?

Look at 'dmesg'.  It's shown at boot time in one of the first few
lines.  IIRC, you have to add up the several types of memory presented.

Wil

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Mon Jun  9 11:48:02 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Mon Jun  9 11:48:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] dhcpcd crashes consistently
Message-ID: <3EE4D645.2030103@pacifier.com>

This happens on two different laptops, the only commonality is similiar NICs 
(Intel Pro100 pcmcia) and RedHat 7.3.

After booting the laptop, an address is assigned okay from my dhcp server 
and I start an ssh session to another machine.  After ~2 minutes the 
connection locks up.

Client's (laptop) /var/log/messages reads,

dhcpcd[1047]: sendto: Socket operation on non-socket
dhcpcd[1047]: dhcpStop: ioctl SIOSIFADDR: Inappropriate ioctl for device
dhcpcd[1047]: dhcpStop: ioctl SIOSIFFLAGS: Inappropriate ioctl for device

I switch to vt2 and can ping the server so the interface stays up, but
whatever causes this glitch, nukes ssh.

If I close the xterm (killing the ssh session) and open another xterm and 
start another ssh session, everything works fine forever.

process 1047 reads
/sbin/dhcpcd -n -h dinky eth0

Q: Does this look like a driver issue? (Have had good luck with the e100 
driver for pci nics)  Or is it a dhcpcd issue?  (Two other machines are also 
using this daemon and e100 for pci cards and do not have this problem AFAICT.)

--
Kyle Accardi

From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Mon Jun  9 13:09:02 2003
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: Mon Jun  9 13:09:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Converting C to java
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306091254280.12821-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306091301170.7811-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>



On Mon, 9 Jun 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   Has anyone here done this? I'm looking for 1) tools (such as C2J and
> ephedra) that can automate at least part of the port and 2) estimates of how
> much time might be required (for the non-UI portions of the program). That
> is, would 100 lines/hour be reasonable for mathematical functions and the
> like?
>

Does Java have some sort of extention mechanism that lets you wrap your C
code into a shared lib that can be loaded into Java?  Actually, I think it
does since the swig page lists java (http://www.swig.org) as a supported
language.  That way you can just use your C code unchanged - AND since
you're talking about mathematical functions they'll be a lot faster in C
than in Java. I'd recommend checking out swig (Simple wrapper
interface generator) for doing this for you automatically.  Swig is a
great tool.  I used it to wrap a computational geometry C++ lib so that I
could access it's objects from Ruby.  I suspect you can do the same with
your code to access the C functions from Java.  Another advantage of swig
is that if you decide that you want to use another language later (like
Perl or Ruby or Python instead of Java) then you can very easily use the
same C code and by changing a commandline argument to swig, generate a
wrapper for the language of your choice.

BTW: I'm doing a talk at OSCON on mixed language development with Swig.

Phil

From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Mon Jun  9 14:35:02 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Mon Jun  9 14:35:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306090942200.27690-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu> <006301c32eaf$9f2df6d0$1901a8c0@madcat> <200306091303.36963.pundit@teleport.com> <1055190694.26405.11752.camel@obelisk.spek.org>

This CAN be true, but having worked at a company that had a "special"
overpriced contract with Sprint for a couple of T-1s I can say that lots and
lots of money doesn't always equal satisfaction either. I cannot count how
many times the upstream DNS server would delete the reverse dns records. It
was always an "oops!" situation involving the CEO's email getting rejected
from a client that would alert us to this situation too!!!

Pluses of DSL over cablemodem (in this area):
*Future upgradeability
*Not getting constant advertisements for services I will never use (i.e.
television)
Pluses of Cablemodem over DSL:
*"Standard" Higher download bandwidth
*Not getting constant advertisements for services I will never use (i.e.
telephone)

From drl at drloree.com  Mon Jun  9 16:20:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Mon Jun  9 16:20:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Partition USB storage device
In-Reply-To: <20030609163741.GA17682@boora.com>
References: <E19P3GT-0008AV-00@bridget.jatol.com>
	 <20030609163741.GA17682@boora.com>
Message-ID: <1055200936.18103.330.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

Hi all,

I've found this great firewall, based on Debian Woody, that runs the
root file system from a CD (http://www.gibraltar.at/). What I like is
that it will save its configuration to a floppy, USB storage device, or
a harddrive.  In particular, I really like the idea of being able to
save to a lockable USB storage device (no floppy disk sitting in the
drive - exposed to the elements).

The question I have is about USB storage devices.  Have any of you tried
to re-partition them?  I can get fdisk to recognize the drive (cfdisk
won't open it), and read its partition information, but I didn't have
the guts to delete the partition.  The winblowz tool that comes with it
can format it and make it bootable (win'98 only), but there doesn't seem
to be any partitioning tool.

TIA,

Derek Loree





From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Mon Jun  9 16:33:02 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Mon Jun  9 16:33:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Partition USB storage device
In-Reply-To: <1055200936.18103.330.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0306091623560.27960-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

USB storage devices under Linux are handled by usb-storage module which
should create a scsi host, so it will appear in /proc/scsi/scsi. The
disk will be /dev/sda if it's the only SCSI disk you have, or the next one
available, sdb, sdc, etc. You should be able to fdisk, format, and do
whatever you want with it. I have 3 external USB disks, that's how they
behave. Plug them in, check dmesg to see what device just got added, fdisk
them.

From drl at drloree.com  Mon Jun  9 16:57:01 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Mon Jun  9 16:57:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
In-Reply-To: <003401c32ece$5c0b7020$1901a8c0@madcat>
References: 
	 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306090942200.27690-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
