On Mon, 2003-06-09 at 14:30, Matt Chorman wrote:
> This CAN be true, but having worked at a company that had a "special"
> overpriced contract with Sprint for a couple of T-1s I can say that lots and
> lots of money doesn't always equal satisfaction either. I cannot count how
> many times the upstream DNS server would delete the reverse dns records. It
> was always an "oops!" situation involving the CEO's email getting rejected
> from a client that would alert us to this situation too!!!

I had even worse experience with a big national provider and a pair of
T-1's.  How about staying up all night (more than 4 hours - starting at
midnight), on hold to tech support (both T-1's were down), because they
had a glitch in their phone system that made everybody stick in the que,
no way out.  Or: deciding that the pair wasn't worth the money, placing
the order with explicit directions to call me before the change was
made, and coming in to work a week before the change was supposed to
happen to find two dead circuits (only took eight hours to get it back
up).  The really stupid part was that months later, the billing
department was still billing us for the pair!  Then there were the DNS
problems, man what a nightmare (I told the boss we should have run our
own DNS, but you know bosses)!

Compared to that, QWest is nice and friendly.
> 
> Pluses of DSL over cablemodem (in this area):
> *Future upgradeability
> *Not getting constant advertisements for services I will never use (i.e.
> television)

You forgot the biggest advantage - static IP addresses.  With DSL it is
trivial (either no charge or a little extra charge) to have a static IP
address, and a more can be had for a small fee.  This does depend on the
ISP, but you do have a choice.  Cable only allows dynamic addresses and
no choice of ISP's.

> Pluses of Cablemodem over DSL:
> *"Standard" Higher download bandwidth
> *Not getting constant advertisements for services I will never use (i.e.
> telephone)

I think Ken should expand on the security problems of cable, I haven't
read about any problems that a properly configured firewall couldn't
deal with, but then again I chose QWest instead of cable.:)

Good Luck,

Derek Loree





From kyle at silverbeach.net  Mon Jun  9 17:12:02 2003
From: kyle at silverbeach.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Mon Jun  9 17:12:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Converting C to java
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306091254280.12821-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306091254280.12821-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200306091707.42334.kyle@silverbeach.net>

On Monday 09 June 2003 12:56, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Has anyone here done this? I'm looking for 1) tools (such as C2J and
> ephedra) that can automate at least part of the port and 2) estimates of
> how much time might be required (for the non-UI portions of the program).
> That is, would 100 lines/hour be reasonable for mathematical functions and
> the like?

As previously noted, SWIG does a fair job.  Java has the Java Native Interface 
API.  This is really pretty much a Java-to-C API (and vice versa I think).  
Never used it myself, but I have a book on it :-)  Look up JNI online at the 
main Sun Java site.  I seem to remember it being quite thorough.

If you're going to be doing some heavy lifting in the math world, then you 
should look around and make sure that someone hasn't already done the work of 
wrapping highly optimized libraries for you.  I keep hearing about scientific 
computing projects that use Java, so someone's done some wrapping.

Code translators will give you code that works, but a good way to do things in 
C may not be a good way to do things in Java and vice versa.  I've never used 
any of the tools, so I'm not going to guess how long it will take.

Best,
Kyle




From drl at drloree.com  Mon Jun  9 17:12:08 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Mon Jun  9 17:12:08 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Partition USB storage device
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0306091623560.27960-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0306091623560.27960-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>
Message-ID: <1055204099.18299.368.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Mon, 2003-06-09 at 16:32, Fedor G. Pikus wrote:
> USB storage devices under Linux are handled by usb-storage module which
> should create a scsi host, so it will appear in /proc/scsi/scsi. The
> disk will be /dev/sda if it's the only SCSI disk you have, or the next one
> available, sdb, sdc, etc. You should be able to fdisk, format, and do
> whatever you want with it. I have 3 external USB disks, that's how they
> behave. Plug them in, check dmesg to see what device just got added, fdisk
> them.

The device is there, I can mount it, read from it and write to it.
However, it isn't a real disk drive, it is one of those key chain
storage devices (64Meg NexDisk), and I can't find any concrete
information about how the partition information is stored, if it can be
changed, or if it is possible to have more than one partition.  Seems
like someone out there must have tried this.  The fact that cfdisk
chokes while reading the device is a little worrysome.

Thanks,

Derek Loree





From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Jun  9 17:16:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon Jun  9 17:16:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
In-Reply-To: <1055203175.18103.355.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306091705430.27690-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

All of you who have a choice between cable and DSL should count
yourselves very fortunate. I'm too bloomin' far from our CO to get
DSL, so unless someone sets up a long-distance WI-FI network in
Gladstone, cable is my only broadband choice. (Well, ISDN may be
available, but I'm not going there...)

That said, I have to say that my experience with @Home/ATT/Comcast has
been very uneventful, which I count as a Good Thing. I work from home
two days a week and never worry about my connectivity. Lately, it's
far more likely that our Verio/ATT network connection at work will be 
the source of any problem.

Still, I'd go with DSL if I could, just so I could host my own servers
here at home without violating the cable AUP.

Three years ago or so, Ted Mittelstaed told me that there was a deal
in the works whereby independent ISPs could backend a cable connection
in a manner analogous to the way they can be your DSL ISP. I haven't
heard anything about it, but I'd certainly give it a good look if the
opportunity every came my way.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Mon Jun  9 18:01:01 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Mon Jun  9 18:01:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306090942200.27690-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu> <006301c32eaf$9f2df6d0$1901a8c0@madcat> <200306091303.36963.pundit@teleport.com> <1055190694.26405.11752.camel@obelisk.spek.org> <003401c32ece$5c0b7020$1901a8c0@madcat> <1055203175.18103.355.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
Message-ID: <003601c32eeb$2a2c6290$1901a8c0@madcat>

> You forgot the biggest advantage - static IP addresses.  With DSL it is
> trivial (either no charge or a little extra charge) to have a static IP
> address, and a more can be had for a small fee.  This does depend on the
> ISP, but you do have a choice.  Cable only allows dynamic addresses and
> no choice of ISP's.

Comcast has an "upgraded" package now that allows 2.5Mdown/384kUp that comes
with up to 5 static IPs.. With that small of a pipe upstream it doesn't seem
entirely worth it ($99).

> I think Ken should expand on the security problems of cable, I haven't
> read about any problems that a properly configured firewall couldn't
> deal with, but then again I chose QWest instead of cable.:)

Yes, this is one thing they DON'T tell you when running cable - there are so
many damn bored script kiddies anymore it is not even funny - and since
cable modems still have the 'lan effect', these kids sit and port scan all
attbi IPs (i.e. 12.x.x.x). I get an average of 5-10 unique attempts on port
80 a day, all trying to various IIS exploits. I get port scanned (1-4000 or
so) at least once or twice a day. I get specific targets hit (i.e. smtp,
ssh, telnet) ALL day. In fact I can pretty much be assured that at any given
moment someone is probing my defenses.

This is the #1 main reason I want off broadband - some of my already limited
upstream bandwidth is ALWAYS being shared with malicious and/or curious
folk.

M




From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Mon Jun  9 18:01:08 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Mon Jun  9 18:01:08 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Partition USB storage device
In-Reply-To: <1055204099.18299.368.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0306091757250.27960-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

If it's anything like compact flash, you can fdisk and partition it any
way you want, as far as Linux is concerned. My USB readed with a flashcard
in it appears also as a SCSI disk. Of course, cameras have their own idea
about the proper format, so I let them do it, but Linux can put any
filesystem and partition table on it.

From pundit at teleport.com  Mon Jun  9 20:10:02 2003
From: pundit at teleport.com (Ken Barber)
Date: Mon Jun  9 20:10:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
In-Reply-To: <1055203175.18103.355.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306090942200.27690-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu> <003401c32ece$5c0b7020$1901a8c0@madcat> <1055203175.18103.355.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
Message-ID: <200306092009.05318.pundit@teleport.com>

On Monday 09 June 2003 16:59, Derek Loree wrote:

> I think Ken should expand on the security problems of cable, I
> haven't read about any problems that a properly configured
> firewall couldn't deal with, 

I have not actually tried this myself, so I cannot vouch for it.  
However, several network engineers whom I trust have told me the 
same thing.

The security problem with cable modems is the same problem with 
any shared-media network:  all traffic on the network can be seen 
by all nodes on the network, making it trivial to sniff traffic 
and capture everyone's email, passwords to Web sites, chat and 
any/all other activity.

Now, it's true that any 'hacker' who can compromise a router can 
do the same thing, but for the love o' god at least it takes a 
little bit of skill to crack a router.  Apparently all that's 
needed to sniff cable modem traffic is to put one's ethernet 
interface into promiscuous mode.

Most people will respond with, "I have nothing to hide" but are 
you SURE?  Are you sure you've NEVER said anything in an email 
that would be embarrassing if your neighbors knew about it?

Suppose you were running for office, or were a volunteer for a 
political campaign.  Are you sure no one would be interested in 
your emails?

It's one thing for someone halfway across the world to read your 
steamy love letters, but quite another for them to be read by 
people you see every day in church, or PTA meetings or whatever.  
Imagine your daughter trying to seek advice online because she's 
afraid she's pregnant... would the kid down the street have a 
field day with that?

Ken
-- 
"I never consider a difference of opinion in politics, in 
religion, in philosophy, as cause for withdrawing from a friend."  
	- Thomas Jefferson





From sean at fork.com  Mon Jun  9 21:02:01 2003
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Mon Jun  9 21:02:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
In-Reply-To: <003601c32eeb$2a2c6290$1901a8c0@madcat>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306090942200.27690-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu> <1055203175.18103.355.camel@fastlinux.homenet> <003601c32eeb$2a2c6290$1901a8c0@madcat>
Message-ID: <200306092101.24496.sean@fork.com>

> cable modems still have the 'lan effect', these kids sit and port scan all
> attbi IPs (i.e. 12.x.x.x). I get an average of 5-10 unique attempts on port
> 80 a day, all trying to various IIS exploits. I get port scanned (1-4000 or
> so) at least once or twice a day. I get specific targets hit (i.e. smtp,
> ssh, telnet) ALL day. In fact I can pretty much be assured that at any

Care to explain what the lan effect is?  Especially since every protocol you 
listed is routable.  Sorry to disappoint you but there is no lan effect for 
cable modems.  Every packet you generate must go back to the CMTS.  If there 
is no CMTS you can't just talk with your neighbor.  DOCSIS doesn't work that 
way, it's not Ethernet.
If you're not protecting your computers with a firewall that's your fault.  It 
doesn't matter whether its cable, dsl, T1, OC3, or dialup.  You put a 
computer on the internet, it's your job to protect it.  Every firewall in the 
world gets hits, that's their jobs.


Sean



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jun  9 21:07:01 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon Jun  9 21:07:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Converting C to java
In-Reply-To: <200306091707.42334.kyle@silverbeach.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306092049200.13372-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 9 Jun 2003, Kyle Hayes wrote:

> As previously noted, SWIG does a fair job.  Java has the Java Native Interface 
> API.  This is really pretty much a Java-to-C API (and vice versa I think).  
> Never used it myself, but I have a book on it :-)  Look up JNI online at the 
> main Sun Java site.  I seem to remember it being quite thorough.

Kyle,

  When I looked at the SWIG Web site I saw a section on JNI. I'll get to
reading more about this, I'm sure.
 
> If you're going to be doing some heavy lifting in the math world, then you 
> should look around and make sure that someone hasn't already done the work of 
> wrapping highly optimized libraries for you.  I keep hearing about scientific 
> computing projects that use Java, so someone's done some wrapping.

  Aside from a couple of folks working for private companies or offering
highly-specialized soluttions doing the type of modeling I'll be doing,
there's only one person in the country actively producing work in this
field. The other one with a very high degree of knowledge is the retired
head of the Department of Biological Mathematics at the University of
Alabama/Birmingham. He's 83 years old now and I'm drafting the agreements
that will allow me to buy his code and expertise. I'm talking about fuzzy
system models that use fuzzy sets to describe linguistic variables and are
manipulated using the mathematics of fuzzy logic (t-norms, anyone?). Ergo,
nothing's available.

  Well, let me modify that. NASA wrote a expert system modeling tool and Sandia Labs
translated it from C to java. A unit of the Canadian government made fuzzy
modules for each. Other than the original NASA code (in the public domain)
use of the others costs big bucks: $15,000 and up. Also, they are neither
complete nor well written systems and the fuzzy portions are designed more
for control than for decision support systems.

  My friend and mentor would let me use his code but he signed it over to
his new company (he's started four software companies over the past few
decades and sold three of them; one to IBM for a figure comfortably in 9
digits -- to the left of the decimal point. His advice is to buy the source
code that I'm working on getting.
 
> Code translators will give you code that works, but a good way to do
> things in C may not be a good way to do things in Java and vice versa. 
> I've never used any of the tools, so I'm not going to guess how long it
> will take.

  True; very true. But, if I can get working code in java by wrapping or
hand porting the core functions and re-creating the UI in pure java then
I'll have a working system sooner rather than later. As time permits and my
knowledge and skill with java increase I can working on optimizing
performance.

Many thanks for the thoughts,

Rich

not anyone elses traffic.  Maybe it was like that at one time, but I
don't think it is anymore.

From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Mon Jun  9 22:59:02 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Mon Jun  9 22:59:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306090942200.27690-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu> <1055203175.18103.355.camel@fastlinux.homenet> <003601c32eeb$2a2c6290$1901a8c0@madcat> <200306092101.24496.sean@fork.com>
Message-ID: <001801c32f14$b6c08eb0$1901a8c0@madcat>

> Care to explain what the lan effect is?  Especially since every protocol
you
> listed is routable.  Sorry to disappoint you but there is no lan effect
for

I do have a firewall. I host a web server so port 80 is open, which is why I
am able to log the traffic I get on that port. I have a friend who is rather
dumb and does not run a firewall. He runs windows xp, by itself, without
even the pathetic XP firewall enabled.. (Something about a quake server..) I
always get a kick out of changing his workgroup around and finding the
occasional share suddenly available - the two most popular workgroups are
"workgroup" and "homegroup". This is the "lan effect" I speak of.

I know those (protocols mentioned) are routable protocols - as are the many
other dozens that are targeted out specifically - but what I'm saying is I
get an extraordinary amount of portscans targeting these ports specifically,
and they come "internally" from the comcast/attbi network.

> cable modems.  Every packet you generate must go back to the CMTS.  If
there
> is no CMTS you can't just talk with your neighbor.  DOCSIS doesn't work
that
> way, it's not Ethernet.

Excuse my ignorance, but I don't know what that means. Frankly it doesn't
matter. All I know is I'm sitting here watching my lights flash away - once
again, someone is doing a port scan. This time it's been going on for about
3 minutes. Trusty IPTABLES is doing it's job! Stupid comcast is not - and my
bandwidth suffers accordingly.

From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Tue Jun 10 07:31:02 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Tue Jun 10 07:31:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306090942200.27690-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu><1055203175.18103.355.camel@fastlinux.homenet><003601c32eeb$2a2c6290$1901a8c0@madcat><200306092101.24496.sean@fork.com><001801c32f14$b6c08eb0$1901a8c0@madcat> <86adcq4faf.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <001401c32f5c$44571400$1901a8c0@madcat>

You're right. Right this second. I also know the difference between "light
arp traffic" and a port scan on the blinking lights.

Earlier, when I wrote the previous email, I checked firestarter (my firewall
monitor) - I had a port scan coming in.  Funny, as I'm typing this another
scan for port 2987 is taking place... from yet another 12.x.x.x.attbi.com
address... and now for 5631.. This one seems to be light, two attempts every
20 seconds.

I'm not making this up.

TheI know that there is a lot I don't know, but I'm not going to speak up in
a public forum when I'm not sure about what I know. What I said earlier -
and this is all I said - is that I get an inordinate amount of inbound port
scans coming from the internal attbi.com IPs. This takes up a portion of my
bandwidth.

If any here is interested I will start posting the IP's of these annoyances
for all to "poke and prod"..

M

From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Tue Jun 10 07:38:01 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Tue Jun 10 07:38:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Firewall software
Message-ID: <001d01c32f5d$3687cf80$1901a8c0@madcat>

Speaking of firewalls..

I like firestarter - it is a simple little utility that keeps me from having to dig into firewall.sh too much. It has a very basic gui which allows you to monitor your firewall's effectiveness.. It's worked so far, but it is rather limited..

I would like a different/new firewall monitor. I've looked around but can't seem to find what I'm looking for. Has anyone used Watchguard's firewall utility? It shows current connections as well as violations. It allows you to assign nodes to groups for quick visual identification.. It is a very functional utility. I can't seem to find a utility like this for linux..

So my question to the masses: what firewall software do you use? Is there anything out there that will show both current and attempted connections and give me the information I need? My requirements are a visual interface (so my roommate with limited linux experience can navigate through it) and a "connection"-based display, i.e. open ports with open connections show on the list as well as attempts on closed ports..

Thanks!
Matt

From drl at drloree.com  Tue Jun 10 09:50:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)

Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
In-Reply-To: <200306092009.05318.pundit@teleport.com>
References: 
	 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306090942200.27690-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
	 <003401c32ece$5c0b7020$1901a8c0@madcat>

Message-ID: <1055263968.18102.1106.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Mon, 2003-06-09 at 20:09, Ken Barber wrote:
> On Monday 09 June 2003 16:59, Derek Loree wrote:
> 
> > I think Ken should expand on the security problems of cable, I
> > haven't read about any problems that a properly configured
> > firewall couldn't deal with, 
> 
> I have not actually tried this myself, so I cannot vouch for it.  
> However, several network engineers whom I trust have told me the 
> same thing.
> 
> The security problem with cable modems is the same problem with 
> any shared-media network:  all traffic on the network can be seen 
> by all nodes on the network, making it trivial to sniff traffic 
> and capture everyone's email, passwords to Web sites, chat and 
> any/all other activity.

I have always assumed that any un-encrypted packets were sniffable,
regardless of the type of connection.
> 
> Now, it's true that any 'hacker' who can compromise a router can 
> do the same thing, but for the love o' god at least it takes a 
> little bit of skill to crack a router.  Apparently all that's 
> needed to sniff cable modem traffic is to put one's ethernet 
> interface into promiscuous mode.

This could be fun, in combination with the DSL/Cable modem firewall
appliances that route private IP addresses, you could not only sniff
your neighbors packets, but dish out private addresses and take over
their routing and DNS.
> 
> Most people will respond with, "I have nothing to hide" but are 
> you SURE?  Are you sure you've NEVER said anything in an email 
> that would be embarrassing if your neighbors knew about it?

Yep, most people have no idea what they are exposing, either.
> 
> Suppose you were running for office, or were a volunteer for a 
> political campaign.  Are you sure no one would be interested in 
> your emails?
> 
> It's one thing for someone halfway across the world to read your 
> steamy love letters, but quite another for them to be read by 
> people you see every day in church, or PTA meetings or whatever.  
> Imagine your daughter trying to seek advice online because she's 
> afraid she's pregnant... would the kid down the street have a 
> field day with that?

'Tis kind of scarey.

Thanks,

Derek Loree

From drl at drloree.com  Tue Jun 10 10:40:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Tue Jun 10 10:40:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Partition USB storage device
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0306091757250.27960-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0306091757250.27960-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>
Message-ID: <1055266953.18299.1132.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Mon, 2003-06-09 at 18:00, Fedor G. Pikus wrote:
> If it's anything like compact flash, you can fdisk and partition it any
> way you want, as far as Linux is concerned. My USB readed with a flashcard
> in it appears also as a SCSI disk. Of course, cameras have their own idea
> about the proper format, so I let them do it, but Linux can put any
> filesystem and partition table on it.

It worked!  I should have known that linux would do the right things to
make it work.  It turns out that they start with a broken partition,
which is why cfdisk chokes.  Using fdisk, I was able to create a new
partition table, and 4 primary partitions, one FAT12, one swap, and 2
ext3's.  Now cfdisk can read it, the FAT12 is accessible to the M$ OS's,
and I can mount /var, /home and swap.

I am one happy camper! Thanks!

Derek Loree

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Tue Jun 10 11:40:03 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Tue Jun 10 11:40:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Are either of these cards XFree86 compatible?
In-Reply-To: <1055268165.6936.13.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0306101129360.6759-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

On 10 Jun 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> Asus GF4 V8170DDR/SE MX440SE 64MB DDR
This is a GeForce4 MX card. It is XFree86-compatible, XFree includes
open-source non-accelerated driver, and NVidia provides their Detonator
driver which is of the same quality as the Windows driver, and supports
all features of the card.
In general, I'm not a big fan of MX series of GeForce, all revies I've
seen show that one would be better off going to the previous line of cards
instead, i.e. in this case GeForce 3 Ti cards (a "real" GeForce) can be
bought for about as much as GeForce 4 MX (GeForce "lite") and will perform
better, although you won't be able to brag that you have a GeForce 4.

> ATI Radeon 7500 64MB DDR
This one is supported in XFree 4.2 (possibly 4.1 but there were some
issues there, and some people needed to get files from CVS to hack their
XFree installation). There are open-source drivers, I was never able to
get the full scoop on whether they are from ATI or ATI helped in their
development or they have nothing to do with ATI, and how well they support
the hardware features. My guess is that not too well, but it's based on
the fact that in most discussions I've seen the main argument used against
someone who says "This and this is not supported and the card is not used
at full potential and will perform much slower than similar GeForce" is
"but the drivers are open source". May be the drivers are good and zealots
just haven't bothered to learn about it.

> How do you tell the voltage an agp card operates at?
>
>      --  Michael C. Robinson
>
>
>

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Tue Jun 10 11:44:02 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Tue Jun 10 11:44:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Partition USB storage device
In-Reply-To: <20030610182848.GA15654@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0306101139510.6759-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

On Tue, 10 Jun 2003, Colin Kuskie wrote:
> On Tue, Jun 10, 2003 at 10:42:33AM -0700, Derek Loree wrote:
> >
> > It worked!  I should have known that linux would do the right things to
> > make it work.  It turns out that they start with a broken partition,
> > which is why cfdisk chokes.  Using fdisk, I was able to create a new
> > partition table, and 4 primary partitions, one FAT12, one swap, and 2
> > ext3's.  Now cfdisk can read it, the FAT12 is accessible to the M$ OS's,
> > and I can mount /var, /home and swap.
>
> Why FAT12 instead of FAT32?
Small drive?

BTW, the "weird" partition table may be what's used by whatever device
formatted this drive (or whatever device it was intended for, if it's
factory-formatted). I've seen in on flash cards and ZIP disks, I was able
to read them under Linux but they have strange partitioning. This
partitioning is required by their "native" devices (in case of ZIP drive,
under Linux you can partition it any way you like, but IOmega drivers for
Windows will only recognize their way, and in case of flash cards the
camera or other device must have the formatting it wants and no other).

>
> Colin
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>

8405 SW Boeckman Road               | FAX:   (503) 685-1239
Wilsonville, Oregon 97070           | http://www.pikus.net/~pikus/

From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Tue Jun 10 12:02:01 2003
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: Tue Jun 10 12:02:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] dial-in connections
In-Reply-To: <20030610182848.GA15654@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306101157490.28898-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>

An old friend of mine who has never played with Linux has a client that
wants to start looking into Linux.  Apparently they want to set up a
machine that can be dialed-into and establish a PPP connection.  Just so I
can point him in the right direction, what's needed to allow another
machine to dial into your box and establish a PPP connection with it?

He tells me that he tried to set up a RedHat box but found that it didn't
support dial-in - I suspect that this is not entirely true.

Phil





From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Jun 10 12:22:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue Jun 10 12:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] dial-in connections
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306101157490.28898-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306101219410.1002-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Tue, 10 Jun 2003, Phil Tomson wrote:

> Just so I can point him in the right direction, what's needed to
> allow another machine to dial into your box and establish a PPP
> connection with it?
> 
> He tells me that he tried to set up a RedHat box but found that it
> didn't support dial-in - I suspect that this is not entirely true.

The mgetty package is, I believe, the standard for such things:

  [RPMS]$ rpm -qp --qf '%{DESCRIPTION}' mgetty-1.1.30-2.i386.rpm 
  The mgetty package contains a "smart" getty which allows logins over 
  a serial line (i.e., through a modem).  If you're using a Class 2 or 
  2.0 modem, mgetty can receive faxes.  If you also need to send 
  faxes, you'll need to install the sendfax program.

  If you'll be dialing in to your system using a modem, you should
  install the mgetty package.  If you'd like to send faxes using 
  mgetty and your modem, you'll need to install the mgetty-sendfax 
  program.  If you need a viewer for faxes, you'll also need to 
  install the mgetty-viewfax package.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

On Monday 09 June 2003 21:46, Russell Senior wrote:
> >>>>> "Ken" == Ken Barber <pundit at teleport.com> writes:
>
> Ken> The security problem with cable modems is the same problem
> with Ken> any shared-media network: all traffic on the network
> can be seen Ken> by all nodes on the network, making it trivial
> to sniff traffic Ken> and capture everyone's email, passwords
> to Web sites, chat and Ken> any/all other activity.
>
> I don't see this behaviour.  When I do a tcpdump on the
> cable-modem interface, all I see is ARP broadcasts, not the
> "client" replies, and not anyone elses traffic. 

That's interesting, you can see Layer 2 packets but nothing any 
higher?  Weird.

I was almost tempted to get cable anyway and see how easy it 
really is to sniff traffic, but I really don't have the income to 
support two broadband connections (one I trust marginally; one I 
don't trust that is just for 'hacking') right now.

Ken

I never see anyone elses traffic.  That's not to say that with
appropriate hardware you couldn't, but I don't think that equipment is
widely deployed.  Casual snooping by neighbors seems quite unlikely
these days.

From drl at drloree.com  Tue Jun 10 13:51:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Tue Jun 10 13:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] dial-in connections
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306101219410.1002-100000@pecos.madboa.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306101219410.1002-100000@pecos.madboa.com>
Message-ID: <1055278440.18299.1135.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Tue, 2003-06-10 at 12:21, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On Tue, 10 Jun 2003, Phil Tomson wrote:
> 
> > Just so I can point him in the right direction, what's needed to
> > allow another machine to dial into your box and establish a PPP
> > connection with it?
> > 
> > He tells me that he tried to set up a RedHat box but found that it
> > didn't support dial-in - I suspect that this is not entirely true.
> 
> The mgetty package is, I believe, the standard for such things:
> 
>   [RPMS]$ rpm -qp --qf '%{DESCRIPTION}' mgetty-1.1.30-2.i386.rpm 
>   The mgetty package contains a "smart" getty which allows logins over 
>   a serial line (i.e., through a modem).  If you're using a Class 2 or 
>   2.0 modem, mgetty can receive faxes.  If you also need to send 
>   faxes, you'll need to install the sendfax program.
> 
>   If you'll be dialing in to your system using a modem, you should
>   install the mgetty package.  If you'd like to send faxes using 
>   mgetty and your modem, you'll need to install the mgetty-sendfax 
>   program.  If you need a viewer for faxes, you'll also need to 
>   install the mgetty-viewfax package.

And if you want your computer to answer with a voice messaging system,
install the vgetty package.

Derek Loree

Subject: [PLUG] Getting a red Hat system to play audio files

Red hat 9 has one glaring weakness. the deliberately disabled MP3
support, making their audio player virtually useless. Worse, the video
player (which is supposed to have MP3 support) that I just downloaded
not only won;t play MP3 files (it starts the files but no sound comes
out) but it won't play the audio track on my video files. Is there
something in the Red Hat system that blocks out those audio standards
from ALL pieces of software, or is there some RPM or code I can install
that would re-enable MP3 and audio?

Before anyone asks, Red Hat did test the sound card successfully.




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Jun 10 14:02:01 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue Jun 10 14:02:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] GIS/Mapping Newbie - needs help.
In-Reply-To: <200306101150.50027.scott_list@mischko.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306101356140.16198-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 10 Jun 2003, Scott Chapman wrote:

> I would like to find/make/customize an application that will allow me to
> enter multiple addresses in a city and have it generate an image that I
> can print.

  Don't hold your breath.
 
> I'm looking for:
> 1) Suggestions directly related to this.

  This type of address matching is the domain of the vector GIS vendors
(MapInfo, ESRI, etc.). There _is_ MapServer out of the U. Minnesota but I've
never looked at it. The former run only on Microsoft, the latter runs on
linux (is OSS) and can apparently be integrated with GRASS but I don't know
if you can do address matching. 

> 2) Email lists devoted to GIS/Mapping issues on Linux.

  There's gis-l and mapinfo-l, but the only linux list is GRASS
(http://grass.baylor.edu/)
 
> Any help would be greatly appreciated!

  Try MapQuest or send a message to Bill Thoen: bthoen at gisnet.com.

Rich

From drl at drloree.com  Tue Jun 10 14:06:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Tue Jun 10 14:06:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Partition USB storage device
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0306101139510.6759-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0306101139510.6759-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>
Message-ID: <1055279328.18103.1149.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Tue, 2003-06-10 at 11:43, Fedor G. Pikus wrote:
> On Tue, 10 Jun 2003, Colin Kuskie wrote:
> > On Tue, Jun 10, 2003 at 10:42:33AM -0700, Derek Loree wrote:
> > >
> > > It worked!  I should have known that linux would do the right things to
> > > make it work.  It turns out that they start with a broken partition,
> > > which is why cfdisk chokes.  Using fdisk, I was able to create a new
> > > partition table, and 4 primary partitions, one FAT12, one swap, and 2
> > > ext3's.  Now cfdisk can read it, the FAT12 is accessible to the M$ OS's,
> > > and I can mount /var, /home and swap.
> >
> > Why FAT12 instead of FAT32?
> Small drive?

2 Meg.  FAT12 has smaller block sizes, so less space is wasted in
partially filled blocks.  However, it only works on small partitions (I
can't recall the maximum size).
> 
> BTW, the "weird" partition table may be what's used by whatever device
> formatted this drive (or whatever device it was intended for, if it's
> factory-formatted). I've seen in on flash cards and ZIP disks, I was able
> to read them under Linux but they have strange partitioning. This
> partitioning is required by their "native" devices (in case of ZIP drive,
> under Linux you can partition it any way you like, but IOmega drivers for
> Windows will only recognize their way, and in case of flash cards the
> camera or other device must have the formatting it wants and no other).

Fortunately, Winblowz recongnized it for what it was, instead of what
the tool thought it should be.  In fact I used the native winblowz tool
to format the FAT12 partition.

Thanks for the information about the IOmega, I know that will come in
handy sometime.

Derek Loree




From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Tue Jun 10 14:21:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Tue Jun 10 14:21:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
In-Reply-To: <86brx5hdvx.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <22953-94010@sneakemail.com>

On 10 Jun 2003, Russell Senior seniorr-at-aracnet.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> Here's a sample:
> 
>   # tcpdump -n 
>   tcpdump: listening on eth0
>   13:29:35.847438 arp who-has 12.225.145.190 tell 12.225.145.1
>   13:29:35.898320 arp who-has 12.224.141.59 tell 12.224.140.1
>   13:29:35.927603 arp who-has 12.225.200.28 tell 12.225.200.1

> I never see anyone elses traffic.  That's not to say that with
> appropriate hardware you couldn't, but I don't think that equipment is
> widely deployed.  Casual snooping by neighbors seems quite unlikely
> these days.

I'll second this-- it's more complicated than a simple tcpdump to see your
neighbors' unicast traffic.  I'm sure that some (most?) cable modems can
be configured or hacked to pass all traffic through, but casual
observation is no longer possible.

Besides, any reasonably sensitive information should be encrypted before
it ever leaves your own network, and preferably before it leaves your own
host.  ;-)

  -- Steve





From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Tue Jun 10 14:26:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Tue Jun 10 14:26:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] GIS/Mapping Newbie - needs help.
In-Reply-To: <200306101150.50027.scott_list@mischko.com>
Message-ID: <22953-29931@sneakemail.com>

On Tue, 10 Jun 2003, Scott Chapman scott_list-at-mischko.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> I would like to find/make/customize an application that will allow me
> to enter multiple addresses in a city and have it generate an image
> that I can print.
> 
> I'm looking for:
> 1) Suggestions directly related to this.
> 2) Email lists devoted to GIS/Mapping issues on Linux.

The only thing that I've seen that came reasonably close was the Thomas
Guide mapping software for Windows.  It would allow you to store multiple
address points on a map and then print the map with notations for each
point.  It was extremely crude, but it did do the multiple address thing
well.

If you find something that lets you do this without Windows, please let me
know.

GRASS is a decent GIS package, but it has no concept of an "address".  You
will need to devote a reasonable amount of work to find the raw data
needed to plot street addresses along with street information.  You might
be able to get some raw data on Portland from:

http://www.cgis.ci.portland.or.us/Main.cfm

  -- Steve




From rschlosser at newedgenetworks.com  Tue Jun 10 14:29:02 2003
From: rschlosser at newedgenetworks.com (Schlosser, Ryan)
Date: Tue Jun 10 14:29:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
Message-ID: <170830AA1EB8D611AD2300508B6BD10A038C15EE@smaug.newedgenetworks.com>

I investigated this somewhat last night, and from what I could extract from
Comcasts 'support' website, it appears you need to login to the comcast
support site with your username/password and request NNTP access - you'll
receive a username/password, which you can then use to point to giganews.
Basically, it appears that Comcast has thrown in and outsourced their news
servers.  Oh, and btw, you only get 1GB of transfer per month - but giganews
will gladly offer you upgraded service, for a fee.  (um, consolidation to a
single national monopoly provider is good for consumers, cough cough, oh
yah, this isn't the plug-chat, raised our rates and lowered the service
offering, cough cough)

I have not jumped thru the hoops, so I can neither confirm nor deny this.
However, it seems the days of gleefully sucking binaries from AT&T's netnews
server has passed.

-----Original Message-----
From: Paul Heinlein [mailto:heinlein at attbi.com]
Sent: Monday, June 09, 2003 9:45 AM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: Re: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch


On Mon, 9 Jun 2003, Scott Van Hoosen wrote:

> They say they'll post instuctions for manual settings next month for
> Linux users. Does anyone know the new Comcast pop3, smtp and
> newsgroup server settings?

Don't know about news/nntp, but here are some mail hosts:

  [heinlein]$ host smtp.comcast.net
  smtp.comcast.net has address 24.153.64.2
  [heinlein]$ host imap.comcast.net
  imap.comcast.net has address 24.153.64.69
  [heinlein]$ host pop3.comcast.net
  pop3.comcast.net has address 24.153.64.3

There's also a mail.comcast.net that points to the pop3 server.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From svanhoosen at yahoo.com  Tue Jun 10 14:36:02 2003
From: svanhoosen at yahoo.com (Scott Van Hoosen)
Date: Tue Jun 10 14:36:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Getting a red Hat system to play audio files
In-Reply-To: <1055278587.4575.12.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <20030610213452.52092.qmail@web40809.mail.yahoo.com>

Michael,

Red Hat removed MP3 support from xmms due to patent
issues, I believe. There is an rpm that will add mp3
support back into it. It is no longer on their web
page like it used to be, but I have posted a copy of
it to my web page. This is actually the Red Hat 8
version, but works for Red Hat 9. The URL is:


http://vanhoosen.net/temp/xmms-mpg123-1.2.7-13.i386.rpm

Hope this helps.

-Scott

From barryb at proaxis.com  Tue Jun 10 15:25:03 2003

In-Reply-To: <1055278587.4575.12.camel@localhost.localdomain>

Message-ID: <20030610222559.GA25967@edge>

On Tue, Jun 10, 2003 at 01:56:27PM -0700, Michael Hopcroft wrote:
> Red hat 9 has one glaring weakness. the deliberately disabled MP3
> support, making their audio player virtually useless. Worse, the video
> player (which is supposed to have MP3 support) that I just downloaded
> not only won;t play MP3 files (it starts the files but no sound comes
> out) but it won't play the audio track on my video files. Is there
> something in the Red Hat system that blocks out those audio standards
> from ALL pieces of software, or is there some RPM or code I can install
> that would re-enable MP3 and audio?
> 
> Before anyone asks, Red Hat did test the sound card successfully.

In what way do you know that Red Hat tested the sound card successfully?
Did you hear a sound? The default is often to mute and or turn the
volume all the way down. To counter this you need to start  up a mixer
like alsamixer and unmute, and turn up the volume. What motherboard/soundchip
are you trying to use?

Bill Barry

From robbert at vafam.com  Tue Jun 10 15:43:01 2003

I don't know if someone has mentioned this, but my onboard audio device (which tested successfully with Red Hat) has a bug in the driver.  I had to put the speaker cable into the audio in port.  Works great now.  When I boot into Windows, I simply switch the cable over.  It's weird, I don't understand it, but sometimes not caring makes life a lot less stressful :-)

Robbert

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Jun 10 16:19:01 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue Jun 10 16:19:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla-1.2.1 bookmarks disappearing
In-Reply-To: <20030606215612.4f806e16.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306101615050.16825-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 6 Jun 2003, Jason Van Cleve wrote:

> Lame suggestion, I guess, but you are using the menu option to shut down
> the browser, right?

Jason,

  Not lame, but the solution. Up until the 1.2.x releases I could leave
mozilla open when I killed X and all open applications were registered with
xfce's session manager. The next time I logged in and ran 'startx', up would
come mozilla, along with four xterms, pine, OpenOffice.org, The GIMP, etc.

  Since this release mozilla no longer automatically reloads and it loses
all new bookmarks.

  But, extensive testing has shown me that manually closing mozilla (ctrl-q)
retains the bookmarks when I invoke it again.

  Strange ... but true.

Thanks,

Rich

From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Tue Jun 10 16:58:01 2003
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Tue Jun 10 16:58:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] GIS/Mapping Newbie - needs help.
Message-ID: <EX-20030610-185823-0001@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>


Scott Chapman asks:

> I would like to find/make/customize an application that will 
> allow me to enter 
> multiple addresses in a city and have it generate an image 
> that I can print.
> 
> I'm looking for:
> 1) Suggestions directly related to this.
> 2) Email lists devoted to GIS/Mapping issues on Linux.
> 
> Any help would be greatly appreciated!
> 
  The USPS has the TIGER (Topological Integrated Geographic Encoding and Reference) / ZIP+4 File.

http://www.usps.com/ncsc/products/tiger.htm

  It's $50 shipping/handling the last time I looked, but I believe Eric Raymond used to keep the database up on his FTP site.  

  The ZIP+4 looked a little flakey when I went through the data.  It looked like the XY of the ZIP+4 was often the same as the main ZIP.  

Steve D...




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Jun 10 17:19:01 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue Jun 10 17:19:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] GIS/Mapping Newbie - needs help.
In-Reply-To: <EX-20030610-185823-0001@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306101714010.16905-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 10 Jun 2003, Daggett, Steve wrote:

>   The USPS has the TIGER (Topological Integrated Geographic Encoding and
>   Reference) / ZIP+4 File.
> 
> http://www.usps.com/ncsc/products/tiger.htm

  TIGER files are notorious for needing to be cleaned before use.
 
>   It's $50 shipping/handling the last time I looked, but I believe Eric
>   Raymond used to keep the database up on his FTP site.

  You can get the Census Bureau block data for free. That's what the USPS
uses.

  I have street files for the entire US, but they're at 1:100K resolution
and about 5+ years old. You can get current ones from the Oregon GIS Web
site in ARC/Info export or ARCview shape formats.

  Raw data files are only part of the equation.

Rich

From jtodd at loligo.com  Tue Jun 10 17:46:02 2003
From: jtodd at loligo.com (John Todd)
Date: Tue Jun 10 17:46:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] GIS/Mapping Newbie - needs help.
In-Reply-To: <200306101150.50027.scott_list@mischko.com>
References: <200306101150.50027.scott_list@mischko.com>
Message-ID: <p05210609bb0c29e43875@loligo.com>

>I would like to find/make/customize an application that will allow me to enter
>multiple addresses in a city and have it generate an image that I can print.
>
>I'm looking for:
>1) Suggestions directly related to this.
>2) Email lists devoted to GIS/Mapping issues on Linux.
>
>Any help would be greatly appreciated!
>
>Scott

1)  You should investigate the Open-Source mapserv toolkit at 
http://mapserver.gis.umn.edu/

    I have installed this on several systems that my firm uses, and it 
works like a charm.  There's a firm in Maryland that sells Tiger 
datasets (the "raw data" files that contain the streets, zip, 
political boundaries, etc.) in ARC form for a reasonable figure, and 
he also has a Perl-based application that layers on top of mapserv 
that will do address-to-lat/lon mapping.  You can find them at:

mapsurf at midsouth.rr.com.
Silicon Mapping Solutions
http://www.siliconmapping.com/

As mentioned by others, mapserv runs on Linux, but will also run on 
almost any other UNIX-like operating system (I have it running on a 
handful of OpenBSD platforms.)


2) Google will help you with mailing lists.   :)

3) Nothing is free, especially mapping systems.  Despite the Open 
Source moniker, getting _quality_ data will cost you at least $2k for 
the whole project, excluding hardware.  If it's less, you win, but 
that's what you should bank on.  This is far less than commercial 
rights to any of the "professional" datasets out there, which are 
(for your purposes) just scrubbed Tiger datasets.

JT



From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Jun 10 17:52:01 2003

So my dream of having a mapquest-like application that was aware of
elevation changes (and, ideally, road quality) to punch in a couple of
addresses and choose how much climbing you want to do to output a route
for biking through the city is way out of the realm of feasibility right
now?

Why don't the MANY public agencies that compile and use this kind of data
make it available to the public?

One of the many problems with public agencies contracting private
tyrannies, I suppose.

From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Tue Jun 10 17:58:02 2003

> > earlier - and this is all I said - is that I get an inordinate amount of

>
> What's "inordinate"?  I mean to say, how do you know you're getting more

More than I would expect. I've had DSL in the past (granted it was over a
year ago) but I do not remember even close to the amount of portscans I get
now that I'm on cable. Maybe it is the same amount that everyone else gets-
if so then I wonder how much bandwidth across the internet at any given
moment is taken to port scans, whether curious, professional, or malicious?
How much bandwidth does poor grandma lose if she gets a major port scan
(i.e. more than 1000 ports) for every two hours she is online? If I were to
scan a dial-up, even with my limited upstream bandwidth I could quickly
drown it.

> I get a buttload of snoops and portscans and things, too... and mostly
> from cable modem subscribers, but I'm on DSL.
> I don't really think cable exposes you any more or less.

I agree - but having that 12.x.x.x address..... I dunno. This would be an
interesting metric - which type of internet service attracts the most
hackers? Which attracts the least? Why type of scans does connection X get
vs. connection Y? What type of service do most of the script kiddies out in
userville have?

> However, I do think that the AUP at the private cable monopoly is bad
> shit.

There's a great line from "Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas" that I am going
to adapt and steal: "You can turn your back on a person but you can never
turn your back on a monopoly."

Ahem.... ;-)

M




From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Jun 10 18:21:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue Jun 10 18:21:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
In-Reply-To: <004101c32fb3$ced93a20$1901a8c0@madcat>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306090942200.27690-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu><1055203175.18103.355.camel@fastlinux.homenet><003601c32eeb$2a2c6290$1901a8c0@madcat><200306092101.24496.sean@fork.com><001801c32f14$b6c08eb0$1901a8c0@madcat>
 <86adcq4faf.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <001401c32f5c$44571400$1901a8c0@madcat>
 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306101536170.3166@shaft.bitmine.net> <004101c32fb3$ced93a20$1901a8c0@madcat>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306101801000.5062@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 10 Jun 2003, Matt Chorman wrote:
> > I get a buttload of snoops and portscans and things, too... and mostly
> > from cable modem subscribers, but I'm on DSL.
> > I don't really think cable exposes you any more or less.
>
> I agree - but having that 12.x.x.x address..... I dunno. This would be
> an interesting metric - which type of internet service attracts the most
> hackers? Which attracts the least?
[snip]
> What type of service do most of the script kiddies out in userville
> have?

Obviously, cable is going to be the #1 perpetrator here, but for social,
not technological reasons.

DSL is pretty much for geeks and businesses (whose internet connections
are chosen by geeks).  DSL is urban (gotta be close to the CO), the IPs
are generally static, and the service agreements usually allow some kind
of services.  Geeks have more interesting projects than portscanning
strangers.  Boredom is not generally an issue with geeks (loneliness,
maybe; boredom, no).

Cable is for suburbanites.  It's for people that bought into the american
dream of highway culture or are caught up in servicing the sprawl itself
and don't know any better.  The suburbs are just about the worst
environment for a teenager.  There's lots of space between things,
generally no sidewalks, terribly road design (long slow curves, super-wide
streets -- both contribute to high-speed, reckless driving -- all for
motorist safety, no on-street parking or regularly planted trees to
protect pedestrians from traffic, again for motorist safety at the expense
of a pleasant environment).  Between the ages of about 8 and 16, you're a
prisoner in the "development" in which you live.  There are no social
spots, no public space, and no non-residential buildings.  There's nothing
to do but watch TV and dick around on the internet.  And since your entire
environment is anti-social, you really don't perceive the human harm in
your abusive, selfish behavior.

Script-kiddies are suburban, bored, and anti-social.  The suburbs are
pretty much designed to turn out these kinds of people.  It's not a
surprise that so many american kids are obese.  It IS a surprise that more
aren't certifiably psychotic (or maybe that's what all the medication is
for).

> Why type of scans does connection X get vs. connection Y?

I think all connections get the same kinds of scans.

I suppose it might make sense that kids try to scan other people in their
close proximity (IP, speaking) in an attempt to gain access to or
information about their neighbors (which is a gross misunderstanding of
the scale of the cable business model, but I digress...).  An adult would
probably know better than to scan folks on his own network because the
complaints are more likely to result in a suspension of service.  An adult
is paying the bill... a suburban kid is just fucking with Mom and Dad's
connection and they'll just go to anothe provider (in the kid's mind).

> There's a great line from "Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas" that I am
> going to adapt and steal: "You can turn your back on a person but you
> can never turn your back on a monopoly."

I'm not sure it's ever a good idea to turn your back on anything.

[Note that it means something entirely different to turn your back on a
person than it does to turn your back on a non-person.  If you "turn your
back on" an alligator or a corporation or the gub'mint, you're becoming
vulnerable and openning yourself to attack.  If you "turn your back on" a
person, you're ignoring their problems and failing to lend a hand where
you otherwise could have.  It's an interesting phrase.]

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

Rich Shepard wrote:

>  Not lame, but the solution. Up until the 1.2.x releases I could leave
>mozilla open when I killed X and all open applications were registered with
>xfce's session manager. The next time I logged in and ran 'startx', up would
>come mozilla, along with four xterms, pine, OpenOffice.org, The GIMP, etc.
>
>  Since this release mozilla no longer automatically reloads and it loses
>all new bookmarks.
>  
>
Another bit of information...  running in a Gnome/Metacity environment, 
I normally exit either by cntrl-alt-backspace, or just by simply logging 
out.  Neither loses any bookmarks, on any release of Mozilla.  The only 
time I've ever lost bookmark info was on a Windows system running a pre 
1.0 release of Mozilla.

I'm currently running Mozilla 1.4 rc1.

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Jun 10 19:14:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue Jun 10 19:14:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Bandwidth Shaping
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306101858200.5912@shaft.bitmine.net>

Hi.

I'm about to reorganize my home network here and I'm hoping to get some
advice and pointers from the crowd.

The portion of my network that needs reorganizing is this /29 and the
associated private network of PCs and stuff behind the firewall in that
subnet.

The private network (10.42.42.0/24) contains my fileserver, one
address-translatin' firewall interface and default gateway (10.42.42.1),
one private interface on my public web/shell server for access to the
private net through ssh and for NFS mounting homedirs from the fileserver,
and a handful of desktop systems.

Ideally, I want the firewall to be serving DHCP to the bulk of the desktop
machines (OK, all but mine) and all statically addressed interfaces to
have bandwidth preference for the gateway, but all interfaces (including
those addressed via DHCP) would be allowed a minimum of, say, 10kB/s.

So, should I just slap another interface into the firewall, break out the
network into two /25s?  My only concern there is that I only have one
100Mb switch (the /29 publicly addressable network is all 10MB because
it's only a 1Mb pipe coming in anyway), so the DHCP systems would be
limited to 10Mb connections and I'd have more equipment and then routing
rules for the two /25s.  Would NAT work normally in that circumstance?  I
mean, is there any reason why the firewall couldn't NAT two internal
interfaces to one external IP?  I can't imagine why not, but that doesn't
mean there isn't a reason.

Any comments appreciated (though some just for the mockery I get to make
of you).

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Jun 10 19:32:08 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue Jun 10 19:32:08 2003
Subject: [PLUG] GIS/Mapping Newbie - needs help.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306101908160.17112-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306101908160.17112-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306101914460.5912@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 10 Jun 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Tue, 10 Jun 2003, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> > Why don't the MANY public agencies that compile and use this kind of data
> > make it available to the public?
>
>   They do. Some charge, others don't. Oregon provides a ton of data for
> free. Washington sells it through DNR (Dept. of Natural Resources). Nevada
> and Idaho sell their data, too.
>
>   At the County level you'll pay for the data. Every county now has its own
> GIS, complete with staff.
>
>   We pay for water, sewage, roads and education all provided by "guv'mint"
> so why not spatial data?

Well, education and roads as general "public goods" are paid for out of
the general fund.

Sewage and water are paid for in a way that attempts to appropriately
disperse the cost across the users of the system by the amount of strain
they place on the system itself.

It would be great of roads were funded the same way.  Right now, roads are
funded mostly out of the state general fund and very little of the money
comes from the users who put the most strain on the system.  I use the
roads and I pay, annually, about 80% as much as, say, you do, but I put
almost no strain on the system (nor do I contribute to the other public
debts the roads and automobile use currently incur such as air and noise
pollution, public health and safety, or sprawl).  But, unfortunately, such
a system would be considered an "undue burden" on the car drivers, so
everyone else has to subsidize their destructive habits.

Anyway, spatial data is INFORMATION.  There is almost no strain on the
system to provide that information to the public for free.  The public
agencies collect, develop, and aggregate the information for their own
purposes, but once that is done, the cost of making it available to the
public for free download is minimal and the cost per user, once such a
system is in place, is almost nil.

It makes sense to fund a system by fees paid by those who most benefit
(though, in the case of education, it's just about impossible to say
whether the educated person benefits any more or less than society as a
whole for having one more well-educated member), but the cost of providing
the service of shared information is so low, it's absurd to try to collect
it.

And remember, a public agency has (rather, should have) absolutely no
interest in charging any user of a system anything more than the
additional cost added by that user to the system as a whole.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

From stever at woo-hoo.com  Tue Jun 10 20:04:01 2003
From: stever at woo-hoo.com (Steven Raymond)
Date: Tue Jun 10 20:04:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix access filter error
Message-ID: <3597.168.156.153.112.1055300613.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>

Just recently updated my access file per the template linked below:
http://www.securitysage.com/files/access

Among lots of other changes, I messed with my main.cf file (current copy
UCE section below):
smtpd_client_restrictions =
        permit_mynetworks,
        reject_maps_rbl,
        check_client_access hash:/etc/postfix/access,
        check_client_access hash:/etc/postfix/permit-domains,
        permit

smtpd_helo_required = yes

smtpd_helo_restrictions =
        permit_mynetworks,
        check_helo_access hash:/etc/postfix/access,
        reject_non_fqdn_hostname,
        reject_unknown_sender_domain,
        reject_unknown_hostname,
        reject_invalid_hostname,
        permit

smtpd_sender_restrictions =
        permit_mynetworks,
        check_sender_access hash:/etc/postfix/access,
        reject_non_fqdn_hostname,
        reject_invalid_hostname,
        reject_non_fqdn_sender,
        reject_unknown_sender_domain,
        reject_unknown_hostname,
        permit

smtpd_recipient_restrictions =
        permit_mynetworks,
        check_recipient_access hash:/etc/postfix/access,
        reject_unknown_sender_domain,
        reject_unauth_pipelining,
        reject_unknown_recipient_domain,
        reject_non_fqdn_sender,
        reject_non_fqdn_recipient,
        reject_non_fqdn_hostname,
        reject_unknown_sender_domain,
        reject_unknown_hostname,
        check_relay_domains

header_checks = regexp:/etc/postfix/header_checks
body_checks = regexp:/etc/postfix/body_checks


Problem is that now I get these error messages in maillog when a spammer
sends me mail- it would normally be rejected anyway.  But now it doesn't
flat out reject it an complains about my access file having a lookup
table.  Any clues here on what it's talking about are appreciated.  Have
googled for the error message and fine only discussions pertaining to the
source code- not troubleshooting the error.
Thanks!


Jun 10 18:53:44 sparky postfix/smtpd[14627]: connect from
outbound13.sub1mail.com[64.70.49.78]
Jun 10 18:53:46 sparky postfix/smtpd[14627]: AC9B27E80E8:
client=outbound13.sub1mail.com[64.70.49.78]
Jun 10 18:53:47 sparky postfix/smtpd[14627]: warning: SMTPD access map
hash:/etc/postfix/access has entry with lookup table: R
EJECT Your server has been identified as a spam source and has been
blacklisted - Please see http://www.securitysage.com/spam.
html
Jun 10 18:53:47 sparky postfix/smtpd[14627]: warning: do not specify
lookup tables inside SMTPD access maps
Jun 10 18:53:47 sparky postfix/smtpd[14627]: warning: define a restriction
class and specify its name instead
Jun 10 18:53:47 sparky postfix/smtpd[14627]: reject: RCPT from
outbound13.sub1mail.com[64.70.49.78]: 451 Server configuration
error; from=<81976 at found-love.net> to=<titch_40k at woo-hoo.com>

From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Jun 10 20:18:02 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue Jun 10 20:18:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
In-Reply-To: <200306092009.05318.pundit@teleport.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306090942200.27690-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu> <003401c32ece$5c0b7020$1901a8c0@madcat> <1055203175.18103.355.camel@fastlinux.homenet> <200306092009.05318.pundit@teleport.com>
Message-ID: <20030611031741.GA3695@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Ken Barber <pundit at teleport.com> [2003-06-09 20:10]:
> The security problem with cable modems is the same problem with 
> any shared-media network:  all traffic on the network can be seen 
> by all nodes on the network, making it trivial to sniff traffic 
> and capture everyone's email, passwords to Web sites, chat and 
> any/all other activity.

Everything I'm writing here is second hand. I have never had a cable
modem, and I don't plan on getting one.

>From what I have been told, what you say above used to be true. You
could sniff the traffic hitting your cable modem, and get all sorts of
interesting information about everyone in your neighborhood. 

Supposedly, that changed sometime in the last couple of years. Traffic
between the cable modem and the head end (equivalent to a DSLAM, only on
cable) is supposedly encrypted. Another cable modem isn't supposed to be
able to unencrypt traffic not bound for itself. 

I have no idea if this is true, or if it is, what level of encryption is
used, or what type. 

-- 
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Jun 10 21:11:01 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue Jun 10 21:11:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix access filter error

On Wed, 11 Jun 2003, Billy Dimaculangan wrote:

> How do I ignore the case of the attachment extension name.

  Append 'i' to your regex or pcre expression. After the final slash.

From jtodd at loligo.com  Tue Jun 10 21:58:01 2003
From: jtodd at loligo.com (John Todd)
Date: Tue Jun 10 21:58:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] GIS/Mapping Newbie - needs help.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306101748390.5062@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <200306101150.50027.scott_list@mischko.com>
 <p05210609bb0c29e43875@loligo.com>
 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306101748390.5062@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <p05210613bb0c5f30b666@loligo.com>

>On Tue, 10 Jun 2003, John Todd wrote:
>>      I have installed this on several systems that my firm uses, and it
>>  works like a charm.  There's a firm in Maryland that sells Tiger
>>  datasets (the "raw data" files that contain the streets, zip, political
>>  boundaries, etc.) in ARC form for a reasonable figure, and he also has a
>>  Perl-based application that layers on top of mapserv that will do
>>  address-to-lat/lon mapping.  You can find them at:
>[snip]
>>  3) Nothing is free, especially mapping systems.  Despite the Open Source
>>  moniker, getting _quality_ data will cost you at least $2k for the whole
>>  project, excluding hardware.  If it's less, you win, but that's what you
>>  should bank on.  This is far less than commercial rights to any of the
>>  "professional" datasets out there, which are (for your purposes) just
>>  scrubbed Tiger datasets.
>
>So my dream of having a mapquest-like application that was aware of
>elevation changes (and, ideally, road quality) to punch in a couple of
>addresses and choose how much climbing you want to do to output a route
>for biking through the city is way out of the realm of feasibility right
>now?
>
>Why don't the MANY public agencies that compile and use this kind of data
>make it available to the public?
>
>One of the many problems with public agencies contracting private
>tyrannies, I suppose.
>
>J.
>--
>    -----------------
>      Jeme A Brelin
>     jeme at brelin.net
>    -----------------
>  [cc] counter-copyright
>  http://www.openlaw.org


Holding my comments on your later, more politicized reply, I will 
address your technical questions below.

As mentioned, ARC-formatted shapefile info is readily available from 
multiple states, for multiple services.  If you know where to look, 
and who to ask.  A consolidated form of this data is currently not 
available, and pointing to the Federal Government as a repository for 
this data is difficult, at best, as the volume of points and shapes 
is staggering.  It's a miracle enough that the Tiger dataset exists - 
most other nations have nothing even remotely resembling it.  Try 
getting maps for Mexico - that's good for a laugh or two on a boring 
day, and the concept of "free information" will get you laughed off 
the phone in almost every other nation.  Some enlightened nations 
have it, but most do not.

Topo data is even harder to represent.  There is a firm that has the 
entire USA in topo map form down to 1:25,000 format, and the'll be 
happy to sell it to you on a tidy little server running (surprise!) 
Mapserv.  It'll only set you back $35,000. 
(http://www.topozone.com/)  Or, you can do as I do, and simply pay 
them per map impression (another cool feature of mapserve is it's 
ability to render remote maps.)

The military has a huge advantage in this area, but they aren't 
releasing things as Linux-compatible "auto-conf" packages or RPMs, if 
they release their software at all.  And now, in this environment of 
"heightened security", we will undoubtedly see more map data that was 
once public being withdrawn for fear that it may be used by enemies 
of the US.  (Anyone recall the stories about maps of Moscow in the 
60's?)

But back to my point: the data exists, and is often even free, but is 
extremely fragmented.  If you are persistent, you will find that for 
which you seek, but it is not going to be found as a rainy-day 
project.  It will be found as the result of long hours of searching, 
phone calls, and confusing dead-end data.

JT



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Jun 10 22:15:03 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue Jun 10 22:15:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] GIS/Mapping Newbie - needs help.
In-Reply-To: <p05210613bb0c5f30b666@loligo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306102205340.17715-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 10 Jun 2003, John Todd wrote:

> A consolidated form of this data is currently not available, and pointing
> to the Federal Government as a repository for this data is difficult, at
> best, as the volume of points and shapes is staggering.

  The new federal standard -- the name escapes me at the moment -- replaced
the DLG with an extremely complex binary format that was supposed to
encapsulate and handle _all_ spatial data regardless of what it was. Well,
it's so bloody complex even federal folks have trouble with it and since the
documentation is so piss-poor the difficulties in reverse-engineering it so
that data can be imported to a GIS are extreme.

> Topo data is even harder to represent.  There is a firm that has the 
> entire USA in topo map form down to 1:25,000 format, and the'll be 
                                        ^^^^^^
                                        24,000 actually. Except for Alaska.

> happy to sell it to you on a tidy little server running (surprise!) 
> Mapserv.  It'll only set you back $35,000. 
> (http://www.topozone.com/)  Or, you can do as I do, and simply pay 
> them per map impression (another cool feature of mapserve is it's 
> ability to render remote maps.)

  You can find DEM data for most places at 1:24K, interpolate it and overlay
it with vector data such as roads, hydrography and PLSS boundaries. That's
what I do. Or, you can get free DRGs (Digital Raster Graphics, a.k.a.
scanned 1:24K topographic maps without the marginal annotations).
 
> The military has a huge advantage in this area, but they aren't 
> releasing things as Linux-compatible "auto-conf" packages or RPMs, if 
> they release their software at all.  And now, in this environment of 
> "heightened security", we will undoubtedly see more map data that was 
> once public being withdrawn for fear that it may be used by enemies 
> of the US.  (Anyone recall the stories about maps of Moscow in the 
> 60's?)

  Have you looked at USGS GIS programs and data? Do you work only with
cadastral data that's unprojected or do you need projected data of all
sorts? There's the free PROJ4 software that does datum transformations as
well as reprojecting data and translating coordinate systems. 

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

> support, making their audio player virtually useless. Worse, the video
> player (which is supposed to have MP3 support) that I just downloaded
> not only won;t play MP3 files (it starts the files but no sound comes
> out) but it won't play the audio track on my video files. Is there
> something in the Red Hat system that blocks out those audio standards
> from ALL pieces of software, or is there some RPM or code I can install
> that would re-enable MP3 and audio?

From: mhopcroft at seraphimguard.com (Michael Hopcroft)

Subject: [PLUG] Getting a red Hat system to play audio files
In-Reply-To: <1055309484.1993.9.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Tue, 2003-06-10 at 22:31, Wil Cooley wrote:
> On Tue, 2003-06-10 at 13:56, Michael Hopcroft wrote:
> > Red hat 9 has one glaring weakness. the deliberately disabled MP3
> > support, making their audio player virtually useless. Worse, the video
> > player (which is supposed to have MP3 support) that I just downloaded
> > not only won;t play MP3 files (it starts the files but no sound comes
> > out) but it won't play the audio track on my video files. Is there
> > something in the Red Hat system that blocks out those audio standards
> > from ALL pieces of software, or is there some RPM or code I can install
> > that would re-enable MP3 and audio?
> 
> See http://www.xmms.org or http://freshrpms.net for a replacement XMMS.

I downloaded a replacement xmms. Installing it is another matter
entirely -- I have yet to master RPMs. I'm certainly having a great deal
of difficulty installing any software that does NOT come in RPM form.
The replacement xmms I downloaded is for Red Hat 8. I don;t know if Red
Hat has some code that defeats my attempts to install it over the xmms
that came with the distro or not (I bought the CD package you can get
for $41 at Office Depot and $40 at Fry's.)

As far as getting audio itself to work, however, I managed to solve that
problem. One of the list members sent me a not encouraging me to
brainstorm the situation through a little more. It turned out I had a
bad connection between my sound card and my speakers. Once I
straightened that out (by physically moving the speaker plug) audio
plays. I even got the Video/DVD player I installed to play MP3 files.

This leads to a new problem, though -- whenever I click on an MP3 file
in XWindow, it takes me to xmms in its current, crippled state, It's
sort of like a Windows file association problem -- the files are linked
to a program you don;t want them to be linked to. I don;t know if even
installing the repaired xmms would solve that particular problem because
I don;t know if Red hat will simply install it beside the current
version or replace the disabled version with the fixed one. I don't know
why red Hat crippled one of the major reasons people own computers these
days (to play media files), but I'm sure they have their reasons (not
sound ones, mind you, but reasons).

In-Reply-To: <1055313154.7197.16.camel@localhost.localdomain>

Message-ID: <20030611071454.GA27158@edge>

On Tue, Jun 10, 2003 at 11:32:35PM -0700, Michael Hopcroft wrote:
> ...
> I downloaded a replacement xmms. Installing it is another matter
> entirely -- I have yet to master RPMs. I'm certainly having a great deal

as root
rpm -hUv xmms-1.2.7-21.i386.rpm
or whatever your rpm filename is. This updates any existing rpm
and if one doesn't exist it installs it.

Bill Barry



From marcm at dsl-only.net  Wed Jun 11 00:26:02 2003
From: marcm at dsl-only.net (Marc)
Date: Wed Jun 11 00:26:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Getting a red Hat system to play audio files
In-Reply-To: <1055313154.7197.16.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1055278587.4575.12.camel@localhost.localdomain> <1055309484.1993.9.camel@localhost.localdomain> <1055313154.7197.16.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <20030611072535.GB18647@mentorg.com>

On Tue 06/10/03 23:32, Michael Hopcroft wrote:
> The replacement xmms I downloaded is for Red Hat 8.
 
Why not Red Hat 9 -- isn't that what you are running?

> I don;t know if Red Hat has some code that defeats my attempts to install it
> over the xmms that came with the distro or not 

I have not seen any evidence of code that intentionally prevents you from
installing over the top of original distro packages, nor would such a feature
be tolerated.

> This leads to a new problem, though -- whenever I click on an MP3 file
> in XWindow, it takes me to xmms in its current, crippled state,

If you are interested in a suggestion, the term "XWindow" does not apply here.
Instead, your window manager (e.g. KDE, GNOME) is the active element that
manages the MIME types for you, and controls which program is launched for a
given file type.

> I don;t know if Red hat will simply install it beside the current
> version or replace the disabled version with the fixed one.

I ran a quick test on my RH9 box and downloaded the file 

    http://ftp.freshrpms.net/pub/freshrpms/redhat/9/xmms-mp3/xmms-mp3-1.2.7-21.p.fr1.i386.rpm

to look at its file contents:

    % rpm -qpl xmms-mp3-1.2.7-21.p.fr1.i386.rpm
    warning: xmms-mp3-1.2.7-21.p.fr1.i386.rpm: V3 DSA signature: NOKEY, key ID e42d547b
    /usr/lib/xmms/Input/libmpg123.so

This indicates the RPM only contains one shared library ("libmpg123.so"), thus
the original "xmms" executable is not getting replaced.  From this it seems
reasonable that your window manager _should_ continue invoking the same
"crippled" program.  What should have changed is that XMMS should now recognize
that it has MP3 input support.  

Can you check the XMMS gui to see if the Options>Preferences/Audio I/O Plugins
menu shows that "MPEG Layer 1/2/3 Player 1.2.7 [libmpg123.so]" is enabled?

> I don't know why red Hat crippled one of the major reasons people own
> computers these days (to play media files), but I'm sure they have their
> reasons (not sound ones, mind you, but reasons).

Why would you presume Red Hat made an irrational decision here?  A perception
of legal liability can alter anyone's priorities.

Marc
