From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jun 11 09:47:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Jun 11 09:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] A typographic phenomenon
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306110936200.19930-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  I'm using OpenOffice.org a lot now and I've discovered a couple of
interesting quirks. I'm curious if others have seen these, too.

  First, the color matching using the ESP PrintPro driver is not very good.
The printed colors are lighter than those on screen. But, that's an ESP
issue I presume.

  Second, the one that causes me to write is with the display of text. I get
a lot of winWord docs and they invariably use Times New Roman/12 pt as the
bodytext font. Apostrophes and quotes display as question marks here, even
after I save them in the native OO.o format. That could be because I don't
have that particular foundry's type face installed.

  Anyway, I noticed that when I changed the typeface from Times New Roman to
my standard Bitstream Amerigo the question marks were replaced by
apostrophes or quotation marks. This makes sense if the one font is not
installed. What I discovered this morning is that the change also occurred
when I changed from 12pt to 10pt. _That's_ unexpected.

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

                       Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
            2404 SW 22nd Street | Troutdale, OR 97060-1247 | U.S.A.
 + 1 503-667-4517 (voice) | + 1 503-667-8863 (fax) | rshepard&#64;appl-ecosys.com
                         http://www.appl-ecosys.com/




From danielx.j.petcher at intel.com  Wed Jun 11 09:54:02 2003
From: danielx.j.petcher at intel.com (Petcher, Danielx J)
Date: Wed Jun 11 09:54:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] A typographic phenomenon
Message-ID: <7D6F4CF55743264F8B23E20353705EEC0A8F26@orsmsx408.amr.corp.intel.com>

Your AutoCorrect setting is turning the ' and " (single- and
double-prime symbols) into curly apostrophes as you type. Some fonts
have a glyph defined for this ASCII value; others don't. When it's
undefined, you see the question mark symbol. If you turn-off this
autocorrect feature, you'll have typography that is not quite so pretty
at its best, but it will always be legible.

-djp
http://folding.stanford.edu - the brain you save may be your own!

From srau at rauhaus.org  Wed Jun 11 10:05:02 2003
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)

Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306101801000.5062@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <86adcq4faf.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <001401c32f5c$44571400$1901a8c0@madcat> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306101536170.3166@shaft.bitmine.net> <004101c32fb3$ced93a20$1901a8c0@madcat> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306101801000.5062@shaft.bitmine.net>

* Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> [030610 18:19]:
> 
> 
> Obviously, cable is going to be the #1 perpetrator here, but for social,
> not technological reasons.

<long socio-economic text snipped>

I'm going to vote for technical reasons. Cable networks are a source of
often poorly-protected hosts to be compromised and incorporated into
DDOS'ers herds of zombies. DSL networks are almost as good a source, but
the IP ranges for cable networks are very large, contiguous, and well
known, while DSL IP ranges are all over the place.

--Stafford

From pundit at teleport.com  Wed Jun 11 10:23:02 2003
From: pundit at teleport.com (Ken Barber)
Date: Wed Jun 11 10:23:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] A typographic phenomenon
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306110936200.19930-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

Message-ID: <200306111022.26495.pundit@teleport.com>

On Wednesday 11 June 2003 09:46, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   I'm using OpenOffice.org a lot now and I've discovered a
> couple of interesting quirks. I'm curious if others have seen
> these, too.
>
>   First, the color matching using the ESP PrintPro driver is
> not very good. The printed colors are lighter than those on
> screen. But, that's an ESP issue I presume.

I don't know what ESP is so I might be talking out of my ass, 
but...

Have you adjusted your monitor's gamma?  If not, then images will 
look darker on your monitor than they really are.

It is possible that the colors are printing correctly, but are 
being displayed too dark.

You can find more than you ever wanted to know about gamma 
(unless, like me, you're a serious photographer) here:

http://www.normankoren.com/makingfineprints1A.html

Note that the Macintosh gamma of 1.8 is the "standard" for 
pre-press work; the PC gamma of 2.2 is the "standard" for Web 
pages.

Ken
-- 
"It was like a visit by Don Corleone.  I expected to find a bloody 
computer monitor in my bed the next day." 
          --Marc Andreessen, Netscape's chief technology officer, 
on a May 1995 meeting with Microsoft





From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jun 11 10:44:01 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Jun 11 10:44:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] A typographic phenomenon
In-Reply-To: <7D6F4CF55743264F8B23E20353705EEC0A8F26@orsmsx408.amr.corp.intel.com>

> it's undefined, you see the question mark symbol.

  This I understand.

  I can more readily believe that different typefaces would either have or
lack that glyph than that two different sizes of the same typeface differ.

From danielx.j.petcher at intel.com  Wed Jun 11 11:00:02 2003
From: danielx.j.petcher at intel.com (Petcher, Danielx J)
Date: Wed Jun 11 11:00:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] A typographic phenomenon
Message-ID: <7D6F4CF55743264F8B23E20353705EEC0A8F27@orsmsx408.amr.corp.intel.com>

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Rich Shepard [mailto:rshepard at appl-ecosys.com]
> Sent: Wednesday, June 11, 2003 10:43 AM
> To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
> Subject: RE: [PLUG] A typographic phenomenon
> 
> On Wed, 11 Jun 2003, Petcher, Danielx J wrote:
> 
> > Some fonts have a glyph defined for this ASCII value; others don't.
When
> > it's undefined, you see the question mark symbol.
> 
>   This I understand.
> 
>   I can more readily believe that different typefaces would either
have or
> lack that glyph than that two different sizes of the same typeface
differ.
[Daniel Petcher] 
Here's where my understanding of the font rendering architecture of
Linux breaks-off completely and we enter the realm of educated
speculation. Feel free to call "B*llsh*t" on me at any time. My feelings
will not be hurt.

On Macintosh System 8 and earlier and Windows 95 (I dunno about current
technology), bitmaps of a given font, rendered at popular sizes are
stored on the disk. Without vector-based font rendering like TrueType or
Adobe Type Manager, these several different bitmaps are stretched and
distorted to approximate the appearance of a printed page.

If the right size of type is already rendered as a bitmap in your
system, there will be no fresh rendering of the typeface from its
vector-oriented description. Factors that can conspire against you here:
-The bitmap and vector type fonts may come from different sources
-The typefaces may have been machine-converted from another platform
which used different ASCII values or meta-character names for the glyphs
in question
-There may be some typeface substitution happening at the print
rendering engine, the printer, or the screen rendering engine.
-Some lazy font author may have missed bitmapping a glyph or two of
bitmap work.
-djp

From michael at robinson-west.com  Wed Jun 11 11:53:01 2003
From: michael at robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Wed Jun 11 11:53:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Can't get a hold of Habas...
Message-ID: <1055357096.8482.32.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

Andrew

Don't know what the deal is, but having gotten an email to pay for the
stuff today it blows my mind that I can't call him on the phone.
His number is ( 503 ) 397 - 4767.  Can you call him?  I think he's
hostile toward my intended use for this machine because when I
asked him to look for a 100% Linux compatible Pentium 4 he didn't
do it.  The Linux user's group in Portland pointed one out and he
can get it yet he's trying to talk me out of it saying that the
memory technology is experimental.  The Linux user's group 
suggested I go to EMU.

I've been trying to call him since Monday and am starting to wonder
if he has blocked my calls.  If he doesn't think he's going to get
business from me that is ridiculous considering I've gotten the
last two computers from him.  Even then I remember him pushing
Windows.

Since I want 98 installed I can ask him how much he would charge
to install it and xosl for me, I shouldn't have to have him do that
though.  I looked at one of his price quotes for the board I want
and it appears that he quoted me this board before for five dollars
less, I accidentally asked for it twice.

I asked him why he advertises Windows 2000 server, seems he 
went on the defensive.  I asked what applications his customers 
need Windows for, he didn't respond except to say that he
has successfully set up a motorcycle business on 2000.  He
simply said that his customers need Windows.  Why are 
businessses so willing to pay for Microsoft certifications and
maintain a status quo of everybody will use Microsoft
applications for all their computing needs?  Doesn't Habas
know that he can support Linux and Windows customers equally
and that it is illegal for Microsoft or anyone else to stop 
him?  For that matter, he could add Apple computers to
his inventory.

     --  Michael C. Robinson

you remember that St. Helens requires a '1-' prefix from Portland? Many folks 
who live in the city retain city-like expectations when visiting out in the 
county - especially Columbia County. Bus to town? Yup. Twice a week, even. 
(Things are getting built up, sadly. Time to look at moving out to Mist or 
Jewell.) That and city-like expectations of connection speeds.

: I've been trying to call him since Monday and am starting to wonder
: if he has blocked my calls.  If he doesn't think he's going to get
: business from me that is ridiculous considering I've gotten the
: last two computers from him. 

I live between St. Helens & Scappoose, and the following is JUST my opinion, 
but his store and Preheim in Scappoose are pretty much the only thing going 
in town for any kind of computer parts - even simple stuff like, say, a 15' 
Cat-V cable.

Rob H. is a nice guy to talk with. I really -tried- to give him my business, 
but in my particular experience with him, his kid kept getting in the way of 
his business hours - I'd call and ask if he'd be in at say, 1:30pm one day, 
and I'd get there and find the 'Stepped out for 15 min' sign in the window. 
Still there 35 min later. This sort of thing happened about 3 times in one 
week. I also asked him to quote a system, than asked by what day he'd think 
he'd have the quote ready. Just to be extra nice, I came in 4 - 6 hours after 
the agreed-upon time, and he hadn't even touched it - so I lost a week with 
-my- boss & customers. Needless to say, since I couldn't get a quote for him 
for the system I wanted, I never got around to buying from him.

Preheim is a nice guy too, but if it's Linux, it might as well be from  
Neptune. I buy most of my incidental hardware from him (cables, fens etc.) 
when & if a trip to Norvac or Fry's is too much fuel.

- GLL

Here's another Columbia County thought. Mr. Habas is runs his own business and 
makes his best decisions. He gets to choose which customers he serves. 
Columbia Country probably has enough MS-user Gomers that he can look pretty

sort of customer, and he could service 'y' Gomer-customers instead of dealing 
with you. If y>x, then it's to his profit to blow you off, and fix 'y' 
customers with their stoopid-Windoze annoyances. And more county-dwelling

> county - especially Columbia County. Bus to town? Yup. Twice a week, even. 
> (Things are getting built up, sadly. Time to look at moving out to Mist or 
> Jewell.) That and city-like expectations of connection speeds.
> 

> I live between St. Helens & Scappoose, and the following is JUST my opinion, 
> but his store and Preheim in Scappoose are pretty much the only thing going 
> in town for any kind of computer parts - even simple stuff like, say, a 15' 
> Cat-V cable.
> 
> Rob H. is a nice guy to talk with. I really -tried- to give him my business, 
> but in my particular experience with him, his kid kept getting in the way of 
> his business hours - I'd call and ask if he'd be in at say, 1:30pm one day, 
> and I'd get there and find the 'Stepped out for 15 min' sign in the window. 
> Still there 35 min later. This sort of thing happened about 3 times in one 
> week. I also asked him to quote a system, than asked by what day he'd think 
> he'd have the quote ready. Just to be extra nice, I came in 4 - 6 hours after 
> the agreed-upon time, and he hadn't even touched it - so I lost a week with 
> -my- boss & customers. Needless to say, since I couldn't get a quote for him 
> for the system I wanted, I never got around to buying from him.

> Neptune. I buy most of my incidental hardware from him (cables, fens etc.) 
> when & if a trip to Norvac or Fry's is too much fuel.

with Mr. Preheim himself than the people who work with him, especially
Brady.  I bought enough one day that Preheim actually walked me out to

knew my brother was a 95 tech or maybe he appreciated the amount of
business my family had done at his establishment.  Lately though, noone
in my family will go there at all because I've been burned.  I had a
fiasco with a bad Fujitsu hard drive around the time that Fujitsu USA
went out of business.  I was never offered a direct refund for it.  Even
though I got a replacement that works, I for reasons I still haven't
figured out, can not partition it correctly with Linux fdisk.  I gave up
and decided to use the whole drive at once, all 40 gigs of it.  Needless
to say, I ended up having to get another hard drive that would partition
where this Fujitsu drive got relegated to being a dump disk for
backups.  This was back when I was taking cis279n over at Sylvania.

Well I never did get a hold of Habas on the phone but I have managed to
pay for half the order and he should tell me tomorrow that I need to pay
the same amount for the rest.  Historically, we've been on a pay half,
finish buying the parts at pickup time.  He wants the full cost upfront
because he's shopping tomorrow.  Maybe I should just take the DVD and
disk drive he's going to need along with a copy of xosl and tell him I
want to stick with pay half upfront, the rest when the job is done. 
He's says I'll get it next week instead of Friday or Saturday.  

Surprisingly,
he was nicer in person than he has been in email.  He understood
why I avoided the built in video card which is good.  He still says
the board hasn't been certified by Intel for 512 mbit technology up
to it's supposed 2 gig capacity.  I doubt there is going to be
a problem.  If there is, I suppose since these products come with
warranties that I can use those warranties and say to Intel that
their product isn't meeting spec.  Aren't these warranties something
like three years?

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jun 11 16:11:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Jun 11 16:11:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] starting the new mozilla
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306111600450.20946-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  I just upgraded from mozilla-1.2.1 to mozilla-1.3.1. I cannot get it
running from the Xfce icon.

  Version 1.2.1 (and earlier) was installed in /usr/lib/mozilla-<verson>
with the invoking script in /usr/bin/mozilla. So, the command line
associated with the xfce panel's icon was '/usr/bin/mozilla' and this worked
just fine.

  Version 1.3.1 is installed in /usr/local/mozilla and the script to turn
over the engine and get it running is run-mozilla.sh. I made
/usr/local/mozilla owned by rshepard.users and so are all files below that
directory.

  From the command line, typing '/usr/local/mozilla/run-mozilla.sh' results
in:

[rshepard at salmo ~]$ /usr/local/mozilla/run-mozilla.sh 

run-mozilla.sh: Cannot execute .

  But, typing 'cd /usr/local/mozilla/; ./run-mozilla.sh' works as expected.
Unless that same command is presented by the panel button. Then nothing
happens. I'm confused why the string works from the command line but not
from the icon's command line.

Any ideas?

Rich

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Wed Jun 11 16:22:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Wed Jun 11 16:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] starting the new mozilla
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306111600450.20946-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306111600450.20946-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1055373657.1993.49.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Wed, 2003-06-11 at 16:09, Rich Shepard wrote:

> [rshepard at salmo ~]$ /usr/local/mozilla/run-mozilla.sh 
> 
> run-mozilla.sh: Cannot execute .
> 
>   But, typing 'cd /usr/local/mozilla/; ./run-mozilla.sh' works as expected.
> Unless that same command is presented by the panel button. Then nothing
> happens. I'm confused why the string works from the command line but not
> from the icon's command line.
> 
> Any ideas?

Mozilla looks in its current working directory for chrome, loadable
libraries, etc.  I think you might also be able to set 'MOZILLA_HOME' to
its home and get it to work.

Wil

From dpool at hevanet.com  Wed Jun 11 16:23:01 2003
From: dpool at hevanet.com (david pool)
Date: Wed Jun 11 16:23:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Open Source Bill Update
Message-ID: <3EE7B9D0.6060408@hevanet.com>

I guess I overstated the case earlier. SB 589 isn't yet the Open Source 
Bill because it hasn't been amended and passed out of the Senate 
committee. The word is that the votes probably aren't there to pull it 
out of committee. On Monday night I questioned the panel of 16 
legislators at Grant HS about the bill and none of them were aware of 
the move to get SB 589 amended with the HB 2892 contents.

SB 589 is currently in the Transportation and Economic Development 
Committee. The Chair, Rick Metzger is supportive of this bill, but we 
need the support of Sen. Ryan Deckert and either Bruce Starr or David 
Nelson to move it out of Committee.

Also, to quote a Democratic Representative: "Karen Minnis is God" (ie if 
she wants to kill it she will).

Nevertheless, the legislators were supportive and said our efforts on HB 
2892 were noticed and it raised the visibility. They encouraged us to 
e-mail the Senate. Frankly, I was surprised and disappointed that the 
Senate was oblivious to our attempts there.

If you haven't e-mailed some Senators, now would be the best time to do 
so. They're all listed here:

http://www.leg.state.or.us/senate/senateset.htm

d

ps Pardon the cross posts - this is probably the last of em from me for 
a while.

From stever at woo-hoo.com  Wed Jun 11 18:38:02 2003
From: stever at woo-hoo.com (Steven Raymond)
Date: Wed Jun 11 18:38:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix access filter error - RESOLVED
In-Reply-To: <3597.168.156.153.112.1055300613.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
References: <3597.168.156.153.112.1055300613.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
Message-ID: <2608.168.156.153.112.1055381873.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>

Turns out that the most recent access file at:
http://www.securitysage.com/files/access
Expects to be supporting Postfix 2.0 and higher.  Am running the most
recent package from RH9 and it's still 1.11 :(
A friendly fellow from securitysage advised that the old versions of
Postfix do not take kindly to the REJECT keyword in the access file.  They
are looking for something along the lines of 553 or 554, being some reject
code.  A simple :s/REJECT/554/ in fixed that problem.
Regards


> Just recently updated my access file per the template linked below:
> http://www.securitysage.com/files/access
>
> Among lots of other changes, I messed with my main.cf file (current copy
> UCE section below):
> smtpd_client_restrictions =
>         permit_mynetworks,
>         reject_maps_rbl,
>         check_client_access hash:/etc/postfix/access,
>         check_client_access hash:/etc/postfix/permit-domains,
>         permit
>
> smtpd_helo_required = yes
>
> smtpd_helo_restrictions =
>         permit_mynetworks,
>         check_helo_access hash:/etc/postfix/access,
>         reject_non_fqdn_hostname,
>         reject_unknown_sender_domain,
>         reject_unknown_hostname,
>         reject_invalid_hostname,
>         permit
>
> smtpd_sender_restrictions =
>         permit_mynetworks,
>         check_sender_access hash:/etc/postfix/access,
>         reject_non_fqdn_hostname,
>         reject_invalid_hostname,
>         reject_non_fqdn_sender,
>         reject_unknown_sender_domain,
>         reject_unknown_hostname,
>         permit
>
> smtpd_recipient_restrictions =
>         permit_mynetworks,
>         check_recipient_access hash:/etc/postfix/access,
>         reject_unknown_sender_domain,
>         reject_unauth_pipelining,
>         reject_unknown_recipient_domain,
>         reject_non_fqdn_sender,
>         reject_non_fqdn_recipient,
>         reject_non_fqdn_hostname,
>         reject_unknown_sender_domain,
>         reject_unknown_hostname,
>         check_relay_domains
>
> header_checks = regexp:/etc/postfix/header_checks
> body_checks = regexp:/etc/postfix/body_checks
>
>
> Problem is that now I get these error messages in maillog when a spammer
> sends me mail- it would normally be rejected anyway.  But now it doesn't
> flat out reject it an complains about my access file having a lookup
> table.  Any clues here on what it's talking about are appreciated.  Have
> googled for the error message and fine only discussions pertaining to
> the source code- not troubleshooting the error.
> Thanks!
>
>
> Jun 10 18:53:44 sparky postfix/smtpd[14627]: connect from
> outbound13.sub1mail.com[64.70.49.78]
> Jun 10 18:53:46 sparky postfix/smtpd[14627]: AC9B27E80E8:
> client=outbound13.sub1mail.com[64.70.49.78]
> Jun 10 18:53:47 sparky postfix/smtpd[14627]: warning: SMTPD access map
> hash:/etc/postfix/access has entry with lookup table: R
> EJECT Your server has been identified as a spam source and has been
> blacklisted - Please see http://www.securitysage.com/spam.
> html

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Wed Jun 11 19:07:01 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Wed Jun 11 19:07:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
In-Reply-To: <20030611170241.GB22047@rauhaus.org>
References: <86adcq4faf.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	 <001401c32f5c$44571400$1901a8c0@madcat>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306101536170.3166@shaft.bitmine.net>
	 <004101c32fb3$ced93a20$1901a8c0@madcat>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306101801000.5062@shaft.bitmine.net>
	 <20030611170241.GB22047@rauhaus.org>
Message-ID: <1055383568.929.42.camel@main>

On Wed, 2003-06-11 at 10:02, Stafford A. Rau wrote:

> I'm going to vote for technical reasons. Cable networks are a source of
> often poorly-protected hosts to be compromised and incorporated into
> DDOS'ers herds of zombies. DSL networks are almost as good a source, but
> the IP ranges for cable networks are very large, contiguous, and well
> known, while DSL IP ranges are all over the place.
> 
> --Stafford
> 

I can't disagree or agree that cable network segments are full of
unprotected hosts or contain large, unruly IP segments. 

If they truly are full of unprotected hosts than it's not a technical
problem since the same tools used to protect a host exist in both types
of WAN topologies. The fact that the users of these hosts do not, or
will not, protect their hosts is a matter of human choice and not a
matter of lacking technology. 

As for the segment sizes, that is also not a technical issue. Someone
decided to create larger segments instead of creating smaller broadcast
domains in the normal manner - with routers. Hence the reason that you
see lots of layer 3/4 broadcast traffic such as the ARP traffic that was
offered up earlier in this thread. Larger segments also become much more
difficult to effectively monitor ( in some cases ) than smaller ones but
it's still a management/business choice to not create smaller, easily
managed segments.

No matter how I look at this I still don't see any technical issues to
support one technology over the other. The security issue is all a
matter of either personal choice of the user or a choice of the
provider. All in all, in my opinion, the choice between cable and DSL is
about equal, you will still be connected to a hostile network and will
need to take the appropriate precautions no matter which way you turn.

Date: Wed Jun 11 21:26:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
In-Reply-To: <1055383568.929.42.camel@main>
References: <86adcq4faf.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<001401c32f5c$44571400$1901a8c0@madcat>
	<Pine.LNX.4.52.0306101536170.3166@shaft.bitmine.net>
	<004101c32fb3$ced93a20$1901a8c0@madcat>
	<Pine.LNX.4.52.0306101801000.5062@shaft.bitmine.net>
	<20030611170241.GB22047@rauhaus.org> <1055383568.929.42.camel@main>
Message-ID: <86ptlj2acd.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Steven" == Steven A Adams <stevea at nwtechops.com> writes:

Steven> No matter how I look at this I still don't see any technical
Steven> issues to support one technology over the other. 

There _are_ substantial technical reasons to choose one technology
over another one, but they aren't particularly security reasons, they
are ISP (and thus policy) choice reasons.  With DSL you have a lot
more (many) choices than for cable (essentially one).  With DSL you
can shop around for an ISP that meets your service and policy needs.
With cable, you'd better hope that one-size-fits-you [1].

[1] actually two sizes these days, but still a lot less choice than DSL.

--

seniorr at aracnet.com       whole earth.  But not forever!  I tell you, the day
                          Rome falls there will be a shout of freedom such as
                          the world has never heard before.'' -- Ben Hur

From rcamacke at attbi.com  Thu Jun 12 01:58:02 2003
From: rcamacke at attbi.com (Linux)
Date: Thu Jun 12 01:58:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
In-Reply-To: <1055398998.1993.69.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <013101c330c0$a1f8d840$65a8a8c0@Main>

I don't have as much technical knowledge as the rest on this board, but I do
have experience in this area.  

I have had a cable modem since @Home made it into my neighbor some time ago.
Initially the service was so unreliable, I went with Verizon DSL.  Very
dependable, but SLOW... It crawled compared to cable.  

My DSL was interrupted due to a digital phone upgrade (the installer swore
they were compatible).  When it was going to take a week to get re-connected
from Verizon, I called ATTBI and they installed the next day.  That was over
a year ago and I can't remember my last service outage.

So, what I have learned of cable vs. DSL - 

CABLE                                      DSL
Yes, many more port                      SLOW!
Scans.

No static IP.                            Expensive.

Don't need those flippin'
Noise suppressors on each 
Phone outlet (OK, I'm out of legitimate
Points).

Bottom line?  Broadband = good thing.  Security shouldn't be an issue as if
you have ANY broadband connection, you should be protecting yourself.  A
static IP might be an issue if you're wanting to run servers.  I still feel
cable has the edge on speed, unless you shell out big $$$ for the upper-end
DSL connections.

Lastly... BILL GATES ROCKS! Microsoft is the King!  ALL HAIL... OK, just
wanted to start the flame war.

Richard

From jason at vancleve.com  Thu Jun 12 06:43:03 2003
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Thu Jun 12 06:43:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Debian Network Problem
Message-ID: <20030612084159.412ce2ed.jason@vancleve.com>

I'm having one of my goofy catch-22 issues again, trying to install
woody.  Something about this hardware is preventing my network interface
from being detected during the installation, even after the tulip driver
is supposedly loaded.  Once the initial install is done and I reboot,
the NIC is found, but yet I cannot get dhcp to work. 
/etc/network/interfaces is configured with the dhcp option, and when I
run ifup -a, it waits a moment and then exits without error.  At this
point the interface is up, but there's no IP.

Now, I can set the IP manually and ping other LAN hosts, so this must be
a dhcp issue.  I googled awhile and found some notes about enabling
"socket filtering" in the kernel, but the kernel source is not present
on this system, so I can't easily test that theory.  Nor is etherconf
available on this install CD, so I can't try "dpkg-reconfigure
etherconf" either.

What's to be done?  All I can think of is to unplug another machine from
the hub, borrow all its IP information and try using that on the woody
box to connect to the Internet, then download a new kernel and make sure
to enable this "socket filtering" option in hopes that maybe then dhcp
will work. For all that, I'd just as soon resort to my old SUSE disks!

--Jason



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Jun 12 06:55:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu Jun 12 06:55:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Cannot run mozilla-1.3.1 from panel icon
In-Reply-To: <1055407704.4660.18.camel@kma1.kma.com.au>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306120644050.24110-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On 12 Jun 2003, Stephen Kuhn wrote:

> It would appear as though there is a problem with system paths - and
> possibly lib paths as well.

Stephen,

  Nope, that's not it.
 
> Else, a trick would be to create a script in your ~/home/yournamehere/
> directory calling the program and then change the link in the panel to
> suit the new script (make sure you chmod +x scriptname prior to
> attempting to run it).

  That's exactly what I did and was stumped when it didn't work.

  However, I just found the problem and fixed it. For the benefit of future
generations I'll pass on what I've learned.

  When I upgraded mozilla from 1.2.1 to 1.3.1 the default installation
directory changed from /usr/lib/mozilla-<version> with a startup script as
/usr/bin/mozilla to /usr/local/mozilla with a start up script of
/usr/local/mozilla/run-mozilla.sh.

  On the panel's icon, I changed the command line from /usr/bin/mozilla to
/usr/local/mozilla/run-mozilla.sh, but that didn't work. Eventually I wrote
a three-line shell script and this worked from the command line but not from
the panel icon.

  This time, rather than retyping the comand line on the icon's dialog box,
I used the "browse" button and discovered that the path was set to
/usr/local/mozilla although the command line read, "/home/rshepard/mozilla".
I clicked my way up and down the filesystem tree and let the dialog box put
the string in the command line of the icon.

  This fixed the problem. Shrug. I've not had to do this before, but what
the heck: as long as it works I can go back to my real life now.

Thanks to everyone who offered suggestions,

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

                       Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
            2404 SW 22nd Street | Troutdale, OR 97060-1247 | U.S.A.
 + 1 503-667-4517 (voice) | + 1 503-667-8863 (fax) | rshepard&#64;appl-ecosys.com
                         http://www.appl-ecosys.com/




From ed at alcpress.com  Thu Jun 12 08:00:03 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Thu Jun 12 08:00:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Microsoft to kill popular Linux antivirus product (fwd)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306120622540.23862-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306120622540.23862-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1055429943.1199.148.camel@red>

On Thu, 2003-06-12 at 06:23, Rich Shepard wrote:
> MICROSOFT TO KILL POPULAR LINUX ANTIVIRUS PRODUCT
>      (Source: LinuxWorld.com) Users and resellers of RAV
> AntiVirus, popular especially on Linux platforms, are in limbo
> after Microsoft announced plans to buy the RAV technology from
> Romania's GeCAD Software.
> http://www.linuxworld.com/go.cgi?id=742532

I can't seem to come up with a scenario where I would
care about this. Nothing I do here makes me vulnerable
to viruses. My email program doesn't automatically run
binary attachments, javascript, etc. I don't run FTP.
I strictly control access via my firewall. I generally
install new software from source. My desktop computer
doesn't run any daemons that are better run on a server.
My server daemons run as non-root and in a jail or
on a separate computer or in a UML when that's not
possible.

Is there a vulnerability I don't see?

-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>
ALC

From linux at chrisroberts.org  Thu Jun 12 08:12:02 2003
From: linux at chrisroberts.org (chris)
Date: Thu Jun 12 08:12:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Microsoft to kill popular Linux antivirus product (fwd)
In-Reply-To: <1055429943.1199.148.camel@red>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306120622540.23862-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <1055429943.1199.148.camel@red>
Message-ID: <200306120815.29210.linux@chrisroberts.org>

this was mostly used in the *nix and *bsd worlds as an add on to mail servers 
to scan for viruses thus catching them before the end user got them. it seems 
that there are quite a few mail servers out there that use this, and now 
people are looking for something new, as support for this will likely cease 
to exist on any non-windows platform. the thought is that microsoft will be 
integrating this into their own mail server product.

chris

From danielx.j.petcher at intel.com  Thu Jun 12 08:12:10 2003
From: danielx.j.petcher at intel.com (Petcher, Danielx J)
Date: Thu Jun 12 08:12:10 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Microsoft to kill popular Linux antivirus product (fwd)
Message-ID: <7D6F4CF55743264F8B23E20353705EEC0A8F28@orsmsx408.amr.corp.intel.com>

If you're networked, you are theoretically vulnerable to someone
invading your system from outside. (Though I'm sure you've got a
firewall of some sort, there may be a newly discovered vulnerability.)

If any computer behind your firewall is in a physically insecure area,
someone could theoretically gain control of it and insert malicious
code.

If there's a technically unsophisticated user (especially one whose
privileges are set too high) behind your firewall who can be tricked
into executing malicious code, someone could theoretically gain control
of your computer.

Nobody's perfectly safe, but a few common precautions can protect you
from the majority of threats.
-djp

From Linux.Administrator at odot.state.or.us  Thu Jun 12 08:38:02 2003
From: Linux.Administrator at odot.state.or.us (Linux.Administrator at odot.state.or.us)

Can anyone tell me of a virus that will actually do anything to Linux? Sure,
you can pass the "Outlook virus du jour" to your clients if you're running a
server, but what virus can actually do damage on a Linux client without
becoming root first? I've never understood that one.

Dave

doesn't run any daemons that are better run on a server.

on a separate computer or in a UML when that's not
possible.

Is there a vulnerability I don't see?

-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>
ALC

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Thu Jun 12 09:08:01 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Thu Jun 12 09:08:01 2003
Subject: FW: [PLUG] Microsoft to kill popular Linux antivirus product
	(fwd )
In-Reply-To: <A9031B213036D3119BD100A0C973D4BB039C3D34@exsalem6.odot.state.or.us>
References: 
	 <A9031B213036D3119BD100A0C973D4BB039C3D34@exsalem6.odot.state.or.us>
Message-ID: <1055433996.1993.78.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Thu, 2003-06-12 at 08:37, Linux.Administrator at odot.state.or.us wrote:
> Can anyone tell me of a virus that will actually do anything to Linux? Sure,
> you can pass the "Outlook virus du jour" to your clients if you're running a
> server, but what virus can actually do damage on a Linux client without
> becoming root first? I've never understood that one.

In theory, a poorly-written end-user app is just as vulnerable on Linux
as on Windows.  It might not root your system, but the bulk of the nasty
Windows viruses these days are user-level viruses: They come through
e-mail, execute as Word Macro viruses, read your files, sometimes send
them to other people, look for files on network shares and infect them. 
Nothing that requires any sort of superuser privileges.  In reality,
there are a couple proof-of-concept viruses for Linux and our end-user
applications tend to be a little less stupidly written.

However, few people actually buy anti-virus software for Linux to
protect it; most buy it for servers for Windows clients, like my Mail
Defender setup.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

*     Tired of spam and viruses in your e-mail?  Get the     *
* Naked Ape Mail Defender! http://nakedape.cc/r/maildefender *

From crispin at immunix.com  Thu Jun 12 09:20:03 2003
From: crispin at immunix.com (Crispin Cowan)
Date: Thu Jun 12 09:20:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: CRIME Advanced Linux SIG - 7PM Wednesday June 18th --"Modern
 File	Systems"
In-Reply-To: <1055394953.2332.575.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
References: <1055394953.2332.575.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
Message-ID: <3EE8163D.4060709@immunix.com>

Zot O'Connor wrote:

>Chris Jantzen will give his talk "Modern File Systems" 
>
Could we be a tad more specific?

I'd be particularly interested in a convincing resolution to the 
persistent, conflicting rumors of "EXT3 is ready for production/no it 
isn't", and "ReiserFS sux0rs/no it doesn't". The fast recovery times and 
theoretical lack of disk corruption are attractive, but need to be 
balanced against the threat of code instability in these new FS's.

Everyone has an anecdote, while claims of "production ready" really 
require masses of experience that are *free* of anecdotes.

Crispin

From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Thu Jun 12 09:21:02 2003
From: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name (cooper at cooper.stevenson.name)
Date: Thu Jun 12 09:21:02 2003
Subject: FW: [PLUG] Microsoft to kill popular Linux antivirus product (fwd )
In-Reply-To: <A9031B213036D3119BD100A0C973D4BB039C3D34@exsalem6.odot.state.or.us>
References: <A9031B213036D3119BD100A0C973D4BB039C3D34@exsalem6.odot.state.or.us>
Message-ID: <40436.192.168.1.1.1055434819.squirrel@www.intrinzix.us>

Dave,

While it is true that the nature of open source prevents many poor designs
such as giving the user the ability to run executables from an email
message, there is nothing normally done in this case to prevent a user
from saving a copy of an attached executable or batch file, changing it's
permissions, and running the application manually.

For example, suppose I sent an email with a harmfull attachment to you
with the subject line: "This is a pretty funny joke, you'll like this."
<-- DISCLAIMER: I would never knowingly do that :)

The good news is that you cannot simply "double-click" the attachment with
a Linux Email client and have it run, nor can simply viewing the
attachment with the "preview pane" launch a malicious attack.

The bad news is that there is nothing normally to prevent a user from
saving the attachement, changing the attachment's permissions, and running
it.

Even this is so far is not so bad because the user has now had to have
gone through a lot of work to actually launch the malicious code. If the
administrator has a proper backup plan in place, providing the user with a
completely restored environment is truly trivial.

Moreover, because the user is "canned" in their own little world on a
properly configured system they cannot in any way delete or modify files
that do not belong to them.

This prevents a command like "find / -exec 'rm -rf' {} \;" in a malicious
script from damaging the rest of the system; the script runs as the user
running it. This means the script will simply not have sufficient
permissions to damage the system at large.

All this makes Linux really a thistle patch for exploits. Before we roll
out the ticker tape though let's pause to remember that gardner snakes are
known to travel through thistle patches. Here's an example of how an
exploit can damage the system:

  1. Malicious code is placed in /tmp through a trojan horse or similiar
exploit

  2. Malicous code compiles itself in /tmp and launches the executable

  3. The executable uses a know privilege escalation exploit (such as one
found in older BIND 9 severs) to escalate itself to root privileges

  4. The executable dumps it's payload wich can include the
deletion/modification of files, etc.

The only way to be as secure as possible is to scan the CERT advisories
periodically (I do it daily) and ensure that your system is up to date.

Keep this in perspective, though, the code in your Linux system, combined
with it's Unix like architecture, has undergone a great amount of scrutiny
before it ever landed on your hard drive. Further, the speed at wich
exploits are patched with Open Source is second to none; usually within
hours.

One must still, however, be diligent to be secure and even then there are
no gaurantees.

See my presentation on Linux security to find out more about "hardening"
your Linux system:

  http://www.mwvlug.org/module_5/index.html

  http://www.mwvlug.org/module_6/index.html


Sincerely,


Cooper Stevenson
Open Source Consultant
Em: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name
Ph: (541)979-9434

From srau at rauhaus.org  Thu Jun 12 09:30:02 2003
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Thu Jun 12 09:30:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
In-Reply-To: <1055383568.929.42.camel@main>
References: <86adcq4faf.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <001401c32f5c$44571400$1901a8c0@madcat> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306101536170.3166@shaft.bitmine.net> <004101c32fb3$ced93a20$1901a8c0@madcat> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306101801000.5062@shaft.bitmine.net> <20030611170241.GB22047@rauhaus.org> <1055383568.929.42.camel@main>
Message-ID: <20030612162652.GB31355@rauhaus.org>

* Steven A. Adams <stevea at nwtechops.com> [030611 19:05]:

> As for the segment sizes, that is also not a technical issue. Someone
> decided to create larger segments instead of creating smaller broadcast
> domains in the normal manner - with routers. Hence the reason that you
> see lots of layer 3/4 broadcast traffic such as the ARP traffic that was
> offered up earlier in this thread. Larger segments also become much more
> difficult to effectively monitor ( in some cases ) than smaller ones but
> it's still a management/business choice to not create smaller, easily
> managed segments.

I was perhaps not clear in my post on this - I wasn't talking about
broadcast domains, but rather the larger ip allocations. From the point
of view of a script kiddie, residential broadband hosts are going to be
the best combination of decent bandwidth and a higher percentage of
poorly or completely unprotected machines. That is likely to be true of
both DSL and cable.

Cable may have a somewhat higher rate of port scans than DSL because
there are only a small number of cable providers, and they have very
large ip allocations for cable subscribers, such as 12.0.0.0/8 (and I'm
just using that as an example - I don't know that the full /8 is used
for subscribers).

So a script kiddie can port scan all of 12.0.0.0/8 and hit almost
entirely cable subscribers. To look for DSL subscribers, one would need
to scan a few /24s here, a few there, maybe a /18 or two, but regardless
there aren't the big contiguous blocks of subscribers like there are
with cable.

My comment that I was voting for technical reasons was in contrast to
Jeme's socio-economic explanation, and was I not referring to
differences in the underlying transport technologies of DSL and cable.

--Stafford

From drl at drloree.com  Thu Jun 12 09:44:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Thu Jun 12 09:44:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Debian Network Problem
In-Reply-To: <20030612084159.412ce2ed.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20030612084159.412ce2ed.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <1055436436.18102.1232.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Thu, 2003-06-12 at 06:41, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> I'm having one of my goofy catch-22 issues again, trying to install
> woody.  Something about this hardware is preventing my network interface
> from being detected during the installation, even after the tulip driver
> is supposedly loaded.  Once the initial install is done and I reboot,
> the NIC is found, but yet I cannot get dhcp to work. 
> /etc/network/interfaces is configured with the dhcp option, and when I
> run ifup -a, it waits a moment and then exits without error.  At this
> point the interface is up, but there's no IP.

Check the syslog, it will tell you if the dhcp-client was successful, or
if there was an error.  If nothing is there, then your DHCP-client is
not running.
> 
> Now, I can set the IP manually and ping other LAN hosts, so this must be
> a dhcp issue.  I googled awhile and found some notes about enabling
> "socket filtering" in the kernel, but the kernel source is not present
> on this system, so I can't easily test that theory.  Nor is etherconf
> available on this install CD, so I can't try "dpkg-reconfigure
> etherconf" either.
> 
> What's to be done?  All I can think of is to unplug another machine from
> the hub, borrow all its IP information and try using that on the woody
> box to connect to the Internet, then download a new kernel and make sure
> to enable this "socket filtering" option in hopes that maybe then dhcp
> will work. For all that, I'd just as soon resort to my old SUSE disks!
> 
Don't bother trying to download the kernel source to fix this, the stock
kernel is capable of receiving dhcp information.

You don't need to borrow another computers IP address, just assign one
that is not being used by any other machines.

Good Luck

Derek Loree

From m at pdxlug.org  Thu Jun 12 10:28:02 2003
From: m at pdxlug.org (m at pdxlug.org)
Date: Thu Jun 12 10:28:02 2003
Subject: FW: [PLUG] Microsoft to kill popular Linux antivirus product 
     (fwd)
In-Reply-To: 
     <A9031B213036D3119BD100A0C973D4BB039C3D34@exsalem6.odot.state.or.us>
References: 
     <A9031B213036D3119BD100A0C973D4BB039C3D34@exsalem6.odot.state.or.us>
Message-ID: <6030.68.96.48.205.1055438855.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>

> Can anyone tell me of a virus that will actually do anything to Linux?
> Sure,
> you can pass the "Outlook virus du jour" to your clients if you're running
> a server, but what virus can actually do damage on a Linux client without
> becoming root first? I've never understood that one.

Since when do viruses need root to spread?  And wouldn't a user be rather
annoyed if that non-root virus wiped out all the files in their home
directory?  Then we have things like Lindows where the user runs as root
all the time (for ease of use).  Eventually Linux GUI email clients will
allow you to simply click the attachment to open it (for ease of use). 
And if it was an RPM file attached, for example, and the email client
refused to do anything with it, then we still have user-training issues
like, "Oh, hey, that's an RPM file, I remember Bob from PLUG told me that
I just have to switch to root and run 'rpm -i badfile.rpm' to install it. 
Cool.  This Linux stuff isn't so hard."
~M




From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Thu Jun 12 10:35:02 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Thu Jun 12 10:35:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Microsoft to kill popular Linux antivirus product (fwd)
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306120622540.23862-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com><1055429943.1199.148.camel@red>  <200306120817.22263.pluglist@bratgrrl.com> <1055436888.10541.1.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <00bc01c33108$5415a570$1901a8c0@madcat>

I think this is the start of a rather disturbing change in the tactics of
M$. First, it was "buy out all competition on the windows platform for M$
products, or cause them to not work. Be uncomeptitive." This evidenced by
the dozens and dozens and dozens of acquisitons/buy outs microsoft has made
over the last 10 years or so.

In the market of today, Microsoft has no real competitors for anything they
make. Notice I said "real" - this means someone who would consitute a direct
threat to Microsoft revenues. Well, except for OSS that is. We all know the
most prevelant OSS (at least in people's minds and in the news) is linux.
Microsoft has decided to take it's "working" domination plan and modify it
for the OSS world. How long before they start buying other OSS companies?
Can you envision a buyout of redhat? Sure, it's farfetched, but who's to say
it's not possible? Redhat "won't be bought" - well, they've never had a
multi-billion dollar offer before.

Microsoft will be careful - they will identify "hot spots" of production,
commercial software on linux. They will *slowly* buy out these vendors. The
less vendors for a platform the less successful - this was evidenced by
apple in the early days of competition vs. windows 95.

This is my own conjecture, based on the trends on what I see and what is
happening.

The only real way to combay microsoft is to make everything free. If it is
free, then it cannot be bought out.

I'll end with a poem:

To cost, or not to cost: that is the question:
Whether 'tis nobler for the pocket to pay
The costs and moneys of outrageous fortune
And to bow down to those who would enslave you
or to support freedom of choice? There is choice:
To crash, to bluescreen? No more; A bluescreen ends;
The documents lost, the work is gone, heartaches
headaches and the computer out the window. Nay!
To process, to compute. To type in freedom
without worry of cost or crash; and the feeling,
the user is heir to, 'tis a computation
Devoutly to be wish'd. To crash, to fix;
to fix: perchance to learn new things: so hard!
Research, frustration, lost sleep: ay, there's the rub;
For in that brief crash what data may be lost
When you reboot your pc and scan your disk....
For those that would suffer the indignity
of microsoft, of paying for bits of nothing,
The oppressor's wrong, the guru contumely,
The pangs of monopoly, from law's delay.

My apologies to the great bard.
-Matt Chorman

From Linux.Administrator at odot.state.or.us  Thu Jun 12 10:52:02 2003

While it's true that a script to wipe out the user's home directory would be
trivial, my original question about being root to actually do any damage was
focusing on things like the kernel and root file system. Neither of these
would be impacted by a simple script unless it ran as root.

-----Original Message-----
From: m at pdxlug.org [mailto:m at pdxlug.org] 
Sent: Thursday, June 12, 2003 10:28 AM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: Re: FW: [PLUG] Microsoft to kill popular Linux antivirus product
(fwd)


> Can anyone tell me of a virus that will actually do anything to Linux?
> Sure,
> you can pass the "Outlook virus du jour" to your clients if you're running
> a server, but what virus can actually do damage on a Linux client without
> becoming root first? I've never understood that one.

Since when do viruses need root to spread?  And wouldn't a user be rather
annoyed if that non-root virus wiped out all the files in their home
directory?  Then we have things like Lindows where the user runs as root
all the time (for ease of use).  Eventually Linux GUI email clients will
allow you to simply click the attachment to open it (for ease of use). 
And if it was an RPM file attached, for example, and the email client
refused to do anything with it, then we still have user-training issues
like, "Oh, hey, that's an RPM file, I remember Bob from PLUG told me that
I just have to switch to root and run 'rpm -i badfile.rpm' to install it. 
Cool.  This Linux stuff isn't so hard."
~M

From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Thu Jun 12 10:59:01 2003
From: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name (cooper at cooper.stevenson.name)
Date: Thu Jun 12 10:59:01 2003
Subject: FW: [PLUG] Microsoft to kill popular Linux antivirus product  (fwd)
In-Reply-To: <6030.68.96.48.205.1055438855.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
References: <A9031B213036D3119BD100A0C973D4BB039C3D34@exsalem6.odot.state.or.us>
        <6030.68.96.48.205.1055438855.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <40562.192.168.1.1.1055440695.squirrel@www.intrinzix.us>

> Since when do viruses need root to spread?

Well, most viruses are email born.
 And wouldn't a user be
> rather annoyed if that non-root virus wiped out all the files in their
> home directory?

Please note: the modular filesystem design of Unix/Linux makes home
directories trivial to backup/restore. Also note that it is very simple to
prevent executeables to be run from /tmp, /home/user or any other
directory. Please refer to my documentation about this at
http://www.mwvlug.org .

Also, please keep this in perspective. Here's what a user would have to do
on a "normal" Linux system to run malicious code from a Linux email
client:

  1. Select "Save As" and save the file to the hard drive

  2. Go to a terminal and type 'chmod u+x badfile' or change the
permissions using Nautilus or similiar file manager

  3. Run the file: ./badfile

Anything short of this is preventing users from running executables on the
system wich is definately possible. See above. The point is that there
needs to be a balance. The truth is that the steps above shift the
responsibility to the user as it was he that overtly ran the command; the
system simply did what is was commanded to do.

Then we have things like Lindows where the user runs as
> root all the time (for ease of use).

And hammered by the Linux community and the press for it. This is an issue
with Lindows, not Linux. I personally do not recommend Lindows for my
clients. I do think though that they provide warnings with their system
when a user is about to run a potentially dangerous command.

 Eventually Linux GUI email clients
> will allow you to simply click the attachment to open it (for ease of
> use).

No they won't. How long do think it would be before the news groups hammer
an email client for allowing executables? I tell you through my experience
there would be an outcry before the software even made it out of beta.

Even barring that, because it's Open Source you can do something about it.
Nobody in the Linux community wants to be considered "stupid" for allowing
GUI's to run code from an unknown source. Believe it or not, there are
solid security design principles that are well known to the security
community, and they won't hesitate to let a developer know when their code
is not up to current security engineering practices.

Of course, you could take your chances with a proprietary product and see
how far you get. Can you say, "Bugbear?"

  And if it was an RPM file attached, for example, and the email
> client refused to do anything with it, then we still have user-training
> issues like, "Oh, hey, that's an RPM file, I remember Bob from PLUG told
> me that I just have to switch to root and run 'rpm -i badfile.rpm' to
> install it.  Cool.  This Linux stuff isn't so hard."

This is more of a social engineering exploit than a technical flaw with
the system's security, and you're still running the command as root. One
of the first things you learn with Unix/Linux is that root is almighty.

You could turn the tables for an NT2000 system by saying, "Yeah, Bob from
the Windows list said that I only had to run this service_pack.exe as
Administrator to fix the system. Cool, Windows isn't so bad."

Mandatory access control helps solve even this type of issue.


Best,


Cooper Stevenson

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Thu Jun 12 11:06:01 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Thu Jun 12 11:06:01 2003
Subject: FW: [PLUG] Microsoft to kill popular Linux antivirus product 
	(fwd)
In-Reply-To: <40562.192.168.1.1.1055440695.squirrel@www.intrinzix.us>
References: 
	 <A9031B213036D3119BD100A0C973D4BB039C3D34@exsalem6.odot.state.or.us>
	 <6030.68.96.48.205.1055438855.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
	 <40562.192.168.1.1.1055440695.squirrel@www.intrinzix.us>
Message-ID: <1055441108.1993.92.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Thu, 2003-06-12 at 10:58, cooper at cooper.stevenson.name wrote:

> Also, please keep this in perspective. Here's what a user would have to do
> on a "normal" Linux system to run malicious code from a Linux email
> client:

You're thinking about the /obvious/ way you would download and run an
executable e-mail attachment.  Even the Lookout exploits don't usually
use /obvious/ means--they exploit bugs in handling of multi-part
boundaries and such.

1. Use an exploit in MUA code; e.g. MIME handling or something.
2. Inject malicious code.

It's certainly not as easy as having Lookout automatically open the
malicious file, but it's entirely conceivable.

Wil

From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Thu Jun 12 11:24:01 2003
From: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name (cooper at cooper.stevenson.name)
Date: Thu Jun 12 11:24:01 2003
Subject: FW: [PLUG] Microsoft to kill popular Linux antivirus product  (fwd)
In-Reply-To: <1055441108.1993.92.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <A9031B213036D3119BD100A0C973D4BB039C3D34@exsalem6.odot.state.or.us>
        <6030.68.96.48.205.1055438855.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
        <40562.192.168.1.1.1055440695.squirrel@www.intrinzix.us>
        <1055441108.1993.92.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <40579.192.168.1.1.1055442213.squirrel@www.intrinzix.us>

> You're thinking about the /obvious/ way you would download and run an
> executable e-mail attachment.  Even the Lookout exploits don't usually
> use /obvious/ means--they exploit bugs in handling of multi-part
> boundaries and such.

Right. Not to be dogmatic but exploits are caught and patched early. This
helps prevent MIME type and other exploits.

Again, I must stress that there are several mechanisms available to
prevent even this type of exploit, including MIME type handling, buffer
overflow, or otherwise. Please see my documentation listed in a previous
post.

Anything is conceivable but open review during the development phase and
due diligence with security updates go a long way to stopping known
exploits with sound design.



-Cooper







From list at sonofhans.net  Thu Jun 12 12:11:01 2003
From: list at sonofhans.net (Randall Hansen)
Date: Thu Jun 12 12:11:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Microsoft to kill popular Linux antivirus product
In-Reply-To: <40579.192.168.1.1.1055442213.squirrel@www.intrinzix.us>
References: <A9031B213036D3119BD100A0C973D4BB039C3D34@exsalem6.odot.state.or.us>
	<6030.68.96.48.205.1055438855.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
	<40562.192.168.1.1.1055440695.squirrel@www.intrinzix.us>
	<1055441108.1993.92.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	<40579.192.168.1.1.1055442213.squirrel@www.intrinzix.us>
Message-ID: <20030612121241.323eb832.list@sonofhans.net>

Thus spoke cooper at cooper.stevenson.name
( Thu, 12 Jun 2003 18:23:33 -0000 (GMT) ):

> Anything is conceivable but open review during the development phase
> and due diligence with security updates go a long way to stopping
> known exploits with sound design.

'due diligence with security updates' is where the rubber meets the
road, and (to further torture the analogy) most people who run a
personal computers are hydroplaning.  

patching a security hole is usually trivial.  getting end-users to
update their own systems is like trying to herd cats with telepathy. 
sharper minds than my own (e.g. Bruce Shneier's) have said that the
"release then patch" security policy is bankrupt.

most large-scale exploits of Microsoft code use holes that have been
patched for months; the same is true of the rare worms that have
affected *nix systems.  there's no reason to think that wide-scale
adoption of linux on the desktop will change this, and every reasons
to think the situation will get worse.

viruses, worms, etc. spread mostly due to user and administrator
ignorance.  the particular flavor of computer on which they run is
incidental and largely determined by market share.  if Linux had 90%
share, most worms and viruses would target it.  fewer would succeed,
perhaps, than on windows machines, but it's been pointed out before
that most malware is poorly written to begin with.  there's room for
improvement :)  when your exploit target is Outlook Express you don't
have to try as hard as you would with (e.g.) Pine.

the more people using Linux who want a simple "click this" interface,
the harder it is for companies to justify secure-by-default systems. 
and i don't mean "justify" from a security standpoint, but from a
shareholder one.  like it or not, shareholders don't much care how
easily your software can be exploited as long as you sell lots of it.
pillory Lindows all you want for running as 'root' by default, but
they're basing their decision on market share, not security.  sound
familiar?  that's one reasons Windows has 90%+ share and OpenBSD is an
arcane specialists' tool.

more and more it's easier and cheaper to keep Bad Things away from
desktop machines than to keep them secure (i'm talking mostly about
corporate networks, not home machines).  TCPA et. al. aren't likely to
solve the problem -- they'll have exploits of their own.

so as someone said earlier, it looks like microsoft is making a pretty
smart attack here.  a successful attack on the barrier between your
competitor and a hostile environment means you won't have to attack
your competitor directly.

r

> Check the syslog, it will tell you if the dhcp-client was successful,
> or if there was an error.  If nothing is there, then your DHCP-client
> is not running.

There is nothing in the syslog, but ps tells me that dhclient is
running.  Does anyone know anything about that client?  Like, does it
really suck, or something?  Its config file says that little or no
tweaking should be necessary.  (I tend to agree with that statement,
considering how preponderant the use of DHCP is.)  There was a message
somewhere explaining that dhcpd is no longer recommended, but maybe
that's poppycock, and I should try to get it installed.

installed, incidentally, which allowed me to reconfigure the network via
debconf. But it still doesn't work:  it tries for maybe fourty seconds
to get its IPs, then gives up without a word indicating its failure.  I
have a Win98 machine and a Linux From Scratch box which have no trouble
with DHCP, so I'm wondering why this woody distro is being so mulish.

Any clues?

From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Thu Jun 12 15:43:02 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Thu Jun 12 15:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Debian Network Problem
References: <20030612084159.412ce2ed.jason@vancleve.com><1055436436.18102.1232.camel@fastlinux.homenet> <20030612172208.45a6b547.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <002601c33133$5cfcf280$1901a8c0@madcat>

I wish I could remember where I saw this, but I know dhclient needs to be
rebuilt for the current kernel version. I know I had this problem once and
it was solved by recompiling/reinstalling.

I googled a little too, and it seems like people who also have this problem
and could not find a resolution switched over to dhcpcd and it worked..

Hope this helps!

From: "Jason Van Cleve" <jason at vancleve.com>

From mhopcroft at seraphimguard.com  Thu Jun 12 16:14:01 2003
From: mhopcroft at seraphimguard.com (Michael Hopcroft)
Date: Thu Jun 12 16:14:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Printers
Message-ID: <1055459593.7910.25.camel@localhost.localdomain>

I've got almost everything working on my system now. MP3s play (though
not through XMMS), video works fine, my Internet connection goes through
without a hitch. Qwest should be sending me DSL equipment in a couple of
weeks (I need to contact my ISP and tell them i won;t be going over to
MSN after all).

The one hitch left (besides the old bugaboo of installing software and
the face that none of the software I install shows up in my Red hat
menus) is that my printer, a lovely new Lexmark Z65, is not supported by
Linux. We have already determined that there is no driver for it, it
runs on a USB connection and while Linux will recognize it's there when
it's plugged in it won't print to it.

Since neither I nor anyone I know have the patience to hack my way
through to a driver, I need a replacement printer. Preferably used and
in good condition, at least 18 months old, and one that is known to be
supported by Red Hat Linux. A color inkjet would be my personal
preference. price is definitely an object, and it would have to come
with a parallel cable of its own. Ideally I'd like to buy from someone
who's upgrading.

Anyone know where I can get such a printer?

Michael,

it that printer has a driver in their PrintPro-4.4. I bought a copy several
years ago for my HP LaserJet 5 and DeskJet 2500C and I have no complaints.

From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Thu Jun 12 17:01:02 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Thu Jun 12 17:01:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Printers
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306121623140.25444-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <1055461194.7910.34.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <005201c3313e$31904e20$1901a8c0@madcat>

I would stay away from the cheapo specials - unless you don't mind replacing
your printer when your ink runs out. I myself have a Z35 color inkjet, the
quality is superb! The printer cost $30! The replacement cartridges cost
MORE. So I ask myself, is it worthwhile to purchase a cartridge for a used
printer or to buy a new one that will come with cartridges? The
environmentalist in me screams out in pain! I chucked it and bought a used
HP laserjet 1100 - It's a workhorse! Replacement toner is $40, but it will
print thousands more pages than that inkjet.

If you don't mind used (and have no luck here), try ebay -  here is a
lexmark lj 1100 (color) for $10!
http://cgi.ebay.com/ws/eBayISAPI.dll?ViewItem&item=3418417236&category=14305

M

Date: Thu Jun 12 17:26:05 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: CRIME Advanced Linux SIG - 7PM Wednesday June 18th
 --"Modern File Systems"
In-Reply-To: <3EE8163D.4060709@immunix.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306120832210.1624-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>

On Wed, 11 Jun 2003, Crispin Cowan wrote:

> Zot O'Connor wrote:
> 
> >Chris Jantzen will give his talk "Modern File Systems" 
> >
> Could we be a tad more specific?
> 
> I'd be particularly interested in a convincing resolution to the 
> persistent, conflicting rumors of "EXT3 is ready for production/no it 
> isn't", and "ReiserFS sux0rs/no it doesn't". The fast recovery times and 
> theoretical lack of disk corruption are attractive, but need to be 
> balanced against the threat of code instability in these new FS's.
> 
> Everyone has an anecdote, while claims of "production ready" really 
> require masses of experience that are *free* of anecdotes.

I would also be interested if it is possible to do secure file deletion on 
journaling file systems.  (Without leaving tell-tale scattered bits lieing 
around.)





From stevea at nwtechops.com  Thu Jun 12 17:36:02 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Thu Jun 12 17:36:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
In-Reply-To: <20030612162652.GB31355@rauhaus.org>
References: <86adcq4faf.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	 <001401c32f5c$44571400$1901a8c0@madcat>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306101536170.3166@shaft.bitmine.net>
	 <004101c32fb3$ced93a20$1901a8c0@madcat>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306101801000.5062@shaft.bitmine.net>
	 <20030611170241.GB22047@rauhaus.org> <1055383568.929.42.camel@main>
	 <20030612162652.GB31355@rauhaus.org>
Message-ID: <1055464539.930.74.camel@main>

On Thu, 2003-06-12 at 09:26, Stafford A. Rau wrote:

> I was perhaps not clear in my post on this - I wasn't talking about
> broadcast domains, but rather the larger ip allocations. From the point
> of view of a script kiddie, residential broadband hosts are going to be
> the best combination of decent bandwidth and a higher percentage of
> poorly or completely unprotected machines. That is likely to be true of
> both DSL and cable.
> 
> Cable may have a somewhat higher rate of port scans than DSL because
> there are only a small number of cable providers, and they have very
> large ip allocations for cable subscribers, such as 12.0.0.0/8 (and I'm
> just using that as an example - I don't know that the full /8 is used
> for subscribers).
> 
> So a script kiddie can port scan all of 12.0.0.0/8 and hit almost
> entirely cable subscribers. To look for DSL subscribers, one would need
> to scan a few /24s here, a few there, maybe a /18 or two, but regardless
> there aren't the big contiguous blocks of subscribers like there are
> with cable.
> 
> My comment that I was voting for technical reasons was in contrast to
> Jeme's socio-economic explanation, and was I not referring to
> differences in the underlying transport technologies of DSL and cable.

I see, I did misunderstand your original point, sorry about that
Stafford. I still can't agree that much of what's been presented defines
any technical weakness though. I see the main problem as being a lack of
measures taken by users and providers to manage and secure their
resources.

As for the socio-economics theory; I've seen no qualification that
supports it. Until there is actual fact presented I remain skeptical.

On Thu, 2003-06-12 at 08:41, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> I'm having one of my goofy catch-22 issues again, trying to install
> woody.  Something about this hardware is preventing my network interface
> from being detected during the installation, even after the tulip driver
> is supposedly loaded.  Once the initial install is done and I reboot,
> the NIC is found, but yet I cannot get dhcp to work. 
> /etc/network/interfaces is configured with the dhcp option, and when I
> run ifup -a, it waits a moment and then exits without error.  At this
> point the interface is up, but there's no IP.

I have an older NIC which can use either the tulip or de4x5 driver. 
Well that statement is actually wrong.  The tulip driver will load but I
can never get the NIC to work properly.  It works like a charm when I
use the de4x5 module.

From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Thu Jun 12 20:40:03 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Thu Jun 12 20:40:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Debian Network Problem
References: <20030612084159.412ce2ed.jason@vancleve.com><1055436436.18102.1232.camel@fastlinux.homenet><20030612172208.45a6b547.jason@vancleve.com><002601c33133$5cfcf280$1901a8c0@madcat> <20030612191247.7fe5891c.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <000601c3315c$cabb4a50$1901a8c0@madcat>

If you are looking for an automatic dependancy resolution/package
downloader/portage system, try gentoo.. I've installed it on everything from
a p120 laptop to an athlon xp 2000 - and everything in between.. Granted,
you do have to wait for everything to compile but it is well worth the wait.
Most gentoo users are either ex-debian users or newbs (or so it seems from
the forums.)

Bonus - you don't have to download a bunch of isos. In fact, you don't have
to download ANY isos if you don't wish to.. You can install from an existing
installation, as long as it has net access and chroot ability (you will just
have to wait for bootstraping to finish which takes a few hours by itself,
more or less depending on system speed.).

M

From sean at fork.com  Thu Jun 12 20:43:02 2003
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Thu Jun 12 20:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
In-Reply-To: <20030612162652.GB31355@rauhaus.org>
References: <86adcq4faf.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <1055383568.929.42.camel@main> <20030612162652.GB31355@rauhaus.org>
Message-ID: <200306121346.23745.sean@fork.com>

> So a script kiddie can port scan all of 12.0.0.0/8 and hit almost
> entirely cable subscribers. To look for DSL subscribers, one would need
> to scan a few /24s here, a few there, maybe a /18 or two, but regardless
> there aren't the big contiguous blocks of subscribers like there are
> with cable.


From experience (I work for one of the evil cable companies, not Comast) I 
would say this too is a overgeneralization.

Turns out we have about 120,000 for our cable network covering areas in 
Washington, Oregon and Northern California.  Most our our IPs are within /18 
blocks in the 66.X.X.X and 68.X.X.X range.  Turns out my IP at my house, 
provided by Earthlink DSL is also a 66.X.X.X IP address.

ATT owns the 12/8 block because in the early days they were giving IPs away to 
whomever wanted them.  Somebody at ATT was smart enought to get a class A 
network.

There are Universities with class A networks.  So what.

Recently I was at a NANOG meeting and found out that if you as an individual 
had requested IPv6 IP addresses a couple of years ago, they would have given 
you a /32, which in IPv6 terms is HUGE.  Just because you asked.

BTW, we (cable company) made the decision in the beginning to distribute 
public IP's on our cable network in /23s to limit LAN type portscans and 
protect the customers.  

The technical people who manage cable IP network usually have telco and DSL 
experience as well.  Most of the differences you see between cable and DSL 
isn't how the companies operate, it's because FCC rules are applied 
differently to cable companies and telco's.  Telco's would love to live in 
the cable world and have similar AUPs, however federal regulations prevent 
that from happening.  Cable companies are not going to sit back and live like 
a telco just because, they are going to take advantage of everything the law 
will allow.

Sean

I tryed to collect information on everyone who had contacted me by
mid day Monday 9 June 2003, and I gave this information to Gretchen
Bartholomew at O'Reilly.  At that point, we had 32 volunteers.
Gretchen is checking into things, but she thinks O'Reilly can use
all 32 volunteers - altho a few people will be asked to work days
other than Wednesday or Thursday.  In any case, Gretchen will
contact volunteers directly with details.  Also, I missed a few
people who didn't contact me by mid day Monday.  Sorry about that,
but I had to cut things off at some point.  Also, I really tryed
to include everyone who contacted me and I think I succeeded.
However, if by chance I missed someone - please forgive me.

<Jeme-snip>
Script-kiddies are suburban, bored, and anti-social.  The suburbs are
pretty much designed to turn out these kinds of people.

It IS a surprise that more aren't certifiably psychotic (or maybe that's
what all the medication is for).

I suppose it might make sense that kids try to scan other people in
their close proximity (IP, speaking) in an attempt to gain access to or
information about their neighbors (which is a gross misunderstanding of
the scale of the cable business model, but I digress...).  An adult
would probably know better than to scan folks on his own network because
the complaints are more likely to result in a suspension of service.  An
adult is paying the bill... a suburban kid is just fucking with Mom and
Dad's connection and they'll just go to anothe provider (in the kid's
mind).

</Jeme-snip>

Can you qualify any of these statements with fact (medical and/or
legal)? Don't misunderstand me Jeme, your comments sound feasible but
they appear to be pure speculation.

Steve

From list at sonofhans.net  Fri Jun 13 07:26:01 2003
From: list at sonofhans.net (Randall Hansen)
Date: Fri Jun 13 07:26:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Debian Network Problem
In-Reply-To: <20030612191247.7fe5891c.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20030612084159.412ce2ed.jason@vancleve.com>
	<1055436436.18102.1232.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
	<20030612172208.45a6b547.jason@vancleve.com>
	<002601c33133$5cfcf280$1901a8c0@madcat>
	<20030612191247.7fe5891c.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <20030613072707.6626404d.list@sonofhans.net>

Thus spoke Jason Van Cleve <jason at vancleve.com>
( Thu, 12 Jun 2003 19:12:47 -0500 ):

> I hate to download all eight ISOs for the official release.

no doubt.  i use nothing but Debian; last time i needed to install on
a laptop, i downloaded the disc 1 ISO of Sarge[1].  even this, as you
know, is massive overkill -- really all you need is the bare minimum
required to get the installer connected to the 'net.  the smaller the
better, which is why the LordSutch ISOs are so cool.  but they're not
always as stable or driver-full as the official ISOs.

i tried a LordSutch ISO a year or two ago and had no luck.  you can
also try Jigdo[2], but the download takes freaking forever since it's
billions of small files.

Debian's install process needs work, no doubt.  but take comfort in
this: one reasons it's sub-optimal is that the developers never need
to use it.  once you install Debian on a machine you never need to do
it again unless you massively hose something; apt-get lets you stay
incrementally up-to-date.

randall

1) http://www.debian.org/CD/http-ftp/#testing
2) http://www.debian.org/CD/jigdo-cd/

Message-ID: <20030613095802.6b05dd3c.jason@vancleve.com>

Always wanted to try gentoo.  Looks cool.  So I did, just now, and it,
too, fails to connect to the 'Net:  and it uses dhcpcd instead of
dhclient. Now I'm scritchin' my head again, because I've tried two
different NICs and every combination of options to dhcpcd.  Tried
sending the host name, the MAC address, everything I could find on
google.

I noticed the dhcpcd process IDs keep changing rapidly, until they
finally die out altogether.  I don't know if that's how it's supposed to
work, but then I checked the syslog (the "everything" log, in
gentooland), and I saw a whole lot of these messages (I'm guessing one
for every process):

[dhcpcd] dhcpStop: ioctl SIOCSIFADDR: Bad file descriptor
[dhcpcd] dhcpStop: ioctl SIOCSIFFLAGS: Bad file descriptor

I don't suppose anyone can explain that, because google produced nothing
useful.  Maybe my motherboard is fscked, or maybe it's a memory problem.
At one point I was getting outa memory errors.  (Sure could use a
descriptive error message once in a while. . . .)  Mr. Chorman, do you
know how I can set up a swap partition after booting from the gentoo CD?
 Maybe that would help.

It seems Win98 is the only OS this machine is capable of running.

--Jason V. C.


On Thu, 12 Jun 2003 20:35:10 -0700
"Matt Chorman" <matt at legalizefreedom.org> wrote:

> If you are looking for an automatic dependancy resolution/package
> downloader/portage system, try gentoo.. I've installed it on
> everything from a p120 laptop to an athlon xp 2000 - and everything in
> between.. Granted, you do have to wait for everything to compile but
> it is well worth the wait. Most gentoo users are either ex-debian
> users or newbs (or so it seems from the forums.)
> 
> Bonus - you don't have to download a bunch of isos. In fact, you don't
> have to download ANY isos if you don't wish to.. You can install from
> an existing installation, as long as it has net access and chroot
> ability (you will just have to wait for bootstraping to finish which
> takes a few hours by itself, more or less depending on system speed.).
> 
> M

From srau at rauhaus.org  Fri Jun 13 09:56:02 2003

Date: Fri Jun 13 09:56:02 2003
