In-Reply-To: <20030613100136.1d2548fe.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20030613130602.7022.25895.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org> <20030613133255.19379.qmail@web20208.mail.yahoo.com> <20030613100136.1d2548fe.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <20030613165324.GE8458@rauhaus.org>

* Jason Van Cleve <jason at vancleve.com> [030613 08:00]:
> On Fri, 13 Jun 2003 06:32:55 -0700 (PDT)
> Gerardo Arnaez <garnaez at yahoo.com> wrote:
> 
> > 2. What problem are you having?
> 
> As I said, no 'Net connection.  dhclient fails to initialize eth0.  So
> does dhcpcd, evidently.
> 
> > 3. Why are you dong a net install?
> 
> The debian site recommended it.  And it didn't tell me which of the full
> ISO I would need, if not all eight.

As much as I hate floppies, you can download the rescue.bin, root.bin,
and driver-1.bin through driver-4.bin floppy and use rawrite (dos) or dd
(nix). You can then do a netinstall with for everything else.

That's probably the most common way to install Debian systems.

--Stafford



From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Fri Jun 13 11:01:02 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Fri Jun 13 11:01:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
References: <86adcq4faf.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <001401c32f5c$44571400$1901a8c0@madcat> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306101536170.3166@shaft.bitmine.net> <004101c32fb3$ced93a20$1901a8c0@madcat> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306101801000.5062@shaft.bitmine.net> <20030611170241.GB22047@rauhaus.org> <1055383568.929.42.camel@main> <20030612162652.GB31355@rauhaus.org> <1055464539.930.74.camel@main> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306122105140.16539@shaft.bitmine.net> <1055510177.929.90.camel@main>
Message-ID: <001501c3320e$5aafafa0$1901a8c0@madcat>

I will answer for him.. :-) Anyone wishing to add may do so. Sorry for the
off-topic post, but this needs to be responded to.

> <Jeme-snip>
> Script-kiddies are suburban, bored, and anti-social.  The suburbs are
> pretty much designed to turn out these kinds of people.

FACT:
Have you ever been a kid growing up in suburbia?? I spent most of my teenage
years in Salem, Oregon and in Provo, Utah (don't cry for me portland.) I,
and every damn last person I've known in similiar environments, can vouch
for this. There will be no "hard" proof, other than looking at economics. Is
it feasible to put large stadiums/many theaters/recreational activities in
less-populated environments? They won't make money. You need a population
base. If things are close enough together that you can walk/ride bike is
that really suburbia, or is it an urban environment?

Sure, some kids get through it ok. I also knew kids who grew up in the worst
possible circumstances (you don't want to knw) who are in college, "doing
okay."

Some of this is speculation. Some of this is looking at things like
Columbine High. Enough said.

> It IS a surprise that more aren't certifiably psychotic (or maybe that's
> what all the medication is for).

Surgeon General David Satcher announced in 1999 that 20 percent of the
population -- one in five Americans -- is mentally ill and in need of
treatment. A recent UN study puts this number at 30 percent - sorry, I don't
have a link for this (saw it on CNN). People seem to forget this, and seem
to forget that crime, imprisonment, and institutionalization are on the
rise. Is this number decreasing or increasing? You be the judge. Look around
you. 1 out of every 5 people you know is crazy (on some level.) Does this
REALLY suprise anyone?

> I suppose it might make sense that kids try to scan other people in
> their close proximity (IP, speaking) in an attempt to gain access to or
> information about their neighbors (which is a gross misunderstanding of
> the scale of the cable business model, but I digress...).

This may be partially true.. As a teenager I was dialing the BBS circuits
(anyone remember capricorn rising in salem? i loved that place.) and didn't
get net (slip) access until 1993 - none of my neighbors had this and I
wasn't interested in scanning establishments.

I *think* (being one of those disillusioned, bored, and anti-social teens at
one time) it is a combination of A. Boredom and B. Curiosity and in some
unusual cases C. A need for destruction (much like graffiti and vandalism).
The cable networks give you a guaranteed pool to search from. I just did a
scan for port 80 on my local /24 net and found 2 dozen web servers, most
IIS. The odds are just greatly increased when you have a "bigger pool" to
fish in.

> An adult would probably know better than to scan folks on his own network
because
> the complaints are more likely to result in a suspension of service.

Hahaha! I just did that, but I don't do it regularly. And I know some pretty
dumb adults. Most adults get their kicks out of porn sites.. Teens can't
watch porn with their parents around, but how many parents know what the
output of nmap looks like, or what it is for? Ahh, my child is doing
technical things and expanding their brain! :-p

>  An adult is paying the bill... a suburban kid is just fucking with Mom
and
> Dad's connection and they'll just go to anothe provider (in the kid's
> mind).

On top of that, most kids don't realize that there are consquences for
electronic vandalism/trespassing.

Let me know if any of these are not the "hard facts" you are looking for and
I will do research for proof..

M




From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Fri Jun 13 11:18:02 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Fri Jun 13 11:18:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Debian Network Problem
References: <20030612084159.412ce2ed.jason@vancleve.com><1055436436.18102.1232.camel@fastlinux.homenet><20030612172208.45a6b547.jason@vancleve.com><002601c33133$5cfcf280$1901a8c0@madcat><20030612191247.7fe5891c.jason@vancleve.com><000601c3315c$cabb4a50$1901a8c0@madcat> <20030613095802.6b05dd3c.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <003c01c33210$c48b60c0$1901a8c0@madcat>

> I noticed the dhcpcd process IDs keep changing rapidly, until they
> finally die out altogether.  I don't know if that's how it's supposed to
> work, but then I checked the syslog (the "everything" log, in
> gentooland), and I saw a whole lot of these messages (I'm guessing one
> for every process):
> [dhcpcd] dhcpStop: ioctl SIOCSIFADDR: Bad file descriptor
> [dhcpcd] dhcpStop: ioctl SIOCSIFFLAGS: Bad file descriptor

It sounds like your driver is not the correct one for the card you have -
what type of network card do you have in your machine? I remember briefly
something about a tulip driver... What driver does it show when you run
lsmod? If nothing, what about cat /proc/pci?

Have you switched NICs lately? Some cable/dsl modems "remember" the MAC
address and will not give out a dhcp address to anything other than the
original NIC. Try rebooting your cable modem.

> I don't suppose anyone can explain that, because google produced nothing
> useful.  Maybe my motherboard is fscked, or maybe it's a memory problem.

It's *probably* one of a few things - network communication getting garbled,
bad driver, bad cable, NIC on the fritz, modem on the fritz, etc.
Communications are not working correctly, basically. Pretty vague, eh? When
you see this, do the logs give you any more detail?

> At one point I was getting outa memory errors.  (Sure could use a
> descriptive error message once in a while. . . .)  Mr. Chorman, do you
> know how I can set up a swap partition after booting from the gentoo CD?

Sure, if you have swap partition /dev/hdax, type
#swapon /dev/hdax

if the swap partion gives you errors, type
#mkswap /dev/hdax
#swapon /dev/hdax

>  Maybe that would help.
> It seems Win98 is the only OS this machine is capable of running.

What type of chipset is it? The info on the NIC type would be helpful in
troubleshooting. Also, which live CD did you try to install from? The latest
is 1.4rc4 - don't use rc2 as there are many known issues with that cd.

M




From drl at drloree.com  Fri Jun 13 11:18:11 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Fri Jun 13 11:18:11 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Debian Network Problem
In-Reply-To: <20030613095802.6b05dd3c.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20030612084159.412ce2ed.jason@vancleve.com>
	 <1055436436.18102.1232.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
	 <20030612172208.45a6b547.jason@vancleve.com>
	 <002601c33133$5cfcf280$1901a8c0@madcat>
	 <20030612191247.7fe5891c.jason@vancleve.com>
	 <000601c3315c$cabb4a50$1901a8c0@madcat>
	 <20030613095802.6b05dd3c.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <1055528479.18103.1261.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Fri, 2003-06-13 at 07:58, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> Always wanted to try gentoo.  Looks cool.  So I did, just now, and it,
> too, fails to connect to the 'Net:  and it uses dhcpcd instead of
> dhclient. Now I'm scritchin' my head again, because I've tried two
> different NICs and every combination of options to dhcpcd.  Tried
> sending the host name, the MAC address, everything I could find on
> google.

What are the chipsets on the NIC's you have tried?
> 
> I noticed the dhcpcd process IDs keep changing rapidly, until they
> finally die out altogether.  I don't know if that's how it's supposed to
> work, but then I checked the syslog (the "everything" log, in
> gentooland), and I saw a whole lot of these messages (I'm guessing one
> for every process):
> 
> [dhcpcd] dhcpStop: ioctl SIOCSIFADDR: Bad file descriptor
> [dhcpcd] dhcpStop: ioctl SIOCSIFFLAGS: Bad file descriptor

This is acting like the interface isn't connected to the cable, or the
cable is bad or the hub is bad, or something along those lines.
> 
> I don't suppose anyone can explain that, because google produced nothing
> useful.  Maybe my motherboard is fscked, or maybe it's a memory problem.
> At one point I was getting outa memory errors.  (Sure could use a
> descriptive error message once in a while. . . .)  Mr. Chorman, do you
> know how I can set up a swap partition after booting from the gentoo CD?
>  Maybe that would help.
> 
> It seems Win98 is the only OS this machine is capable of running.

Success in getting an IP address is not a good criteria for deciding if
an OS is compatible with the hardware.  At most it lets you know that
the NIC you've got isn't compatible.  However, it could also be pointing
to hardware problems elsewhere on your network.

If you have a bad hub, or an incorrectly wired cable, then the slower
than a dog WinIP stack still might function, but even slower than
usual.  The nice fast linux stack will still work, just not well.

This is looking more like a hardware problem than a distribution
problem.

I've installed the Debian Net Install on a fair number of machines, and
only once did I have to change the dhcp client, and that was back when
Woody was still unstable.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

From barryb at proaxis.com  Fri Jun 13 16:19:01 2003
From: barryb at proaxis.com (Bill Barry)
Date: Fri Jun 13 16:19:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Serial ATA & RH 9 ?

This article 
http://www.linuxhardware.org/Features/03/04/16/1610236.shtml
suggests that the sata part of the bios can be set to some  legacy mode 
enabling the installation of RH9.
I know that with my  845P chipset Intel m/b, the 2.5.68 kernel checked for
Sata drives. I don't have one so I don't know whether it would work or not.
Once you get installed, you might want to go
for a development kernel to get full use of the drives.

Bill Barry

From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Fri Jun 13 16:44:01 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Fri Jun 13 16:44:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Windows emulation
References: <1055545178.14238.6.camel@localhost.localdomain>

It helps if you do research.

And read the manual.

Wine is not a trivial thing, though it appears to be at first glance..
Depends on whether you are trying to play games or not.

To give an overview would take me 3 hours to type. I don't feel like it, as
someone else has already done this. Did you read the manual? It gives an
overview. I know you didn't - one of the first things it states in the
manual is what WINE stands for - WINE is not an emulator. There is no
windows emulation in linux (disclaimer: that I know of) ..

http://www.la-sorciere.de/Wine-HOWTO/book1.html

A little light reading for your Friday evening... ;-)

  I tried getting it back up, but cannot start the daemon. I _can_ start
cups, but it reports the daemon exited with an error. Infinite loop.

From barryb at proaxis.com  Fri Jun 13 16:51:02 2003
From: barryb at proaxis.com (Bill Barry)
Date: Fri Jun 13 16:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] MInicom script
In-Reply-To: <oV3qPk+F1Gi79RDRpJH7Y=H8fwFu@4ax.com>
References: <oV3qPk+F1Gi79RDRpJH7Y=H8fwFu@4ax.com>
Message-ID: <20030613235150.GA12429@edge>

On Fri, Jun 13, 2003 at 04:36:36PM -0700, Prutzer wrote:
> HI,
> Okay, well I finally got off my lazy butt and started setting up my
> linux box to dialup my isp. The first step of weaning myself of the
> one reason I keep a windows box around. 
> After much frustration with finding my modem and making it work I now
> find I can't get past the login to my ISP. Simple, yes I know,but I'm
> stuck trying to locate something intelligent (okay, simple to
> understand) off the web. 
> I need to know how to write a login script for minicom.
> Granted, I know HOW to write a script file, but I'm nervous about this
> one. Grepping a log for who logged in when is easy. 
> This I'm just nervous about. 
> I 'm only using minicom until I can find and understand something
> better, like xisp or maybe something else. But I'd appreciate(with as
> little jesting as possible) some help in getting me past this first
> low hurdle.
> ...

wvdial and wvdialconf are useful here. 

wvdialconf finds the modem and sets up an initial configuration file
in which you can put your phone numbers, login names, etc.  

wvdial does the dialing and starts ppp for your network connection.

Bill Barry



From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Fri Jun 13 17:31:02 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Fri Jun 13 17:31:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Debian Network Problem
References: <20030612084159.412ce2ed.jason@vancleve.com><1055436436.18102.1232.camel@fastlinux.homenet><20030612172208.45a6b547.jason@vancleve.com><002601c33133$5cfcf280$1901a8c0@madcat><20030612191247.7fe5891c.jason@vancleve.com><000601c3315c$cabb4a50$1901a8c0@madcat><20030613095802.6b05dd3c.jason@vancleve.com><003c01c33210$c48b60c0$1901a8c0@madcat> <20030613184512.6cfab52a.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <007401c3320c$455d61d0$1901a8c0@madcat>

This card should not be giving you problems.. (Not in the face! Not in the
face!!!!!)

OK. So basically what is happening is for some reason the tulip driver is
(probably) not getting configured properly. Probably something stupid like
autodetection not working (or maybe even some sort of PnP Aware OS setting
in the bios.. Maybe gremlins came down and are nesting on your card,
shorting some connections.) Who knows, right? hehe

The one thing you have in your favor is that the card is being detected and
the correct driver installed.

I found this great utility that  Donald Becker (author of the tulip driver +
many others) wrote to find the current state of a card running the tulip
driver. I have attached it to this email (and sent it to you directly in
case this list does not allow attachments).. One thing to check is the
current link speed and duplex settings - this will tell you what the card
thinks its running and you can compare it to what it's really running..

Save this source to disk and from the prompt type:

#gcc test.c -o diag -O

The -O was necessary. I don't know why.. I don't know what this program
returns, but it is supposed to give the information I mentioned above. My
thoughts are that your card is trying to force the wrong speed (i.e.
100BaseT FDX) when the cable modem thinks it is supposed to be 100BaseT
HDX.. Or something different.

There are a number of options you can pass to the module to force various
things.. Run that diag program and let us know the outcome...

M

> FACT:
> Have you ever been a kid growing up in suburbia?? I spent most of my teenage
> years in Salem, Oregon and in Provo, Utah (don't cry for me portland.) I,
> and every damn last person I've known in similiar environments, can vouch
> for this. There will be no "hard" proof, other than looking at economics. Is
> it feasible to put large stadiums/many theaters/recreational activities in
> less-populated environments? They won't make money. You need a population
> base. If things are close enough together that you can walk/ride bike is
> that really suburbia, or is it an urban environment?
> 
> Sure, some kids get through it ok. I also knew kids who grew up in the worst
> possible circumstances (you don't want to knw) who are in college, "doing
> okay."

> Columbine High. Enough said.
> 
> > It IS a surprise that more aren't certifiably psychotic (or maybe that's
> > what all the medication is for).
> 
> Surgeon General David Satcher announced in 1999 that 20 percent of the
> population -- one in five Americans -- is mentally ill and in need of
> treatment. A recent UN study puts this number at 30 percent - sorry, I don't
> have a link for this (saw it on CNN). People seem to forget this, and seem
> to forget that crime, imprisonment, and institutionalization are on the
> rise. Is this number decreasing or increasing? You be the judge. Look around
> you. 1 out of every 5 people you know is crazy (on some level.) Does this
> REALLY suprise anyone?
> 
> > I suppose it might make sense that kids try to scan other people in
> > their close proximity (IP, speaking) in an attempt to gain access to or
> > information about their neighbors (which is a gross misunderstanding of
> > the scale of the cable business model, but I digress...).
> 
> This may be partially true.. As a teenager I was dialing the BBS circuits
> (anyone remember capricorn rising in salem? i loved that place.) and didn't
> get net (slip) access until 1993 - none of my neighbors had this and I
> wasn't interested in scanning establishments.
> 
> I *think* (being one of those disillusioned, bored, and anti-social teens at
> one time) it is a combination of A. Boredom and B. Curiosity and in some
> unusual cases C. A need for destruction (much like graffiti and vandalism).
> The cable networks give you a guaranteed pool to search from. I just did a
> scan for port 80 on my local /24 net and found 2 dozen web servers, most
> IIS. The odds are just greatly increased when you have a "bigger pool" to
> fish in.
> 
> > An adult would probably know better than to scan folks on his own network
> because
> > the complaints are more likely to result in a suspension of service.
> 
> Hahaha! I just did that, but I don't do it regularly. And I know some pretty
> dumb adults. Most adults get their kicks out of porn sites.. Teens can't
> watch porn with their parents around, but how many parents know what the
> output of nmap looks like, or what it is for? Ahh, my child is doing
> technical things and expanding their brain! :-p
> 
> >  An adult is paying the bill... a suburban kid is just fucking with Mom
> and
> > Dad's connection and they'll just go to anothe provider (in the kid's
> > mind).
> 
> On top of that, most kids don't realize that there are consquences for
> electronic vandalism/trespassing.

> I will do research for proof..
> 
> M
> 

What you state here is almost all speculation and generalization mixed
with some facts that may or may not be relevant to the original thread
reply. As I said before, I see the feasibility of the argument but in
the absence of any evidence that script-kiddies are bored suburbanites
that hang on cable networks, that this generalization somehow pollutes
cable networks making these networks technically inferior to DSL, I
remain skeptical. Now if someone could present meaningful, quality,
numbers that prove this theory I would be a little less on the fence
about the subject.

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Steven A. Adams" <stevea at nwtechops.com>
To: <plug at lists.pdxlinux.org>
Sent: Friday, June 13, 2003 6:31 PM
Subject: Re: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
> What you state here is almost all speculation and generalization mixed
> with some facts that may or may not be relevant to the original thread
> reply. As I said before, I see the feasibility of the argument but in
> the absence of any evidence that script-kiddies are bored suburbanites
> that hang on cable networks, that this generalization somehow pollutes
> cable networks making these networks technically inferior to DSL, I
> remain skeptical. Now if someone could present meaningful, quality,
> numbers that prove this theory I would be a little less on the fence
> about the subject.

There are no hard numbers. No studies, no facts, no figures. Just educated
guesses. What I do know is that most of the warez and self-proclaimed
hackers that I see trolling newsgroups and forums are uneducated and
immature. This does not mean they are teenagers, but it does imply this.
Most, but not all, adults I have known and worked with are too scared of the
repercussions to do anything illegal - plus most of them are too busy with
their "lives" to attempt this. The few hardcore adult "security experts" I
know don't bother with the average joe unless the average joe crosses them.
This is a generalization based on experience.

I finally found something though - I did not want to send this empty handed.
No hard numbers, but information submitted to the government of New Zealand
by the Internet Society of New Zealand - who better to come up with numbers?
This is reinforced by numbers from the FBI. Apparently the parliament was
having the same skeptical issues as yourself. This is a snippet from this
document -
http://www.internetnz.net.nz/public/working-group-reports/wg-internet-surveillance/iswg010317letter-ageinfo-SelectCtte.html

<-----start snippet----->
"LETTER TO LAW AND ORDER COMMITEE, PARLIAMENT, NEW ZEALAND.

...
The Internet Society of New Zealand, Inc (ISOCNZ) was pleased to have the
opportunity last Thursday to make an Oral Submission on the Crimes Amendment
Bill #6. We appreciated the fact that the Committee members had obviously
thoroughly read our Submission and had penetrating questions to ask.

During our Oral Submission we felt it important to flag that a percentage,
possibly significant, of offenders under the proposed legislation will fall
into the under-16 and under-18-year-old categories and that therefore the
ability of the legislation to deal with such offenders will need to be
considered. Anecdotal evidence suggests that "hackers" start "exploring" in
their mid-teens through to their early twenties, and while some may continue
longer, many give it up once they get a "real life" with the pressures of
their job, and associated responsibilities.

In response to the request for documentation on the age-groups of people who
maliciously interfere with computer systems, our team has spent considerable
time searching for documented studies. We have to report that we have not
found evidence of any formal studies to back up the widely quoted anecdotal
evidence. This may be a useful area for the Select Committee to research.

I attach two documents sourced on the Internet which reinforce the anecdotal
evidence. The first is an FBI Congressional Statement (1) and the second a
report from Dorothy Denning (2) who is a well respected computer security
writer"

<-----end snippet----->

Proof enough? :-p

M




From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Fri Jun 13 19:17:02 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Fri Jun 13 19:17:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] MInicom script
References: <oV3qPk+F1Gi79RDRpJH7Y=H8fwFu@4ax.com> <20030613235150.GA12429@edge> <on3qPuaagOtjI4oToq4cZmbP2LRc@4ax.com>
Message-ID: <001501c3321b$151613a0$1901a8c0@madcat>

I personally don't use a modem - haven't for years. I used to work for
netgear - we had this really great modem router and the #1 authentication
people had was with the authentication protocol - CHAP, PAP and MS-CHAP. If
the protocol was wrong, the modem would hand shake but fail at the point
where a username/password was asked for.

Things may have changed, but knowing the internet they are probably the
same, but more bloated.. ;-)

I don't know about the items you are using - most of our customers used M$
products.. Check with your ISP and see what auth protocol they are using and
make sure yours is set to the same.

M

	 <20030611170241.GB22047@rauhaus.org> <1055383568.929.42.camel@main>
	 <20030612162652.GB31355@rauhaus.org> <1055464539.930.74.camel@main>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306122105140.16539@shaft.bitmine.net>
	 <1055510177.929.90.camel@main>  <001501c3320e$5aafafa0$1901a8c0@madcat>
	 <1055554273.930.143.camel@main>  <000f01c33219$eb495a10$1901a8c0@madcat>
Message-ID: <1055559224.930.153.camel@main>

On Fri, 2003-06-13 at 19:08, Matt Chorman wrote:
> ----- Original Message ----- 
> From: "Steven A. Adams" <stevea at nwtechops.com>
> To: <plug at lists.pdxlinux.org>
> Sent: Friday, June 13, 2003 6:31 PM
> Subject: Re: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
> > What you state here is almost all speculation and generalization mixed
> > with some facts that may or may not be relevant to the original thread
> > reply. As I said before, I see the feasibility of the argument but in
> > the absence of any evidence that script-kiddies are bored suburbanites
> > that hang on cable networks, that this generalization somehow pollutes
> > cable networks making these networks technically inferior to DSL, I
> > remain skeptical. Now if someone could present meaningful, quality,
> > numbers that prove this theory I would be a little less on the fence
> > about the subject.
> 
> There are no hard numbers. No studies, no facts, no figures. Just educated
> guesses. What I do know is that most of the warez and self-proclaimed
> hackers that I see trolling newsgroups and forums are uneducated and
> immature. This does not mean they are teenagers, but it does imply this.
> Most, but not all, adults I have known and worked with are too scared of the
> repercussions to do anything illegal - plus most of them are too busy with
> their "lives" to attempt this. The few hardcore adult "security experts" I
> know don't bother with the average joe unless the average joe crosses them.
> This is a generalization based on experience.
> 
> I finally found something though - I did not want to send this empty handed.
> No hard numbers, but information submitted to the government of New Zealand
> by the Internet Society of New Zealand - who better to come up with numbers?
> This is reinforced by numbers from the FBI. Apparently the parliament was
> having the same skeptical issues as yourself. This is a snippet from this
> document -
> http://www.internetnz.net.nz/public/working-group-reports/wg-internet-surveillance/iswg010317letter-ageinfo-SelectCtte.html
> 
> <-----start snippet----->
> "LETTER TO LAW AND ORDER COMMITEE, PARLIAMENT, NEW ZEALAND.
> 
> ...
> The Internet Society of New Zealand, Inc (ISOCNZ) was pleased to have the
> opportunity last Thursday to make an Oral Submission on the Crimes Amendment
> Bill #6. We appreciated the fact that the Committee members had obviously
> thoroughly read our Submission and had penetrating questions to ask.
> 
> During our Oral Submission we felt it important to flag that a percentage,
> possibly significant, of offenders under the proposed legislation will fall
> into the under-16 and under-18-year-old categories and that therefore the
> ability of the legislation to deal with such offenders will need to be
> considered. Anecdotal evidence suggests that "hackers" start "exploring" in
> their mid-teens through to their early twenties, and while some may continue
> longer, many give it up once they get a "real life" with the pressures of
> their job, and associated responsibilities.
> 
> In response to the request for documentation on the age-groups of people who
> maliciously interfere with computer systems, our team has spent considerable
> time searching for documented studies. We have to report that we have not
> found evidence of any formal studies to back up the widely quoted anecdotal
> evidence. This may be a useful area for the Select Committee to research.
> 
> I attach two documents sourced on the Internet which reinforce the anecdotal
> evidence. The first is an FBI Congressional Statement (1) and the second a
> report from Dorothy Denning (2) who is a well respected computer security
> writer"
> 
> <-----end snippet----->
> 
> Proof enough? :-p

Actually, it does seem to reinforce the argument that script-kiddies are
kids (hence the term kiddie) but it does not speak a word to their
origin or media of choice, which is the question on this thread. Tis
true that with maturity comes responsibility and that "youth is wasted
on the young" but are they wasting away in suburbia hanging off of a
cable modem or are they apartment dwellers on DSL? I'm remain
unconvinced that it's on cable alone.

> 
> M
> 
>

> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
--

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Steven A. Adams" <stevea at nwtechops.com>
To: <plug at lists.pdxlinux.org>
Sent: Friday, June 13, 2003 8:08 PM
Subject: Re: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch


>I remain unconvinced that <live primarily> on cable.

Me too................. But I have that gut instinct that tells me I'm right
(he said knowingly as he jumped off a cliff, knowing wings will mysteriously
grow from his feet..)

I started a poll on the gentoo forums, asking for age demographics combined
with internet access type.. There were six options:

Under 25, Dial-up user, DSL user, Cable user
Over 25, Dial-up user, DSL user, Cable user

I will respond with the results once the poll has had enough responses, that
is - if I still care that far in the future.... The problems with this
metric include: the fact that I did not include an option for script-kiddie
or not, and only asked "those who consider themselves 'hackers'" to respond.
There is always the chance the response will be inaccurate or a lie. This is
only polling one particular cross-section of computer users, not including
other distros or the Mac or M$ world. I'm sure there are more problems I
have not thought of; however, the gentoo forums are full of people who call
themselves l33t (I hate that term!) and like to talk about haX0rs and such,
so perhaps this will be at least partially informative.

My curiosity is getting the better of me.....

Here is the link for the poll -
http://forums.gentoo.org/viewtopic.php?t=60561

> By the way, I admire your tenacity.

Heh, wish my girlfriend did too...... :-o

M




From jorgens at coho.net  Sat Jun 14 02:04:01 2003
From: jorgens at coho.net (Steve Jorgensen)
Date: Sat Jun 14 02:04:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Ambitious newby question
Message-ID: <01C33219.D50A9E80.jorgens@coho.net>

Hi all,

I've played with Linux on and off for years, but have never done enough to 
get more than a modest comfort level with it.  I have decided to play with 
it again though, and I have a relatively ambitious plan (for a newby like 
myself).

I have set up a Debian Sarge box I want to use as a general purpose server, 
primarily a file backup server.  I really have 3 separate purposes for the 
box, and I want to keep them all isolated.  Since I'm neither a Linux nor a 
security expert, but I will be backing up both sensitive personal data and 
sensitive business data, and I hope to play around with setting up other 
Linux services such as mail spam filtering, etc.,  I'm hoping to set up 
something that can be relatively secure over the long term even with the 
shabby maintenance I'm likely to provide, and User-Mode-Linux looks like 
just the ticket.

My idea is that I would have a Samba backup system for personal systems in 
one UML, another Samba backup system on a separate IP address on another 
UML, another UML for experimentation, and another UML for mail filtering, 
DNS server, etc. after I've made them work in the experimental UML.

Of course, the trouble is that I really have no clue how to get started 
setting up UML on Debian/Sarge.  I found a document at 
http://www.megahosted.com/~en/papers/uml-debian-mini.html that looks 
probably really useful if I had someone to translate it into newbyese for 
me.

Oh, one more thing.  I'm trying to use a Western Digital 185GB IDE drive 
(not the boot/root drive) on the controller that comes in the box with it, 
and so far Debian only sees it as 137GB (The Extended Int-13 limit as I 
understand).

Can anyone do any of the following for me?
1.  Tell me what I need to do to get the full 185 GB regognized on my data 
drive.
2.  Help me with how to get started (I have gotten as far as getting a 
basic Sarge system installed/booting).
3.  Tell me this is too ambitious for a newby, and suggest an alternative 
strategy.

Thanks in advance,

- Steve Jorgensen

It would be interesting to study a month of firewall logs generated by
that random group. My suspicions are that you would find just as many
scans and hack attempts, percentage wise, on DSL as you would on the
cable users. Considering that you would not likely know the source
address of the hack (providing the scanner/hacker had half a brain),
this would only paint half of the picture - it would be a good start
though.

From jeme at brelin.net  Sat Jun 14 15:53:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sat Jun 14 15:53:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
In-Reply-To: <001501c3320e$5aafafa0$1901a8c0@madcat>

 <1055383568.929.42.camel@main> <20030612162652.GB31355@rauhaus.org>
 <1055464539.930.74.camel@main> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306122105140.16539@shaft.bitmine.net>
 <1055510177.929.90.camel@main> <001501c3320e$5aafafa0$1901a8c0@madcat>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306141540090.14710@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Fri, 13 Jun 2003, Matt Chorman wrote:
> I will answer for him.. :-) Anyone wishing to add may do so. Sorry for the
> off-topic post, but this needs to be responded to.

I appreciate the back-up there, sir.

I might add a point or two (or counterpoint, even).

[Re: Suburbs make kids bored and anti-social]
> I, and every damn last person I've known in similiar environments, can
> vouch for this. There will be no "hard" proof, other than looking at
> economics.

> Is it feasible to put large stadiums/many theaters/recreational
> activities in less-populated environments? They won't make money. You
> need a population base.

It's not the population of suburbia, it's the sprawl and the zoning that
prevent real neighborhood or town square development.  Small towns exist
all over the country that have low populations but nice town centers with
theaters, shops, public spaces, and easy access from all corners.

> If things are close enough together that you can walk/ride bike is that
> really suburbia, or is it an urban environment?

It doesn't have to be urban.  It can be a town or a village.  Suburban
sprawl throws out everything humanity has ever known about building places
where people live happily and started from scratch with the idea that
people don't want to be anywhere near one another and drive everywhere
they go.

In most suburban subdivisions, there's just one (maybe two) outlets from
the (zoned and enforced) residential area onto a "feeder" road.  You can't
leave the single-use monoculture without a car.

> > It IS a surprise that more aren't certifiably psychotic (or maybe
> > that's what all the medication is for).
>
> Surgeon General David Satcher announced in 1999 that 20 percent of the
> population -- one in five Americans -- is mentally ill and in need of
> treatment. A recent UN study puts this number at 30 percent - sorry, I
> don't have a link for this (saw it on CNN).

We live in a really sick society.  I'm not surprised by those numbers
(though I'd be interested to see how the bases for the estimation).
Mainstream culture seems to promote nothing but isolation, fear,
insecurity, and suspicion.

> Let me know if any of these are not the "hard facts" you are looking for
> and I will do research for proof..

Yeah, I'm not sure what kind of "hard facts" a person could produce that
would show that suburban youth are bored and anti-social.  There's plenty
of anecodotal evidence and we see the aggregate behavior of bored,
anti-social people in mall culture and so on, but how do you derive
accurate survey information (say) from people who are too anti-social to
care about giving accurate results and too bored to be honest?

We can look at the actions at various scales and we can look at the
environment and what it's effects appear to be.  That's as far as we can
go.

J.

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

From jeme at brelin.net  Sat Jun 14 16:10:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sat Jun 14 16:10:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
In-Reply-To: <1055554273.930.143.camel@main>
References: <86adcq4faf.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>  <001401c32f5c$44571400$1901a8c0@madcat>
  <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306101536170.3166@shaft.bitmine.net> 
 <004101c32fb3$ced93a20$1901a8c0@madcat>  <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306101801000.5062@shaft.bitmine.net>
  <20030611170241.GB22047@rauhaus.org> <1055383568.929.42.camel@main> 
 <20030612162652.GB31355@rauhaus.org> <1055464539.930.74.camel@main> 
 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306122105140.16539@shaft.bitmine.net>  <1055510177.929.90.camel@main>
  <001501c3320e$5aafafa0$1901a8c0@madcat> <1055554273.930.143.camel@main>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306141553330.14710@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Fri, 13 Jun 2003, Steven A. Adams wrote:
> As I said before, I see the feasibility of the argument but in the
> absence of any evidence that script-kiddies are bored suburbanites that
> hang on cable networks, that this generalization somehow pollutes cable
> networks making these networks technically inferior to DSL, I remain
> skeptical.

(That's quite a sentence.  [Well, it only has one period, anyway.])

I asked what you meant because I didn't understand what part you felt
needed further proof.  I can go into that now.

First, I didn't mean to imply that cable is technically inferior to DSL
for any reason at all.  I certainly didn't state that the actions of
script-kiddies "pollute" the networks they transit.

I essentially had four elements that I tied together:
Script-kiddies
Bored, anti-social behavior
Suburbs
Cable internet service

The assumptions, I felt, were the seemingly obvious associations of the
first and last pair as couplets.  The rest was just reason.

The actions of script-kiddies corresponds pretty well with people that are
bored and anti-social.  They're scanning huge networks for some nominal
thrill-in-destruction.  If you've got the time and energy to scan huge
networks AND you get some kind of thrill out of very small challenges
(like slipping a trojan to IIS), you're probably bored.  And if you're
attempting to do damage or find ways to do damage to other people's
systems, you're probably anti-social.

The suburbs are typically sprawling masses of "development" with very
little centralization of resources or services (except at the mall).  It's
hard to provide DSL service without telephone central offices regularly
intermixed among the subscribers.  This is best achieved where the
telephone system corresponds to centralized systems of roads, sewers, and
human activity.  Cable internet, however, requires only cable television,
which has been building out to the suburbs for more than twenty-five
years.

The rest of the original post was just pointing out that the suburbs were
also really good place to raise bored, anti-social people and therefore
script-kiddies flourish there.  That wasn't so much speculation as plain
cause and effect analysis.

> Now if someone could present meaningful, quality, numbers that prove
> this theory I would be a little less on the fence about the subject.

What kind of numbers would make you feel warm and fuzzy?  Some things just
don't quantify in any meaningful way.  There's this constant attempt in
our society to make everything seem like science because science is
somehow more right and justifiable than anything human (neglecting the
simple philosophical fact that science is a purely human invention).

Could numbers show you that an image is beautiful or an action served
justice or a person loves you?

I don't think numbers apply here.  We're talking about quality, not
quantity.  Post-war Suburbs are terrible places.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------

 http://www.openlaw.org

On Fri, 13 Jun 2003, Steven A. Adams wrote:
> Actually, it does seem to reinforce the argument that script-kiddies are
> kids (hence the term kiddie) but it does not speak a word to their
> origin or media of choice, which is the question on this thread.

OK, so now we're in the realm of my earlier posts.

> Tis true that with maturity comes responsibility and that "youth is
> wasted on the young" but are they wasting away in suburbia hanging off
> of a cable modem or are they apartment dwellers on DSL? I'm remain
> unconvinced that it's on cable alone.

Woah!  Now you want someone to show you that script-kiddies are ONLY on
cable?  I don't think that was a conjecture in this thread at all.

However, I think it's pretty easy to show the relationship between the
suburbs and the mindset of the script-kiddie... and the association of the
suburbs and cable is pretty clear, too.

	 <001401c32f5c$44571400$1901a8c0@madcat>

	 <004101c32fb3$ced93a20$1901a8c0@madcat>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306101801000.5062@shaft.bitmine.net>
	 <20030611170241.GB22047@rauhaus.org> <1055383568.929.42.camel@main>

	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306122105140.16539@shaft.bitmine.net>
	 <1055510177.929.90.camel@main> <001501c3320e$5aafafa0$1901a8c0@madcat>
	 <1055554273.930.143.camel@main>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306141553330.14710@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <1055634777.929.207.camel@main>

On Sat, 2003-06-14 at 16:10, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> First, I didn't mean to imply that cable is technically inferior to DSL
> for any reason at all.  I certainly didn't state that the actions of
> script-kiddies "pollute" the networks they transit.
> 
> I essentially had four elements that I tied together:
> Script-kiddies
> Bored, anti-social behavior
> Suburbs
> Cable internet service
> 
> The assumptions, I felt, were the seemingly obvious associations of the
> first and last pair as couplets.  The rest was just reason.

And the statement that script-kiddies and cable modems are somehow
associated is the root of my skepticism. Do you think that
script-kiddies are a product of cable modems? They did exist, and
practice, before cable modems were in wide distribution you know.

> The actions of script-kiddies corresponds pretty well with people that are
> bored and anti-social.  They're scanning huge networks for some nominal
> thrill-in-destruction.  If you've got the time and energy to scan huge
> networks AND you get some kind of thrill out of very small challenges
> (like slipping a trojan to IIS), you're probably bored.  And if you're
> attempting to do damage or find ways to do damage to other people's
> systems, you're probably anti-social.

Read this again Jeme, you have to see that it's based on generalization
and speculation. It is an interesting opinion though, which is why I
stated that I would like to see it qualified.

> associated is the root of my skepticism. Do you think that
> script-kiddies are a product of cable modems? They did exist, and
> practice, before cable modems were in wide distribution you know.

No, I don't think script-kiddies are a product of cable modems.

I think that there are lots of both in the suburbs.

> > The actions of script-kiddies corresponds pretty well with people that
> > are bored and anti-social.  They're scanning huge networks for some
> > nominal thrill-in-destruction.  If you've got the time and energy to
> > scan huge networks AND you get some kind of thrill out of very small
> > challenges (like slipping a trojan to IIS), you're probably bored.
> > And if you're attempting to do damage or find ways to do damage to
> > other people's systems, you're probably anti-social.
>
> Read this again Jeme, you have to see that it's based on generalization
> and speculation.

It's not generalization, it's practically a proof by definition.  Bored
and anti-social only mean anything in the context of supposition and
speculation.

> It is an interesting opinion though, which is why I stated that I would
> like to see it qualified.

It's as qualified as you make it.  You wanted to see it quantified which
is impossible.  (The best you could MAYBE do is provide some numbers to
show that network probing might appear to originate from cable modem
assigned IP segments than certain others, but that doesn't mean much.)

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Sat Jun 14 18:03:02 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor Pikus)
Date: Sat Jun 14 18:03:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATTBI to Comcast switch
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306141702120.14710@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0306141757330.27494-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

I think the correlation between the suburban life and script kiddies is an
interesting idea. After all, we can all agree for sure that there are much
more script kiddies in affluent suburbs than in urban areas. Walk through
downtown Los Angeles, after 6 pm. Do any of these teens look like script
kiddies to you? Do you think any of them is about to head home and sit in
front of the computer with their rootkits and exploits? No, they have an
active social life and human interactions. They form very close and
tight-knit communities where they come to spend most of their time,
socialize, and even depend on one another for their very survival.

>From here, it's a simple and straightforward reasoning to conclude that
the suburban life has turned the script kiddies into what they are.

--

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Sat Jun 14 20:49:01 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Sat Jun 14 20:49:01 2003

Message-ID: <1055648921.930.258.camel@main>

On Sat, 2003-06-14 at 18:02, Fedor Pikus wrote:
> I think the correlation between the suburban life and script kiddies is an
> interesting idea. After all, we can all agree for sure that there are much
> more script kiddies in affluent suburbs than in urban areas. 

I'm not sure that I fully agree with this. Although this seems feasible
I think that it lacks substance necessary to make a convincing argument.
After all, not every kid in an urban setting needs to rely on peer
membership for survival.

> Walk through downtown Los Angeles, after 6 pm. Do any of these teens look like script
> kiddies to you? Do you think any of them is about to head home and sit in
> front of the computer with their rootkits and exploits?

We are assuming that the individuals in which you speak of don't have
Internet access at breakfast or in the computer lab in school (which,
incidentally, is where most of my incoming scans come from - high school
and college labs). Besides, what exactly does a script-kiddie look like
to you, Marilyn Manson, John Ashcroft?

>  No, they have an active social life and human interactions. They form very close and
> tight-knit communities where they come to spend most of their time,
> socialize, and even depend on one another for their very survival.

You don't need to iterate this to me but there are some on the list that
could benefit from the knowledge that a month in Santa Ana would put the
burbs of Anytown Oregon in a much different perspective.

> >From here, it's a simple and straightforward reasoning to conclude that
> the suburban life has turned the script kiddies into what they are.

But the script-kiddies are just what they were five or more years ago,
nothing to worry about if you know how to protect yourself. I see no
difference between now and then except that the tools are getting
better, as are all software tools.

Sorry my friend, the argument is weak.
--

> you use precompiled glibc and gcc for your platform - they are generally 
> optimized for each generation of processor.)
>

From mhopcroft at seraphimguard.com  Sun Jun 15 11:56:03 2003

Date: Sun Jun 15 11:56:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Class and.or tutoring in Red Hat 9
Message-ID: <1055703330.19822.15.camel@localhost.localdomain>

	I have come to the conclusion that I am going to need to either take a
seminar or get some tutoring in Red Hat 9 to use at its greatest
effectiveness. There is a learning curve with all operating systems, and
I am slamming into the wall on this one. The problem I've encountered is
that none of the technicians I've discussed my problems with in the past
in more detail have been all that familiar with Red Hat and its
proprietary elements themselves.
	Are there Red Hat users on this list at all, or is everyone using some
other distro? Is there any way to change distros of Linux without losing
either the file structure or the files themselves if it comes right down
to it having to?
	But if I keep Red Hat 9, I have to learn how to install and upgrade
software, preferably so it shows up in the GUI menus (the one piece of
software I've successfully installed, an AV player, does not show up in
any of the menus on the interface. I have to type in the filename
whenever I want to use it.)
	Does anyone know of either a weekend seminar I can attend or a tutor
who will come over and teach me the fundamentals? Alternatively, is
there a really good manual for Red Hat 9 that assumes the user is an
absolute beginner with Linux? (I bought a book called "Linux for Windows
System Administrators". Problem is I'm an 'end-user".....)




From jeme at brelin.net  Sun Jun 15 12:07:03 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sun Jun 15 12:07:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Class and.or tutoring in Red Hat 9
In-Reply-To: <1055703330.19822.15.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1055703330.19822.15.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306151204380.31137@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sun, 15 Jun 2003, Michael Hopcroft wrote:
> 	Are there Red Hat users on this list at all, or is everyone using
> some other distro?

That's kind of hilarious because those of us who don't use Red Hat stuff
sometimes feel like that's all anybody on this list uses.

> Is there any way to change distros of Linux without losing either the
> file structure or the files themselves if it comes right down to it
> having to?

Are you concerned with stuff outside /home?

It's pretty easy to just move the stuff you don't want touched at all to
another partition and just wipe the standing installation.  MOST of your
config files and all of your data files will be just fine after the
change.

If you're looking for ease of administration, I'd recommend a Debian
system, though you should recognize that a stable Debian distribution is
going to keep you within a stable, secure set of programs (tens of
thousands of them, of course) and you'll have to work a little to be on
the bleeding edge of software revision.

J.

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Sun Jun 15 12:51:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Sun Jun 15 12:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Class and.or tutoring in Red Hat 9
In-Reply-To: <1055704613.19822.27.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1055703330.19822.15.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306151204380.31137@shaft.bitmine.net>
	 <1055704613.19822.27.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1055706616.5304.59.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Sun, 2003-06-15 at 12:16, Michael Hopcroft wrote:

> I have yet to encounter a Red Hat user on this list. Maybe they simply
> don't post.

No, there are plenty people here who use Red Hat.   A number of the
people I see posting I know from familiarity run Red Hat.  If it's
because no one answered, your questions, well, maybe the people who know
don't have time or inclination.  You might, however, try Red Hat's
mailing lists, which are pretty busy.

> If I can install the latest editions of OpenOffice.org, Scribus (a DTP
> program native to linux) and Adobe Acrobat Reader (for some reason there
> are some .pdf files the other PDF readers won't handle).

There's nothing terribly RH-specific about installing these; the problem
you're having adding them to the menu is, I think, that there isn't a
graphic menu editor for GNOME like there is for KDE.  (At least, if
there is, I haven't found it.)  The actual means of adding to the main
menu is difficult; actually, I think you just have to add your own
Drawer to the Panel for custom Launchers.  If you right click on the
Panel (in a blank area), "Add to Panel" -> "Launcher", then fill in the
name, executable name, and select an icon, it'll create it on the Panel,
which you can then drag into your own Drawer.  I just a custom Drawer to
keep the handful of applications I actually use in.

I wouldn't bother trying to upgrade to the latest OOo, unless the new
version has something you really need.  I tried to upgrade to the Ximian
edition, but it crashes consistently when trying to save in the native
OOo formats (they had the "brilliant" notion of changes the defaults to
MS Office formats), so don't try to install that one either, unless
you're prepared to revert.  (It doesn't seem to happen to everyone, or
they'd have fixed it by now, I guess.)

You might also consider a subscription to Ximian Red Carpet; the paid
version of the service will let you install a number of common
proprietary applications, like Acrobat.  That will, at least, fix the
problem of creating menu entries.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

*     Tired of spam and viruses in your e-mail?  Get the     *

From ed at alcpress.com  Sun Jun 15 13:13:01 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Sun Jun 15 13:13:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Class and.or tutoring in Red Hat 9
In-Reply-To: <1055703330.19822.15.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1055703330.19822.15.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1055707912.16225.33.camel@red>

I'm convinced that Red Hat is the worst distribution to
use if you're trying to learn _Linux_. There are far
too many Red Hat-specific things that conflict with
learning materials, documentation, common practice, etc.

It's best to learn _Linux_ using a distribution like
Debian or Slackware (or anything else besides Red Hat).
Once you're reasonably up to speed on Linux, then
install Red Hat and learn how it is different.

Note that you can install more than one distribution on
your hard disk. You can install, say, Red Hat Linux and
Debian Linux. Boot into Red Hat Linux for doing your
desktop publishing and into Debian for learning Linux
and everything else.

As you learn more about Linux, you'll realize that your
choice of a distribution grows less important. Experience
and knowledge allows you to do things yourself rather
than relying on a vendor.

Naturally, there are people on this list who love Red Hat
Linux and will disagree with me. Their opinions are
important as well. Welcome to the freedom of choice.

Ed

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sun Jun 15 14:43:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sun Jun 15 14:43:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Class and.or tutoring in Red Hat 9
In-Reply-To: <1055707912.16225.33.camel@red>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306151428210.18634-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On 15 Jun 2003, Ed Sawicki wrote:

> I'm convinced that Red Hat is the worst distribution to use if
> you're trying to learn _Linux_. There are far too many Red
> Hat-specific things that conflict with learning materials,
> documentation, common practice, etc.
> 
> It's best to learn _Linux_ using a distribution like Debian or
> Slackware (or anything else besides Red Hat). Once you're reasonably
> up to speed on Linux, then install Red Hat and learn how it is
> different.

I don't know if Red Hat is the 'worst' in this regard, but I tend to
agree with Ed that Debian feels more specifically Linux-like than Red
Hat. (I haven't used Slackware for about six years, so I'm not really
qualified to comment on it.)

Whether that's good or bad, however, isn't necessarily clear. I work 
in a mixed Solaris/Linux environment, and I really appreciate Red Hat 
for being more Unix-like than Linux-like. There are things I really 
like about the Linux-ness of Debian, too, but the generic Unix feel of 
Red Hat sits well with me.

Your mileage, of course, may vary.

> As you learn more about Linux, you'll realize that your choice of a
> distribution grows less important. Experience and knowledge allows
> you to do things yourself rather than relying on a vendor.

That's true as a user -- though as an admin, I'm somewhat chagrined at 
how Red Hat-specific many of my home-brewed scripts are. I've thought 
about trying to integrate Debian or Slackware into our common Unix 
infrastructure at work, and I realize that it's a nontrivial task to

* set up the local distro mirror
* write/learn the tools to keep said mirror up to date
* write/learn the tools to do hands-off installation and first-time 
  configuration
* write scripts to get the local package manager to safely report
  on the state of the local system vis-a-vis the central mirror
* figure out how to model the distribution-specific stuff in our 
  cfengine rules

None of this is particularly hard, but getting it to work in such a 
way that it handles errors gracefully is more than a little time 
consuming.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Sun Jun 15 15:23:02 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor Pikus)
Date: Sun Jun 15 15:23:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Class and.or tutoring in Red Hat 9
In-Reply-To: <1055714296.16225.39.camel@red>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0306151514250.13086-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

On 15 Jun 2003, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> Is Red Hat more Unix-like or more Solaris-like - or both?
> I rarely use Solaris so I don't know.
Among Unix (non-Linux) users, Solaris has gained reputaion of being "The Unix",
and if another Unix does something differently, then that Unix is "just weird".
It's not entirely deserved, but well entrenched. For example, for a long time
Solaris threading support was the standard everyone else was measured
against. It was also the best-working one. You developed a multithreaded
application on Solaris, then, if you ran it on another OS and it did not work,
you knew with almost absolute certainty that their threads are broken.
Then IBM came out with a new threading model, which is much easier to work with
and in general provides superior performance. But it does not behave quite
the same way as Solaris. Guess what? It's "that weird threading library from
AIX", and the one from Solaris is still the golden standard.

> I'm curious. Do you use Red Hat for both servers and workstations?
I do.

-- 
                                  Fedor G. Pikus
Mentor Graphics Corporation         | Phone: (503) 685-4857
8405 SW Boeckman Road               | FAX:   (503) 685-1239
Wilsonville, Oregon 97070           | http://www.pikus.net/~pikus/

  I do believe, Ed, that you've hit on the major stumbling block of those
who defenestrate and leave the One True Way of Redmond behind. With linux
(and, I presume, all unices) we all can arrange everything to work as _we_
want it to.

  Rembember when the Berlin Wall came down and the East Germans didn't know
what to do with their freedom and choices? It's the same in Afganistan and
Iraq. Simple things like deciding on what you want to be when you grow up,
where you want to live, and what you like are all decisions that were made
for folks before by the central governments. Well, the analogy with OSes
holds.

  I'm learning the differences between Slackware and Red Hat. Can't say
one's better than the other (well, for my needs I can), but that's why we
have a gazillion different distributions.

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Sun Jun 15 17:48:02 2003
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Sun Jun 15 17:48:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Class and.or tutoring in Red Hat 9
In-Reply-To: <1055703330.19822.15.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1055703330.19822.15.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <200306151757.03089.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

On Sunday 15 June 2003 11:55 am, Michael Hopcroft wrote:
>  Does anyone know of either a weekend seminar I can attend or a tutor
> who will come over and teach me the fundamentals? Alternatively, is
> there a really good manual for Red Hat 9 that assumes the user is an
> absolute beginner with Linux?

So, given the number of under/unemployed persons here, this sounds like a nice 
little opportunity. I'd love to lend a hand, but commuting from Eastern 
Oregon is a bit much. :)

Have you looked at the manuals that come with Red Hat? I think they are very 
good. Hard copies come with the boxed sets, and also the complete set is 
available somewheres on redhat.com. I recommend starting there. As Ed pointed 
out, Red Hat does things their own way, so starting with the RH manuals will 
get you up and running faster than anything else.

Red Hat has a habit of changing things with every release, so you really want 
the manuals for your specific release.

Another thing to keep in mind is most of the software is third-party, such as 
the window managers & desktop environments. The RH manuals will help some 
with those, for deeper knowledge visit their various web sites. Sign up for 
support lists wherever you can, for example KDE has its own lists, you'll get 
better help there than on a general list like PLUG.

-- 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Carla Schroder
www.tuxcomputing.com
this message brought to you
by Libranet 2.7 and Kmail
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Well, I have answered your questions as best I could, as have others on this
list. In fact I have spent a number of hours doing research and sending you
emails privately off this list. Apparently you were using other people on
this list the same way, and none of us "fit the bill". I feel used... I even
emailed LEXMARK TECH SUPPORT FOR YOU! I'm breaking up with you....

I am almost offended by this - I spent over 3 hours last week trying to help
you - I told you I do not have a lot of money, and I reiterated that I keep
myself fed by supporting people on a contract basis. You seemed desperate,
so I decided to help the best I could for free over the e-wire. Research,
time spent in emails, a little more research - that's $120, please.. Just
kidding... Anyway.. I kept running up against the fact that you had not
*seemed* to do any research at all. Judging from your posts you seem to be
well spoken and half-way intellegent, so perhaps your problems are not
coming from our inability to help you but from your unwillingness to help
yourself? Did you ever, even once, RTM? (read the manual?) With your xmms
problem (not playing mp3s) - if you had gone to the xmms website you would
find, this:

      Red Hat 9 Apr 01, 2003
      The mpg123 plugin for Red Hat 9 can be downloaded here. This plugin is
needed to play mp3 files.


Why do I post here, you might ask? Simple - sometimes people just need a
"nudge". A little pointer in the right direction brings a ton of help.. None
of my friends have any technical skill and this seemed a great place to
network and find a group of people who have similiar skills. My brain was
stagnating (technically)...... I am not a free tutor - there are other
people on this list who run a great workshop that will help you install your
distro of choice and also teach you a little about what you need to know.

> Are there Red Hat users on this list at all, or is everyone using some
> other distro? Is there any way to change distros of Linux without losing
> either the file structure or the files themselves if it comes right down
> to it having to?

I do not run Redhat, though I am fairly familiar with Red Hat 7.3 (and a
little with 8.) Most of the problems you were having were pretty general.
You were wanting to know how to install RPMs - I and others told you how to
do this. You were having problems with XMMS and the redhat decision - we,
once again, showed you The Path To Knowledge. Did this not work? Apparently
not. What was the error? Maybe now you see my frustration?????????

Redhat is the closest thing you will get to a commerical distro. They offer
excellent support options. If you PURCHASE redhat 9 you get 30 days of free
support/installation help.

Let me guess, you don't want to lose the 1000 emails you had to download?
Stick it out - the learning curve is not as steep as you might think, if you
try and learn (even a little.....) We can't carry you up the mountain.

> But if I keep Red Hat 9, I have to learn how to install and upgrade
> software, preferably so it shows up in the GUI menus (the one piece of
> software I've successfully installed, an AV player, does not show up in
> any of the menus on the interface. I have to type in the filename
> whenever I want to use it.)

When I was using Redhat 7.3 almost every piece of software I installed via
RPM DID install a menu entry. Perhaps things have changed - perhaps that is
why you are asking for a "redhat user". Stick it out - switching now will
only make things more confusing... (Maybe you are not looking in the right
spot for the item? Perhaps it is a KDE program and it is under the KDE
menu?)

> Does anyone know of either a weekend seminar I can attend or a tutor
> who will come over and teach me the fundamentals? Alternatively, is
> there a really good manual for Red Hat 9 that assumes the user is an
> absolute beginner with Linux? (I bought a book called "Linux for Windows
> System Administrators". Problem is I'm an 'end-user".....)

There are really thick books available at Borders, Powells, Barnes And
Noble, etc.. (i.e. any new book store that has a tech section). Once again,
only you will know whether or not it is good as only you seem to know where
your problems lie. Why don't you run down to the store and check out the
books for yourself? Only you know what you need.

Whether or not you run windoze XX or GNU/anything, you are administering
your system yourself (unless you are at work and you are not the admin.)
That is the problem that you are having - you think that you should not have
to get your hands dirty. YOU are administring your system, we are merely a
knowledgebase/moral support. You just jumped headfirst into a sticky
situation and you are asking for help in learning to escape and navigate.
Please remember this - you are asking for help in LEARNING - not for an
administrator.. Switching distros to something else is not going to solve
the problems I mentioned above. You, not I, must study and find the answers
to problems. If you have trouble implementing those answers, feel free to
ask me for help again. I will be more than willing to help you!

Matt

(PS - this email may sound harsh, but anyone interested may see a copy of
the emails exchanged between Michael and myself.)

Redhat always offers you your choice of WM (i.e. kde vs. gnome).. It is up
to you to decide which you want to use. I know for a fact Redhat 7/8/9 all
came with both KDE and gnome.. Perhaps it is you who has not used the same
WM for two consecutive releases?

> How can newbies learn Linux when the system is changing
> all the time?

Stick with a release - Redhat 8 is no better or worse than Redhat 9. You can
then say, "Well then the newbie won't have the most up2date release, just
up2date security patches.."  How many newbies know the difference between
tried and true and bleeding edge? (Other than the amount of crashing.)

> Much of what you learn today will be different tomorrow.

As is true with any sort of highly technical and evolving profession. Ask
your doctor how many hours a week he spends in either continuing eductation
or reading medical journals, etc.....

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Sun Jun 15 18:16:02 2003
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Sun Jun 15 18:16:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Class and.or tutoring in Red Hat 9
In-Reply-To: <1055725140.16226.55.camel@red>
References: <1055703330.19822.15.camel@localhost.localdomain> <200306151757.03089.pluglist@bratgrrl.com> <1055725140.16226.55.camel@red>
Message-ID: <200306151824.30712.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

On Sunday 15 June 2003 5:59 pm, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> On Sun, 2003-06-15 at 17:57, Carla Schroder wrote:
> > Red Hat has a habit of changing things with every release, so you really
> > want the manuals for your specific release.
>
> Amen on that. Has Red Hat ever used the same window manager
> for more than two consecutive releases?
> Few things are more worthless than old Red Hat manuals.
>
> How can newbies learn Linux when the system is changing
> all the time?
> Much of what you learn today will be different tomorrow.

I see Red Hat as the bleeding-edge Linux, the one that pushes development 
forward. If it weren't for Red Hat, I think a lot of things would not have 
advanced as quickly or as far as they have- like RPM, Unicode support, Xfree, 
gcc, and other stuff I forget now. Every distro does things its own way- 
Mandrake, Slack, SuSE, Debian, Gentoo, etc- there is no "universal Linux". 
This is the great strength of Linux, though it can be a bit daunting when 
you're getting started.

Remember also Red Hat funds a considerable amount of Linux development. Kernel 
hackers gotta eat too! I think their low-end/free-download releases are more 
for testing new things, and to get people to use them. Their high-end server 
products are more stable and consistent, and obviously are the real 
revenue-generators for the company.

As others have pointed out in this thread, there are no bad Linuxes, just 
different ones.

-- 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Carla Schroder
www.tuxcomputing.com
this message brought to you
by Libranet 2.7 and Kmail

you like being on the cutting edge and your boss doesn't care
that you can't fix problems quickly because you have to learn
the new version of Red Hat.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sun Jun 15 19:38:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sun Jun 15 19:38:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Class and.or tutoring in Red Hat 9
In-Reply-To: <1055714296.16225.39.camel@red>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306151926300.30816-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On 15 Jun 2003, Ed Sawicki wrote:

> Is Red Hat more Unix-like or more Solaris-like - or both?
> I rarely use Solaris so I don't know.

I think Fedor answered that as well as I could, so ... er ... "what he 
said!" :-)

> I'm chagrined at how my scripts are so specific to my view of the
> way I think things _should_ be. If I ever get a job in a Linux shop,
> I'll have to change my evil ways.

It's my turn to be curious: in what way is your view of the way things 
should be evil?

> I'm curious. Do you use Red Hat for both servers and workstations?

Yep. Given the cavernous size of local hard drives these days, I
basically have two profiles: login server and infrastructure server.
The first might be a shared server or a personal workstation, but it 
essentially comes with all manner of user applications and development 
tools. The latter has restricted login rights (admins only), typically 
doesn't have much (if any) X stuff, has few development tools, and 
only the apps/daemons it needs to fulfill its niche in the network 
ecosystem.

Combine Red Hat's kickstart system with cfengine and Eric Harrison's
nice tips on maintaining a fully patched install tree using the
anaconda tools, et voila! It takes me well under an hour to bring a
machine online, fully patched and configured for our environment. 
Server or workstation, it doesn't matter...

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From ed at alcpress.com  Sun Jun 15 20:13:01 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Sun Jun 15 20:13:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Class and.or tutoring in Red Hat 9
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306151926300.30816-100000@pecos.madboa.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306151926300.30816-100000@pecos.madboa.com>
Message-ID: <1055733132.16226.98.camel@red>

On Sun, 2003-06-15 at 19:37, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On 15 Jun 2003, Ed Sawicki wrote:

> > I'm chagrined at how my scripts are so specific to my view of the
> > way I think things _should_ be. If I ever get a job in a Linux shop,
> > I'll have to change my evil ways.
> 
> It's my turn to be curious: in what way is your view of the way things 
> should be evil?

It's evil because it's not mainstream; it's not the way the
rest of admindom does it. Of course, I don't teach this in
classes.

I tend to be a minimalist and an advocate of simplicity.
Layers of abstraction that exist only to compensate for
a lack of knowledge on the part of the admin and/or
increased complexity for little benefit are annoying to
me.

The best example is /etc/sysconfig - that's another
learning curve and for what benefit? If I have to set
a default route, I can do it with one simple command. I
don't want to have to remember which file in which
directory contains the GATEWAY parameter. If /etc/sysconfig
eliminated the need to know how to use the route command, I
could acknowledge a benefit, but you have to know the route
command anyway - unless you want to call a consultant
every time you have a network problem (back to billable hours).

I also prefer BSD-style startup. Everything is is one
directory and I can easily and quickly adjust the scripts
to accomplish whatever I need to do. No chasing your tail
across directories. Of course, SystemV startup is not
difficult to master so I don't complain too loudly. BSD-style
is a minor preference. However, when you marry SystemV-style
startup with /etc/sysconfig, it gets ugly and I complain
more loudly.


-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>
ALC




From m at pdxlug.org  Sun Jun 15 21:50:02 2003
From: m at pdxlug.org (m at pdxlug.org)
Date: Sun Jun 15 21:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Class and.or tutoring in Red Hat 9
In-Reply-To: <1055733132.16226.98.camel@red>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306151926300.30816-100000@pecos.madboa.com> 
     <1055733132.16226.98.camel@red>
Message-ID: <6572.68.96.48.205.1055738995.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>

> On 15 Jun 2003, Ed Sawicki wrote:
>
> The best example is /etc/sysconfig - that's another
> learning curve and for what benefit? If I have to set
> a default route, I can do it with one simple command. I
> don't want to have to remember which file in which
> directory contains the GATEWAY parameter.

Errr...  OK, so you use the route command everytime your system starts up?
 Wouldn't it be convenient to store those network settings in a file?  I
personally like /etc/sysconfig because it's a central location where most
system/network variables are stored.  The rc scripts then parse their
appropriate config file in this directory for setting various parameters. 
In any case, even if you didn't know where to set the GATEWAY parameter
you could quickly scan through the network rc script, just like you would
on any other *nix.
~M



From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Sun Jun 15 22:51:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Sun Jun 15 22:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Class and.or tutoring in Red Hat 9
In-Reply-To: <1055733132.16226.98.camel@red>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306151926300.30816-100000@pecos.madboa.com>
	 <1055733132.16226.98.camel@red>
Message-ID: <1055742642.5304.111.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Sun, 2003-06-15 at 20:12, Ed Sawicki wrote:

> I also prefer BSD-style startup. Everything is is one
> directory and I can easily and quickly adjust the scripts
> to accomplish whatever I need to do. No chasing your tail
> across directories. Of course, SystemV startup is not
> difficult to master so I don't complain too loudly. BSD-style
> is a minor preference. However, when you marry SystemV-style
> startup with /etc/sysconfig, it gets ugly and I complain
> more loudly.

Hm, I might argue the SysV init sucks without /etc/sysconfig.  When
written correctly, I have a good deal of control over the init scripts
and the processes they start, without diverging significantly from the
standard installation.  I can do it more easily than I can with the
rc.conf approach, especially programmatically.  I can be more confident
that my script to, say, configure BIND to run chrooted will work as it's
supposed to and more importantly, not mess anything else up.  The
'network-scripts' part can be a little hairy, especially if you're not
working with Ethernet interfaces and if you're not using the Red Hat
tools to set it up.  But I find basic actions like renumbering an
interface to be much easier with the sysconfig approach--I edit the
ifcfg-ifaceX file, ifdown ifaceX; ifup ifaceX.  I know that a) The
running machine has the new IP address and b) It will work on reboot.

The SysV approach for process initialization I also really like.  I like
being able to start and stop and restart daemons with easy commands. 
With BSD, I have to read through its init portion, sometimes actually
figuring out what a complex shell script is doing, and stop it and start
it.  With the SysV approach (and the 'service' command, which might be
RH-specific), I can easily stop and start a daemon.  With the
'chkconfig' command, I can easily set it to start or not (and I can
easily grep for the commands that do or don't start).  The lack of a
'chkconfig' command really aggravates me about Solaris too; I have to
sort through the scripts and figure out where to make the appropriate
symlink and look through the directories to figure out what's starting
and what's not (and SCO OpenServer [may it rot in hell] is even worse).

And if I install a piece of software, what's the appropriate way to
configure it to start or not?  With BSD, it's either a) Put it in
rc.local or b) put it in /usr/local/etc/something, and I also have to
figure out whether its a "system" daemon or port/package/tarball daemon,
so it may or may not be set to start through rc.conf.  (Not to mention
if you're upgrading a system daemon with one installed separately.) 
With a SysV system, you drop a script into /etc/init.d and possibly an
init config file in /etc/sysconfig and you've done a good deal of work
that the sys admin doesn't have to do and you've given yourself or
people who will write tools for your daemon a good headstart.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
