I run gentoo on my server which is currently hosting two domains, both email
and www. I run WinXP/gentoo on my desktop (Sometimes I like games, sometimes
I wish to be productive). I cut my teeth on slackware and have tried debian.
Neither lived up to MY expectation - though they probably work well for you.
That's what makes it fun!

> you like being on the cutting edge and your boss doesn't care
> that you can't fix problems quickly because you have to learn
> the new version of Red Hat.

That's funny because I've heard people say just the opposite. In fact, I
still run across people in the gentoo forums (don't ask me why) who run an
OLD version of redhat at work and need help (old=6.x or something). They
keep it up2date and though it may not be the latest, greatest Redhat 9, it
is rock solid and works great for them still (though redhat has dropped
support for older stuff now..)

All I'm saying is it is your choice whether or not you install the latest
and greatest and possibly changed distro or whether you stick with something
you know and something that works (and take the time to keep it Secure(tm)).

Also, I'm not sure where you worked, but in my experience the SA would have
soiled his pants if we EVER upgraded any of the OS (win nt/redhat/win 98)
that we ran arbitrarily. You have to have integration testing and systems
validation to make sure product X will run product Y and blah blah blah
(stupid corporate talk for "Cover Your Ass"). Which makes my point - if you
don't do research on what you are running and don't check things out first
you are just asking to have problems you can't fix quickly (regardless of
the OS).

Just my observation.. ;-)

From michael at robinson-west.com  Mon Jun 16 01:40:02 2003
From: michael at robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Mon Jun 16 01:40:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Not airing vendor problems...
Message-ID: <1055752285.14450.133.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

It's been suggested that vendor problems should not be aired on this
list.  I haven't seen another way offered by the Portland Linux User's
Group to address this problem better.  One suggestion is a list just for
finding and dealing with vendors aside from this one.  Another point
I want to make, Linux is limited at this time by how difficult it is
to build through a licensed bonded vendor.  The purpose I see in a
vendor more than anything is to not get into troublesome or faulty
hardware in the first place and to avoid having to do all the research.

I hope many will appreciate that I want to go with 100% Linux 
compatible hardware.  I think my experience is insightful for all
those who have been pushing Salem legislation that would force
public institutions to research OSS in all purchasing decisions.
Who on this list has built a Linux only vendor or at the very least
a Linux friendly one?  EMU may be a good choice, but it is neither
in St.Helens nor in Scappoose where purchasing online all the time
isn't what I imagine most people consider ideal.  

Especially if your time matters at all.  Part of pushing and 
developing legislation is connecting it to real life situations.  

Considering Portland is rumored to lack an accredited computer
science program at PSU, I must strongly question the claim that 
Portland is the whole world.  This lack of a strong, diversified,
computer science program at PSU in my opinion is one of Portland's
biggest problems right now.

On a positive note, it looks like my vendor is going to
do enough of what I asked to end my need to go after him.

Maybe if I could know more about other people's vendor experiences
I could have fared better and saved this list from potentially
irritating posts.  Hope this satisfies anyone who considers my
posts "dirty laundry."

     --  Michael C. Robinson




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jun 16 06:26:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon Jun 16 06:26:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] header checka
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCMEGJCMAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306160610030.27121-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 16 Jun 2003, Billy Dimaculangan wrote:

> I need to filter out mails that we keep on receiving, it has
> "undisclosed-recipients: " in the to: field. How do I filter this in our
> header checks.

  You shouldn't. I asked the same question on the mail help and postfix mail
lists months ago and I was convinced that doing so will produce unintended
consequences.

  Many legitimate broadcasts are sent with all names in the Bcc: field to
ensure privacy among recipients. I know that I get legitimate mail from
organizations of which I am a member that are sent that way. So, since this
is not a good idea, what are the alternatives?

  In my postfix UCE filters I check for IP addresses and domain names I
don't want coming in. In the header_checks I have subjects, individuals and
other key phrases (such as references to the "Quicker Dicker-Upper",
appendage-enhancement drugs and other common spam topics. Then, of course,
there are the body_checks and a large list of RBLs that are checked.

  These are working extremely well for me; I guess that I average fewer than
three spam per day that sneak past the defenses. I've also taken the
suggestion posted here a couple of months ago and changed the '@' in my .sig
file and Web pages to the html code.

HTH,

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

                       Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
            2404 SW 22nd Street | Troutdale, OR 97060-1247 | U.S.A.
 + 1 503-667-4517 (voice) | + 1 503-667-8863 (fax) | rshepard&#64;appl-ecosys.com
                         http://www.appl-ecosys.com/




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jun 16 06:28:01 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon Jun 16 06:28:01 2003

I'm going to be burning a lot of music to CD from MP3 archives I've
created. In the script that I run to convert the MP3 to a wav and
normalize them, I would like to strip the title only from the filename.
Can BASH do this with the aid of SED perhaps?

>From this:

"The artist - Optional album title - Song title.mp3"

I would like to (1) strip the extension (2) Find the last " - " sequence,
and return the string from that point foreword, and (3) convert to upper
case, leaving me with:

"SONG TITLE"

Thanks in advance for your help!

From ali at axian.com  Mon Jun 16 09:02:02 2003
From: ali at axian.com (Alice Corbin)
Date: Mon Jun 16 09:02:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] BASH string manipulation
In-Reply-To: <1096.192.168.1.252.1055774736.squirrel@localhost>; from paul@lankow.net on Mon, Jun 16, 2003 at 07:45:36AM -0700
References: <1096.192.168.1.252.1055774736.squirrel@localhost>
Message-ID: <20030616090122.A25462@zaphod.axian.com>

Well, I don't know how to fiddle with the case inside of bash,
but I have done some stripping off of text.

>text="The artist - Optional album title - Song title.mp3"
>noext=${text%\.*}
>echo $noext
The artist - Optional album title - Song title
>nopre=${noext##*- }
>echo $nopre
Song title
>caps=`echo $nopre | tr a-z A-Z`
>echo $caps
SONG TITLE

From shahms at shahms.com  Mon Jun 16 09:21:01 2003
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms King)
Date: Mon Jun 16 09:21:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] re: Setting up basic X on Debian Sarge
In-Reply-To: <01C333E8.6C43D580.jorgens@coho.net>
References: <01C333E8.6C43D580.jorgens@coho.net>
Message-ID: <1055780402.6832.1.camel@ltsp.mesd.k12.or.us>

Well, from the XFree86.0.log you have there, X isn't starting because it
can't find any fonts. (Well, specifically the required font 'fixed'). 
It looks like X is configured to look for fonts from a local X Font
Server which is not running.  Assuming it's installed, you might want to
start it or add all of the font directories in /etc/X11/fs/config to
/etc/X11/XF86Config instead and see if that helps.

-- 
Shahms King <shahms at shahms.com>

locking the rpm database.

under linux. Not to say it doesn't exist, but I would say that if you buy 
modern hardware from well known manufactures, chances are (99.9%) you can get 
it to work with linux. And what the hell does this have to do with OSS?? 
People have a right to pick and choose - he picked and chose, you either deal 
with it or "strong-arm" him like you did. Who is right? I abstain from voting 
on that.

have skyrocketed - people like you don't have to be limited by who is around 
them. Go online - there are some great and reputable stores online. You can 
order overnight. Impatient? Don't want to wait? Then quit complaining and 
deal with what you have.

> Especially if your time matters at all.  Part of pushing and
> developing legislation is connecting it to real life situations.

My friend, if politicians thought like you would we have laws that state "Do 
not put ice cream cones in your pants pockets?" (virginia).. No, generally 
legislation COMES from real life situations that, errr,  "require" action. 
Like the law that says you can't put squirrels down your pants for the 
purposes of gambling (Once again, virginia). What the hell prompted THAT 
law???

This is why the OSS law is fizzling - some people (though small %) actually do 
use OSS in state govt - why make a law for it? If there was NO OSS in state 
govt I bet this law would have been passed in a heartbeat.. MS is no fool.

Portland is my whole world.. I live here and don't have a car so I leave VERY 
rarely. And what is your definition of diversified? Portland *seems* to be 
turning into the heart of OSS on the west coast. I don't know man, I didn't 
do it.

> On a positive note, it looks like my vendor is going to
> do enough of what I asked to end my need to go after him.

Congratulations, strong-arm tactics worked. Perhaps you would be better server 
reading the bill gates story the next time you are working on your 
legislation.

From mikeraz at patch.com  Mon Jun 16 09:36:02 2003
From: mikeraz at patch.com (Michael Rasmussen)
Date: Mon Jun 16 09:36:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] BASH string manipulation
In-Reply-To: <1096.192.168.1.252.1055774736.squirrel@localhost>
References: <1096.192.168.1.252.1055774736.squirrel@localhost>
Message-ID: <20030616163415.GD17176@patch.com>

If you're not allergic to perl:

   #!/usr/bin/perl
   
   $name = $ARGV[0];
   $name =~ s/.* - //;
   $name =~ s/.mp3//;
   print uc $name, "\n";


There's better ways to do it than that . . .

From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Mon Jun 16 09:42:01 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Mon Jun 16 09:42:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] re: Setting up basic X on Debian Sarge
In-Reply-To: <01C333E8.6C43D580.jorgens@coho.net>
References: <01C333E8.6C43D580.jorgens@coho.net>
Message-ID: <200306160942.16173.matt@legalizefreedom.org>

A ton of errors, lets deal with the first "fatal" - Are you using fontdirs or 
xfs (X font server)? According to the logs X cannot find any fonts to use for 
a mandatory type (fixed). There are also no fonts listed that it finds.

If you are using xfs change the path to read unix/:0 If you are using xfs, 
remove the fontdirs. If you are using fontdirs, remove the unix/: line.  
Check to make sure that /usr/lib/X11/fonts/Type1 and any others you may need 
exist (i.e. 100dpi, 75dpi, CID, Speedo, lcal, truetypes and any others you 
may have installed.)

M

From paul at lankow.net  Mon Jun 16 10:12:02 2003
From: paul at lankow.net (Paul Lankow)
Date: Mon Jun 16 10:12:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] BASH string manipulation
In-Reply-To: <20030616090122.A25462@zaphod.axian.com>
References: <1096.192.168.1.252.1055774736.squirrel@localhost>
 <20030616090122.A25462@zaphod.axian.com>
Message-ID: <1284.192.168.1.252.1055783327.squirrel@localhost>

Thanks, Ali.

 for F in *.[Mm][Pp]3 ; do           # Find each .mp3 file
   echo "Converting $F"              # Show what we're working on
   WF=`echo $F | tr a-z A-Z`         # Convert to upper case
   WF=${WF%\.*}                      # Strip extension
   WF=${WF##*- }                     # Extract song title
   WF="$WF".WAV                      # Complete the new filename
   echo "Creating $WF"               # Show resulting filename
   mpg123 -w /storage/wav/"$WF" "$F" # Create a wav file from mp3
 done

Works great. :-)

Regards,
Paul

> Well, I don't know how to fiddle with the case inside of bash,
> but I have done some stripping off of text.
>
>>text="The artist - Optional album title - Song title.mp3"
>>noext=${text%\.*}
>>echo $noext
> The artist - Optional album title - Song title
>>nopre=${noext##*- }
>>echo $nopre
> Song title
>>caps=`echo $nopre | tr a-z A-Z`
>>echo $caps
> SONG TITLE

From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Jun 16 13:34:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Mon Jun 16 13:34:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] BASH string manipulation
In-Reply-To: <1284.192.168.1.252.1055783327.squirrel@localhost>
References: <1096.192.168.1.252.1055774736.squirrel@localhost>
 <20030616090122.A25462@zaphod.axian.com> <1284.192.168.1.252.1055783327.squirrel@localhost>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306161315010.17804@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 16 Jun 2003, Paul Lankow wrote:
> Thanks, Ali.
>
>  for F in *.[Mm][Pp]3 ; do           # Find each .mp3 file
>    echo "Converting $F"              # Show what we're working on
>    WF=`echo $F | tr a-z A-Z`         # Convert to upper case
>    WF=${WF%\.*}                      # Strip extension
>    WF=${WF##*- }                     # Extract song title
>    WF="$WF".WAV                      # Complete the new filename
>    echo "Creating $WF"               # Show resulting filename
>    mpg123 -w /storage/wav/"$WF" "$F" # Create a wav file from mp3
>  done
>
> Works great. :-)

Have you tried using some of the existing normalization tools?  I use
something called normalize with great success.

Also, instead of manipulating the filename, you could just extract the
song title from the ID3 tag with something like
echo `mp3info -p "%t" $file|sed -e 's/ /_/g'`.mp3

J.

-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

On Thu, 2003-06-12 at 10:58, cooper at cooper.stevenson.name wrote:
> > someone else wrote:

> > Since when do viruses need root to spread?
> 

vadmind or slapper worked on apache without needing to anything but the
apache user.


> Well, most viruses are email born.

This is not necessarily true.  If you allow for the blurring of
worm/virus/trojan then the most virus by number are office macros
(though there are not as many written anymore).

email is used as *one* of the methods for the nasty virii, like NIMDA,
which came in most systems via a hole in I.E. and then used local
network to attack shares, and then scanned for IIS, and then emailed.


>  Eventually Linux GUI email clients
> > will allow you to simply click the attachment to open it (for ease of
> > use).
> 
> No they won't. How long do think it would be before the news groups hammer
> an email client for allowing executables? I tell you through my experience
> there would be an outcry before the software even made it out of beta.
> 


Most modern clients will launch an app based on MIME type, today. 
Word/Openoffice/pdf holes can be access with a click.  If these
corresponding apps have holes, then the malware wins.


...

> Even barring that, because it's Open Source you can do something about it.
> Nobody in the Linux community wants to be considered "stupid" for allowing
> GUI's to run code from an unknown source. Believe it or not, there are
> solid security design principles that are well known to the security
> community, and they won't hesitate to let a developer know when their code
> is not up to current security engineering practices.
> 

Still Mozilla, ghostscript, bind, sendmail and others have made errors. 
They are not perfect.  Plenty of people have chosen designs that are
stupid.


> You could turn the tables for an NT2000 system by saying, "Yeah, Bob from
> the Windows list said that I only had to run this service_pack.exe as
> Administrator to fix the system. Cool, Windows isn't so bad."
> 

This was a recent malware.....

> Mandatory access control helps solve even this type of issue.
> 

For a enterprise desktop solution this would help!


-- 
Zot O'Connor

http://www.ZotConsulting.com
http://www.WhiteKnightHackers.com

From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Jun 16 15:45:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Mon Jun 16 15:45:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] BASH string manipulation
In-Reply-To: <1689.192.168.1.252.1055802573.squirrel@localhost>
References: <1096.192.168.1.252.1055774736.squirrel@localhost> <"20030616090122.A254
 62"@zaphod.axian.com> <1284.192.168.1.252.1055783327.squirrel@localhost>
 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306161315010.17804@shaft.bitmine.net>
 <1689.192.168.1.252.1055802573.squirrel@localhost>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306161539230.22189@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 16 Jun 2003, Paul Lankow wrote:
> > Have you tried using some of the existing normalization tools?  I use
> > something called normalize with great success.
>
> Yes, the next step in that very script changes to the destination
> directory to run "normalize *.WAV" - it's great since the volume level
> on my MP3 collection can really very. Have you found a difference in
> volume level consistency when you normalize one at a time vs. batch
> normalization like I do?

There is a difference, that's why there's both a -b and a -m.  -b is batch
mode for multiple files, but it assumes that all of the tracks are volume
balanced as though they were ripped from the same album.  -m is mix mode
and attempts to reset the volume level for each track after scanning them
all.

Which mode are you using and to what effect?

> > Also, instead of manipulating the filename, you could just extract the
> > song title from the ID3 tag with something like
> > echo `mp3info -p "%t" $file|sed -e 's/ /_/g'`.mp3
>
> Most of these files were downloaded from (shared by) collector's PC's,
> so the tags aren't reliable. I appreciate the code, though. I'm sure I
> can put it to good use in some project. If nothing else, it could help
> me identify those files that need some ID3 tag work.

Retagging MP3s is a pain, but it's really helpful when you want to
dynamically or automatically generate playlists and stuff.

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------

 http://www.openlaw.org



From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Mon Jun 16 16:14:02 2003
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Mon Jun 16 16:14:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Microsoft to kill popular Linux antivirus product (fwd)
In-Reply-To: <1055429943.1199.148.camel@red>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306120622540.23862-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	 <1055429943.1199.148.camel@red>
Message-ID: <1055805331.1780.4381.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

On Thu, 2003-06-12 at 07:59, Ed Sawicki wrote:

> I can't seem to come up with a scenario where I would
> care about this. Nothing I do here makes me vulnerable
> to viruses. My email program doesn't automatically run
> binary attachments, javascript, etc. 
> Is there a vulnerability I don't see?

Unix email in the past have had header issues like Outlook.  Mutt, mh,
pine all have been vulnerable to header attacks.

So if you update constantly, and are 100% sure no one is every going to
run out of date software (to the day), then no.

I think a good chunk of the people on this list fit that description.

On the other hand if you are running older versions of mozilla mail, or
mutt, or pine, then a vulnerability may come out.  A virus scanner on
the emails will catch (based on updated signatures) new attacks on old
software.

There is still the social engineering attacks, some of which the virus
writers have used, albeit poorly.

-- 
Zot O'Connor

http://www.ZotConsulting.com
http://www.WhiteKnightHackers.com

From mhopcroft at seraphimguard.com  Mon Jun 16 19:37:02 2003

Subject: [PLUG] A matgter of netiquette

	I;ve missed about two days' worth of posts, because after reading
Matt's comments in public to the list about our ongoing interaction I
immediately felt so ashamed of myself that I unsubscribed from the list.
Right then and there, without a moment's hesitation. Then i wrote
privately to all the people who had offered advice in the posts I had
received thus far, thanking them for listening to me and telling them
how essentially frustrated I was with the whole process. Except for
Matt, they all told me I should resubscribe forthwith if i wanted to get
the right kind fo advice. So that's what I did.

	I still feel I violated netiquette at some point, but I don't think
Matt was entirely blameless either. I didn;t expect him to publicly
explode like that, and offering to give away our private correspondence
to all and sundry struck me as somewhat beyond the pale, especially as
he was willing to do so just to make a point.

	It wasn't really necessary to make a point like that. Everyone here
knows by now that, at least as far as Linux is concerned, i am a
complete newbie. That I am not a trained technician, that I am not
skilled at troubleshooting, and that when a piece of advice is
complicated or contradictory I can't gain any benefit from it. people
who talk to me about a technical matter will have to talk to me as
though I were a high school freshman -- a particularly dense high school
freshman. I don;t administer systems for a living -- I'm a writer who's
just trying to run his own computer and free himself from the Microsoft
cycle. maybe someday, with the proper experience and counsel, I'll be
able to do some of the things that other members of this list do
routinely. Right now, though, most of the system administration tasks I
attempt simply don't work. For example, I had no way of knowing the
reason i was not getting sound from any of my applications was that I
had my speakers plugged in wrong. And nobody even suggested checking my
physical connections.

	 the frustration of any of you in dealing with me pales in comparison
to my own frustration in dealing with myself. If I can;t give detailed
descriptions, it's because I don't know the descriptions myself. I
suppose this means I should stop asking questions and maybe
resubscribing myself to this list was a bad idea and a lapse of
netiquette. Tell you what  -- if anyone doesn't want me around, tell me
so by private e-mail. If I get even one such letter, i will unsubscribe
again never to return.

	Michael Hopcroft

Jun 15 23:03:42 syarchive Xprt_64: Couldn't open RGB_DB 
'usr/X11R6/lib/X11/rgb
Jun 15 23:03:43 syarchive Xprt_64: error opening security policy file 
/usr/X11R6/lib/X11/xserver/SecurityPolicy
Jun 15 23:03:43 syarchive Xprt_64:
Jun 15 23:03:43 syarchive Xprt_64: Fatal server error:
Jun 15 23:03:43 syarchive Xprt_64: could not open default font 'fixed'.

I remember the configuration sequence specifically telling me it was going 
to set up RGB and the Security Policy, and it didn't report any errors, so 
I don't know what the problem is.

Thanks,

- Steve Jorgensen




From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Mon Jun 16 23:16:02 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Mon Jun 16 23:16:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Setting up basic X on Debian Sarge
References: <01C3345B.374D0A90.jorgens@coho.net>
Message-ID: <003401c33497$de1aa4e0$1901a8c0@madcat>

Uhhhhh.. My bad.. Sorry.. Not verbose enough and the wrong information to
boot. I'm having a great day :-}

Change this line in XF86Config (or XF86Config.4, depending on your setup):

Section "Files"
               FontPath "unix/:7000"
EndSection

to

Section "Files"
               FontPath "unix/:-1"
EndSection

Sorry about that...

M

From holger at selover.net  Tue Jun 17 00:51:02 2003
From: holger at selover.net (Holger Stephan)
Date: Tue Jun 17 00:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] eBay scam
In-Reply-To: <003401c33497$de1aa4e0$1901a8c0@madcat>
References: <01C3345B.374D0A90.jorgens@coho.net> 
	<003401c33497$de1aa4e0$1901a8c0@madcat>
Message-ID: <1055836230.23440.263.camel@halo>

Please excuse a non-technical question. 

While looking at eBay to find a used VMWare license this guy sells a
bunch of current VMWare licenses for $31. After inquiring about the
legal status of these licenses he shares with me that 68% of the people
copy software anyways and selling the key that he bought is his way to
recover the costs (original mail appended). 

As one who earns his living with copyrighted IP I really feel like
turning this <german>Saftsack</german> in. Would you? And where?

Thanks

Holger

-----------------------------------------------

Hi,
There are over 68% people using copied version of
software. How many people anounces widely that they
use copied software? Not many people have enough money
to buy software. I know when i was madly looking for a
software to run windows in my linux machine. Then
after  cut down some serious expanses i saved enough
money to buy the original VMware. Isnt there people
like me who is dieing to switch to linux? Thats why i
m selling it for. 
You can still keep ur present Linux version VMware
running in ur computer with my license code. If u
think about it the auction is mainly for the license
code. Because anyone can download evalution version of
vmware from their website. If you really want you can
just pay the auction amount & i will give you the
licesne code instantly. That way u wont have to wait
for shipping. The license code will instantly unlock
the expiration date. 
What do u think?






From michael at robinson-west.com  Tue Jun 17 01:17:02 2003
From: michael at robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Tue Jun 17 01:17:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] eBay scam
In-Reply-To: <1055836230.23440.263.camel@halo>
References: <01C3345B.374D0A90.jorgens@coho.net> 
	<003401c33497$de1aa4e0$1901a8c0@madcat>  <1055836230.23440.263.camel@halo>
Message-ID: <1055837337.26819.32.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

On Tue, 2003-06-17 at 00:50, Holger Stephan wrote:
> Please excuse a non-technical question. 
> 
> While looking at eBay to find a used VMWare license this guy sells a
> bunch of current VMWare licenses for $31. After inquiring about the
> legal status of these licenses he shares with me that 68% of the people
> copy software anyways and selling the key that he bought is his way to
> recover the costs (original mail appended). 
> 
> As one who earns his living with copyrighted IP I really feel like
> turning this <german>Saftsack</german> in. Would you? And where?
> 
> Thanks
> 
> Holger

My first suggestion is to look at whether or not closed source forever
is the right thing to do for your customers and the world.  I have said
to my mother that I believe keeping a program closed is wrong
though I'll admit she's not convinced yet.  I'm looking at studying
gnucash and the palm pilot since I'm now laid off.  To make money I
may enter into a project to add a conduit to Linux so that the gnucash
and quicken lite can work together.  Thing is, I want
my code if I accomplish this project to be open yet I need to earn money
for my efforts.  I think older versions of vmware should be open
sourced, but this isn't happening.  I think the best alternative is to
work on supplying Linux directly, no emulation layer, with what it needs
to support people from Windows land.  There is some question about what
constitutes fair use with many highly restrictive licenses.  Legally
though, I don't think anyone should try to sell keys to copyrighted
software they themselves are not going to supply with those keys in
accordance with the software's license agreement.

     -- Michael C. Robinson

From sigma_x at attbi.com  Tue Jun 17 01:51:02 2003
From: sigma_x at attbi.com (Roman Robinson)
Date: Tue Jun 17 01:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Apache2, etc
Message-ID: <002501c334ad$775dac00$6501a8c0@dual>

Okay, so I have done this before! I have my main server running just fine,
and I have a copy of all the configures I have used. So I started to use
them on my friends server.. Got it (PHP, MySQL, Apache2) all installed, and
went to start Apache.. No dice! First it was giving a bind error, but that
can't be right, we have it all setup right. Now it is not giving any error,
but just won't start the server. Here is the configs:


###
# Apache
###
cd /usr/local/src &&
wget 'http://www.apache.org/dist/httpd/httpd-2.0.46.tar.gz' &&
tar -xzf httpd-2.0.46.tar.gz &&
cd httpd-2.0.46 &&
./configure --prefix=/usr/local/apache2 --enable-so &&
make &&
make install

###
# PHP
###
cd /usr/local/src &&
wget 'http://www.php.net/get/php-4.3.2.tar.gz/from/this/mirror' &&
tar -xzf php-4.3.2.tar.gz &&
cd php-4.3.2 &&
./configure --with-mysql --with-apxs2=/usr/local/apache2/bin/apxs --with-ope
nssl --with-zlib --with-jpeg-dir --with-png-dir --with-freetype --with-ttf -
-enable-ftp --enable-sockets --enable-track-vars --enable-debugger --enable-
magic-quotes &&
make &&
make install


If you can help, PLEASE DO!!!!




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Jun 17 06:38:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue Jun 17 06:38:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] eBay scam
In-Reply-To: <1055836230.23440.263.camel@halo>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306170616190.2968-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On 17 Jun 2003, Holger Stephan wrote:

> As one who earns his living with copyrighted IP I really feel like
> turning this <german>Saftsack</german> in. Would you? And where?

Holger,

  Please do turn him in to both eBay and VMware. It's illegal and it hurts
us all.

  The mis-placed idealism from some on this list is sometimes amusing and
sometimes annoying. It was the same naive idealism that resulted in
yellow-painted bicycles in downtown Portland for _everyone's_ use. Need a
ride? Take a bike and leave it for the next person. Guess what? Every single
bike was stolen and not recovered. Where's this program now in support of
"freedom of transportation"?

  How many of you have seen people pushing shopping carts stolen from
supermarkets? Do you know that those carts cost a minimum of $275 each?
Guess who's paying for the thefts? We all are in higher prices in the store.

  If you were a farmer, how would you feel about folks walking through your
fields and taking crops because everyone has the right to be fed?

  Perhaps the reason some of you are unemployed is because others with your
philosophy, values and total disregard for anyone else's rights stole the
product of the greedy, scum-sucking, filthy capitalist who employed you.
May the next language you learn include the phrases, "Do you want fries with
that?" and "Regular or premium?"

  Too many people today have either forgotten, or never learned, how to
function as a part of a society. There's an almost complete lack of
courtesy, consideration of others and a willingness to work with a group for
the betterment of all. Starting about 20 years ago the mantra used to be "me
first". Now it's "me only, and screw you, too".

  Peter Yarrow (of Peter, Paul and Mary -- go ask your parents who they are)
accurately summarized this change during their 25th anniversary concert
several years ago. He pointed out the history of American society as
reflected by the magazines available. First there was "Life". Then there was
"People". After this came "Us". Now we have "Self".

  My wish is that someday you grow up and become both responsible and
productive to society as a whole. In the meantime I'd appreciate not knowing
that you support theft and other illegal acts.

Rich

From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Tue Jun 17 07:31:01 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Tue Jun 17 07:31:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] eBay scam
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306170616190.2968-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <001801c334dc$ebe44140$1901a8c0@madcat>

I was going to break this down and respond to individual parts, but I
decided not to.

The entire argument (which, in a nutshell, is capitalism works if you work
with it) is well thought out. The problem is that, in this "global economy",
capitalism only works for those willing to steal, bully, and push the little
guy around. In fact, the entire argument's flaw can be summed up in this
line:

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Rich Shepard" <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com>
To: <plug at lists.pdxlinux.org>
Sent: Tuesday, June 17, 2003 6:37 AM
Subject: Re: [PLUG] eBay scam

[snip]
> Too many people today have either forgotten, or never learned, how to
> function as a part of a society.

I was never taught how to function as part of a coporate, ad-sponsored
society intent on selling me crap that is polluting the environment and
raping the third world. Don't blame me if I see around it and choose not to
participate.

Don't blame just the people, but corporations as well. Never forget that.
Did the family cause the family unit to break down? It functioned WELL for
humanity up until 50 years ago.. WTF happened??? Oh yes - corporate media.
Television.

[snip]
>There's an almost complete lack of
> courtesy, consideration of others and a willingness to work with a group
for
> the betterment of all. Starting about 20 years ago the mantra used to be
"me
> first". Now it's "me only, and screw you, too".

You seem to imply that it's this reason (applied to the software piracy
world) that has caused me, and thousands of others, to be unemployed. Come,
come now.. We both know it is bush, dick, and colon in the white house that
caused that.. ;-)

This line - "Me only, and screw you, too" - sums up capitalism nicely! The
dictionary def. of capitalism: an economic system based on private ownership
of capital. Notice the word private, or closed. Which means if you are not a
part of our group you do not share our wealth. This is the major problem in
the world. American Capitalism is waging rampant war on the peoples of the
world, just to make a buck. It's a private club.

How does this compare with VMWare? It doesn't - I don't think he should take
that license. This german guy WILL be caught - eventually - and Holger would
then be liable. More than likely he would be implicated in a criminal trial
as well (notice my morals correspond with "cover your ass"). Is VMWare the
cause of the wars in East Timor? The oil battles of the middle east? The
diamond genocides in Africa? The drug wars in South America? No - they are
not. But capitalism as itself is not a good enough argument not to steal.

One more, then I'm done:

[snip]
>   The mis-placed idealism from some on this list is sometimes amusing and
> sometimes annoying. It was the same naive idealism that resulted in
> yellow-painted bicycles in downtown Portland for _everyone's_ use. Need a
> ride? Take a bike and leave it for the next person. Guess what? Every
single
> bike was stolen and not recovered. Where's this program now in support of
> "freedom of transportation"?

This is communism, my friend. This has ALWAYS been at odds with capitalism.
It takes from those rich old white bastards (no offense to any rich old
white bastards in the room ;-)) sitting in their ivory towers and
distributes it fairly. It equals the odds. Our societal consciousness is too
entrenched in capitalism for a friendly communist gesture to ever work.
Linux is the first communal experiment (that I know of, on such a global
scale) to work. Which is why I'm here - and I know that MANY (though not
all) in the OSS movement are socialist/communist at heart. Microsoft? I have
no more of an issue with them then I do with Mobil/Chevron or McDonalds. I
have the SAME issue with ALL of them. STOP RAPING MY WORLD!

All I'm saying is don't just blame the people - blame the corporate media,
the corporate government, the corporations, and THEN blame the damn people
who buy into it for current societal trends.

M

> cd php-4.3.2 &&
>
./configure --with-mysql --with-apxs2=/usr/local/apache2/bin/apxs --with-ope
>
nssl --with-zlib --with-jpeg-dir --with-png-dir --with-freetype --with-ttf -
> -enable-ftp --enable-sockets --enable-track-vars --enable-debugger --enabl
e-
> magic-quotes &&
> make &&
> make install
>
>
> If you can help, PLEASE DO!!!!
>
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>

From paul at lankow.net  Tue Jun 17 07:49:02 2003
From: paul at lankow.net (Paul Lankow)
Date: Tue Jun 17 07:49:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Burning and cataloging music
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306161539230.22189@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <1096.192.168.1.252.1055774736.squirrel@localhost>

Message-ID: <2113.192.168.1.252.1055861240.squirrel@localhost>

> There is a difference, that's why there's both a -b and a -m.

Wow. Interesting MAN page -- never read it before. :-)

> Which mode are you using and to what effect?

The default, which would be -b, I would think. I don't want any averaging
so I put normalize in the loop, and let each file get normalized based on
the internal standard, rather than one set by a group.

> Retagging MP3s is a pain, but it's really helpful when you want to
> dynamically or automatically generate playlists and stuff.

Aren't there programs out there that make it fairly easy? I would think a
program could/would work on a directory at a time, listing editable tags
in a table. Know of any?

Regards,
Paul

From michael at robinson-west.com  Tue Jun 17 09:15:02 2003
From: michael at robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)

Subject: OT [PLUG] eBay scam
In-Reply-To: <001801c334dc$ebe44140$1901a8c0@madcat>

	 <001801c334dc$ebe44140$1901a8c0@madcat>

On Tue, 2003-06-17 at 07:29, Matt Chorman wrote:
> I was going to break this down and respond to individual parts, but I
> decided not to.
> 
> The entire argument (which, in a nutshell, is capitalism works if you work
> with it) is well thought out. The problem is that, in this "global economy",
> capitalism only works for those willing to steal, bully, and push the little
> guy around. In fact, the entire argument's flaw can be summed up in this
> line:
> 
The whole idea behind capitalism is that you need individual initiative
where profit can motivate that.  The problem rises when people worship
profit and don't apply values to earning it such as how it affects the
environment, what affect it has on other people's ability to earn
profit, etc.  Capitalism isn't the only model that is destroyed by
greed:  monarchy fails under greed as does communism and yes even
socialism can be leveled by it.  Atheistic communism in the former
Soviet Union said that you had to believe that the State is God and
yes people were killed to enforce this.  What the Soviet Union did to
Russian Catholics made Hitler's Auschwitz look like nothing.  Capitalism
needs to be regulated properly.  The idea of private property, insofar
as theft is wrong, is important too though fair use and competition
sometimes need protection also.  Anyways, this seems to be getting OT 
so I hope people don't take it much farther.

     --  Michael C. Robinson

From russell-evans at uswest.net  Tue Jun 17 09:18:02 2003
From: russell-evans at uswest.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Tue Jun 17 09:18:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] eBay scam
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306170616190.2968-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306170616190.2968-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <E19SJ8r-0003Gc-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

I've read the original post a few times and I keep wondering if I'm reading it
correctly. There are two cases that are very different that I can read into the
post. One, the person bought VMware and is now selling only one copy, or two,
the person bought VMware and is selling many copies. I assume a person has the
right to sell used software that the person holds a license for, to another
party, if that person isn't using the software and not keeping a copy of it. I
think there are some EULAs that specify that you can't do this, but I don't
know if there is something legal backing that. One of the reasons for using
Linux is that this type of murkiness disappears.

I can't make up my mind what the person is really saying, especially if the
person isn't a native English speaker. English aside, I've watched many, many
disputes erupt over email because what one person was posting was read
differently by a reader. The Constitution was written how long ago and we are
still arguing over what it says? I have to assume the Constitution had a lot
more thought put into it than a email and was meant to clearly state what the
author meant, yet, it is still means different things to different people.

I'm also wondering why a person looking for an illegal copy of VMware, would be
buying it on ebay. I'm assuming it can't be hard to find a VMware key via a
search on google that won't require an exchange of funds and proof of a crime.
It seems the seller would be very silly to put up illegal software. Maybe ebay,
the seller, and you could sit down and determine what this seller is really
selling? It just seems to me there isn't enough information.

Thank you
Russell

    The entire argument (which, in a nutshell, is capitalism works if you work
    with it) is well thought out. The problem is that, in this "global economy",
    capitalism only works for those willing to steal, bully, and push the little
    guy around. In fact, the entire argument's flaw can be summed up in this
    line:
    
    ----- Original Message ----- 
    From: "Rich Shepard" <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com>

    [snip]
    > Too many people today have either forgotten, or never learned, how to
    > function as a part of a society.
    
    I was never taught how to function as part of a coporate, ad-sponsored
    society intent on selling me crap that is polluting the environment and
    raping the third world. Don't blame me if I see around it and choose not to
    participate.
    
    Don't blame just the people, but corporations as well. Never forget that.
    Did the family cause the family unit to break down? It functioned WELL for
    humanity up until 50 years ago.. WTF happened??? Oh yes - corporate media.
    Television.
    
    [snip]
    >There's an almost complete lack of
    > courtesy, consideration of others and a willingness to work with a group
    for
    > the betterment of all. Starting about 20 years ago the mantra used to be
    "me
    > first". Now it's "me only, and screw you, too".
    
    You seem to imply that it's this reason (applied to the software piracy
    world) that has caused me, and thousands of others, to be unemployed. Come,
    come now.. We both know it is bush, dick, and colon in the white house that
    caused that.. ;-)
    
    This line - "Me only, and screw you, too" - sums up capitalism nicely! The
    dictionary def. of capitalism: an economic system based on private ownership
    of capital. Notice the word private, or closed. Which means if you are not a
    part of our group you do not share our wealth. This is the major problem in
    the world. American Capitalism is waging rampant war on the peoples of the
    world, just to make a buck. It's a private club.
    
    How does this compare with VMWare? It doesn't - I don't think he should take
    that license. This german guy WILL be caught - eventually - and Holger would
    then be liable. More than likely he would be implicated in a criminal trial
    as well (notice my morals correspond with "cover your ass"). Is VMWare the
    cause of the wars in East Timor? The oil battles of the middle east? The
    diamond genocides in Africa? The drug wars in South America? No - they are
    not. But capitalism as itself is not a good enough argument not to steal.
    
    One more, then I'm done:
    
    [snip]
    >   The mis-placed idealism from some on this list is sometimes amusing and
    > sometimes annoying. It was the same naive idealism that resulted in
    > yellow-painted bicycles in downtown Portland for _everyone's_ use. Need a
    > ride? Take a bike and leave it for the next person. Guess what? Every
    single
    > bike was stolen and not recovered. Where's this program now in support of
    > "freedom of transportation"?
    
    This is communism, my friend. This has ALWAYS been at odds with capitalism.
    It takes from those rich old white bastards (no offense to any rich old
    white bastards in the room ;-)) sitting in their ivory towers and
    distributes it fairly. It equals the odds. Our societal consciousness is too
    entrenched in capitalism for a friendly communist gesture to ever work.
    Linux is the first communal experiment (that I know of, on such a global
    scale) to work. Which is why I'm here - and I know that MANY (though not
    all) in the OSS movement are socialist/communist at heart. Microsoft? I have
    no more of an issue with them then I do with Mobil/Chevron or McDonalds. I
    have the SAME issue with ALL of them. STOP RAPING MY WORLD!
    
    All I'm saying is don't just blame the people - blame the corporate media,
    the corporate government, the corporations, and THEN blame the damn people
    who buy into it for current societal trends.

From svanhoosen at yahoo.com  Tue Jun 17 09:54:01 2003
From: svanhoosen at yahoo.com (Scott Van Hoosen)
Date: Tue Jun 17 09:54:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] That's it.
In-Reply-To: <1055821629.5888.4.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <20030617165312.30547.qmail@web40804.mail.yahoo.com>

Michael,

My advice is to not take the criticism you received
personally. Stay a member of the list, there is a lot
that can be learned just by listening.

If you need to find an answer to a question, first go
to Google. Man pages can be helpful, though they're
better for reference than instruction. There are
numerous tutorials online for all sorts of subjects.

If you can't find your answer in other sources, then
post your question to PLUG. Just make sure your
question is specific. I don't remember your original
question that irritated some people, but I remember it
was very general, and would have been impossible to
answer in an email.

Anyway, don't give up on the PLUG list, it is a very
useful tool, just make sure you use the tool
correctly. One rule I try to follow personally is to
answer at least one question for every question I ask.

-Scott

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Tue Jun 17 10:18:01 2003

You'd think there is no market for illegal software on e-bay (at least not
unless it comes with the actual media, not everyone fancies a download of
Windows XP in a hundred pieced of a large zip file, may be more, I have
no idea how large XP download might be). If you go to Google
and search for "vmware warez" you find quite a few sites (don't do it,
even out of curiosity, if you're easilly offended by porn - you have been
warned). Nonetheless, lots of illegal software is sold on ebay, I can only
assume that most people don't dig the internet and view it in sort of AOL
model (content is provided for you by vendors, internet is a conduit to
connect to these vendors).

    that I thought a person looking for an illegal copy, could find one without
    buying. I thought I was saying, I don't think there is a market and I can't
    believe anyone would try to sell illegal software on ebay.
    
    Holger, I apologize if in anyway I've offended you. 
    
    Thank you
    Russell

From guy1656 at ados.com  Tue Jun 17 11:11:01 2003
From: guy1656 at ados.com (guy1656)
Date: Tue Jun 17 11:11:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Way the hell OT - was eBay scam
In-Reply-To: <001801c334dc$ebe44140$1901a8c0@madcat>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306170616190.2968-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <001801c334dc$ebe44140$1901a8c0@madcat>
Message-ID: <200306171110.17948.guy1656@ados.com>

On-topic for a moment: I just received a (legal) copy of VMWare 4.0. My first 
goal (which I am baffled - BUT- attempting to RTFM first)  is to set up  a 
SAMBA share so I can 'see' the linux /home/[my user directory] files within 
Win2k within VMWare.

Now, OT:

Matt Chorman wrote:
: Did the family cause the family unit to break down? It functioned WELL for
: humanity up until 50 years ago.. WTF happened??? Oh yes - corporate media.
: Television.

What about the invention of a viable form of birth control, which not only 
gave women the NEVER-before opportunity to be something else besides 'mommy,' 
it allowed both sexes to separate the sex act from family obligations. This 
deconstruction of 'sex = babies' unwound most of the social strictures 
encasing 'strong family:'
- Don't 'do it' till you're married, or outside of marriage,
- If marriage means sex it means children & decades-long responsibilities,
- Bastards couldn't inherit by default until about the mid-60's.
- For most men: You ability to get a good job or promotion is somewhat linked 
to society's observation of how well you're rearing your children. Fine, 
quiet, miniature adults versus noisy street-wastrels?

Etc. A bunch of 'WTF' happened in the past 50 years, so pinning it on 
corporations might be a bit too specific.

130 years ago, the Pratt & Whitney company grew faster than, and was larger 
than Microsoft. They made general machine parts, and they specialized in 
rifled barrels and steam and gasoline engine parts.

Advertising of one sort or another had been around for centuries, as had 
corporations - even corporate media. So the corporate thing is probably a red 
herring or if anything a secondary factor in this social change.

GLL





From danh at fork.com  Tue Jun 17 11:26:05 2003
From: danh at fork.com (Dan Haskell)
Date: Tue Jun 17 11:26:05 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Announcement: WMD found at Linux Clinic
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0306171113210.16324-100000@cohiba.fork.com>

Weapons of Mass Distribution (of Linux) can be found this Saturday at the
Linux Clinic. Come and join in the search!



          *** Portland Linux User's Group (PLUG) Announcement ***
                                     
             The Linux Clinic - third Saturday of every month
                                     
    Interested in Linux? Need help installing or configuring Linux? Be
           sure to attend the next session of the Linux Clinic.
                                     
                               Linux Clinic
                                     
                              June 21, 2003
                                     
                                1PM - 4PM
                                     
                             Riverdale School
                                     
                           11733 SW Breyman Ave.
                                     
                          Portland, Oregon 97219
                                     
   What to bring:
     * Your computer, monitor, keyboard and mouse.
     * Any relevant peripherals (printer, modem, etc).
     * Your Linux distribution (if you have already installed).
     * The manuals for your hardware - especially your monitor manual.
       
   Resources available:
     * Volunteers skilled in Linux installation and maintenance.
     * The PLUG CD library (including several recent Linux
       distributions).
     * T-1 Internet connection
     * phone jacks for testing modem and Internet setups.
     * Ethernet drops.
     * Infocus projector for demonstrations.
     * An extra Linux box for experimenting.
     * A number of reference materials
       
   For directions to the school see:
   http://www.riverdale.k12.or.us/info/direct.html
   
   For questions regarding the Clinics email Dan Haskell at:
   dhaskell at acm.org
   
   For information about PLUG or the Clinics see:
   http://www.pdxlinux.org

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Tue Jun 17 11:33:01 2003

When you rn vmware-config it offers you to configure your system so you
can access local filesystems from VMware, and if I remember right, this
means samba. Since I already had samba set up, I did not want it to mess
up the existing configuration, so I told it no, but if you are just
startign with samba, give it a try and see what it really does.

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Tue Jun 17 11:45:03 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor Pikus)
Date: Tue Jun 17 11:45:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Kernel 2.4.21 anyone?
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0306171132580.23363-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

Is anyone running 2.4.21 kernel? I tried it out, because it has several
features I wanted (HPT372 IDE controller support, stable USB2), and one
feature I wanted to try out - supposedly it's much more responsive when
intensive disk I/O takes place.
All features I wanted are as advertized, but later, when I tried to
recompile XFree86, or the kernel itself, the build would fail in strange
ways. It was not the usual compiler sig11 crashes which happen when the
memory fails or CPU overheats. Most often, there were problems in
generated files, like makefiles ("separator missing on line 36"). It was
semi-reproducible, i.e. I could rerun the build several times and few
times it fails in exactly the same place, few times in some other place.

I went back to RedHat's version of 2.4.20 kernel, and several rebuilds of
XFree86 in a row all completed fine.

-- 
                                  Fedor G. Pikus
Mentor Graphics Corporation         | Phone: (503) 685-4857
8405 SW Boeckman Road               | FAX:   (503) 685-1239
Wilsonville, Oregon 97070           | http://www.pikus.net/~pikus/



From matt_chorman at hotmail.com  Tue Jun 17 11:55:02 2003
From: matt_chorman at hotmail.com (Matt Chorman)

Subject: [PLUG] Class and.or tutoring in Red Hat 9
References: <1055703330.19822.15.camel@localhost.localdomain> <200306151757.03089.pluglist@bratgrrl.com> <1055725140.16226.55.camel@red> <200306151824.30712.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <Law11-OE15JD1PIje6n0002716a@hotmail.com>

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Carla Schroder" <pluglist at bratgrrl.com>
To: <plug at lists.pdxlinux.org>
Sent: Sunday, June 15, 2003 6:24 PM
Subject: Re: [PLUG] Class and.or tutoring in Red Hat 9
> I see Red Hat as the bleeding-edge Linux, the one that pushes development
> forward. If it weren't for Red Hat, I think a lot of things would not have
> advanced as quickly or as far as they have- like RPM, Unicode support,
Xfree,
> gcc, and other stuff I forget now. Every distro does things its own way-
> Mandrake, Slack, SuSE, Debian, Gentoo, etc- there is no "universal Linux".
> This is the great strength of Linux, though it can be a bit daunting when
> you're getting started.

I think you underestimate the contribution of the Free World. Redhat is
always a little behind in their kernel too - they do not push the bleeding
edge, though they do help stabalize it. I have no qualms with redhat.. They
are a fine distro - for what they are...

> Remember also Red Hat funds a considerable amount of Linux development.
Kernel
> hackers gotta eat too! I think their low-end/free-download releases are
more
> for testing new things, and to get people to use them. Their high-end
server
> products are more stable and consistent, and obviously are the real
> revenue-generators for the company.

They have only been releasing their "high-end server products" for a short
time. No one distribution is more or less stable than others - it is the
packages, the adminstrator, and the amount of time that the administrator
puts into stabalizing/securing the box. I subscribed to kernel-dev for a
time when I had some issues running coda under 2.5.68 (devfs changes were
not ported to the new coda code.) I would say 75%+ were just regular joes
and janes who love the kernel code. Granted, redhat does help with
stabalizing the current-stable kernel...

> As others have pointed out in this thread, there are no bad Linuxes, just
> different ones.

Well put! (Though I would have to disagree with that statement in regards to
Lindows and SCO, but thats another thread entirely!!!) :-D

M

On Tue, 17 Jun 2003, Fedor Pikus wrote:

> When you rn vmware-config it offers you to configure your system so you
> can access local filesystems from VMware, and if I remember right, this
> means samba. Since I already had samba set up, I did not want it to mess
> up the existing configuration, so I told it no, but if you are just
> startign with samba, give it a try and see what it really does.
 
  I can share my samba.conf with those who want to see how it's set up to
work with VMware. FWIW, I started using VMware as a beta tester in the
pre-1.0 days; I believe the build numbers were in double digits when I first
put it on. And I've paid for every upgrade since.

  What throws me with every upgrade is finding where the virtual win98 hides
the network setup. Once I'm there, and I enter the IP address and other
information, it works. The wonderfully patient support folks hear from me a
couple of times with each upgrade, then not again until we repeat the cycle.

  If Windows says it cannot find the network, it's probably on it's side of
the divide.

Rich

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Jun 17 12:47:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)

Subject: [PLUG] eBay scam
In-Reply-To: <1055836230.23440.263.camel@halo>

 <1055836230.23440.263.camel@halo>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306171244140.6106@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 17 Jun 2003, Holger Stephan wrote:
> While looking at eBay to find a used VMWare license this guy sells a
> bunch of current VMWare licenses for $31. After inquiring about the
> legal status of these licenses he shares with me that 68% of the people
> copy software anyways and selling the key that he bought is his way to
> recover the costs (original mail appended).

I don't read in his letter that he's encouraging people to use duplicate
licenses.  His english isn't perfect, of course, and so many
interpretations are available.  But I, personally, think he's just being
defensive because he interepreted your note to be chastising him for
selling used software.  I'm sure people selling used software get all
kinds of attacks from software company goons.

> As one who earns his living with copyrighted IP I really feel like
> turning this <german>Saftsack</german> in. Would you? And where?

Well, as someone who thinks the term "IP" (not Internet Protocol, of
course) is intended to purposely mislead people into confusing a bargain
between authors and the public (copyright) with realty or personalty, I
think you should buy from the guy and see what you get before you claim
he's some kind of criminal.

J.

From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Tue Jun 17 12:51:02 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Tue Jun 17 12:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Kernel 2.4.21 anyone?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0306171132580.23363-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0306171132580.23363-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>
Message-ID: <200306171249.32992.matt@legalizefreedom.org>

On Tuesday 17 June 2003 11:44 am, Fedor Pikus wrote:
> Is anyone running 2.4.21 kernel? I tried it out, because it has several
> features I wanted (HPT372 IDE controller support, stable USB2), and one
> feature I wanted to try out - supposedly it's much more responsive when
> intensive disk I/O takes place.
> All features I wanted are as advertized, but later, when I tried to
> recompile XFree86, or the kernel itself, the build would fail in strange
> ways. It was not the usual compiler sig11 crashes which happen when the
> memory fails or CPU overheats. Most often, there were problems in
> generated files, like makefiles ("separator missing on line 36"). It was
> semi-reproducible, i.e. I could rerun the build several times and few
> times it fails in exactly the same place, few times in some other place.
>
> I went back to RedHat's version of 2.4.20 kernel, and several rebuilds of
> XFree86 in a row all completed fine.
How many parallel makes are you running?

I don't know whether or not this relates to your experience or not, but I was 
having the same problem under 2.4.18 a month of so back. I was also using a 
openmosix cluster - in this case, I was compiling with make -j8 and XFree 
(and kde for that matter) did not like parallel comilation. I could compile 
*ANYTHING* else and it would work fine, but Xfree would exhibit the exact 
same symptoms you are describing. I dropped the number of jobs down to -j2 
and it worked fine. 

M

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Jun 17 13:37:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue Jun 17 13:37:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] eBay scam
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306170616190.2968-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306170616190.2968-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306171247430.6106@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 17 Jun 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Please do turn him in to both eBay and VMware. It's illegal and it
> hurts us all.

If he's doing anything like what Holger claims, he MAY be doing something
illegal.  I think you assume too much.

>   The mis-placed idealism from some on this list is sometimes amusing
> and sometimes annoying.

There's nothing misplaced about idealism.  You should always know to what
ideal you are aspiring.

> It was the same naive idealism that resulted in yellow-painted bicycles
> in downtown Portland for _everyone's_ use. Need a ride? Take a bike and
> leave it for the next person. Guess what? Every single bike was stolen
> and not recovered. Where's this program now in support of "freedom of
> transportation"?

The Community Cycling Center considered the yellow bikes program a
success.  I do, too.  But it really has NOTHING to do with this thread or
Holger's supposed dilemma.

>   How many of you have seen people pushing shopping carts stolen from
> supermarkets?
[snip]
>   If you were a farmer, how would you feel about folks walking through
> your fields and taking crops because everyone has the right to be fed?

The problem with all three of your examples, Rich, is that they refer to
real property (personalty, in these cases).  Real property is scarce and
of a finite supply.  Information does not suffer from this terrible
scarcity and the "sharability" is inherent.

To quote Thomas Jefferson:

That ideas should freely spread from one to another over the globe, for
the moral and mutual instruction of man, and improvement of his condition,
seems to have been peculiarly and benevolently designed by nature, when
she made them, like fire, expansible over all space, without lessening
their density at any point, and like the air in which we breathe, move,
and have our physical being, incapable of confinement or exclusive
appropriation. Inventions then cannot, in nature, be a subject of
property.

>   Perhaps the reason some of you are unemployed is because others with
> your philosophy, values and total disregard for anyone else's rights
> stole the product of the greedy, scum-sucking, filthy capitalist who
> employed you. May the next language you learn include the phrases, "Do
> you want fries with that?" and "Regular or premium?"

Or perhaps we're unemployed because the greedy, scum-sucking, filthy
capitalists who employed us are afraid of the market and its natural
result in abundance and destruction of profits and must keep a large
percentage of the population out of work in order to encourage "labor
market flexibility" in order to drive wages down and increase profits at
the expense of the very society the capitalist system was installed to
improve.

The means is serving the minority so well that the ends (prosperity for
the majority) are being put off as long as possible.

>   Too many people today have either forgotten, or never learned, how to
> function as a part of a society. There's an almost complete lack of
> courtesy, consideration of others and a willingness to work with a group
> for the betterment of all. Starting about 20 years ago the mantra used
> to be "me first". Now it's "me only, and screw you, too".

I agree with this paragraph completely.  Though I'd say it goes back to
the 1920s, rather than 20 years ago.  (Though the United States is a
strange anomaly wherein nearly every decision from the migration to this
land to westward expansion to the Constitution itself was based on
anti-social ideals.)

>   My wish is that someday you grow up and become both responsible and
> productive to society as a whole.

And see, I would argue that the Free Software movement and other
institutions of abundance and prosperity are replacing the selfish,
unproductive, anti-social structures of the past.

> In the meantime I'd appreciate not knowing that you support theft and
> other illegal acts.

Theft is the appropriation of personalty.  Information is never owned by
anyone.  However, the public does allow authors the opportunity to control
distribution of their work for a limited time in exchange for the
publication of that work.  It's sort of an attempt to encourage people to
share information that they might want to keep secret.  That deal is
nothing like turning information into property.

And, by the way, my morals (and, by extension, those actions I support and
condemn) have only coincidental relationship with the law.  Whether or not
something is "illegal" is irrelevant to whether or not I support it.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

From barryb at proaxis.com  Tue Jun 17 14:16:02 2003
From: barryb at proaxis.com (Bill Barry)
Date: Tue Jun 17 14:16:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Kernel Compile
In-Reply-To: <007b01c33512$c786a780$6501a8c0@dual>
References: <007b01c33512$c786a780$6501a8c0@dual>
Message-ID: <20030617211719.GA19998@edge>

On Tue, Jun 17, 2003 at 01:55:24PM -0700, Roman Robinson wrote:
> Hi,
>     I think I have my kernel ready for install, I just don't know how to do
> it ;-) I don't have a monitor hooked up, and everything I have read online
> says I need to use LILO to choose my new kernel.. Can someone help me with
> this? AIM, ICQ, MSN, YIM, etc?

EMAIL?
first make sure that your system uses lilo and not grub,

for lilo edit /etc/lilo.conf
in the header set
default = newkernel ( or some such name)

and in the section where the new kernel is described,
put 
  label = newkernel

then to install your changes, as root run
lilo

Bill Barry

Russell Senior         ``shtal latta wos ba padre u prett tu nashtonfi

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Tue Jun 17 15:01:02 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Tue Jun 17 15:01:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] PLUG mailing list (back of envelope) statistics
Message-ID: <86y9004b60.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

I've done a few rough estimates (rough primarily because of the
variability in timezones and peoples system clocks) on my recent
archive of PLUG mailing list traffic.  This was mostly prompted by the
sense that message frequencies weren't as high as a few years ago and
by Dave Mandel's usual characterization at PLUG meetings of traffic being
around 100/day, which didn't _feel_ right, but I wasn't sure it wasn't
right.  

In the first 5.5 months of 2003, we are averaging 33.1 posts per day.
During the whole of 2002, we averaged about 54.1 posts per day, about
70.2 in the first quarter and 43.2 in the fourth quarter.

So, posting frequency is down about half of what it was last year.

FWIW.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``shtal latta wos ba padre u prett tu nashtonfi
seniorr at aracnet.com      mrlosh''  -- Bashgali Kafir for ``If you have
                         had diarrhoea many days you will surely die.''

Russell> year.

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Tue Jun 17 17:32:02 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Tue Jun 17 17:32:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Kernel Compile
In-Reply-To: <00de01c3352c$00c94750$6501a8c0@dual>
References: <007b01c33512$c786a780$6501a8c0@dual>
	 <20030617211719.GA19998@edge> <86adcg5rdb.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	 <009b01c3351e$d3ace400$6501a8c0@dual>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306171637510.11569@shaft.bitmine.net>
	 <00de01c3352c$00c94750$6501a8c0@dual>
Message-ID: <1055896328.929.371.camel@main>


I bounce off of this problem with IBM OSA Express drivers with every
kernel update. Look in /lib/modules/<kernelrev> directory tree for your
previous drivers (normally found in the kernel/drivers/net dir) and cp
them to your new kernels /lib/modules. Once that's done you can rename
the new kernels modules.dep and bounce the install.

Of course if you compiled the kernel with your nic driver static then
this is a waste of time.

On Tue, 2003-06-17 at 16:55, Roman Robinson wrote:

>

> to Google. Man pages can be helpful, though they're
> better for reference than instruction. There are
> numerous tutorials online for all sorts of subjects.
>

> post your question to PLUG. Just make sure your
> question is specific. I don't remember your original
> question that irritated some people, but I remember it
> was very general, and would have been impossible to
> answer in an email.
>

From ron at nutriware.com  Tue Jun 17 19:04:02 2003
From: ron at nutriware.com (Ron Braithwaite)
Date: Tue Jun 17 19:04:02 2003
Subject: [Re: [PLUG] That's it.]
Message-ID: <3EEFC7C5.6090205@nutriware.com>

Dear Mike:

I just thought I would forward a little of the dialog on this list 
concerning whoever told you to go away. I do not believe that person is 
representative of the whole.

I've been doing systems programming since 1979 and started using Unix in 
1981. I still have to ask questions of this group and of my friends. I 
know a lot more now than I did then, but there is way to much for anyone 
(including Linus) to hold in their head.

The Linux community is very diverse, ranging from Libertarians to 
Communists, from Fundamentalist Christians and Moslems to Pagan Witches. 
Out of all this diversity, there are going to be people who will flame 
you at the drop of a hat for your stupidity in not knowing exactly what 
they know. Of course, these same playground bullies will roll over and 
play dead if asked questons about things like priority inheritance or 
other subtle real-time programming issues.

So I am asking you to please return. I really, really, really don't like 
the idea that some jerk chased you away and got his bully jollies out of it.

That said, the single most important thing you can learn is *how* to ask 
questions - not just for this group and not just for technology. How to 
frame a question on a subject that you do not yet understand is a tricky 
piece of knowledge that NOBODY knows intuitively. It's a skill learned 
and perhaps you will learn it hanging out on PLUG.

Peas In Our Thyme,
Ron Braithwaite

"It was much better to imagine men in some smoky room somewhere, made 
mad and cynical by privilege and power, plotting over the brandy. You 
had to cling to this sort of image because if you didn't you would have 
to face the fact that ordinary people, the kind who brushed the dog and 
told their children bed time stories, were capable of then going out and 
doing horrible things to other ordinary people. It was so much easier to 
blame it on "them." It was bleakly depressing to think that they were 
"us." If it was "them" then nothing was anyone's fault. If it was "us" 
then what did that make "me?"  After all, I am one of "us." I have 
certainly never thought of myself as one of "them." No one ever thinks 
of themselves as one of "them." We are always one of "us." It's always 
"them" that does the bad things." - from "Jingo" by Terry Pratchett

From techmage at aracnet.com  Tue Jun 17 19:19:01 2003
From: techmage at aracnet.com (Prutzer)
Date: Tue Jun 17 19:19:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Two problems with my dialup connection
In-Reply-To: <G2DqPmEHcgz5rVY0uCj0ZB5TSxxi@4ax.com>
References: <1055459593.7910.25.camel@localhost.localdomain> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306121623140.25444-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <tVzqPhmoJ+aCYbv+gqMviD6SG7SY@4ax.com> <3EEA5DF4.9040609@nutriware.com> <G2DqPmEHcgz5rVY0uCj0ZB5TSxxi@4ax.com>
Message-ID: <XcrvPowxfR=NYMTNv0+MPMqKeO=F@4ax.com>

Hi all,
Okay I have two problems with my dialup connection.
problem one:

I'm logged in as root and I can start the wvdial but, the routing
table requires me to remove and then add the ppp0 routing every time I
connect. 
How can I fix this to just let me dial up and get the mail/browse?

Problem two:
I can't seem to figure out how to get the USERS the needed privileges
or settings so that they can dial out with out having to be in ROOT to
do so. I have wvdial set so the users can dial with it, but pppd
doesn't start when the handshake is done( it gives it's own signal 2)

Better minds than mine reside here, I'm still reading all the Linux
HOWTO PPP stuff. 
Thanks in advance,
Prutzer

Dont immanentize the eschaton

From jorgens at coho.net  Wed Jun 18 00:35:02 2003
From: jorgens at coho.net (Steve Jorgensen)

Subject: [PLUG] re: Setting up basic X on Debian Sarge
Message-ID: <01C33532.2BD93D00.jorgens@coho.net>

I just wanted to update y'all on the X problem I was having with Sarge. 
 Perhaps, there is a way to make it work upgrading from Woody to Sarge, 
-then- installing X, but I never figured it out.  I was, however, able to 
reinstall Woody -with- X, then upgrade to Sarge, and X still works. 
 Problem solved - well enough, anyway.




From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Jun 18 01:41:01 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed Jun 18 01:41:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Two problems with my dialup connection
In-Reply-To: <XcrvPowxfR=NYMTNv0+MPMqKeO=F@4ax.com>
References: <1055459593.7910.25.camel@localhost.localdomain>
 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306121623140.25444-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <tVzqPhmoJ+aCYbv+gqMviD6SG7SY@4ax.com> <3EEA5DF4.9040609@nutriware.com>
 <G2DqPmEHcgz5rVY0uCj0ZB5TSxxi@4ax.com> <XcrvPowxfR=NYMTNv0+MPMqKeO=F@4ax.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306180137280.21128@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 17 Jun 2003, Prutzer wrote:
> I'm logged in as root and I can start the wvdial but, the routing table
> requires me to remove and then add the ppp0 routing every time I
> connect.  How can I fix this to just let me dial up and get the
> mail/browse?

Um, I've never bothered with wvdial on a multiuser system.

The Debian pppconfig includes scripts "pon" and "poff" that dial,
launch pppd, and configure the network all at once, then reverse it all
when you're done.

I have no idea how universal this is.  I haven't used dialup in a long
time, but I just configured a friend's and it was a snap.

> I can't seem to figure out how to get the USERS the needed privileges or
> settings so that they can dial out with out having to be in ROOT to do
> so. I have wvdial set so the users can dial with it, but pppd doesn't
> start when the handshake is done( it gives it's own signal 2)

This was just a matter of adding each user intended to use the internet to
the dialout group (it should be whoever owns the appropriate serial tty
for the modem).

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------

 http://www.openlaw.org

* Matt Chorman <matt at legalizefreedom.org> [2003-06-17 07:31]:
> Don't blame me if I see around it and choose not to
> participate.

So tell me. Did you build your computer from environmentally friendly
parts, built in non-polluting factories?

Or do you simply "not participate" when it suites you and buy mass
produced, corporate supporting commodity things when they are fun and
you want them?

If you are wondering where my questions come from, look into how much
waste and pollution is produced during the production of your
motherboard.

> Don't blame just the people, but corporations as well. Never forget that.
> Did the family cause the family unit to break down? It functioned WELL for
> humanity up until 50 years ago.. WTF happened??? Oh yes - corporate media.
> Television.

I'm remembering a line from the movie, "Family Man". Nick Cage says,
quoting John Lennon, "America is the Roman Empire, and New York is Rome
itself." I watched "Family Man" on TV... How apropos.

Keep in mind that "family" has meant many things in the last few
centuries. A "family" in the 1880's was not "Mom, Dad and the kids".

They say most civilizations last about 2-400 years. We're in that time
frame now. Could we be witnessing the destruction of our own
civilization? The Roman Empire lasted about 400 years.

From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Wed Jun 18 11:41:02 2003

My question:

Does anyone know the code in question? How old is it?

I know in the past, I remember hearing about IP lawsuits where someone "used a 
patent owned by another company". The judge let the IP become PD because of 
how prolific it's use was. I wish I could remember the case and products I am 
talking about, but it did not have to do with software code.... It was only a 
few years back.

Anyway... In this case, the amount of damage that would be caused by SCO being 
allowed to sue the "entire world" (which is, in a sense, what they are going 
to have to do) would be astronomical. No judge in their right mind would let 
them win. And if they do win, may SCO have mercy on our souls.

M

From chris-plug at maybe.net  Wed Jun 18 13:19:01 2003
From: chris-plug at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Wed Jun 18 13:19:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Advanced Topics - Additional Info
Message-ID: <20030618201139.GD1720@maybe.net>

(Actually had this for a while and submitted it to both lists, but as I
heard at one mtg, the moderation queue is woefully unattended.)

Modern File Systems

As this talk was given as additional material for an operating systems
class (my motivation: I was frustrated that all my classmates were
learning about file systems predating 1985) it will touch largely on
structure, theory, and methodology. As such performance characteristics
will be discussed (and are important), but no detailed hard benchmarks
will be provided. Only two file systems will be covered internally (ext2
and WAFL).

The talk is divided into two principle sections: traditional, local file
systems and modern advances; and network-oriented file systems (be
careful -- not network file systems).

As a projector may or may not be present, you might want to at least
glance over the slides from the presentation so as not to squint at my
tiny laptop. I don't feel inclined to drop them from the presentation as
many are fairly visual.

http://www.maybe.net/fs/fs.html

Note that the direction and content of the talk given at Paddy's will
probably vary a fair bit from the slides as presented due to the
different context, interests, and background of both of the audiences.

-- 
chris jantzen kb7rnl =->         __O
Insert witty comment here.     _`\<,_
http://www.maybe.net/         (*)/ (*)
