From chris at maybe.net  Wed Jun 18 13:49:16 2003
From: chris at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Wed Jun 18 13:49:16 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Advanced Topics - Additional Info
Message-ID: <20030618201139.GD1720@maybe.net>

(Actually had this for a while and submitted it to both lists, but as I
heard at one mtg, the moderation queue is woefully unattended.)

Modern File Systems

As this talk was given as additional material for an operating systems
class (my motivation: I was frustrated that all my classmates were
learning about file systems predating 1985) it will touch largely on
structure, theory, and methodology. As such performance characteristics
will be discussed (and are important), but no detailed hard benchmarks
will be provided. Only two file systems will be covered internally (ext2
and WAFL).

The talk is divided into two principle sections: traditional, local file
systems and modern advances; and network-oriented file systems (be
careful -- not network file systems).

As a projector may or may not be present, you might want to at least
glance over the slides from the presentation so as not to squint at my
tiny laptop. I don't feel inclined to drop them from the presentation as
many are fairly visual.

http://www.maybe.net/fs/fs.html

Note that the direction and content of the talk given at Paddy's will
probably vary a fair bit from the slides as presented due to the
different context, interests, and background of both of the audiences.

-- 
chris jantzen kb7rnl =->         __O

http://www.maybe.net/         (*)/ (*)

the Linux Clinic. Come and join in the search!



          *** Portland Linux User's Group (PLUG) Announcement ***
                                     
             The Linux Clinic - third Saturday of every month
                                     
    Interested in Linux? Need help installing or configuring Linux? Be
           sure to attend the next session of the Linux Clinic.
                                     
                               Linux Clinic
                                     
                              June 21, 2003
                                     
                                1PM - 4PM
                                     
                             Riverdale School
                                     
                           11733 SW Breyman Ave.
                                     
                          Portland, Oregon 97219
                                     
   What to bring:
     * Your computer, monitor, keyboard and mouse.
     * Any relevant peripherals (printer, modem, etc).
     * Your Linux distribution (if you have already installed).
     * The manuals for your hardware - especially your monitor manual.
       
   Resources available:
     * Volunteers skilled in Linux installation and maintenance.
     * The PLUG CD library (including several recent Linux
       distributions).
     * T-1 Internet connection
     * phone jacks for testing modem and Internet setups.
     * Ethernet drops.
     * Infocus projector for demonstrations.
     * An extra Linux box for experimenting.
     * A number of reference materials
       
   For directions to the school see:
   http://www.riverdale.k12.or.us/info/direct.html
   
   For questions regarding the Clinics email Dan Haskell at:
   dhaskell at acm.org
   
   For information about PLUG or the Clinics see:
   http://www.pdxlinux.org

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Jun 18 16:48:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed Jun 18 16:48:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Secure mail with virtual domains
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306181642450.1417@shaft.bitmine.net>

Hi!

I'm putting together a mail/web server for a fellow that runs many
companies.  I've got the DNS and web stuff working dreamily and I'm just
starting to get wrist-deep in the mail.

I think I've got an idea of the features I need to use and I'm hoping to
get some input from the gallery about which specific packages to use for
the mail system.

Remote receiving of mail through IMAP
Remote sending of mail with SMTP Auth (preferably through the passwd
  file, directly or indirectly)
Virtual domains for both

I want this to be fairly straightforward for the users who will likely be
using Outhouse and LookOut Express.

I'll probably end up setting up a Squirrelmail system here for the role
accounts (like customerservice at eachdomain and so on).

So what do y'all use?  My immediate temptation is to go with an
all-courier mail system, but my totally irrational bias against maildir is
holding me back.

At home, I've got sendmail and cyrusIMAP running without a hitch for
several years, but I don't really have remote users with multiple roles.

Any discussion on the topic could be helpful.
J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------

 http://www.openlaw.org

Jeme,

I have this system minus the smtp Auth but that is because I have yet to
do that work.  I user Postfix and find that it is easy to add a new domain
and new users.  I have a mix of client users and nobody has complained. 
They mostly are just using POP.  I have set up and use Squirrelmail over
https.  Then I don't need IMAPS.  But that is available.  Have POPS
running also.  Thought about requiring all clients to use that to get the
mail but not sure all clients support that yet.

Josh

I'd just like to say that this was one of the better ALT talks I've seen
to date.

It was super informative while not being overly detailed for someone like
me.  I mean, I know what an inode is and when certain block sizes are
better than others and that sort of thing.  I even had a handle on why
some filesystems are prone to fragmentation while others are not, but I
didn't really understand, for example, how one might go about preventing
fragmentation in the filesystem design.

each others' bicycles are more permanent event... at least for the summer
when the even the timid are leaving their cars at home.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Jun 19 06:28:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu Jun 19 06:28:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Secure mail with virtual domains
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306190627260.18054-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 18 Jun 2003, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> Remote sending of mail with SMTP Auth (preferably through the passwd
>   file, directly or indirectly)

I use sendmail for this, on ports 25 and 587, the latter to support 
folks on networks that prohibit port-25 access to remote hosts. 
(EarthLink has that restriction, iirc).

The sendmail setup is semi-involved, but pretty straightforward:

1. Configure sendmail.cf so that it can handle LOGIN and PLAIN auth 
   mechanisms, knows where your certs are located, and works with an 
   access_db:

   TRUST_AUTH_MECH(`LOGIN PLAIN')dnl
   define(`confAUTH_MECHANISMS', `LOGIN PLAIN')dnl
   define(`confCACERT_PATH',`/usr/share/ssl/certs')dnl
   define(`confCACERT',`/usr/share/ssl/certs/ca-bundle.crt')dnl
   defaine(`confSERVER_CERT',`/var/local/ssl/certs/your.cert')dnl
   define(`confSERVER_KEY',`/var/local/ssl/certs/your.key')dnl
   FEATURE(`access_db',`hash -T<TMPF> -o /etc/mail/access.db')dnl

   LOGIN and/or PLAIN are your only options if you want to use the 
   system password map (NIS, /etc/passwd, ldap) for SMTP auth. If you 
   configure these mechanisms, then password safety is dependent on 
   wire-level crypto (i.e., SSL).

2. Tell sasl that sendmail will be doing pam-based password checks. 
   Typically, that means /usr/lib/sasl/Sendmail.conf has one line:

   pwcheck_method:pam

3. Configure you sendmail access database to require strong crypto 
   from anywhere but localhost:

   localhost.localdomain           RELAY
   localhost                       RELAY
   127.0.0.1                       RELAY
   TLS_Clt:                        ENCR:128

That's worked really well for me.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at cse.ogi.edu>

From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Thu Jun 19 13:08:03 2003
From: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Thu Jun 19 13:08:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] HB 2892: Forwarded Message
Message-ID: <1056053659.15414.155.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>

Honorable Representative Minnis;


I am writing today to express my deepest concern over the events
surrounding HB 2892, the Open Source Consideration Bill. 

The truth is, Representative, that it is very difficult in Oregon to get
Open Source related work. The Information Technology playing field in
Oregon-despite what Jim Craven with the AeA and other lobbyists may tell
you-is not level.

Moreover, HB 2892 does not seek to give preferential treatment to one
type of software over another; it simply requires the consideration of
Open Source Software. This is due primarily because Oregon's Request For
Procurement (RFP) system only considers established vendors. Open Source
applications that can often do the job as well or better than their
proprietary counterparts is sometimes not represented by any one vendor.
Thus, Open Source Software is not considered by those other than the
most technologically savvy Oregon IT departments.

I know from my familiarity with the DOJ v. Microsoft anti-trust trial
that Oregon's computer OEM's such as Intel and Hewlett Packard do not
wish to speak out on these types of issues for fear of retribution from
their primary software vendor. The software vendor can and has
threatened to pull support for a hardware platform. That would all but
devastate a hardware manufacturer's business model. As one industry
executive put it, "it's like being treated like a [bad] step child."

Steve McGeady, the former CEO for Intel, testified for the DOJ that
Intel's support of competing technologies (Netscape and Java) often put
them in hot water with their neighbors in Redmond. McGeady told the
court that in one 1995 meeting "Bill made it very clear that Microsoft
would not support our next processor offerings if we did not get
alignment"-on platform software-a threat that McGeady described as "both
credible and fairly terrifying." 

My guess is that Jim Craven didn't tell you that. I share this knowledge
to impress upon you that this industry is definitely anything but a
level playing field; as evidence contrary to what the lobbyists have
told you.

It is clear through submitted written and oral testimony during
committee as well as independent analysis and case history reports
worldwide that Open Source software can dramatically reduce the total
cost of ownership for State IT agencies.

There are many ways Open Source Software can help Oregon's government
perform it's duties. Try to imagine what effect a completely open and
secure IT system would have for the 911 consolidation project or for
benefit dispersement programs.

Because Open Source Software is superior in many cases, and because it
is known that OSS is effective in saving taxpayer dollars, I can only
conclude that there must be some other reason why a Republican would
want this bill killed.

The following are two links referencing contributions made to your
election campaign in PDF (Adobe Acrobat) format. I am not familiar with
all of the companies listed in the documents. I am releasing these
documents in the hope that someone may be able to shed some light on why
you seem to want this bill killed:

  http://www.mwvlug.org/legislation/oregon/rep_minnis.pdf
  
  http://www.mwvlug.org/legislation/oregon/rep_minnis_1.pdf


Please note that I made several sincere attempts to contact your office
of which I received only one call with a promise to speak with a member
of your staff, of which never materialized.

Representive Minnis, this bill is just as much about Oregon jobs as it
is about saving the taxpayer millions of dollars. It's frustrating to
have had the experience running computer systems worth millions; knowing
that Open Source Software is a better solution in many cases than
proprietary software. And yet have to face the reality that the market
is controlled by a monopoly; a monopoly who has made the process of
killing superior technology a science through illegal business
practices. This trend continues as new concerns are raised over the
terms of the DOJ v. Microsoft settlement.

I am simply at a loss why you seem to pander to out-of-state lobbyists
while ignoring hard working and skilled Oregonians who do not have jobs.

This bill as amended is a worthy bill and should pass, or at very least
be allowed to take it's due course. I urge your reconsideration in this
matter.


Very Truly Yours,


Cooper Stevenson

From montagne at boora.com  Thu Jun 19 13:24:02 2003
From: montagne at boora.com (Michael Montagne)
Date: Thu Jun 19 13:24:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Baby killing Linux
Message-ID: <20030619202329.GB12103@boora.com>

This is a mystery.  My two year old can sit down and completely lock up
my Linux box with a few keystrokes.  I'm assured she is only there for a
minute and this is probably true.  When I got home, there was an xterm
up with the string "  n   " on it.  Everything else was locked up.  No
keyboard, no mouse, no sshing in from a different machine, nothing.
Only option was a reboot.  Not good after my preaching about power,
reliability, and robustness.

So, what did she do?  If you had a few seconds to completely disable a
Linux system how would you do it?  Probably only with keystrokes and
not lgged in as root.  This has happened several times.


-- 
  Michael Montagne  http://www.themontagnes.com  503.226.1575 
--

Michael> completely lock up my Linux box with a few keystrokes.  

Whew!  I am glad there wasn't a hyphen in there.  I wouldn't want that
on my conscience.

Michael> I'm assured she is only there for a minute and this is
Michael> probably true.  When I got home, there was an xterm up with
Michael> the string " n " on it.  Everything else was locked up.  No
Michael> keyboard, no mouse, no sshing in from a different machine,

Michael> how would you do it?  Probably only with keystrokes and not
Michael> lgged in as root.

Me, personally, I'd hit the big red switch or the reset button.  If
the box is on the floor within reach, they are a severe temptation.

Michael> This has happened several times.

Good.  The first step to debugging most problems is repeatability.
Have your little girl show you how.  Video tape it if you have to, so
you can go back frame by frame and reconstruct what happened.

From shahms at shahms.com  Thu Jun 19 13:45:02 2003
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms King)
Date: Thu Jun 19 13:45:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Baby killing Linux
In-Reply-To: <A9031B213036D3119BD100A0C973D4BB039C3D80@exsalem6.odot.state.or.us>
References: 
	 <A9031B213036D3119BD100A0C973D4BB039C3D80@exsalem6.odot.state.or.us>
Message-ID: <1056055362.15453.8.camel@ltsp.mesd.k12.or.us>

Said he couldn't ssh into it, but I'd like to know if it's ping-able or
not.  The best way I know of to quickly "hang" a Linux box is to
convince the X server to consume all of your available resources (or, at
the very least, all of the CPU for a good long while).  Sadly, this
isn't always difficult to do on accident, but I seem to have a good deal
of trouble doing it on purpose ;-)

From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Thu Jun 19 13:52:01 2003

What do the logs say? Specifically bashrc - does it record long enough to show 
her particular keystrokes?

While doing help desk, I always encountered at least one "anti-computer" 
person: i.e. she had negative computer energy, or something. She fried a half 
dozen motherboards. Her computer locked up more frequently than anyone elses 
by 10 to 1. I gave her MY system, which had been rock solid - sure enough, 
within a day, it had locked up 3 times. She would also seem to burn out a ton 
of lights (when turned on by her) and she claimed that street lights would 
turn off whenever she came near.

Perhaps your daughter has this "negative computer energy"?? Scary! Lock the 
server room, quick!!! hahah!

M

From dgc at easystreet.com  Thu Jun 19 14:01:01 2003
From: dgc at easystreet.com (Dave Clemans)
Date: Thu Jun 19 14:01:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Baby killing Linux
Message-ID: <20030619210006.3717BB3DCB@dsl-209-162-216-78.dsl.easystreet.com>

There has been video card / xfree86 driver combinations in the past where
if you try to abruptly exit X windows (say via ctl-alt-backspace) the
video hardware isn't reset correctly back into "normal" mode.  You
could end up with garbage; the screen previous to hitting ctl-alt-bsp,
etc.

I don't know if this is still true with any current hardware, or with the
hardware of the person who's kid locks up his system...

dgc



From shahms at shahms.com  Thu Jun 19 14:06:01 2003
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms King)
Date: Thu Jun 19 14:06:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Baby killing Linux
In-Reply-To: <20030619202329.GB12103@boora.com>
References: <20030619202329.GB12103@boora.com>
Message-ID: <1056056677.15453.12.camel@ltsp.mesd.k12.or.us>

One thing that might be worth checking is, after power-cycling the
machine, boot into single user mode and check /var/log/messages and
/var/log/XFree86.0.log (you can do it without booting into single user,
but it makes finding the "most recent messages prior to rebooting"
*slightly* more difficult to find) and see if there are any telltale
kernel messages in /var/log/messages or (less likely) '(EE)' lines in
/var/log/XFree86.0.log 

On Thu, 2003-06-19 at 13:23, Michael Montagne wrote:
> This is a mystery.  My two year old can sit down and completely lock up
> my Linux box with a few keystrokes.  I'm assured she is only there for a
> minute and this is probably true.  When I got home, there was an xterm
> up with the string "  n   " on it.  Everything else was locked up.  No
> keyboard, no mouse, no sshing in from a different machine, nothing.
> Only option was a reboot.  Not good after my preaching about power,
> reliability, and robustness.
> 
> So, what did she do?  If you had a few seconds to completely disable a
> Linux system how would you do it?  Probably only with keystrokes and
> not lgged in as root.  This has happened several times.
-- 
Shahms King <shahms at shahms.com>




From root at loraksus.d2g.com  Thu Jun 19 14:10:03 2003
From: root at loraksus.d2g.com (Karol Kulaga)
Date: Thu Jun 19 14:10:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Baby killing Linux
In-Reply-To: <20030619202329.GB12103@boora.com>
Message-ID: <CJEBJJGCJIJOPJDPFFMACEHCCJAA.root@loraksus.d2g.com>

Drool on the keyboard perhaps? 

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
[mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org]On Behalf Of Michael Montagne
Sent: Thursday, June 19, 2003 1:23 PM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: [PLUG] Baby killing Linux


This is a mystery.  My two year old can sit down and completely lock up
my Linux box with a few keystrokes.  I'm assured she is only there for a
minute and this is probably true.  When I got home, there was an xterm
up with the string "  n   " on it.  Everything else was locked up.  No
keyboard, no mouse, no sshing in from a different machine, nothing.
Only option was a reboot.  Not good after my preaching about power,
reliability, and robustness.

So, what did she do?  If you had a few seconds to completely disable a
Linux system how would you do it?  Probably only with keystrokes and
not lgged in as root.  This has happened several times.


-- 
  Michael Montagne  http://www.themontagnes.com  503.226.1575 
--

PLUG mailing list
PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug




From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Thu Jun 19 14:15:02 2003
From: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Thu Jun 19 14:15:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] HB 2892
In-Reply-To: <3EF1E6CC.6000206@hevanet.com>
References: <3EF09F27.1060300@hevanet.com>  <3EF1E6CC.6000206@hevanet.com>
Message-ID: <1056053453.15414.152.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>

Honorable Representative Minnis;

I am writing today to express my deepest concern over the events
surrounding HB 2892, the Open Source Consideration Bill. 

The truth is, Representative, that it is very difficult in Oregon to get
Open Source related work. The Information Technology playing field in
Oregon-despite what Jim Craven with the AeA and other lobbyists may tell
you-is not level.

Moreover, HB 2892 does not seek to give preferential treatment to one
type of software over another; it simply requires the consideration of
Open Source Software. This is due primarily because Oregon's Request For
Procurement (RFP) system only considers established vendors. Open Source
applications that can often do the job as well or better than their
proprietary counterparts is sometimes not represented by any one vendor.
Thus, Open Source Software is not considered by those other than the
most technologically savvy Oregon IT departments.

I know from my familiarity with the DOJ v. Microsoft anti-trust trial
that Oregon's computer OEM's such as Intel and Hewlett Packard do not
wish to speak out on these types of issues for fear of retribution from
their primary software vendor. The software vendor can and has
threatened to pull support for a hardware platform. That would all but
devastate a hardware manufacturer's business model. As one industry
executive put it, "it's like being treated like a [bad] step child."

Steve McGeady, the former CEO for Intel, testified for the DOJ that
Intel's support of competing technologies (Netscape and Java) often put
them in hot water with their neighbors in Redmond. McGeady told the
court that in one 1995 meeting "Bill made it very clear that Microsoft
would not support our next processor offerings if we did not get
alignment"-on platform software-a threat that McGeady described as "both
credible and fairly terrifying." 

My guess is that Jim Craven didn't tell you that. I share this knowledge
to impress upon you that this industry is definitely anything but a
level playing field; as evidence contrary to what the lobbyists have
told you.

It is clear through submitted written and oral testimony during
committee as well as independent analysis and case history reports
worldwide that Open Source software can dramatically reduce the total
cost of ownership for State IT agencies.

There are many ways Open Source Software can help Oregon's government
perform it's duties. Try to imagine what effect a completely open and
secure IT system would have for the 911 consolidation project or for
benefit dispersement programs.

Because Open Source Software is superior in many cases, and because it
is known that OSS is effective in saving taxpayer dollars, I can only
conclude that there must be some other reason why a Republican would
want this bill killed.

The following are two links referencing contributions made to your
election campaign in PDF (Adobe Acrobat) format. I am not familiar with
all of the companies listed in the documents. I am releasing these
documents in the hope that someone may be able to shed some light on why
you seem to want this bill killed:

  http://www.mwvlug.org/legislation/oregon/rep_minnis.pdf
  
  http://www.mwvlug.org/legislation/oregon/rep_minnis_1.pdf


Please note that I made several sincere attempts to contact your office
of which I received only one call with a promise to speak with a member
of your staff, of which never materialized.

Representive Minnis, this bill is just as much about Oregon jobs as it
is about saving the taxpayer millions of dollars. It's frustrating to
have had the experience running computer systems worth millions; knowing
that Open Source Software is a better solution in many cases than
proprietary software. And yet have to face the reality that the market
is controlled by a monopoly; a monopoly who has made the process of
killing superior technology a science through illegal business
practices. This trend continues as new concerns are raised over the
terms of the DOJ v. Microsoft settlement.

I am simply at a loss why you seem to pander to out-of-state lobbyists
while ignoring hard working and skilled Oregonians who do not have jobs.

This bill as amended is a worthy bill and should pass, or at very least
be allowed to take it's due course. I urge your reconsideration in this
matter.


Very Truly Yours,


Cooper Stevenson




From dpool at hevanet.com  Thu Jun 19 14:15:17 2003
From: dpool at hevanet.com (david pool)
Date: Thu Jun 19 14:15:17 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Having the Open Source Discussion
References: <3EF09F27.1060300@hevanet.com> <3EF1E6CC.6000206@hevanet.com> <3EF209DE.9000902@hevanet.com>
Message-ID: <3EF21CB9.9010600@hevanet.com>

Legislaters,

An interesting Open Letter to Karen Minnis just got posted to the 
Portland Linux/Unix Group (PLUG) concerning HB 2892. The PLUG's 
list-serve is an open list so feel free to join us as we discuss it. You 
can sign up and tell us your perspectives, we'd love to hear it. 
http://www.pdxlinux.org/

Here's the letter:

Honorable Representative Minnis;


I am writing today to express my deepest concern over the events
surrounding HB 2892, the Open Source Consideration Bill. 

The truth is, Representative, that it is very difficult in Oregon to get
Open Source related work. The Information Technology playing field in
Oregon-despite what Jim Craven with the AeA and other lobbyists may tell
you-is not level.

Moreover, HB 2892 does not seek to give preferential treatment to one
type of software over another; it simply requires the consideration of
Open Source Software. This is due primarily because Oregon's Request For
Procurement (RFP) system only considers established vendors. Open Source
applications that can often do the job as well or better than their
proprietary counterparts is sometimes not represented by any one vendor.
Thus, Open Source Software is not considered by those other than the
most technologically savvy Oregon IT departments.

I know from my familiarity with the DOJ v. Microsoft anti-trust trial
that Oregon's computer OEM's such as Intel and Hewlett Packard do not
wish to speak out on these types of issues for fear of retribution from
their primary software vendor. The software vendor can and has
threatened to pull support for a hardware platform. That would all but
devastate a hardware manufacturer's business model. As one industry
executive put it, "it's like being treated like a [bad] step child."

Steve McGeady, the former CEO for Intel, testified for the DOJ that
Intel's support of competing technologies (Netscape and Java) often put
them in hot water with their neighbors in Redmond. McGeady told the
court that in one 1995 meeting "Bill made it very clear that Microsoft
would not support our next processor offerings if we did not get
alignment"-on platform software-a threat that McGeady described as "both
credible and fairly terrifying." 

My guess is that Jim Craven didn't tell you that. I share this knowledge
to impress upon you that this industry is definitely anything but a
level playing field; as evidence contrary to what the lobbyists have
told you.

It is clear through submitted written and oral testimony during
committee as well as independent analysis and case history reports
worldwide that Open Source software can dramatically reduce the total
cost of ownership for State IT agencies.

There are many ways Open Source Software can help Oregon's government
perform it's duties. Try to imagine what effect a completely open and
secure IT system would have for the 911 consolidation project or for
benefit dispersement programs.

Because Open Source Software is superior in many cases, and because it
is known that OSS is effective in saving taxpayer dollars, I can only
conclude that there must be some other reason why a Republican would
want this bill killed.

The following are two links referencing contributions made to your
election campaign in PDF (Adobe Acrobat) format. I am not familiar with
all of the companies listed in the documents. I am releasing these
documents in the hope that someone may be able to shed some light on why
you seem to want this bill killed:

  http://www.mwvlug.org/legislation/oregon/rep_minnis.pdf
  
  http://www.mwvlug.org/legislation/oregon/rep_minnis_1.pdf


Please note that I made several sincere attempts to contact your office
of which I received only one call with a promise to speak with a member
of your staff, of which never materialized.

Representive Minnis, this bill is just as much about Oregon jobs as it
is about saving the taxpayer millions of dollars. It's frustrating to
have had the experience running computer systems worth millions; knowing
that Open Source Software is a better solution in many cases than
proprietary software. And yet have to face the reality that the market
is controlled by a monopoly; a monopoly who has made the process of
killing superior technology a science through illegal business
practices. This trend continues as new concerns are raised over the
terms of the DOJ v. Microsoft settlement.

I am simply at a loss why you seem to pander to out-of-state lobbyists
while ignoring hard working and skilled Oregonians who do not have jobs.

This bill as amended is a worthy bill and should pass, or at very least
be allowed to take it's due course. I urge your reconsideration in this
matter.


Very Truly Yours,


Cooper Stevenson

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Thu Jun 19 14:38:02 2003

Date: Thu Jun 19 14:38:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Baby killing Linux
In-Reply-To: <20030619202329.GB12103@boora.com>

On Thu, Jun 19, 2003 at 01:23:29PM -0700, Michael Montagne wrote:
> 
> So, what did she do?  If you had a few seconds to completely disable a
> Linux system how would you do it?  Probably only with keystrokes and
> not lgged in as root.  This has happened several times.

Okay, conspiracy theory time...

The Echelon network should have picked this up about 15 minutes ago,
which means that it's already in the hands of the FBI.  A few
hours from now, it will be in hands of the President's press core,
who will then make the following press release:

Ladies and Gentlemen, we have found the weapons of mass destruction
in Iraq, but in a way we thought even beyond the cruel, inhuman
rule of Saddam Hussein.

[Flash to picture of a smiling baby]

The mobile laboratories were not for creating viruses and deadly
plagues, there were actually for genetically manipulating innocent
babies.

[Flash to picture of rows of test tubes]

[Fade to picture of rows of cribs with babies]

These babies have been programmed to destroy technology.  When they see
it, their programming takes over and they implement preset
intructions based on the type of technology such as:

1) Inserting peanut butter and jelly sandwiches into VCRs and DVD players.
2) Sticking their fingers into electrical sockets, shorting out the
   local neighborhood power grids.

One child has even been reported to be able to disable computers running
the vaunted Linux operating system.  It's immune to viruses, but these
children can disable the most hardened Linux box within seconds.  There
are no confirmed reports of Microsoft Windows being vulnerable to
these children.

[Flash to picture of money changing hands]

As a side effect, they produce noxious substances that necessitate
filling our landfills with plastic and chemicals {What, they did that
before?  Well, it still stinks!}

Their master plan was to fill orphanages with these children, and then,
taking advantage of the charity and mercy of American parents, and the
President's new faith-based initiative, to have them be adopted into
loving homes in the United States, where they would wreak their havoc.

[Picture of the lights turning out in Wall Street in mid-trade]

[Picture of massive grid-lock]

We believe that we have identified many of the altered children
and our scientists are working to see if the programming can be
undone.



From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Jun 19 14:42:01 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu Jun 19 14:42:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Baby killing Linux
In-Reply-To: <200306191410.30875.matt@legalizefreedom.org>
References: <20030619202329.GB12103@boora.com> <200306191410.30875.matt@legalizefreedom.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306191436210.17043@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 19 Jun 2003, Matt Chorman wrote:
> While doing help desk, I always encountered at least one "anti-computer"
> person: i.e. she had negative computer energy, or something. She fried a
> half dozen motherboards. Her computer locked up more frequently than
> anyone elses by 10 to 1. I gave her MY system, which had been rock solid
> - sure enough, within a day, it had locked up 3 times.

This very well could be the placement of her system.  My parents were
flying through computer components and had serious lock-ups all the
time... turned out their computer was kept on the other side of the wall
from the power conduit into the house.  They moved the computer and
didn't have another problem of that sort.

I've also fixed many a problem with folks' monitors that were just in the
wrong part of the room.  One woman sent back three monitors as defective
when it was discovered to just be some magnetic interference and moving
her desk fixed it.  (Though, to her credit, the monitors were damaged
enough to have visible display problems even when moved after a couple of
weeks' operation in the evil zone.)

> She would also seem to burn out a ton of lights (when turned on by her)
> and she claimed that street lights would turn off whenever she came
> near.

Street lights turn off all the time and some people notice it and others
don't.  There are people who say they've never seen a streetlight turn off
and others who say they turn off whenever they're around (which isn't at
all reproducible).

I had a friend in school who couldn't handle magnetic media of any kind.
Audio cassettes, floppy disks, and other things would degrade more quickly
in his possession than with other people.  He had to copy his audio
cassettes every few weeks (from originals he kept in the basement and
handled only at copying time) and could GUARANTEE the corruption of a
floppy disk carried in his pocket from the computer lab to his home.  So
maybe there's something to the lightbulb thing, too.

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

 http://www.openlaw.org

From danielx.j.petcher at intel.com  Thu Jun 19 15:06:02 2003
From: danielx.j.petcher at intel.com (Petcher, Danielx J)
Date: Thu Jun 19 15:06:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Baby killing Linux
Message-ID: <7D6F4CF55743264F8B23E20353705EEC089290@orsmsx408.amr.corp.intel.com>

If you have a KVM switch with a spare port, you might consider switching
keyboard and mouse to the vacant port while the little one is around.
This will rule-out whether it's the kid's keyboard action or the kid's
mere presence that's hurting your PC.

-djp
http://folding.stanford.edu - the brain you save may be your own!

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Michael Montagne [mailto:montagne at boora.com]
> Sent: Thursday, June 19, 2003 1:23 PM
> To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
> Subject: [PLUG] Baby killing Linux
> 
> This is a mystery.  My two year old can sit down and completely lock
up
> my Linux box with a few keystrokes.  I'm assured she is only there for
a
> minute and this is probably true.  When I got home, there was an xterm
> up with the string "  n   " on it.  Everything else was locked up.  No
> keyboard, no mouse, no sshing in from a different machine, nothing.
> Only option was a reboot.  Not good after my preaching about power,
> reliability, and robustness.
> 
> So, what did she do?  If you had a few seconds to completely disable a
> Linux system how would you do it?  Probably only with keystrokes and
> not lgged in as root.  This has happened several times.
> 
> 
> --
>   Michael Montagne  http://www.themontagnes.com  503.226.1575

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Jun 19 15:11:17 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu Jun 19 15:11:17 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT  Re: Baby killing Linux
In-Reply-To: <3EF1CBE8.22549.EEC39A9@localhost>
References: <3EF1CBE8.22549.EEC39A9@localhost>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306191449240.17043@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 19 Jun 2003, Richard Williamson wrote:
> Ain't English great. I'm not multilingual. Can phrases can be
> interpreted in different ways so easily in other languages?

Yes.  Actually, it even seems that things like "garden path" sentences
exist in every language.

A garden path sentence is one that cannot be parsed normally because the
word choice leads to a premature parsing of the sentence which assigns
meanings not applicable to the actual sentence stated.  These sentences
are perfectly grammatical, but totally unusable.

Two of my personal favorites:

The old man the boat.
The horse ran past the barn fell.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

From guy1656 at ados.com  Thu Jun 19 15:30:03 2003
From: guy1656 at ados.com (guy1656)
Date: Thu Jun 19 15:30:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT  Re: Baby killing Linux
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306191449240.17043@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <3EF1CBE8.22549.EEC39A9@localhost> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306191449240.17043@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <200306191529.24421.guy1656@ados.com>

Jeme A Brelin wrote:
: On Thu, 19 Jun 2003, Richard Williamson wrote:
: > Ain't English great. I'm not multilingual. Can phrases can be
: > interpreted in different ways so easily in other languages?

: Yes.  Actually, it even seems that things like "garden path" sentences
: exist in every language.

In Japanese, where individual syllables can be represented by many characters 
(about 34 characters are pronounced 'sei,' for example)  many two-character 
words have unrelated homophones. Thus there is a habit of tracing the 
characters, using the right hand as if writing on the palm of the left, in 
spots where confusion might occur. This habit can become so autonomic that 
you can see people doing it while on the phone. 

: Two of my personal favorites:
:
: The old man the boat.
: The horse ran past the barn fell.

Reminds me of Penn-Dutch country, where you can hear gems like: "Throw the 
horse over the fence some hay."

You can also have fun with mixed modifiers, such as the 'giant tire sale.'

GLL

Yes, user

The funny thing is that is dosen't recognize
it's own command/switch structure


NAME
       named - Internet domain name server

SYNOPSIS
       named  [  -c  config-file  ]   [ -d debug-level ]  [ -f ]  [ -g
]  [ -n
       #cpus ]  [ -p port ]  [ -s ]  [ -t directory ]  [ -u user ]  [ -v
]   [
       -x cache-file ]

That is the way it is called out in bind9 file..

??????

On Thu, 19 Jun 2003 15:29:24 -0700
guy1656 <guy1656 at ados.com> wrote:

> Reminds me of Penn-Dutch country, where you can hear gems like: "Throw the 
> horse over the fence some hay."

Or, "Amos stung his toe with a bee."  But these are just quaint
ambiguities, whereas Baby Killing Linux is likely to offend someone. If
Linux is to have any mass appeal, we're simply going to need better
names for distro's.  ("Slackware" and "Woody" are bad enough.)

--Jason V. C.



From serendipity at pobox.com  Thu Jun 19 17:09:01 2003
From: serendipity at pobox.com (Brian Quade)
Date: Thu Jun 19 17:09:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] problem changing local domain name
Message-ID: <3EF24ED2.4000409@pobox.com>

This is more of an admin question but there is no admin list, so I am 
posting it here.

Way back when I originally installed Linux on my system, I set it up 
with the host name 'myhost.testdomain'.  Now I am learning to set up 
BIND and want to change my domain and host names to something that makes 
more sense.  Since my machine uses the hosts file to resolve local host 
names, I thought I could simply change the information in hosts and it 
would work.  Not so.  After I did that, I could no longer get to the 
graphical login screen that I always use to login to KDE, I can only log 
in in text mode.  And after I logged in in text mode, I ran the hostname 
command and it showed the old host name, not the new one that I changed 
it to.  I changed my hosts file back to the way it was and logged in 
again and it sends me to the graphical login screen again.  I did this 
several times.  I tried changing /etc/sysconfig/network too but it made 
no difference.

So my main question is: Where does the hostname command get its 
information?  Not entirely from the hosts file.  But from where?

And when I log in, there is something that must compare the information 
in the hosts file with some information stored somewhere else (where?), 
and if the information is different then it forces me to log in in text 
mode.  What is it comparing hosts to?  (Probably the same information 
that the hostname command uses to get its information, I just can't find 
it.)

The main thing I need to do is figure out how to change my local domain 
and host names properly.  Does anyone know how to do this?  I can't 
really start experimenting with BIND until I get my domain and host 
names set up correctly.


What else can I tell you?
I am using Red Hat 7.3.
I am using a static IP address on my local network which is set up 
behind a gateway router.
I have full Internet access the way my system is currently set up.





From m at pdxlug.org  Thu Jun 19 17:16:02 2003
From: m at pdxlug.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Thu Jun 19 17:16:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] problem changing local domain name
In-Reply-To: <3EF24ED2.4000409@pobox.com>
References: <3EF24ED2.4000409@pobox.com>
Message-ID: <7852.68.96.48.205.1056068106.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>

The 'hostname' command will change the name for the running system.  For
example, 'hostname foo.bar.com'
If you want this change to last a reboot, then you should edit
/etc/sysconfig/network and /etc/hosts, which are read by the various
scripts and daemons when the system starts up.


Brian Quade said:
> This is more of an admin question but there is no admin list, so I am
> posting it here.

On Thu, 2003-06-19 at 14:42, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> On Thu, 19 Jun 2003, Matt Chorman wrote:
> > While doing help desk, I always encountered at least one "anti-computer"
> > person: i.e. she had negative computer energy, or something. She fried a
> > half dozen motherboards. Her computer locked up more frequently than
> > anyone elses by 10 to 1. I gave her MY system, which had been rock solid
> > - sure enough, within a day, it had locked up 3 times.

> I had a friend in school who couldn't handle magnetic media of any kind.
> Audio cassettes, floppy disks, and other things would degrade more quickly
> in his possession than with other people.  He had to copy his audio
> cassettes every few weeks (from originals he kept in the basement and
> handled only at copying time) and could GUARANTEE the corruption of a
> floppy disk carried in his pocket from the computer lab to his home.  So
> maybe there's something to the lightbulb thing, too.
> 
My mother can only wear stainless steel wind-up watches, ALL others quit
working within 2 weeks. She doesn't have a problem with magnetic media,
as far as I know anyway.  Compasses don't act funny around her either :)

Derek Loree





From drl at drloree.com  Thu Jun 19 18:35:03 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Thu Jun 19 18:35:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] bind9
In-Reply-To: <1056063639.696.10.camel@farm-libranet>
References: <1056063639.696.10.camel@farm-libranet>
Message-ID: <1056073147.620.21.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Thu, 2003-06-19 at 16:00, Marvin J. Kosmal wrote:
> Anyone using bind9
> 
> I am having a problem with the following line..
> 
> 
>  # for a chrooted server: "-u nobody -t /var/lib/named"
> 
> This is from /etc/init.d/bind9
> 
> When I run it.
> 
> I get "what's -u" ?????????
> 
This line is a comment in the /etc/init.d/bind9 file on my Debian box. 
It is referring to the OPTIONS="" (it is empty on mine anyway) variable
below the comment.

There is also a line:

# Don't modify this line, change or create /etc/default/bind9.

Which means my system loads OPTIONS from /etc/default/bind9, which has
in it the text:

OPTIONS="-u bind"

So, Bind9 runs as the user "bind" in a chroot environment on my system.

HTH

Derek Loree





From keith at ahapala.net  Thu Jun 19 19:45:03 2003
From: keith at ahapala.net (Keith Nasman)
Date: Thu Jun 19 19:45:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Thinkpad 600 for sale
Message-ID: <32843.10.0.0.100.1056077067.squirrel@skua.ahapala.net>

I used this laptop for nearly a year and it worked really well for me,
even running RH 8 decently.

There is only one thing that is not up to snuff and that is the screen. If
the laptop is put to sleep and then awakened the screen has a neat pink
tint to it that gradually fades. When the screen is warmed up there is
only the slightest
bit of tint in the upper right corner.

Here are the specs:

IBM Thinkpad 600
266Mhz Pentium Processor
256Mb RAM
4Gb HD
CD-ROM
Floppy
One year old battery

and two spare 32Mb sticks o' RAM

I'm asking $250 for it.

Please email me personally if you are interested.

Keith



From sean at fork.com  Thu Jun 19 21:21:01 2003
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Thu Jun 19 21:21:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Baby killing Linux
In-Reply-To: <20030619202329.GB12103@boora.com>
References: <20030619202329.GB12103@boora.com>
Message-ID: <200306191809.36990.sean@fork.com>

I took my son to work one day (he was then two) and he was running around the 
office, while I was fiddling with my Sun workstation.  I noticed he was 
playing with the workstation of one of the other admins who had left the 
company recently.  Anyway before I left I pinged the workstation and it 
responded so we left.

Two days later at work our sendmail admin (Dan Haskell) noticed that our 
server load was growing out of control.  He reset it and we went home.  Next 
day we looked again and it was still out of control.  So we went and looked 
at some ORCA graphs and correlated the change in sendmail behavior to 
Saturday afternoon when I was in the office with my son.  Turns out he must 
have hit the power button just so to upset the OS but not enough to reboot 
it.  It was still reponding to pings and other stuff but ssh and sendmail was 
down which was causing our sendmail server to hang as it was trying to spool 
mail onto the workstation.

Might not be keyboard activities is my point.


Sean

On Thursday 19 June 2003 01:23 pm, Michael Montagne wrote:
> This is a mystery.  My two year old can sit down and completely lock up
> my Linux box with a few keystrokes.  I'm assured she is only there for a
> minute and this is probably true.  When I got home, there was an xterm
> up with the string "  n   " on it.  Everything else was locked up.  No
> keyboard, no mouse, no sshing in from a different machine, nothing.
> Only option was a reboot.  Not good after my preaching about power,
> reliability, and robustness.
>
> So, what did she do?  If you had a few seconds to completely disable a
> Linux system how would you do it?  Probably only with keystrokes and
> not lgged in as root.  This has happened several times.

-- 
If a nation values anything more than freedom, it will lose its freedom;
and the irony of it is that if it is comfort or money it values more, it
will lose that, too.
                -- W. Somerset Maugham

This contract is about 1 month + and has to be done onsite about 30 miles
South of Portland.

Requirements: HTML, JavaScript, XML, IBM Net.Data macros, CSS (Cascading
style sheets), Some knowledge of RPG would be helpful, but not absolutely
necessary.

The client is building a Customer "Portal" to the ERP system.  There are
several customer facing applications that will allow the customer to view
their information on the net.  Some of the applications are A/R, Sales
History, Available Inventory.

Please contact me if you're interested.

From charlie at schluting.com  Fri Jun 20 10:56:01 2003
From: charlie at schluting.com (Charlie Schluting)
Date: Fri Jun 20 10:56:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] bind9
In-Reply-To: <1056130433.768.20.camel@libranet>
References: <PCECIDMMGLFNFLCAPEAPKEHICPAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>	<1056125720.657.9.camel@libranet> <1056128341.657.17.camel@libranet> 	<3EF3400A.3020501@schluting.com> <1056130433.768.20.camel@libranet>
Message-ID: <3EF34A94.4090304@schluting.com>

Ok, here's the deal. you have to set up rndc now. It uses keys and stuff 
so that you can do things remotely (without ssh'ing in). Time to read 
the bind9 docs :)

using ndc reload is probably trying to muck with a previous version of bind.

--charlie

    I am trying to figure out where to put my server for co-lo. I am
currently looking at a rack in Texas, because they are much cheaper. I need
between120GB/month to 200GB/month of transfer, and my current quotes have
been between $799 and $1250 for Portland-based locations. I have found one
for $250, but they don't reply to emails, which is always a concern.. If

From ed at alcpress.com  Fri Jun 20 12:16:01 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Fri Jun 20 12:16:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] bind9
In-Reply-To: <1056130433.768.20.camel@libranet>
References: <PCECIDMMGLFNFLCAPEAPKEHICPAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
	 <1056125720.657.9.camel@libranet> <1056128341.657.17.camel@libranet>
	 <3EF3400A.3020501@schluting.com>  <1056130433.768.20.camel@libranet>
Message-ID: <1056136520.16226.238.camel@red>

On Fri, 2003-06-20 at 10:33, Marvin J. Kosmal wrote:
> I wasn't
> 
> But this is what I get now...
> 
> 
> root at kosmal:/etc/init.d# rndc reload
> rndc: connect failed: connection refused
> 
> 
> Thanks

Maybe you need to use simpler DNS software
that allows you to capitalize on your current
skills.

BIND8 still works well as long as you run it
as either an authority server or a cache - not
both. Few of us really need the features of
BIND9. For example, do you really need a
BIND-specific, secure protocol (rndc) to your
remote DNS daemon when you already know how to
use SSH?

The djbdns software is also simpler though it
may not seem so at first.

On Fri, 2003-06-20 at 12:12, Roman Robinson wrote:
> Hi,
>     I am trying to figure out where to put my server for co-lo. I am
> currently looking at a rack in Texas,

If it's rackspace.com, you need to know that their IP
addresses are on many blacklists. You can use them as
long as you don't want to send mail from there.

From jason at vancleve.com  Fri Jun 20 12:43:02 2003
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Fri Jun 20 12:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Portland Co-Lo's
References: <002b01c3375f$ec49b4a0$6401a8c0@dual>
Message-ID: <12E04DA8.9050208@vancleve.com>

I use SprocketData(.com), which was recommended by this very list.  They 
too have a way of dragging their feet and not paying close attention to 
emails, plus their internal DNS servers keep cutting out for short 
intervals, so they're not perfect.  But they're cheap, flexible and 
Linux-friendly.

--Jason Van Cleve

From bsr at spek.org  Fri Jun 20 13:19:01 2003
From: bsr at spek.org (Brent Rieck)
Date: Fri Jun 20 13:19:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Portland Co-Lo's
In-Reply-To: <002b01c3375f$ec49b4a0$6401a8c0@dual>
References: <002b01c3375f$ec49b4a0$6401a8c0@dual>
Message-ID: <1056140282.9367.2434.camel@obelisk.spek.org>

Have you checked out serverbeach.com?  I have no idea if they suck or
not but they have a halfway decent Linux boxes with 450GB of traffic for
$119/month, or a less than halfway decent box for $99/month.  You don't
own the machine, but you do get root on the box and can do whatever you
please with it (within their TOS).

--Brent

From ed at alcpress.com  Fri Jun 20 13:27:01 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Fri Jun 20 13:27:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Portland Co-Lo's

	 <1056136622.16225.241.camel@red>  <005801c33767$aac1e9a0$6401a8c0@dual>
Message-ID: <1056140754.16226.250.camel@red>

On Fri, 2003-06-20 at 13:08, Roman Robinson wrote:
> I didn't know they were that bad off.. How come?

Because many of their customers are spammers and
they won't work with the folks who maintain black
lists. If you ask them what IP address range one of
their spammer customers use, they won't tell you.
So, you block an entire /24 at a time. I'm blocking
many of their /24s.


> 
> I was thinking of using theplanet.com however, I have a friend on them right
> now.
> 
> --Roman

From jtodd at loligo.com  Fri Jun 20 15:00:02 2003

>Hi,
>     I am trying to figure out where to put my server for co-lo. I am
>currently looking at a rack in Texas, because they are much cheaper. I need
>between120GB/month to 200GB/month of transfer, and my current quotes have
>been between $799 and $1250 for Portland-based locations. I have found one
>for $250, but they don't reply to emails, which is always a concern.. If
>anyone can help with where to go to look for a co-lo, please post!!

>

I was looking at opening a tertiary location here in Portland a while 
ago, and did some non-exhaustive surveys of co-lo providers in the 
area.

These are Portland-based services:

SpireTech
http://www.spiretech.com/shared_colocation.htm
$100/mo for 100g
- make sure you understand what kind of A/C power you're buying


FORTiX
http://www.fortix.net/
- very responsive sales team
- were willing to work with me on pricing


Inherent
http://www.Inherent.com/
- by far the most expensive I had quotes from


Synapse Global
http://www.synapseglobal.com/colocation/index.htm



Due to various external reasons, I decided to stick with my 
non-Portland West coast provider, which was Hurricane Electric. 
Their $500/mo for a full rack _and_ 256kbps (~80gb) of traffic is a 
hard number to beat, though their location in Fremont, CA is 
difficult to service on a regular basis.  (Hey, I've got some space 
left over, if for $25/mo anyone needs space for a 1u machine that 
consumes less than ~2gb per month - perfect for personal email, DNS, 
or authentication servers)

JT

From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Jun 20 15:17:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri Jun 20 15:17:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Hard drive recovery services local to PDX
In-Reply-To: <20030620220015.GB1137@dalsemi.com>
References: <20030620220015.GB1137@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306201515240.4992@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Fri, 20 Jun 2003, Colin Kuskie wrote:
> As long as we're on the subject of local services, are there any local
> shops for hard drive recovery?  I have a Seagate hard drive that
> absolutely refuses to mount, and along with the strange ticking sound
> that it makes convinces me that the drive is damaged.

Before you spend a fortune, try this ridiculous method:

Wrap the drive in a towel, then put it in a plastic bag and put it in the
freezer.  Wait until it's frozen cold (three or so hours in my freezer),
then try to hook it up.

You might get one good mount out of the thing and save your data.

I've heard various people attempt to explain why this works, but nothing
too concrete.  Anecdotal, I've saved two drives of data this way and I've
read dozens of other stories.

Data recovery is exhorbitantly costly.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

copyright issues by saying that technology should be developed to
remotely destroy the computers of people who illegally download
copyrighted material from the Internet. A spokesman in Hatch's office,

From jtodd at loligo.com  Fri Jun 20 15:45:02 2003
From: jtodd at loligo.com (John Todd)
Date: Fri Jun 20 15:45:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Hard drive recovery services local to PDX
In-Reply-To: 
 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306201514140.16715-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: 
 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306201514140.16715-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <p05210632bb193b0a666d@loligo.com>

>On Fri, 20 Jun 2003, Colin Kuskie wrote:
>
>>  As long as we're on the subject of local services, are there any local
>>  shops for hard drive recovery?  I have a Seagate hard drive that
>>  absolutely refuses to mount, and along with the strange ticking sound
>>  that it makes convinces me that the drive is damaged.
>
>Colin,
>
>   There was a fellow to whom I took a drive about 7 years ago. I don't know
>if he's still in business, and that was a DOS drive, too. he recovered about
>85-90% but it was terribly expensive -- about $300, IIRC. However, since it
>held business data I had to get what I could from it.
>
>   Unfortunately, I've no recollection of how I found him.
>
>Rich
>
>Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
[overly large .sig snipped]

Sorry to be a bit off-topic, as this is not a recommendation for 
Portland-based disk-recovery services.

$300 is actually extremely reasonable, depending on your 
circumstances.  I have paid $1500 for a 2g SCSI drive, and once paid 
$15,000 to recover two RAID'ed SCSI drives with an entire company's 
customer/installation/billng database on it, which of course, was not 
backed up.  It failed on the day before Thanksgiving, around 16:30, 
and we were back on line the next business morning with 30 minutes to 
spare.  That involved hand-delivering the drives to the airport and 
charging <gulp> the full $15,000 on the corporate AmEx of the CEO, 
and needless to say I did not have a particularly thankful 
Thanksgiving as I managed the recovery folks and the sysadmins to put 
things together again.  However, we were four weeks away from IPO, 
and a $15k pricetag was extremely small in comparison to the company 
shutting down as we went into the final stages of the public 
offering.  The sysadmin was not fired, amazingly enough, despite my 
screaming at the Ops manager.  It's all relative, I suppose.  In any 
case, I'd be very happy with a $300 disk recovery under any 
circumstances if you're talking to someone with a cleanroom and full 
diag capability and not just someone with an IDE sector tool in their 
garage.

I used OnTrack (http://www.ontrack.com/) and have been enthusiastic 
about my service through them, though they are very expensive.  They 
have recovered Mac, SunOS, and Windows disks for me and/or my staff, 
and they have a 99% data recovery record.

As another side note: if you have two older drives of the same type, 
one working and one not working you can do a triage recovery 
(sometimes) if you're particularly adept with a screwdriver and have 
a room that is exceptionally dust-free.  Move platters from one drive 
to the other - not for the weak of heart or shaky of hand.  Newer 
drives probably are hermetically sealed; I haven't tried that trick 
in many years, but I've done it on many laptop drives and they lived 
long enough to get the data off them into some other form.

JT

Here's the whole story:

The machine in question is a lab machine for data acquisition, serial
port and parallel port interfaces to digital sections of chips,
GPIB for analog stimulus and measurement.

Over last weekend, both drives, the small 3 Gb holding the OS and the
large 40 Gb holding user directories, failed.  Now, the good news is
all collected data and software and tools are under version control
where the repository is NFS mounted from a NetApp, and that's backed up
regularly.   So what we really lost were our Linux dot-files and the
high scores for KAsteroids.

If there was a local place that was cheap, then I'd consider getting
a quote but no one has suggested particular places, just warnings
(that I greatly appreciate) about cost.  I'll hit the YP.

Colin

> >Sent: Friday, June 20, 2003 2:50 PM
> >Subject: Re: [PLUG] Portland Co-Lo's
> >
> >
> >>  >Hi,
> >>  >     I am trying to figure out where to put my server for co-lo. I am
> >>  >currently looking at a rack in Texas, because they are much cheaper.
I
> >need
> >>  >between120GB/month to 200GB/month of transfer, and my current quotes
have
> >>  >been between $799 and $1250 for Portland-based locations. I have
found
> >one
> >>  >for $250, but they don't reply to emails, which is always a concern..
If
> >>  >anyone can help with where to go to look for a co-lo, please post!!
> >>  >
> >>  >--Roman
> >>  >
> >>
> >>  I was looking at opening a tertiary location here in Portland a while
> >>  ago, and did some non-exhaustive surveys of co-lo providers in the
> >>  area.
> >>
> >>  These are Portland-based services:
> >>
> >>  SpireTech
> >  > http://www.spiretech.com/shared_colocation.htm
> >>  $100/mo for 100g
> >>  - make sure you understand what kind of A/C power you're buying
> >>
> >>
> >>  FORTiX
> >>  http://www.fortix.net/
> >>  - very responsive sales team
> >>  - were willing to work with me on pricing
> >>
> >>
> >>  Inherent
> >>  http://www.Inherent.com/
> >>  - by far the most expensive I had quotes from
> >>
> >>
> >>  Synapse Global
> >>  http://www.synapseglobal.com/colocation/index.htm
> >>
> >>
> >>
> >>  Due to various external reasons, I decided to stick with my
> >>  non-Portland West coast provider, which was Hurricane Electric.
> >>  Their $500/mo for a full rack _and_ 256kbps (~80gb) of traffic is a
> >>  hard number to beat, though their location in Fremont, CA is
> >>  difficult to service on a regular basis.  (Hey, I've got some space
> >>  left over, if for $25/mo anyone needs space for a 1u machine that
> >>  consumes less than ~2gb per month - perfect for personal email, DNS,
> >>  or authentication servers)

From jason at vancleve.com  Fri Jun 20 17:19:02 2003
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Fri Jun 20 17:19:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Hard drive recovery services local to PDX
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306201515240.4992@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <20030620220015.GB1137@dalsemi.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.52.0306201515240.4992@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <20030620191809.526a8e86.jason@vancleve.com>

You ain't whistlin' Dixie.  When my primary HD crashed a few weeks ago,
I made a call and was told $100 for an eval', then $1500-$2500 for the
actual recovery.  I let the drive cool overnight, popped it in the next
day, got a mount, and ended up replacing the whole system on another
drive.  It was like putting Humpty Dumpty back together again.

--Jason V. C.


On Fri, 20 Jun 2003 15:17:16 -0700 (PDT)
Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> wrote:

> 
> On Fri, 20 Jun 2003, Colin Kuskie wrote:
> > As long as we're on the subject of local services, are there any
> > local shops for hard drive recovery?  I have a Seagate hard drive
> > that absolutely refuses to mount, and along with the strange ticking
> > sound that it makes convinces me that the drive is damaged.
> 
> Before you spend a fortune, try this ridiculous method:
> 
> Wrap the drive in a towel, then put it in a plastic bag and put it in
> the freezer.  Wait until it's frozen cold (three or so hours in my
> freezer), then try to hook it up.
> 
> You might get one good mount out of the thing and save your data.
> 
> I've heard various people attempt to explain why this works, but
> nothing too concrete.  Anecdotal, I've saved two drives of data this
> way and I've read dozens of other stories.
> 
> Data recovery is exhorbitantly costly.
> 
> J.
> -- 
>    -----------------
>      Jeme A Brelin
>     jeme at brelin.net
>    -----------------

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Fri Jun 20 21:38:01 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor Pikus)
Date: Fri Jun 20 21:38:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] VMWare
In-Reply-To: <1056165549.948.13.camel@main>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0306202130040.16981-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

I use it, but the company I work for bought the license for me. It's nice
if you have a Windows application which does not run under Wine and for
which there is no adequate Linux replacement (for example, Photoshop).
They used to have a license for personal use at only $99, but it's no
longer offered. Would I pay $280 myself for it? Probably not. There is
Win4Lin which runs the same Photoshop, and sells for under $100 (VMware is
better, it runs Win2K, and other Linuxes, and pretty much any guest OS you
want, while Win4Lin runs only Win98/ME). But for $280 I'd probably
dual-boot if I had to :)

On 20 Jun 2003, Steven A. Adams wrote:
> Anybody use VMWare to manage Windows installations from a real OS
> (*nix). For those that do, in your honest opinion, is it worth $279.00?
>
> Steve
>

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Jun 20 21:50:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri Jun 20 21:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] VMWare
In-Reply-To: <1056165549.948.13.camel@main>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306202146050.17455-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On 20 Jun 2003, Steven A. Adams wrote:

> Anybody use VMWare to manage Windows installations from a real OS
> (*nix). For those that do, in your honest opinion, is it worth $279.00?
 
Steve,

  I'm not sure I know just what you're asking. I have vmware installed here
because my legacy GIS application and my GPS mission planning/differential
correction software run only on Microsoft. Is it worth it to me? Yup.

  I started with the pre-1.0 beta versions (I think the build number was in
two digits) and I've paid for upgrades for each major release. Because of
vmware I don't need another box running Microsoft and I don't need to dual
boot. I can transfer data back and forth via samba and my two apps are there
when I need them. Otherwise, they just take up a 2G partition on one of the
hard drives.

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

                       Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
            2404 SW 22nd Street | Troutdale, OR 97060-1247 | U.S.A.
 + 1 503-667-4517 (voice) | + 1 503-667-8863 (fax) | rshepard&#64;appl-ecosys.com
                         http://www.appl-ecosys.com/

From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Fri Jun 20 23:53:02 2003
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: Fri Jun 20 23:53:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] VMWare
In-Reply-To: <1056175510.944.24.camel@main>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306202341400.13969-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>


On 20 Jun 2003, Steven A. Adams wrote:

> On Fri, 2003-06-20 at 21:49, Rich Shepard wrote:
> > On 20 Jun 2003, Steven A. Adams wrote:
> >
> > > Anybody use VMWare to manage Windows installations from a real OS
> > > (*nix). For those that do, in your honest opinion, is it worth $279.00?
> >
> > Steve,
> >
> >   I'm not sure I know just what you're asking. I have vmware installed here
> > because my legacy GIS application and my GPS mission planning/differential
> > correction software run only on Microsoft. Is it worth it to me? Yup.
> >
> >   I started with the pre-1.0 beta versions (I think the build number was in
> > two digits) and I've paid for upgrades for each major release. Because of
> > vmware I don't need another box running Microsoft and I don't need to dual
> > boot. I can transfer data back and forth via samba and my two apps are there
> > when I need them. Otherwise, they just take up a 2G partition on one of the
> > hard drives.
> >
>
> I'm just asking if those that use it like and rely on it enough to pay
> the price. Unfortunately, the one piece of software that I have that
> requires it needs Win2k and I'm tired of the dual-boot.


There might be a couple of other options, but probably would take a lot
more work to setup: bochs ( http://bochs.sourceforge.net/ ) and plex86
( http://plex86.sourceforge.net/ ).  Both are are open source (GPL, LGPL)

bochs wasn't being maintained for a few years, but I notice from looking
at the web page just now that there have been a couple of releases this year,
so it appears to be ative again.  bochs, is an x86 emulator, so it's gonna
be slow.

plex86 is closer to what VMWare does, so it'll be the faster of the two.
As I recall, the plex86 developer was complaining a while back about
VMWare stealing ideas from plex86.  Apparently to run Windoze with plex86
you need to run it in combination with bochs - see the web page for more
details.


Phil

From jorgens at coho.net  Sat Jun 21 01:55:02 2003
From: jorgens at coho.net (Steve Jorgensen)
Date: Sat Jun 21 01:55:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] uml probs - networking and skas 2.4.20 kernel
Message-ID: <01C33798.E0E18AA0.jorgens@coho.net>

Hi,

Ok, on Debian Sarge (Testing), I got the user-mode-linux stuff installed, 
built an umage using rootstrap (first try failed w/ ext3, but works setting 
up ext2), and with the help of a friend, got it to actually load and run 
the image (contrary to the help, one must specify ubd0=<image>), but I 
still have a few problems, issues, and questions.


1.  Networking (besides lo) doesn't work.  During the startup process, the 
uml says...
Configuring network interfaces... SOICSIFADDR: No such device
eth0: ERROR while getting interface flags: No such device
SOICSIFADDR: No such device
eth0: ERROR while getting interface flags: No such device
done.

2.  For good uml performace, I have been trying to build a new host kernel 
with the skas patch, but I can't seem to get the Debian Kernel 2.4.20 
package to build.  From the very little I'm finding on th the Web about the 
errors I'm getting, these look like bugs with 2.4.20 building under gcc 
3.3.  Does anyone know how to fix or get around this besides waiting for a 
Sarge 2.4.21 package or trying to make do with a stock Kernel instead of an 
official Debian-patched one?

3.  It looks like either uml in general, or the way this one is configured 
expects to run under X.  If I run it from a text console, then ps -A shows 
a whole bunch of "linux" processes attached to the tty.  I presume these 
correspond to the Virtual Console windows I get if I do run uml from a 
terminal in X.  This is supposed to be a server box, running on less than 
state-of-the-art hardware, so I was hoping to not run X on it at all during 
normal operation, but I can see how I would likely want virtual consoles 
within my uml sessions from time to time.  What are other folks doing with 
this?

Thanks for any help y'all can offer,

- Steve Jorgensen



From jorgens at coho.net  Sat Jun 21 04:09:01 2003
From: jorgens at coho.net (Steve Jorgensen)

Subject: [PLUG] Specifics on Debian 2.4.20 kernel build problem

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sat Jun 21 08:16:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sat Jun 21 08:16:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] X-message-flag header and LookOut!
In-Reply-To: <20030621011550.GA25839@kippered.herring.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306210811520.22137-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Fri, 20 Jun 2003, Sandy Herring wrote:

> This is one of the coolest tricks I've seen in a long time!
> 
> http://www.rodos.net/outlook/

A number of PLUG folks for have using this hack for some time. A quick 
grep through my (incompete) archive is revealing:

X-Message-Flag: After so many viruses, why are you still using Outlook?

X-Message-Flag: Follow up

X-Message-Flag: Linux- The choice of a GNU generation.

X-Message-Flag: Repeal the DMCA! Real security is only possible when 
subject to open critical review.

X-Message-Flag: This could be an Outlook virus! Are you sure you want 
to continue using Outlook?

X-Message-Flag: Your computer seems to be infected with W32/MSOutlook.

X-message-flag: Usa un vero newsreader! http://www.mutt.org

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From dpool at hevanet.com  Sat Jun 21 08:21:02 2003
From: dpool at hevanet.com (david pool)
Date: Sat Jun 21 08:21:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] The Buck $tops Here (HB 2892)
Message-ID: <3EF477AD.3010707@hevanet.com>

I guess the Oregonian printed an editorial detailing the money that's 
been spent last week. If it's true, I think the politicians are being 
bought off way too cheaply. If you believe, like I do, that Oregon is 
becoming a Center of Gravity for Open Source/ Free Software, then 
eventually folks like Karen Minnis are going to realize they're on the 
wrong side of the tidal wave. To get crushed for a measly few hundred 
grand is short sighted.

http://www.oregonlive.com/letters/oregonian/index.ssf?/base/editorial/1055506030260060.xml

From sean at fork.com  Sat Jun 21 09:35:02 2003

Date: Sat Jun 21 09:35:02 2003

From drl at drloree.com  Sat Jun 21 10:04:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Sat Jun 21 10:04:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] uml probs - networking and skas 2.4.20 kernel
In-Reply-To: <01C33798.E0E18AA0.jorgens@coho.net>
References: <01C33798.E0E18AA0.jorgens@coho.net>
Message-ID: <1056215252.623.50.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Sat, 2003-06-21 at 02:00, Steve Jorgensen wrote:
> Hi,
> 
> Ok, on Debian Sarge (Testing), I got the user-mode-linux stuff installed, 
> built an umage using rootstrap (first try failed w/ ext3, but works setting 
> up ext2), and with the help of a friend, got it to actually load and run 
> the image (contrary to the help, one must specify ubd0=<image>), but I 
> still have a few problems, issues, and questions.
> 
The uml kernel will load a file named "root_fs" if it is present in the
directory that you invoked linux from, and you don't specify ubd0.
> 
> 1.  Networking (besides lo) doesn't work.  During the startup process, the 
> uml says...
> Configuring network interfaces... SOICSIFADDR: No such device
> eth0: ERROR while getting interface flags: No such device
> SOICSIFADDR: No such device
> eth0: ERROR while getting interface flags: No such device
> done.

There a few pieces that need to be in place for this to work.  What
pieces do you have in place?
> 
> 2.  For good uml performace, I have been trying to build a new host kernel 
> with the skas patch, but I can't seem to get the Debian Kernel 2.4.20 
> package to build.  From the very little I'm finding on th the Web about the 
> errors I'm getting, these look like bugs with 2.4.20 building under gcc 
> 3.3.  Does anyone know how to fix or get around this besides waiting for a 
> Sarge 2.4.21 package or trying to make do with a stock Kernel instead of an 
> official Debian-patched one?

I'm just using the Debian image.
> 
> 3.  It looks like either uml in general, or the way this one is configured 
> expects to run under X.  If I run it from a text console, then ps -A shows 
> a whole bunch of "linux" processes attached to the tty.  I presume these 
> correspond to the Virtual Console windows I get if I do run uml from a 
> terminal in X.  This is supposed to be a server box, running on less than 
> state-of-the-art hardware, so I was hoping to not run X on it at all during 
> normal operation, but I can see how I would likely want virtual consoles 
> within my uml sessions from time to time.  What are other folks doing with 
> this?

By default, uml will only load with an X-server capable of spawning
xterm windows.  This behavior can be modified with start up parameters. 
Here is one of my startup lines.

linux eth0=tuntap,,,192.168.2.5 con=port:9000 con1=tty:/dev/tty11 con0=tty:/dev/tty12

This one sets up console login on localhost port 9000 for all consoles
except the first two, which go to tty11 and tty12 on the host.  X is not
required for this work. 

HTH

Derek Loree

> >
> The uml kernel will load a file named "root_fs" if it is present in the
> directory that you invoked linux from, and you don't specify ubd0.

Ah, it mist be called root_fs.  I'm sure I read that, and then blithely 
wondered why it didn't magically find and load test-uml.img.

> >
> > 1.  Networking (besides lo) doesn't work.  During the startup process, 
the
> > uml says...
> > Configuring network interfaces... SOICSIFADDR: No such device
> > eth0: ERROR while getting interface flags: No such device
> > SOICSIFADDR: No such device
> > eth0: ERROR while getting interface flags: No such device
> > done.
>
> There a few pieces that need to be in place for this to work.  What
> pieces do you have in place?

Before I ran rootstrap, I set the following in the [rootstrap] section of 
/etc/rootstrap/rootstrap.conf:
interface=eth0
transport=tuntap
host=192.168.2.3
uml=192.168.2.4
netmask=255.255.255.248
gateway=192.168.2.1
domain=syhome.local
nameserver=192.168.2.2

According to instructions for proxy arp setup (I'll be wanting to run the 
switch daemon later, but thought I'd try this first), I set the host 
address to be the same as the ip address of eth0 on the host.

> >
> > 2.  For good uml performace, I have been trying to build a new host 
kernel
> > with the skas patch, but I can't seem to get the Debian Kernel 2.4.20
> > package to build.  From the very little I'm finding on th the Web about 
the
> > errors I'm getting, these look like bugs with 2.4.20 building under gcc 
> > 3.3.  Does anyone know how to fix or get around this besides waiting 
for a
> > Sarge 2.4.21 package or trying to make do with a stock Kernel instead 
of an
> > official Debian-patched one?
>
> I'm just using the Debian image.

I''m not sure what you're saying on this.  Are you using the skas patch? 
 If so, what Debian version are you running, and which kernel source 
package did you grab?

> > expects to run under X.  If I run it from a text console, then ps -A

> > a whole bunch of "linux" processes attached to the tty.  I presume

From jorgens at coho.net  Sat Jun 21 12:03:02 2003

On Saturday, June 21, 2003 8:45 AM, david may [SMTP:david at davudsplace.net] 
wrote:
> The problems you have (other than the build one)  can
> be addressed with command line  parameters.
> this is the one command line I have bee using recently
>
> ./linux con0=fd:0,fd:1           \
> con=pty \
> eth0=tuntap,,,192.168.1.68  \
> ubd0=deb2.cow,deb2.img  \
> mem=64M \

I didn't think that was supposed to be necessary since I put the network 
settings into /etc/rootstrap/rootstrap.conf (which include an entry for 
host ip address) before I built the uml image.  What are these settings for 
if you have to enter it again on the uml command line?  Is there soemthing 
I'm not understanding about that?

> ubd0=deb2.cow,deb2.img
> This demonstrates the use if a copy on write file ( see the web page)

Yeah, I'm anxious to play with that, but I was startng with just making the 
basics work.  BTW, what if you later decide you want to make a cow/img into 
a single img?

> con=pty makes all the consles attach to ptys instead of starting terms
> for daemons you can add con1=port:/dev/tty8 and the uml will be
> on virtual console 8 so you can ctrl-alt-f8 to get to it.

I guess there's no perfect answer, then, is there because that won't work 
very nicely when I decide to run 4 or 5 umls.

> make-kpkg to work at least once. It is an issue with getting the
> patches applied properly i think.

Well, I see lots of messages about people having trouble building 2.4.20 in 
general, so I'm not sure my issues have anything to do with the skas patch. 
 I made it past that last error by removing the unneeded module from the 
configuration, and now I'm back to an error I had last time I tried 
building this kernel.  At line 440 in ide-cd.h, "long, shoret, or unsigned 
used invalidly for 'slot_tablelen'".  I friend of mine helped me through 
that last time by fixing the data type of that variable, but I don't know  
 what type he changed it to to make it work.  Currently, the definition is 
__u8 short slot_tablelen.

>
> good luck,

illegally.  Hatch was referring to people who download copyrighted music
or movies.  Whether or not those downloads are ILLEGAL must be established
by due process of law.  Hatch wanted to act BEFORE such due process could
be initiated.
