From m at pdxlug.org  Mon Jun 23 14:46:02 2003
From: m at pdxlug.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Mon Jun 23 14:46:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Perl question
Message-ID: <1452.68.107.223.201.1056404754.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>

I'm still learning my way around Perl...  Here's what I want to do...  I
have a file that contains long lines of gibberish and buried in each line
is a phone number (xxx xxxx).  I would like to create an array that holds
just the phone numbers.  So I think I should do something like this:

$i = 0;
while (<INFILE>) {
   $phone[$i] = /\d\d\d \d\d\d\d/;
   $i++;
}

This, of course, doesn't work...  Any suggestions?
Thanks,
~M



From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Mon Jun 23 15:09:01 2003
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Mon Jun 23 15:09:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Perl question
In-Reply-To: <1452.68.107.223.201.1056404754.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
References: <1452.68.107.223.201.1056404754.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <20030623220804.GA9324@dalsemi.com>

On Mon, Jun 23, 2003 at 02:45:54PM -0700, Matt Alexander wrote:
> I'm still learning my way around Perl...  Here's what I want to do...  I
> have a file that contains long lines of gibberish and buried in each line
> is a phone number (xxx xxxx).  I would like to create an array that holds
> just the phone numbers.  So I think I should do something like this:
> 
> $i = 0;
> while (<INFILE>) {
>    $phone[$i] = /\d\d\d \d\d\d\d/;
>    $i++;
> }
> 
> This, of course, doesn't work...  Any suggestions?

It all boils down to 1 line:

$phone[$i] = /\d\d\d \d\d\d\d/;

Here's what it does.

// is the match operator.  By default it matches against $_ and it
returns true for a match and false if it doesn't.  So in the end your
array should hold a bunch of 1's and 0's, and the array index would
be the which line the phone numbers could be found on.

Here's what you'd like to do:

@phone = ();
while (<INFILE>) {
  if (/\d\d\d \d\d\d\d/) {
    push @phone, ""something""; 
  }
}

The push function treats @phone like a stack, and "pushes" the
2nd argument ""something"" onto the end of the array.

perldoc -f push

Array indexing is implicit, and there is a complementary function
called pop, which removes elements from the end of the array.  There
are also orthogonal functions, unshift and shift, for working with the
beginning of the array so that you can create queues, FIFOs and LIFOs.

But how do you get ""something"" to be the phone number?

First, you must know how perl's regexen work.

perldoc perlre
perldoc perlop

You use parentheses to grab data from a regex, and when using the match
operator, if it's called in list context, then it returns all the data
captured by parentheses:

So here's the code:

use strict;
@phone = ();
my $phone;
while (<INFILE>) {
  if (($phone) = /(\d\d\d \d\d\d\d)/) {
    push @phone, $phone; 
  }
}

You could also do this using a little more cryptically with the
$1, $2, variables. (again, perlop and perlre)

use strict;
@phone = ();
while (<INFILE>) {
  push @phone, $1 if /(\d\d\d \d\d\d\d)/; 
}

But using the $1 will cost your code some speed, if that's a
constraint.  Perl will let you constrain it just about any way you
want.

Colin



From m at pdxlug.org  Mon Jun 23 15:41:02 2003
From: m at pdxlug.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Mon Jun 23 15:41:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Perl question
In-Reply-To: <20030623220804.GA9324@dalsemi.com>
References: <1452.68.107.223.201.1056404754.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org> 
     <20030623220804.GA9324@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <1467.68.107.223.201.1056408060.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>

From dan at fiddlers-green.info  Mon Jun 23 15:46:02 2003
From: dan at fiddlers-green.info (Daniel B. Herrington)
Date: Mon Jun 23 15:46:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] PHP style question
Message-ID: <1056407961.3ef781997d524@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>

All,

I have a question about $_SERVER and $_SESSION in php 4.3. I am going to set the
application root directory in one of the superglobals. It seems to me it should
be in the $_SERVER because its specific to the application, although on the php
website it says these array  vars are set by the webserver.  The $_SESSION array
seems more for vars that are specific to the use'rs session, like user name,
home dirs, assigned groups, etc.

I was wondering what sort of rule others used for determing what to set in where.

thanks,
Dan H.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Jun 23 16:03:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon Jun 23 16:03:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Perl question
In-Reply-To: <20030623220804.GA9324@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306231546580.21546-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 23 Jun 2003, Colin Kuskie wrote:

> use strict;
> @phone = ();
> my $phone;
> while (<INFILE>) {
>   if (($phone) = /(\d\d\d \d\d\d\d)/) {
>     push @phone, $phone; 
>   }
> }

Or, get the same list using grep, in a locale-independent way:

  grep -Eo '[[:digit:]]{3}[[:space:]][[:digit:]]{4}' infile.txt

Why? Just because you can. :-)

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From bhoran at hexdev.com  Mon Jun 23 16:40:02 2003
From: bhoran at hexdev.com (Brian Horan)
Date: Mon Jun 23 16:40:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] PHP style question
In-Reply-To: <1056407961.3ef781997d524@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>
References: <1056407961.3ef781997d524@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>
Message-ID: <1056412632.24169.29.camel@localhost.localdomain>

$_SERVER holds items like environment variables
$_SESSION holds items that relate to a user's session as put there by
you, the coder...using session_start(), and session_register(), etc....


make a page with the following php code to take a look....

<?php
phpinfo();
?>

On 22 Jun 2003 20:06:13 -0700
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com> wrote:

> There may be a fatal flaw in all of this. I spent less than

It seems like a good idea, if you assume most spammers create their own
SMTP servers.  But don't they often use open relays or break into
networks to use existing servers?  If so, then validating SMTP servers
would place a great burdon on ISPs to make sure no one abused them. 
Hotmail's relays would get blacklisted faster than you can say "viagra".

By the way, there was a big article today in the news (New York Times,
or the Washington Post, can't remember) on new spam legislation now in
congress.  Anyone paying attention to this stuff?  (I'm guessing so,
knowing this to be a fairly politically-inclined list.)

--Jason

> to reboot in 'Doze to test that my stuff compiled on that platform.
> My employer bought me VmWare to save the reboot time and hassle, but I
> found that it was actually faster to reboot in 'Doze, do the compile,

> app, took so much more time under VmWare.  I had 128 meg of RAM
> dedicated to VmWare, too -- it wasn't that.

than native (but then I don't have to do a lot with it).

club, you know - it's all good as long as it's in a brown paper bag.

On Mon, 2003-06-23 at 07:15, Stevn Bartley wrote:
> I use VMWare to provide access to QuickBooks Pro.  Right now, I am
> really not very happy with VMWare.  I run VMWare on my RH Linux system
> to access a Win98 load which runs my QuickBooks.  I originally purchased
> VMWare under the personal use license for $99.  Then, they changed their
> license costs and I had to pay $249 to upgrade to version 3 because I
> missed the deadline for getting the $99 upgrade so had to pay full
> price.  I was on RH 7.2 at the time I upgraded to VMWare 3.  Some time
> later, RH 8.0 came out and I upgraded my system.  After this, the
> Windows load under VMWare started to have problems with shutting down. 
> I would get an error message everytime.  The system seemed to run fine
> but every time I shut the Windows session down, I would get this error
> and then when I would start the next session, the system would say that
> it had been shutdown unclean and needed to recover.  I reported this
> problem to VMWare around November 2002.  VMWare's answer was "We don't
> support VMWare on RH 8.0".  No where on their web sited did it say this
> at the time. (About a week later, they put a disclaimer on the web.) 
> Not one mention of plans to fix the issue or how long before it would be
> fixed.
> 
> Now, I receive a notice from VMWare last week saying that "We are
> writing to inform you of bugs resolved by VMware Workstation 4, which we
> released in April 2003.  We fixed the following bugs for which you filed
> support requests against VMware Workstation 3:"
> 
> Well thanks VMWare, you finally fixed an issue for me but now, I have to
> pay to upgrade to the next version to get the fix.  I will have spent
> $447.00 on their software.
> 
> I think that this time, I am just going to live with the error.  Doesnt
> seem to affect the system seriously and I have a hard time paying them
> to fix bugs in their software.  
> 
> Just my 2c.

Thanks - This is the information that I was looking for. It looks like
justification to look deeper into Bochs or to just stay with the
dual-boot.

Thanks again

> > Not one mention of plans to fix the issue or how long before it would be
> > fixed.
> > 
> > Now, I receive a notice from VMWare last week saying that "We are
> > writing to inform you of bugs resolved by VMware Workstation 4, which we
> > released in April 2003.  We fixed the following bugs for which you filed
> > support requests against VMware Workstation 3:"
> > 
> > Well thanks VMWare, you finally fixed an issue for me but now, I have to
> > pay to upgrade to the next version to get the fix.  I will have spent
> > $447.00 on their software.
> > 
> > I think that this time, I am just going to live with the error.  Doesnt
> > seem to affect the system seriously and I have a hard time paying them
> > to fix bugs in their software.  
> > 
> > Just my 2c.
> > 
> > Steve
> > On Fri, 2003-06-20 at 20:19, Steven A. Adams wrote:
> > > Anybody use VMWare to manage Windows installations from a real OS
> > > (*nix). For those that do, in your honest opinion, is it worth $279.00?
> > > 
> > > Steve
-- 





From stevea at nwtechops.com  Mon Jun 23 18:47:02 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Mon Jun 23 18:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] VMWare
In-Reply-To: <20030623164147.GC5430@sthelens.dimstar.net>
References: <1056165549.948.13.camel@main>
	 <1056377705.21442.28.camel@aragorn.ints.com> <1056380344.1282.82.camel@red>
	 <20030623164147.GC5430@sthelens.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <1056419154.1313.35.camel@main>

On Mon, 2003-06-23 at 09:41, Russ Johnson wrote:
> * Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com> [2003-06-23 08:00]:
> > I no longer use VMware for similar reasons. I'm
> > unwilling to buy a product more than once.
> 
> This bugs me. :)
> 
> When I buy a new Ford, I have to pay for it. If, two years later, I want
> to upgrade to the latest Ford, because it has new features, they've
> fixed some things and the paint lasts longer, do I get the new Ford for
> free?
> 
> No. I have to pay for it. 

C'mon Russ...  You want the paint job, you take it to Ford and get new
paint. That's available on Fords (as would be expected). They don't
bull-doze you into buying the new car, unlike some Software vendors.

Now, if your Ford required a re-boot every 50 miles do ya think they
would tell you that you had to pay for the "bug fix". They might try but
the AG would have their butt for it.

> 
> Not simply because it's new hardware. A LOT of engineering time and
> effort went into that Ford too. Not only the design team to make the
> sleek new body, but software engineers to write the computer code and
> engineers to make those weak points so that car crumples properly in an
> accident. 
> 
> Commercial, closed source software is the same way. VMWare 4.0 contains
> new features along with bug fixes. 

And if you don't want them? Well, Sir, your out of luck, you see, we at
VMWare don't support your revision anymore. Tell me that Ford will
refuse to support an 85 Bronco.


> 
> Now, if you are only interested in the bug fixes, then maybe it's not
> worth the cost. However, if you need or want the new features, then
> paying for the upgrade is no different than buying a new car. Someone
> has to pay the engineers.

Not in this economy.


> 
> So, in this case, you did pay for it once. You paid for version 3.0 of
> the software. You did so, knowing full well VMWares licensing practices.
> You knew that VMWare is a commercial product, with all that entails.

As I said before, this is great justification not to get sucked in at
all.


>  
> 
> It's a business model. It seems to work for several companies. If you
> don't like how they do business, don't use them.

Great idea.


>  
> 
> Win4Lin, Wine, et al. don't suit my needs, so I have to use VMWare, or I
> might as well just switch back to Windows and use the same platform for
> everything.

We all have to do what we know best (or what we can deal with).


>  
> 
> At this point in the game, there isn't a Linux alternative to
> everything. Someone else just mentioned Photoshop. Well, I'd like to add
> that there's still (four years after I first mentioned it) no COMPLETE
> alternative to MS Money or Quicken on Linux. Neither runs well under
> anything except VMWare.

This is true, there are some workstation apps that are not ready for the
masses yet. This is ok too, most of us aren't the masses (which is why
we're here).

>  
> 
> I think it's absolutely fantastic that we have a choice. I love being
> able to run my OS, and try out software with little cost beyond my time
> and effort. I've been doing that for many years, since before the advent
> of the Internet. Before the OSS movement, we had shareware. It wasn't
> open, but we still had try before you buy.

I remember, it wasn't all that long ago.

> 
> My point is, if you CHOOSE to purchase commercial, closed source
> software, then you do so knowing what the rules are. You also CHOOSE to
> accept those rules by purchasing.

Right, one of my complaints. Read the latest .NET EULA.

> 
> OSS advocacy aside, there is a place in the world for both types of
> software. Everyone makes choices. We have to live with our own choices.


I don't know about all that, 52% of Americans voted for Al Gore.
>  
--

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Mon Jun 23 19:48:01 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor Pikus)
Date: Mon Jun 23 19:48:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: VMWare
In-Reply-To: <1056417656.1313.11.camel@main>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0306231941300.16981-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

On 23 Jun 2003, Steven A. Adams wrote:
> On Mon, 2003-06-23 at 03:30, Eric House wrote:
> > VmWare generally works as advertised, but is dog-slow.
> I don't see the "slow" thing on this machine with vmware 4 in the eval
> version. Perhaps they have made some strides in that arena.
I did not see any "slow" starting from Vmware 1.0. You lose essentially a fixed
amount of performance: on something like pII-400 the VM is pretty much at a
standstill, and after that it scales with whatever your CPU is, only slower
by some amount. On my athlon-2600+ the CPU penalty is not significant.

> I have the 128 MB dedication too. On a pIII 500 it runs a little slower
> than native (but then I don't have to do a lot with it).
Memory us a larger issue. If I allocated 128M to my VM it would be slow too.
But you end up with only a portion of your real memory going to VM, and if you
allocate too much the host OS slows down. On my PC, I could not give VM more than
about 650M when I had 1G total. Now, with 1.5G I can allocate 1G to VM.

> > If the $99 personal-use deal were still available, though, I think I'd
> > get a copy for my home machine.  It's fun to run 'Doze in a sandbox
> > where it belongs. :-)
Try Win4Lin (if WinME does not make you vomit) - it's in that price range.

-- 
                                  Fedor G. Pikus
Mentor Graphics Corporation         | Phone: (503) 685-4857
8405 SW Boeckman Road               | FAX:   (503) 685-1239
Wilsonville, Oregon 97070           | http://www.pikus.net/~pikus/

From plug at laynesoftware.com  Mon Jun 23 20:07:02 2003
From: plug at laynesoftware.com (Terry Layne)
Date: Mon Jun 23 20:07:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] VMWare
In-Reply-To: <1056419363.1312.39.camel@main>
References: <1056165549.948.13.camel@main> <1056377705.21442.28.camel@aragorn.ints.com> <1056380344.1282.82.camel@red> <20030623164147.GC5430@sthelens.dimstar.net> <1056388634.4194.215.camel@halo> <1056419363.1312.39.camel@main>
Message-ID: <20030624030550.M28677@laynesoftware.com>

On 23 Jun 2003 18:49:23 -0700, Steven A. Adams wrote
> 
> I don't begrudge anyone profit, my question was to solicit info from
> current users of the product before I spent the money. So far the
> response has been very informative.
>  

It sounds like you've heard from more whiners and complainers than the product
really deserves.  I'm running two (licensed) copies of WinXP Pro under VMWare
3.x on a Red Hat 7.3 server, which is also doing a bunch of other things, and
everything has been  running trouble free in a production environment for 153
days and counting.  I actually have the two instances of VMWare running in a
VNC session since the server is at a co-lo.  I'd say VMWare is just about the
only piece of PC software I would happily pay $279 for.

If money is really tight, it might make more sense to run Windows in a
headless workstation with VNC, and then access it from your Linux desktop.  It
all depends on the apps you need to support.

--
Terry Layne
Portland, OR

From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Mon Jun 23 20:24:02 2003
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: Mon Jun 23 20:24:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] SB 655 hearing (fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306232021390.30829-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>


Apparently Oregon's super DMCA bill is still alive.  I got this email from
Charles Starr's office today (because I wrote him protesting 655 a few
months back).  Anyone got any other info on this bill?

Phil

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Mon, 23 Jun 2003 16:33:27 -0700
From: Staff SenCharlesStarr <Staff.Sencharlesstarr at state.or.us>
To: kenmcd at kmcd.com
Subject: SB 655 hearing

You are receiving this email because you are on an alert list for SB
655.



You may have heard that SB 655 is up for a hearing tomorrow. The hearing
has been postponed until Wednesday, but the bill is up for a "gut 'n
stuff" which will replace its contents with an entirely different bill.
The replacement language would direct the PUC to prohibit the
disconnection of "local exchange residential service" under certain
circumstances where a person could be endangered by not being able to
call police. The original bill is completely eliminated.



If you have any further questions, I'd be happy to answer them.



Ken McDermott

Legislative Assistant

Senator Charles Starr

900 Court St NE S-312

Salem, OR 97301

staff.sencharlesstarr at state.or.us

On Mon, 2003-06-23 at 20:05, Terry Layne wrote:
> It sounds like you've heard from more whiners and complainers than the product
> really deserves.  I'm running two (licensed) copies of WinXP Pro under VMWare
> 3.x on a Red Hat 7.3 server, which is also doing a bunch of other things, and
> everything has been  running trouble free in a production environment for 153
> days and counting.  I actually have the two instances of VMWare running in a
> VNC session since the server is at a co-lo.  I'd say VMWare is just about the
> only piece of PC software I would happily pay $279 for.

I have also heard a lot of positive feed-back from folks like you that
use the product for more than one image. Unfortunately for VMWare, my
needs are much less complex and they, apparently, don't make a version
that suites this well. In all fairness, I only need one Win2k image with
a very light complement of software. As with most of the folks that have
replied with less-than-favorable reviews, I feel like the absence of a
lower-end version is a market opportunity that they are missing.

> 
> If money is really tight, it might make more sense to run Windows in a
> headless workstation with VNC, and then access it from your Linux desktop.  It
> all depends on the apps you need to support.
> 

Money is tight for almost everyone but if a product has value and meets
the need then I'm in. However, for my current need I just don't see that
value.

Good points though Terry!

http://www.eff.org/IP/DMCA/states/

paying attention any longer.

From jorgens at coho.net  Mon Jun 23 23:34:02 2003
From: jorgens at coho.net (Steve Jorgensen)
Date: Mon Jun 23 23:34:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Debian kernel build - where's my .deb?
Message-ID: <01C339E0.D9423C00.jorgens@coho.net>

I was following the instructions at 
http://newbiedoc.sourceforge.net/system/kernel-pkg.html.  Because of the 
problems with the Debian 2.4.20 kernel and gcc 3.3, it took days and days. 
 Try a build, see which package failed, figure out if I care, if not, 
remove it, if so, fix it (usually a bad data type or string constrant 
wrapping).  So, finally, eureka!  I see echo done > stamp-build.

So, I follow instruction 6 in the link above, cd to /usr/src, and type ls. 
 I see I have the bz2 image, but no .deb file.  What gives?  What didn't 
finish, why didn't it tell me about a problem, and how do I get it to 
finish making the package?

Thanks,

- Steve Jorgensen

P.S.
Actually, I combined the instructions from there with instructions from 
somewhere else I don't recall, and added --initrd to the make-kpkg command 
line since that seems to be the appropriate thing to do.



From sean at fork.com  Tue Jun 24 05:55:03 2003
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Tue Jun 24 05:55:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Debian kernel build - where's my .deb?
In-Reply-To: <01C339E0.D9423C00.jorgens@coho.net>
References: <01C339E0.D9423C00.jorgens@coho.net>
Message-ID: <200306240553.40577.sean@fork.com>

make-kpkg --revision=whatever kernel_image

If there's no kernel_image at the end you don't get the .deb file.


Sean

From bsr at spek.org  Tue Jun 24 08:47:02 2003
From: bsr at spek.org (Brent Rieck)
Date: Tue Jun 24 08:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] PHP style question
In-Reply-To: <1056407961.3ef781997d524@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>
References: <1056407961.3ef781997d524@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>
Message-ID: <1056469565.9372.5159.camel@obelisk.spek.org>

If you're trying to make the choice between $_SERVER and $_SESSION I'd
choose $_SERVER, unless it's set on a per-session basis, then I'd use
$_SESSION.  Were it me though I'd define a constant with the application
root it it which to me 'feels' less cumbersome than interacting with
$_SERVER.

my 0.02,
Brent

On Mon, 2003-06-23 at 15:39, Daniel B. Herrington wrote:
> All,
> 
> I have a question about $_SERVER and $_SESSION in php 4.3. I am going to set the
> application root directory in one of the superglobals. It seems to me it should
> be in the $_SERVER because its specific to the application, although on the php
> website it says these array  vars are set by the webserver.  The $_SESSION array
> seems more for vars that are specific to the use'rs session, like user name,
> home dirs, assigned groups, etc.
> 
> I was wondering what sort of rule others used for determing what to set in where.
> 
> thanks,
> Dan H.

From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Tue Jun 24 09:59:02 2003
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: Tue Jun 24 09:59:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] SB 655 hearing. (clarification)(fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306240957580.24090-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>

Here's some clarification on SB 655..

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Tue, 24 Jun 2003 09:45:51 -0700
From: Staff SenCharlesStarr <Staff.Sencharlesstarr at state.or.us>
To: ptkwt at aracnet.com
Subject: SB 655 hearing.

Phil,



To further clarify what is happening with SB 655. It is essentially too
late in the session to introduce a new bill. So those who want a new
bill have to find a "dead" bill with an appropriate "relating to..."
clause that they can "gut 'n stuff.". In this case, the PUC wants to
have the authority to prohibit a telephone company from cutting off
local service to a customer whose life may depend on being able to make
a phone call for police or an ambulance. Since a telephone is a
"communications service," the relating to clause of SB 655 (Relating to
communications services) allows it to be amended by completely "gutting"
the original bill and "stuffing" the new bill. Only the bill number and
relating to clause will remain the same. SB 655 will now be referred to
as SB 655 A-engrossed and will be a completely different bill and will
have nothing about "unlawful communications devices" or copyrights or
fines as in the original bill.



I believe that Sen. Starr will support the NEW SB 655, but we will have
to wait until the hearing, in case someone raises reasonable objections.



Ken McDermott

Legislative Assistant

Senator Charles Starr

900 Court St NE S-312

Salem, OR 97301

staff.sencharlesstarr at state.or.us

From m at pdxlug.org  Tue Jun 24 12:19:02 2003
From: m at pdxlug.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Tue Jun 24 12:19:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Perl:  Array of structs?
Message-ID: <1444.68.107.223.201.1056482312.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>

I'm trying to create an array of structs.  Each different struct
represents a different page.  I'd like to assign values and print them
out, but the slightly modified example below from the Perl Cookbook
doesn't work.  Any help would be greatly appreciated.
Thanks,
~M


use Class::Struct;

struct Page => {
   pagenumber => '$',
   linenumber => '$',
   column => '$',
   dataline => '$',
   name => '$',
   address => '$',
   phone => '$',
   subcat => '$'
};

my @page = Page->new();

$page[1]->pagenumber("1");
$page[1]->linenumber("1");
$page[1]->column("2");
$page[1]->dataline("blah blah blah some name here 123 4567 blah blah");
$page[1]->name("John Smith");
$page[1]->address("123 SW 123 St.");
$page[1]->phone("123 4567");
$page[1]->subcat("1");

print "STRUCT PHONE TEST: $page[1]->phone";



From mike at linuxlink.com  Tue Jun 24 13:14:01 2003
From: mike at linuxlink.com (mike)
Date: Tue Jun 24 13:14:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Baby killing Linux
In-Reply-To: <20030619210006.3717BB3DCB@dsl-209-162-216-78.dsl.easystreet.com>
References: <20030619210006.3717BB3DCB@dsl-209-162-216-78.dsl.easystreet.com>

From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Jun 24 13:17:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue Jun 24 13:17:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Perl:  Array of structs?
In-Reply-To: <1444.68.107.223.201.1056482312.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306241310331.26216-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 24 Jun 2003, Matt Alexander wrote:

> use Class::Struct;
> 
> struct Page => {
>    pagenumber => '$',
>    linenumber => '$',
>    column => '$',
>    dataline => '$',
>    name => '$',
>    address => '$',
>    phone => '$',
>    subcat => '$'
> };
> 
> my @page = Page->new();

I doubt you can initialize the entire @page array with a single 
constructor. You'll need to initial each element separately:

  my @page = ();
  foreach my $n ( 0 .. $ad_quem ) { $page[$n] = new Page; }

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Jun 24 13:24:02 2003

Subject: [PLUG] pdf options in latest mozilla

  Has anyone else noticed that the mozilla-1.3.x releases no longer offer
the option of using xpdf to view a pdf file rather than downloading it? This
was available at least through the -1.2.1 release I had here.

  Anyone but me miss this option?

From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Tue Jun 24 17:26:01 2003
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)
Date: Tue Jun 24 17:26:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] remote temperature monitoring
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306241628220.11197-100000@antares.mpcu.com>

I'm hoping that some kind soul on this diverse list will have some leads 
about the subject.  Ideally I'd like to use a temperature monitor that 
will sit in a 2foot by 2 foot cabinet.  The box has ethernet and power. 
ideally, I would like to query the temperature monitoring device via snmp 
as to graph it's trend using MRTG.  The closest I've come up with so far 
is:

http://www.tempelert.com/products/products.htm

Model E4 or Model F.


Google is being unusually stingy about coughing up links for this type of 
device.  I'd also like to keep the price below $200.




From barryb at proaxis.com  Tue Jun 24 17:56:02 2003
From: barryb at proaxis.com (Bill Barry)
Date: Tue Jun 24 17:56:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] remote temperature monitoring
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306241628220.11197-100000@antares.mpcu.com>

Message-ID: <20030625005346.GA6585@constraint>

On Tue, Jun 24, 2003 at 05:42:47PM -0700, Keith Morse wrote:
> 
> I'm hoping that some kind soul on this diverse list will have some leads 
> about the subject.  Ideally I'd like to use a temperature monitor that 
> will sit in a 2foot by 2 foot cabinet.  The box has ethernet and power. 
> ideally, I would like to query the temperature monitoring device via snmp 
> as to graph it's trend using MRTG.  

How about an older used computer with a temperature sensor connected
to the serial port. Here is a temperature sensor I have used
and the parts needed to connect it to a serial port.

DS1920 Temperature iButton
http://www.maxim-ic.com/quick_view2.cfm?qv_pk=2818&ln=

iButton to RS-232 adapter
DS1402D-DR8
http://www.maxim-ic.com/quick_view2.cfm/qv_pk/2706

Universal 1-Wire COM Port Adapter
DS9097U-009
http://www.maxim-ic.com/quick_view2.cfm/qv_pk/2983


Bill Barry

From dan at fiddlers-green.info  Wed Jun 25 01:32:02 2003
From: dan at fiddlers-green.info (Daniel B. Herrington)
Date: Wed Jun 25 01:32:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] PHP class instances
Message-ID: <1056529506.3ef95c629d0f1@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>

PHP gurus,

I discovered that I can instantiate classes with a variable name. i.e.:

I create a class called test, then in my script:

$var = test;
$testclass = new $var;

and a new instance of test gets created. I was wondering if this was bad
practice and if I should cease and desist before I make a habit of creating
instances of classes this way?

thanks,
Dan Herrington

-------------------------------------------------
This mail sent through IMP: http://horde.org/imp/




From dcf at aracnet.com  Wed Jun 25 06:14:01 2003
From: dcf at aracnet.com (David Fleck)
Date: Wed Jun 25 06:14:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] 802.11b adapters known to work with Linux?
In-Reply-To: <20030623155818.GB6317@rauhaus.org>
References: <20030622175021.Q322@grond.sourballs.org> <20030623155818.GB6317@rauhaus.org>
Message-ID: <20030625081224.S414@grond.sourballs.org>

Thanks to everyone who responded to my cry for help.  It turns out what I
really needed was a strong dose of RTFM - I got the Linksys USB wireless
adapter (WUSB11v2.6) working with SuSE 8.2 by doing 2 things:

1) finding the correct howto
(http://atmelwlandriver.sourceforge.net/howto/howto.html)

2) reading it carefully.

It turns out the correct driver module is included with SuSE 8.2, but a
bit of fiddling (not detailed in SuSE's docs, as far as I can tell) is
required for the system to load it correctly.

--
David Fleck
dcf at aracnet.com




From linux at chrisroberts.org  Wed Jun 25 07:17:01 2003
From: linux at chrisroberts.org (chris)
Date: Wed Jun 25 07:17:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] PHP class instances
In-Reply-To: <1056529506.3ef95c629d0f1@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>
References: <1056529506.3ef95c629d0f1@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>
Message-ID: <200306250714.44761.linux@chrisroberts.org>

I don't see the point in doing this for just creating objects. there are 
useful applications of this, but there is no point in just doing it for the 
sake of doing it. this also works with functions by the way:
<?
function foo()
{
  print 'hello world\n';
}

$function = 'foo';
$function();
?>

chris

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Wed Jun 25 07:51:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Wed Jun 25 07:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] PHP class instances
In-Reply-To: <1056529506.3ef95c629d0f1@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>
References: <1056529506.3ef95c629d0f1@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>
Message-ID: <1056552622.3088.136.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Wed, 2003-06-25 at 01:25, Daniel B. Herrington wrote:
> PHP gurus,
> 
> I discovered that I can instantiate classes with a variable name. i.e.:
> 
> I create a class called test, then in my script:
> 
> $var = test;
> $testclass = new $var;
> 
> and a new instance of test gets created. I was wondering if this was bad
> practice and if I should cease and desist before I make a habit of creating
> instances of classes this way?

This is a feature that can be used with the AbstractFactory design
pattern, to instatitate objects which adhere to an interface but whose
exact implementation should be decided at run-time.

There are other places you can use this that I'm not thinking of right
now.  Obviously in your test example, there's no need for it, but it can
very useful.  So, use it when it actually solves a problem and don't
when it doesn't.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

*     Tired of spam and viruses in your e-mail?  Get the     *
* Naked Ape Mail Defender! http://nakedape.cc/r/maildefender *

On Wed, 2003-06-25 at 07:59, Shahms King wrote:
> You can also use it to emulate a number of features of C++ templates
> (albeit, at runtime and with a different syntax . . .)

I think you've got it the wrong way around Shams: C++ templates are a
half-assed attempt to do some of the things you can do in better OO
languages: run-time evaulation, dynamic typing, etc.

Wil

From shahms at shahms.com  Wed Jun 25 08:22:02 2003
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms King)
Date: Wed Jun 25 08:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] PHP class instances
In-Reply-To: <1056553771.3088.144.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1056529506.3ef95c629d0f1@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>
	 <1056552622.3088.136.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	 <1056553193.13475.2.camel@ltsp.mesd.k12.or.us>
	 <1056553771.3088.144.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1056554463.13475.10.camel@ltsp.mesd.k12.or.us>

Well, yes, but I've found that people frequently associate a certain
design approach with templates that they don't consider when using more
dynamic languages.  Templates; what a wonderful way of taking all of the
static type checking of C++ and turning it into pages and pages of
cryptic compile errors. Then again, templates *could* be seen as forcing
open source on the C++ world ;-)

On Wed, 2003-06-25 at 08:09, Wil Cooley wrote:
> On Wed, 2003-06-25 at 07:59, Shahms King wrote:
> > You can also use it to emulate a number of features of C++ templates
> > (albeit, at runtime and with a different syntax . . .)
> 
> I think you've got it the wrong way around Shams: C++ templates are a
> half-assed attempt to do some of the things you can do in better OO
> languages: run-time evaulation, dynamic typing, etc.
> 
> Wil

Shahms King <shahms at shahms.com>




From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Wed Jun 25 08:24:01 2003

On Wednesday 25 June 2003 6:13 am, David Fleck wrote:
> Thanks to everyone who responded to my cry for help.  It turns out what I
> really needed was a strong dose of RTFM - I got the Linksys USB wireless
> adapter (WUSB11v2.6) working with SuSE 8.2 by doing 2 things:
>
> 1) finding the correct howto
> (http://atmelwlandriver.sourceforge.net/howto/howto.html)
>

>
> It turns out the correct driver module is included with SuSE 8.2, but a
> bit of fiddling (not detailed in SuSE's docs, as far as I can tell) is
> required for the system to load it correctly.
>

RTFM is good advice when documentation is organized, clear, and easy to find. 
In this case, it isn't. The docs for implementing wireless in Linux are a 
chaotic mess. The worst part is trying to find if a particular card is 
supported. I don't blame the heroic souls who are writing drivers and docs 
for Linux, with little help or support. I am fed up with hardware 
manufacturers and vendors being so completely chickensh*t about Linux 
support. So don't feel bad about needing help.

--

why I looked for this motherboard in the first place.

under 98SE where lack of sound support is an added obstacle so far for

Date: Wed Jun 25 11:47:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] pine 4.56
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0306251139540.27446@pecos.madboa.com>

It looks as if Red Hat will be deprecating pine in future releases due
to some licensing disagreements with the folks up at UW. (I believe
Debian has long recognized this fact.)

Anyway, I'm not prepared to give up pine, so I thought I'd see about
building a home-brewed rpm that duplicated Red Hat's as closely as
possible, including the pinepgp stuff.

So I'm using a test version of 4.56, and, man, do I like it.

The main visible difference between it and 4.4x is that it supports a
threaded view of newsgroups and mailing lists.

Under the hood, however, its IMAP stuff is much quicker. I've got
something like 18 mailboxes here and there that receive new mail
(accounts on three machines, and lots of procmail rules :-). Polling
all those boxes for new mail seems significantly faster than it did
using 4.44.

Just thought someone might like to know.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Wed Jun 25 11:51:01 2003

here.  Time to start brewing some beer...

"Beaverton nabbed dual honors last week with the news that our western 'burb 
will play host to the filming of Thumbsucker, featuring Keanu Reeves as a 
good-hearted orthodontist, and provide a more permanent home for Linux 
inventor Linus Torvalds, who has taken a job with the Beav's Open Source 
Development Lab.

to jump to conclusions here (Linus is
working for OSDL, OSDL is in Beaverton, therefore Linus is moving to
Beaverton).  Pretty sure I read in the Oregonian article (and a coule
of others) that he is going to stay where he is (Sunnyvale?) and work
from home.  Technically he's still employed by Transmeta, he's just on a
leave of absence.

From dan at fiddlers-green.info  Wed Jun 25 12:44:02 2003
From: dan at fiddlers-green.info (Daniel B. Herrington)
Date: Wed Jun 25 12:44:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] PHP class instances
In-Reply-To: <200306250714.44761.linux@chrisroberts.org>
References: <1056529506.3ef95c629d0f1@webmail.fiddlers-green.info> <200306250714.44761.linux@chrisroberts.org>
Message-ID: <1056569819.3ef9f9db8bf81@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>

Chris and Will,

Thanks for the reply. Sorry I didn't go into it further, but it actually
fulfills a need in my case.  I have a framework that will have an unknown amount
of modules (for future expansion) that get installed and recorded in a table in
the db. I need to instantiate an object specific to the mdoules themselves, but
without hardcoding the names of the modules in my code (to the ones I currently
know about, thus limiting future expansion), I coudln't call the specific
classes. I was just worried I had run across something that was an "undocumented
feature" and could easily be eliminated in a future release. I searched php.net,
but hadn't noticed any refrences to the functionality anywhere.

thanks,
Dan H.
Quoting chris <linux at chrisroberts.org>:

> I don't see the point in doing this for just creating objects. there are 
> useful applications of this, but there is no point in just doing it for the 
> sake of doing it. this also works with functions by the way:
> <?
> function foo()
> {
>   print 'hello world\n';
> }
> 
> $function = 'foo';
> $function();
> ?>
> 
> chris
> 
> On Wednesday 25 June 2003 01:25 am, Daniel B. Herrington wrote:
> > PHP gurus,
> >
> > I discovered that I can instantiate classes with a variable name. i.e.:
> >
> > I create a class called test, then in my script:
> >
> > $var = test;
> > $testclass = new $var;
> >
> > and a new instance of test gets created. I was wondering if this was bad
> > practice and if I should cease and desist before I make a habit of
> creating
> > instances of classes this way?
> >
> > thanks,
> > Dan Herrington
> >
> > -------------------------------------------------
> > This mail sent through IMP: http://horde.org/imp/
> >

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Jun 25 14:25:22 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Jun 25 14:25:22 2003
Subject: [PLUG] pine 4.56
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0306251300470.27446@pecos.madboa.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306251205350.24794-100000@antares.mpcu.com>
 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0306251300470.27446@pecos.madboa.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0306251421500.27446@pecos.madboa.com>

Poking around Red Hat's patches that come with the source rpm, I found
this beauty. And you thought PLUG was testy sometimes. :-)

--- imap/src/osdep/unix/env_unix.h.lock_protection_fix  Thu Oct  4 05:26:33 2001
+++ imap/src/osdep/unix/env_unix.h      Thu Oct  4 05:30:33 2001
@@ -46,12 +46,15 @@


 /*
- * Attention: all sorcerer's apprentices who think that 0666 is a mistake.
- * You are wrong.  Read the FAQ.  Do not meddle in the affairs of wizards,
- * for they are subtle and quick to anger.
+ * Attention: all people who do not care about OS security, and think that
+ * mode 0666 is a correct.  You are wrong.  In modern multiuser systems,
+ * both remote and local security is critically important.  Allowing 0666
+ * lockfiles, allows all sorts of security problems to occur.  Feel free to
+ * meddle with it however, if you do not care about local security.
  */

-#define MANDATORYLOCKPROT 0666 /* don't change this */
+/* Change this only if you do not want a secure multiuser system */
+#define MANDATORYLOCKPROT 0600

 /* Function prototypes */


--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From ziggy at anodizing.com  Wed Jun 25 15:21:02 2003

From danielx.j.petcher at intel.com  Wed Jun 25 15:28:02 2003
From: danielx.j.petcher at intel.com (Petcher, Danielx J)
Date: Wed Jun 25 15:28:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] AOL login help needed
Message-ID: <7D6F4CF55743264F8B23E20353705EEC0A8F43@orsmsx408.amr.corp.intel.com>

Here's what I know, unless there have been some recent changes....

AOL uses its own TCP/IP variant for dial-up. They have software for
Macintosh and Windows, but I don't think they have Linux software yet.

If you have another ISP, you can dial-up to them and use a web browser
to read your Email at aol.com or use AOL Instnt Messenger.

-djp
http://folding.stanford.edu - the brain you save may be your own!

Hey folks,

Here's another interesting job opprotunity. Centennial school district
is looking for someone to help support a mix of Windows and Linux desktops,
as well as assist on the backend servers and network. 

Centennial is one of our school districts that is moving over to pure fiber,
all of their schools will have at least 100Mbps of wide area network
bandwidth. Fun stuff!

Hey Eric
This link goes to our web page job link which has a reference to the job and 
how to apply.  http://www.centennial.k12.or.us/employment/jobs.htm
Someone that has reasonable working knowledge of linux, could run or be 
trained to watch and maintain the thin client labs, good with pc hardware, 
and windows OS, some 98SE but mostly going to XP on workstations. And of 
course the big thing would be someone who would trainable or ready to help 
manage the network especially when I am out or on vacation.
See Ya
Dave :-)

Michael Luevane wrote:
> But isn't that 200 gallons per *person*?

Yup, per adult/household.  That's about 356 six packs per year for a person 
(somewhat less in reality).  It'd be a challenge, but you'd never be thirsty.

To return to topicality, there's a pretty good recipe app for Linux here
http://www.usermode.org/code.html

Kyle Accardi

From guy1656 at ados.com  Wed Jun 25 22:24:02 2003
From: guy1656 at ados.com (guy1656)
Date: Wed Jun 25 22:24:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] 2 TAR questions
In-Reply-To: <20030622154602.M95906@laynesoftware.com>
References: <200306211619.57725.guy1656@ados.com> <20030622085714.G1759@grond.sourballs.org> <20030622154602.M95906@laynesoftware.com>
Message-ID: <200306252223.29334.guy1656@ados.com>

(Re: large backup files, 7GB or so, but older computer
will only handle <2Gb file sizes...) 
: I walked into the middle of the
: thread.  But I get by just fine using:
:
: tar -cv  -L 1000000 -F myscript -f archive.tar stuff/to/backup
:
: This creates chunks that are 1 GB in size.  myscript is actually the backup
: script that calls this tar command in the first place.  When called in this
: instance it provides the next archive name.  That way I end up with
: backup00.tar, backup01.tar, etc.  When all done I gzip the lot of them.

OK, now - how would you restore once you have backup00.tar, backup01.tar, etc?
Can a compressed file get split across two backup files? What happens?

-GLL

From drl at drloree.com  Thu Jun 26 00:04:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Thu Jun 26 00:04:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How to shut down uml without forcing fsck on next
	start	(besides cow)
In-Reply-To: <01C33B62.EE9AC4E0.jorgens@coho.net>
References: <01C33B62.EE9AC4E0.jorgens@coho.net>
Message-ID: <1056611295.572.7.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Wed, 2003-06-25 at 21:44, Steve Jorgensen wrote:
> I try shutdown now, but uml is not really gone.  It's sutting there waiting 
> for me to press ctrl+d to reboot it.  I'll try halt, and see if that shuts 
> it all the way down.
> 

killall linux

This will take down all the uml's running under your username.

>From a bad shutdown, just run linux without any network or console
routing.

Then convert to ext3, don't forget about changing fstab.

Derek Loree





From jorgens at coho.net  Thu Jun 26 07:55:03 2003
From: jorgens at coho.net (Steve Jorgensen)
Date: Thu Jun 26 07:55:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How to shut down uml without forcing fsck on next	start	(besides cow)
Message-ID: <01C33BB9.27965CE0.jorgens@coho.net>

On Thursday, June 26, 2003 12:08 AM, Derek Loree [SMTP:drl at drloree.com] wrote:
> On Wed, 2003-06-25 at 21:44, Steve Jorgensen wrote:
> > I try shutdown now, but uml is not really gone.  It's sutting there waiting 
> > for me to press ctrl+d to reboot it.  I'll try halt, and see if that shuts 
> > it all the way down.
> > 
> 
> killall linux

That was giving me the fsck when I restart uml, but I solved that by shutting down properly with the -h option on shutdown.

> This will take down all the uml's running under your username.
> 
> >From a bad shutdown, just run linux without any network or console
> routing.
> 
> Then convert to ext3, don't forget about changing fstab.

Yeah, I was going to do that anyway at some point.  I know about tune2fs -j, but what has to be done in fstab?



From drl at drloree.com  Thu Jun 26 08:15:03 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Thu Jun 26 08:15:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How to shut down uml without forcing fsck on
	next	start	(besides cow)
In-Reply-To: <01C33BB9.27965CE0.jorgens@coho.net>
References: <01C33BB9.27965CE0.jorgens@coho.net>
Message-ID: <1056640737.575.10.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Thu, 2003-06-26 at 08:01, Steve Jorgensen wrote:
> On Thursday, June 26, 2003 12:08 AM, Derek Loree [SMTP:drl at drloree.com] wrote:
> > On Wed, 2003-06-25 at 21:44, Steve Jorgensen wrote:
> > > I try shutdown now, but uml is not really gone.  It's sutting there waiting 
> > > for me to press ctrl+d to reboot it.  I'll try halt, and see if that shuts 
> > > it all the way down.
> > > 
> > 
> > killall linux
> 
> That was giving me the fsck when I restart uml, but I solved that by shutting down properly with the -h option on shutdown.
> 
> > This will take down all the uml's running under your username.
> > 
> > >From a bad shutdown, just run linux without any network or console
> > routing.
> > 
> > Then convert to ext3, don't forget about changing fstab.
> 
> Yeah, I was going to do that anyway at some point.  I know about tune2fs -j, but what has to be done in fstab?
> 
Change the mount type from ext2 to ext3, otherwise it will still be
mounted as ext2.

Derek Loree

On Thu, Jun 26, 2003 at 09:22:32AM -0700, 'Russ Johnson' wrote:
> 
> Does anyone know of a good how-to for beer brewing? 

Any of the Charlie Papazian books.  Any member of the Oregon Brew Crew
that actually brews, rather than just appreciates, beer.  The counter
staff at any of the local home brew stores.  

It's really very simple.  As one professional brewer said, "People
have been brewing for thousands of years.  You may not get what you 
expect but you'll get beer."

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Jun 26 11:40:03 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu Jun 26 11:40:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] pine 4.56
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306261127420.11278-100000@antares.mpcu.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306261123400.4333-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 26 Jun 2003, Keith Morse wrote:

> .spec is fine.

  http://www.madboa.com/geek/specs/pine.spec

For a few days, I'll make available the source rpm:

  ftp://ftp.cse.ogi.edu/pub/people/heinlein/pine-4.56-1.src.rpm

It'll be gone in about a week, but feel free to mirror it.

Because the .src.rpm contains a (trivial) patch, please don't
make binary rpms available unless you remove mention of the patch from 
the .spec file. The UW license specifically prohibits redistribution 
of patched pine binaries. Distributing the original source along with 
patches, however, seems to be OK.

> Another question is does this include support for UTF-8?

Yes, though I can't say I've tested it at all.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

In your ~/.muttrc file:

mailboxes filename [filename...] 


-Cooper

> migrated from pine to mutt has a quick answer?
>

> configure them to be checked upon pressing a key? Also how do you
> define variables in the .muttrc so you don't have to give the whole
> path to the mailbox?
> 
> mailboxes /nfs/foo/u3/u/bar/mail/folders/plug,

>

> anyone else have this problem or know how to solve it?
> 
> TFC

From ali at axian.com  Thu Jun 26 12:46:02 2003
From: ali at axian.com (Alice Corbin)
Date: Thu Jun 26 12:46:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] pine -> mutt: how to check mailbox files?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.53.0306261147590.5052@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>; from creelan@engr.orst.edu on Thu, Jun 26, 2003 at 12:00:13PM -0700
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0306251139540.27446@pecos.madboa.com> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306251416520.30787@shaft.bitmine.net> <Pine.GSO.4.53.0306261147590.5052@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <20030626124505.A17101@zaphod.axian.com>

I've got my mailboxes defined using $HOME, as in:

  mailboxes ! $HOME/Mail/plug $HOME/Mail/abcusers $HOME/Mail/rhnadmin

so you can always use an environment variable if setting a variable
in .muttrc doesn't work.  You might be able to use the =/myFolder 
shortcut as well. And if you want to quickly get all of the 
folders in your mail directory, you can always say:

  mailboxes `echo /nfs/foo/u3/u/bar/mail/folders/*`

You might also need:

  set check_new=yes


Then, when you hit the 'c' command to change folders, if a message
has come in on another folder its name will appear in the command 
area, and hitting the return key will take you there.


I used to have the ugly threading problem, too.  I think that this
line is what fixed it:

  set ascii_chars            # use ASCII instead of ACS chars for threads

Ali


On Thu, Jun 26, 2003 at 12:00:13PM -0700, Tyler F. Creelan wrote:

to bring up a list of mailboxes to browse.

> Then, when you hit the 'c' command to change folders, if a message
> has come in on another folder its name will appear in the command 
> area, and hitting the return key will take you there.

through them by pressing the spacebar.

From sandy at herring.org  Thu Jun 26 13:44:01 2003
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Thu Jun 26 13:44:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] pine -> mutt: how to check mailbox files?
In-Reply-To: <20030626200624.GA10840@constraint>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0306251139540.27446@pecos.madboa.com> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306251416520.30787@shaft.bitmine.net> <Pine.GSO.4.53.0306261147590.5052@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU> <1056659391.13982.16.camel@sparticus> <20030626200624.GA10840@constraint>
Message-ID: <20030626204302.GA5292@kippered.herring.org>

On Thu, 26 Jun 2003, Bill Barry wrote: 
> On Thu, Jun 26, 2003 at 01:29:51PM -0700, Cooper Stevenson wrote:
> > In your ~/.muttrc file:
> > 
> > mailboxes filename [filename...] 
> > 
> 
> After you have defined mailboxes in .muttrc, use mutt -y
> to bring up a list of mailboxes to browse.

And once you're displaying a message list for any mailbox, you can press "c"
and then <TAB><TAB> to display defined mailboxes which have new mail. Press
<TAB> again, and all mailboxes you've defined (as above) will show in the
index, regardless of whether they have new mail. Press <TAB> one more time,
and all of your mail folders (in whatever you've defined as your maildir)
will display, regardless of whether they've been defined by the mailboxes
directive in .muttrc. BUT WAIT, THERE'S MORE! At this point, <TAB> toggles
between the mailboxes index and the maildir index. Mutt is slick!

Sandy
-- 
Sandy Herring, RHCE                        o              sandy at herring.org
Peck of Pickled Pisces               __  o               http://herring.org/

From bmdimaculangan at bhpi.com.ph  Thu Jun 26 23:25:03 2003
From: bmdimaculangan at bhpi.com.ph (Billy Dimaculangan)
Date: Thu Jun 26 23:25:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] FW: port 80 problem
Message-ID: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCKEOMCMAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>

I have here a Linux server that is acting as proxy server with 2(two NICs),
one is facing the Internet and the other is facing our LAN.  The problem I
have is the webpage hosted in that server is only available in our local
area network.  When I tried a port scan using the local address port 80
seems to ok, but when I port scanned the IP Address facing the Internet port
80 is not available. That is why the webpage hosted in that server is only
available for the local area network and inaccessible in the outside world.
I would like to know is how could I make this port 80 available to the
outside world?

TIA

--
Billy

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Jun 27 06:24:01 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri Jun 27 06:24:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux news you may have missed.
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306270621590.20726-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

INDIAN COMPANY OFFERS LINUX HANDHELD TO OEMS
     (Source: LinuxWorld.com) Bangalore-based Mistral Software
has designed a Linux-based handheld computer around the ARM9TDMI
RISC processor from Samsung Electronics that aims to target
vertical markets such as navigation, health care, logistics, and
hospital management.
http://www.linuxworld.com/go.cgi?id=742612

SHAKE VIRUSES OUT OF YOUR MAIL SERVER WITHOUT SLOWDOWN
     (Source: Network World Fusion) Enterprise Linux users
looking to lock down their mail servers may want to check out a
new tool from Eset, aimed at quashing viruses on open source
systems.
http://www.linuxworld.com/go.cgi?id=742615

MORE THAN 500 GERMAN GOVERNMENT AGENCIES USING OPEN SOURCE
     (Source: LinuxWorld.com) One year after the German Federal
Ministry of the Interior agreed to a partnership with IBM to
supply open-source software on new computers to federal, state
and local governments as well as other government agencies, more
than 500 groups have signed up for the service.
http://www.linuxworld.com/go.cgi?id=742616

NOVELL MOVING NETWORKING SERVICES TO LINUX
     (Source: InfoWorld.com) The company will announce Nterprise
Linux Services, although the product will not ship until the end
of this year. The package will consist of Novell's file, print,
messaging, directory, and management services tailored to the Red
Hat and SuSE distributions of Linux.
http://www.linuxworld.com/go.cgi?id=742619

From barryb at proaxis.com  Fri Jun 27 09:45:03 2003
From: barryb at proaxis.com (Bill Barry)
Date: Fri Jun 27 09:45:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] FW: port 80 problem
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCKEOMCMAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
References: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCKEOMCMAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <20030627164410.GA13017@constraint>

On Fri, Jun 27, 2003 at 02:19:31PM +0800, Billy Dimaculangan wrote:
> I have here a Linux server that is acting as proxy server with 2(two NICs),
> one is facing the Internet and the other is facing our LAN.  The problem I
> have is the webpage hosted in that server is only available in our local
> area network.  When I tried a port scan using the local address port 80
> seems to ok, but when I port scanned the IP Address facing the Internet port
> 80 is not available. That is why the webpage hosted in that server is only
> available for the local area network and inaccessible in the outside world.
> I would like to know is how could I make this port 80 available to the
> outside world?

What does netstat tell you about port 80? I.e. what does
netstat -an | grep ":80"
return?

It is possible that your web server is configured to only listen to
port 80 on the local network.  If you are running apache this is
configured with the listen directive in httpd.conf
http://httpd.apache.org/docs/mod/core.html#listen
yours may be something like
Listen 192.168.0.1:80
where you probably want it to be just
Listen 80

Bill Barry



From jtodd at loligo.com  Fri Jun 27 10:01:01 2003
From: jtodd at loligo.com (John Todd)
Date: Fri Jun 27 10:01:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT: VoiceSpamAssassin
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0306270630080.908@pecos.madboa.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0306270630080.908@pecos.madboa.com>
Message-ID: <p05210666bb2226e8e9b4@loligo.com>

>The federal government has opened its national Do-Not-Call registry:
>
>* http://donotcall.gov (I couldn't get through this morning)
>* (888) 382-1222
>
>c|net has a write up:
>
>   http://news.com.com/2100-1037_3-1021645.html?tag=fd_top
>
>--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

A better solution to phone spam is Asterisk, with it's included 
Zapateller and PrivacyManager modules.

Short description: Asterisk (http://www.asterisk.org/) is an OSS PBX 
system which can be easily turned into a voicemail and VoIP gateway 
for your house.  With the addition of a $100 card, it can take your 
house line into the back of your Linux box and pre-parse your calls. 
Then, upon completion of checking your calls, it will forward the 
call to either a SIP device (like a Cisco ATA-186, with two lines at 
~$130) or to any other gateway of your choice.

If your caller does not have caller ID, the Zapateller application 
plays the first three tones of a "number out of order" recording, 
which most automated phone bots will take as a "bad number" and they 
will remove you from their database and hang up at the same time. 
This gets about 50% of the phone spam that I see.

The PrivacyManager application next looks for any inbound calls 
without caller ID.  It forces the caller to enter in a valid caller 
ID through the touch-tone pad.  Most telemarketers will not do this 
(none, actually, in my experience) and they hang up.  Since 
implementing Asterisk, I have had two spam calls get through (six 
months.)

You can get more sophisticated than that if you want: blacklists, 
whitelists, pre-announcements on _all_ calls, database lookups.  It's 
all possible.

JT



From sandy at herring.org  Fri Jun 27 13:03:02 2003
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Fri Jun 27 13:03:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] FW: port 80 problem
In-Reply-To: <20030627153951.GA7610@sthelens.dimstar.net>
References: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCKEOMCMAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph> <VS2ZHEQM51082V1WID1TQTRIE0RB9.3efc5dc1@mike> <20030627153951.GA7610@sthelens.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <20030627200242.GA18982@kippered.herring.org>

On Fri, 27 Jun 2003, Russ Johnson wrote: 
> * Mike De La Mater <mikedela at ipns.com> [2003-06-27 08:08]:
> > BTW- If you post to this list in plaintext, instead of HTML, 
> > you'll get to more geeks. Some on the list hate HTML mail and 
> > send it to the bit bucket before it ever gets seen.
> 
> And others of us, while we don't hate html email, use text based email
> clients, so it's some work to view an "html only" posting. 
> 
> For email, text is best. :)
> 
> Then again, maybe I do hate html email and don't realize it. If I get
> html only mail, 9 times out of 10 I delete it without trying to read it,
> because it's almost always spam.... 

Agreed. But I see you're also a `mutt' user, Russ. Here's a tip to take the
work out of viewing html email...

[.muttrc]
# View html mails using lynx
set implicit_autoview
auto_view text/html  application/x-pgp-message
set mailcap_path="~/.mailcap"
set mailcap_sanitize=yes


[.mailcap]
text/html; /usr/bin/lynx -dump -force_html '%s'; copiousoutput; description=HTML Text; nametemplate=%s.html

cheers,
Sandy

> 
> Short description: Asterisk (http://www.asterisk.org/) is an OSS PBX 
> system which can be easily turned into a voicemail and VoIP gateway 
> for your house.  With the addition of a $100 card, it can take your 
> house line into the back of your Linux box and pre-parse your calls. 
> Then, upon completion of checking your calls, it will forward the 
> call to either a SIP device (like a Cisco ATA-186, with two lines at 
> ~$130) or to any other gateway of your choice.
> 
> If your caller does not have caller ID, the Zapateller application 
> plays the first three tones of a "number out of order" recording, 
> which most automated phone bots will take as a "bad number" and they 
> will remove you from their database and hang up at the same time. 
> This gets about 50% of the phone spam that I see.
> 
> The PrivacyManager application next looks for any inbound calls 
> without caller ID.  It forces the caller to enter in a valid caller 
> ID through the touch-tone pad.  Most telemarketers will not do this 
> (none, actually, in my experience) and they hang up.  Since 
> implementing Asterisk, I have had two spam calls get through (six 
> months.)
> 
> You can get more sophisticated than that if you want: blacklists, 
> whitelists, pre-announcements on _all_ calls, database lookups.  It's 
> all possible.
> 
> JT
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
> 




From hapibeli at attbi.com  Fri Jun 27 17:39:01 2003
From: hapibeli at attbi.com (Dirk Ouellette)
Date: Fri Jun 27 17:39:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] apt problem
Message-ID: <1056760661.1295.1.camel@localhost.localdomain>

When apt-get update reaches the following point and hangs, what are the
possible solutions?
TIA, Dirk

Fetched 1325kB in 17s (76.7kB/s)
Reading Package Lists... 66%





From list at sonofhans.net  Fri Jun 27 18:19:02 2003
From: list at sonofhans.net (Randall Hansen)
Date: Fri Jun 27 18:19:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] apt problem
In-Reply-To: <1056760661.1295.1.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1056760661.1295.1.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <20030627181831.340f379a.list@sonofhans.net>

Thus spoke Dirk Ouellette <hapibeli at attbi.com>
( 27 Jun 2003 17:37:42 -0700 ):

> When apt-get update reaches the following point and hangs, what are
> the possible solutions?

> Fetched 1325kB in 17s (76.7kB/s)
> Reading Package Lists... 66%

My first guess is that one of your package lists in
/var/lib/apt/lists/ is corrupt somehow and apt-get has trouble reading
it.  Try this (either as root or under 'sudo'):

  $ cd /var/lib/apt
  $ mv lists old_lists
  $ mkdir -p lists/partial

Here you're renaming your old 'lists' directory, then recreating
'lists' and 'lists/partial' (without these apt-get will fail).  Then
run 'apt-get update' again and it should fetch brand new lists.

If that doesn't work, try 'strace' to see if you can find out exactly
where it's hanging by running (as root or under 'sudo'):

  $ strace apt-get update | less

'| less' pipes the output (which will be very long) to 'less', which
will make it much easier to read; if you don't have 'less'
installed use 'more' instead (or any other pager program).

If these don't help and no one here offers better advice consider
asking the debian-users mailing list.  It's high-traffic, but
generally friendly and tolerant of varying skill levels:

  http://lists.debian.org/users.html

r

Subject: [PLUG] 802.11b adapters known to work with Linux?
In-Reply-To: <200306250829.38777.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

On Wednesday 25 June 2003 08:29 am, Carla Schroder wrote:
> On Wednesday 25 June 2003 6:13 am, David Fleck wrote:
> > Thanks to everyone who responded to my cry for help.  It turns out
> > what I really needed was a strong dose of RTFM - I got the Linksys
> > USB wireless adapter (WUSB11v2.6) working with SuSE 8.2 by doing 2
> > things:
> >
> > 1) finding the correct howto
> > (http://atmelwlandriver.sourceforge.net/howto/howto.html)
> >
> > 2) reading it carefully.
> >
> > It turns out the correct driver module is included with SuSE 8.2,
> > but a bit of fiddling (not detailed in SuSE's docs, as far as I can
> > tell) is required for the system to load it correctly.
>
> RTFM is good advice when documentation is organized, clear, and easy
> to find. In this case, it isn't. The docs for implementing wireless
> in Linux are a chaotic mess. The worst part is trying to find if a
> particular card is supported. I don't blame the heroic souls who are
> writing drivers and docs for Linux, with little help or support. I am
> fed up with hardware manufacturers and vendors being so completely
> chickensh*t about Linux support. So don't feel bad about needing
> help.

I read at /. not too long ago that Linksys was using Linux as the 
underlying OS on some of their newer 802.11g access points/routers. The 
issue was raised as to whether or not they're violating the GPL by 
doing that. 

I have one of Linksys's new 802.11g access points and when I OS 
fingerprint it with "nmap" it identifies the device as being a 2.4.x 
version of Linux. It would be nice if Linksys would give back to the 
Linux community and provide Linux drivers for their newer 802.11g NICs. 
When last I checked there wasn't any support.

Right now I'm using Win2K on a laptop with one of Linksys's 802.11g PC 
Cards. Since my laptop belongs to the company I work for I don't really 
have a choice as to what OS I use on it at this point. We do have 
several Linux systems running in our server closet which is a step in 
the right direction IMHO.

Tony

Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at attbi.com




From jorgens at coho.net  Sat Jun 28 01:25:03 2003
From: jorgens at coho.net (Steve Jorgensen)
Date: Sat Jun 28 01:25:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Plug hostfs hole in uml without kernel recompile?
Message-ID: <01C33D15.1F9FA6B0.jorgens@coho.net>

Hi all,

Yet another User Mode Linux question...  Here I am, happily setting up User 
Mode Linux becuase I know I'm going to be a security bonehead, and this 
seems like a good way to keep services isolated from one another without a 
room full of systems to run my home network.  Also, it was seeming actually 
easier to understand and set up than chroot.  Now, come to find out that 
UML can happily access the host filesystem using hostfs - so much for 
bullet proof security.  Sure, it's still more secure than not using uml, 
but not nearly so much as I thought.  On article I saw recommended running 
uml in chroot for this reason - so much for not having to learn about 
chroot.

So, I know that I could compile my own uml kernel with hostfs support 
ommitted, but I just finished a week-long ordeal getting my host kernel to 
compile with gcc 3.3 so I could set up the skas patches.  I'm not looking 
forward to another kernel recompile experiment at this particular time. 
 Shouldn't there just be a uml start-up option to disable hostfs?  OK, 
"should" and reality appear to differ in this case, but I'm hoping someone 
here knows some simple, clever trick I could use.

Anyone?

Thanks,

- Steve Jorgensen



From jorgens at coho.net  Sat Jun 28 01:41:02 2003
From: jorgens at coho.net (Steve Jorgensen)
Date: Sat Jun 28 01:41:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] uml hostfs issue follow-up
Message-ID: <01C33D17.3E1595D0.jorgens@coho.net>

I just realized there are options in linux --help that are not in man 
linux, so I just tried starting with hostfs=/dev/null.

With this option, if I try mount -t hostfs none /testmount from inside the 
uml, I get "mount: Not a directory".  That's good, but then I try mount -t 
hostfs none /testmount -o ../.., and I get the host root mounted at 
/testmount.  It appears that this option does not truly "confine" the user 
to a subdirectory, it merely makes that the initial path, and does nothing 
to aid security.

From fixin at peak.org  Sun Jun 29 18:29:01 2003
From: fixin at peak.org (Eric House)
Date: Sun Jun 29 18:29:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Can I send mail from an attbi/comcast account?
Message-ID: <20030630012819.GP25919@peak.org>

I have a small LAN running behind a LEAF (leaf.sourceforge.net)
firewall and a comcast cable modem -- in Corvallis.  I'd like to be
able to send mail from hosts on the LAN.  I'm happy to use my ISP
address (fixin at peak.org) as the reply-to address and not to have any
mail coming into my LAN from the network: I just want to be able to
send mail out.

Is this possible?

(The modem gets its IP address via DHCP, but the router registers it
with dyndns.org -- so dig works, but dig -x will give you comcast's
funky name for my interface rather than mine.  Not sure if all this
matters.)

If it's possible, where's the best place to start reading?  I'm in
exim docs right now.

Thanks,

--Eric
-- 
******************************************************************************
* From the desktop of: Eric House, fixin at peak.org                            *
*    Crosswords 4.0 for PalmOS is out!: <http://www.peak.org/~fixin/xwords>  *

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sun Jun 29 19:40:02 2003
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sun Jun 29 19:40:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Can I send mail from an attbi/comcast account?
In-Reply-To: <20030630012819.GP25919@peak.org>
References: <20030630012819.GP25919@peak.org>
Message-ID: <200306291938.29957.aschlemm@attbi.com>

The hosts behind the firewall/router can access Comcast's email servers 
without any problem so you don't need anything fancy to do this. 
Depending on what sort of hosts you have on the LAN, there are several 
ways of connecting. We have several email addresses through Comcast and 
we just use POP3 clients on the hosts inside our network. They have no 
problems sending/receiving email via POP3/SMTP to Comcast's email 
servers.

I actually had a use for using sendmail on one of my Linux boxes inside 
my LAN and so I setup my firewall/router box to run sendmail as a relay 
for systems on my LAN. My firewall relays all outgoing email to  
Comcast's email servers. I only send e-mail out and I don't allow any 
in bound connections into my firewall/router box.

Tony

From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Sun Jun 29 19:54:02 2003
From: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Sun Jun 29 19:54:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Apache Reverse Proxy
Message-ID: <1056943140.1496.26.camel@sparticus>

All,

I have a router that has two web servers sitting behind it. The router
is configured such such that all outside requests on port 80 are routed
to Host A. I have several virtual domains on host A and it works fine.

The snag comes when I bring up a new web server and want it to also
receive requests from the Internet. Since I can specify traffic only by
it's host name with my router (e.g. I cannot direct traffic by URL), the
only way is to route the request through Host A.

It's easier to show you than explain what I would like to have; here it
is:

   http://www.domain_A.com ---> Router Port 80 ----> Host A

   http://www.domain_B.com ---> Router Port 80 ---> Host A ---> Host B

I want to expose only one IP to the Internet for security purposes. This
seems trivial but surprisingly it isn't. 

Although I find Apache's modular design fascinating (mod_proxy,
mod_rewrite, etc.) these modules don't seem to do exactly what I need.

I think you'll find this challenging...


Thanks,


Cooper





From robbert at vafam.com  Sun Jun 29 20:03:01 2003
From: robbert at vafam.com (Robbert van Andel)
Date: Sun Jun 29 20:03:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Configure a sound card
Message-ID: <1056942171.1688.6.camel@localhost.localdomain>

My sound card recently stopped working on my Red Hat 8 machine after I
upgraded to the latest kernel.  I cannot find sndconfig on my system so
I figure it is not used.  Is there an equivalent tool or some tool that
I can use to set up my card.  When I use the sound card configuration
from the System Settings panel, I get the following 

Vendor: Intel Corp.
Model: 82801DB AC
Module: i810_audio

Pressing "Play test sound" plays no sound but gives no error either (not
sure if it's supposed to).

Any help will be greatly appreciated.

Robbert van Andel

From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Sun Jun 29 20:56:02 2003
From: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Sun Jun 29 20:56:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] It Worked! (Was: Re: [lug] Apache Reverse Proxy)
In-Reply-To: <1056946166.1496.93.camel@sparticus>
References: <1056943140.1496.26.camel@sparticus>
	 <20030630031726.GA11976@oregonstate.edu>
	 <1056946166.1496.93.camel@sparticus>
Message-ID: <1056946897.1496.124.camel@sparticus>

Robert,

Just exactly "something along those lines!!"

Here's what did the trick:

<VirtualHost *:80>
     ServerName hostb.domain.com
     ProxyPass        / http://<ip address of host b>/
</VirtualHost>


That was just the tip I needed! Thank you very much!


-Cooper

On Sun, 2003-06-29 at 20:17, Robert Hopson wrote:
> Cooper,
> 
> Apache's ProxyPass and ProxyPassReverse directives both apply in a
> virtual host context.  So in Host A's apache config file, you should
be
> able to set up a virtual host
> 
> <VirtualHost *:80>
>     ServerName www.domain_B.com
>     ProxyPassReverse / http://<Host B's internal address>/
> </VirtualHost>
> 
> or, at least, something along those lines :)
> 
> 
> Robert Hopson
> 
> 
> On Sun, Jun 29, 2003 at 08:19:00PM -0700, Cooper Stevenson wrote:
> > All,
> >

From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Sun Jun 29 21:22:02 2003
From: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Sun Jun 29 21:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Configure a sound card
In-Reply-To: <1056942171.1688.6.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1056942171.1688.6.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1056948461.1496.178.camel@sparticus>

Robbert,

Just a few things to try...

First, let's find sndconfig...

  # whereis sndconfig

Or, if you're feeling spry...

  # find / -name sndconfig 2>/dev/null

Now, let's see if we can get the module installed...

  # cd /lib/modules/<kernel_version>/drivers/kernel/sound

Look for a module called i810_audio. If you find it...

  # modprobe i810_audio

Also, see the documentation in /usr/src/linux/Documentation/modules.txt
for getting this module to load automatically...it's fairly well written
and gives some good examples.

Check to make sure that the volume and line controls are up in X...

  # xmixer

Hope this helps...


-Cooper

On Sun, 2003-06-29 at 20:02, Robbert van Andel wrote:
> My sound card recently stopped working on my Red Hat 8 machine after I
> upgraded to the latest kernel.  I cannot find sndconfig on my system so
> I figure it is not used.  Is there an equivalent tool or some tool that
> I can use to set up my card.  When I use the sound card configuration
> from the System Settings panel, I get the following 
> 
> Vendor: Intel Corp.
> Model: 82801DB AC
> Module: i810_audio
> 
> Pressing "Play test sound" plays no sound but gives no error either (not
> sure if it's supposed to).
> 
> Any help will be greatly appreciated.
> 
> Robbert van Andel
> 
>

From bmdimaculangan at bhpi.com.ph  Sun Jun 29 21:42:02 2003
From: bmdimaculangan at bhpi.com.ph (Billy Dimaculangan)
Date: Sun Jun 29 21:42:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] "from=<>"
Message-ID: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCIEAKCNAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>

I found this strange things going on in our server maillog.  upon reviewing
the the daily mail delivery report, if found out that "from=<>"  was
included in top 10 Senders by message count and top 10 Senders by message
size. This "from=<>" also exist in our maillog and sending out mails to
other domain. we are currently running postfix in our mail server.  i'm
wondering if any one can clear things for me regarding this matter. i hope

From robbert at vafam.com  Mon Jun 30 06:37:02 2003
From: robbert at vafam.com (Robbert van Andel)
Date: Mon Jun 30 06:37:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Configure a sound card
In-Reply-To: <1056948461.1496.178.camel@sparticus>
References: <1056942171.1688.6.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	 <1056948461.1496.178.camel@sparticus>
Message-ID: <1056980176.1188.2.camel@localhost.localdomain>

Thanks, I just needed to reload the module.

Robbert

On Sun, 2003-06-29 at 21:47, Cooper Stevenson wrote:
> Robbert,
> 
> Just a few things to try...
> 
> First, let's find sndconfig...
> 
>   # whereis sndconfig
> 
> Or, if you're feeling spry...
> 
>   # find / -name sndconfig 2>/dev/null
> 
> Now, let's see if we can get the module installed...
> 
>   # cd /lib/modules/<kernel_version>/drivers/kernel/sound
> 
> Look for a module called i810_audio. If you find it...
> 
>   # modprobe i810_audio
> 
> Also, see the documentation in /usr/src/linux/Documentation/modules.txt
> for getting this module to load automatically...it's fairly well written
> and gives some good examples.
> 
> Check to make sure that the volume and line controls are up in X...
> 
>   # xmixer
> 
> Hope this helps...
> 
> 
> -Cooper
> 
> On Sun, 2003-06-29 at 20:02, Robbert van Andel wrote:
> > My sound card recently stopped working on my Red Hat 8 machine after I
> > upgraded to the latest kernel.  I cannot find sndconfig on my system so
> > I figure it is not used.  Is there an equivalent tool or some tool that
> > I can use to set up my card.  When I use the sound card configuration
> > from the System Settings panel, I get the following 
> > 
> > Vendor: Intel Corp.
> > Model: 82801DB AC
> > Module: i810_audio
> > 
> > Pressing "Play test sound" plays no sound but gives no error either (not
> > sure if it's supposed to).
> > 
> > Any help will be greatly appreciated.
> > 
> > Robbert van Andel
> > 
> > 
> > _______________________________________________
> > PLUG mailing list
> > PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> > http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From aschlemm at comcast.net  Mon Jun 30 07:39:02 2003
From: aschlemm at comcast.net (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Mon Jun 30 07:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] attbi -> comcast switch..
In-Reply-To: <1056981890.5189.5.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
References: <1056981890.5189.5.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
Message-ID: <200306300737.51809.aschlemm@comcast.net>

I'm not in the Portland area but I did have to transition from attbi.com 
to comcast.net. The mail server names for POP and SMTP have been 
changed and everyone gets the "comcast.net" domain on their userids. My 
user ID stayed the same and everything appears to be working normally 
for email. It's a pain though since I subscribe to a number mailing 
lists. At least Comcast is nice enough to keep forwarding email to our 
new addresses even if people use our old attbi.com domain. 

I'm assuming everyone will use the following email servers no matter 
where they are located geographically:

incoming (POP) server: mail.comcast.net
outgoing (SMTP) server: smtp.comcast.net

Tony
