From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Mon Jun 30 08:51:01 2003
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Mon Jun 30 08:51:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Apache Reverse Proxy
References: <mailman.1056941662.29687.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86wuf3muu2.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Cooper" == Cooper Stevenson <cooper at cooper.stevenson.name> writes:

Cooper> Although I find Apache's modular design fascinating (mod_proxy,
Cooper> mod_rewrite, etc.) these modules don't seem to do exactly what I need.

You can certainly pass through everything arriving for a namedvirtual
host or a port-based host to another host using only mod_rewrite and
mod_proxy.  www.stonehenge.com does that for nearly every hit.  Maybe
you should email me what you've tried, and I can send you some of the
configs from stonehenge.com.

From mwlist at planetwills.com  Mon Jun 30 09:47:02 2003
From: mwlist at planetwills.com (Mark Wills)
Date: Mon Jun 30 09:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] attbi -> comcast switch..
In-Reply-To: <200306300737.51809.aschlemm@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <CAENLEIHEHPLANCLMFKMIEMKDGAA.mwlist@planetwills.com>

I have opened the transition pages - with difficulty after many refreshes! I
suspect the servers are slammed.
Anthony has the servers right. In addition add netnews.comcast.net for News
Server
They also support ssl connection to the POP server (port 995)
All of my mail was waiting at the new servers. I couldn't get any from the
old.
The forwarding seems to work. mail sent to attbi.com or comcast.net comes
though to the new mail boxes.
I avoided having to change email addresses by getting my own domain name
from domainforte.com with email forwarding for $12.95/yr.

Mark

Here's what I've found:

1. Web page for Manual transition:

http://online.comcast.net/connect/manual.asp

2. Public cert for mail.comcast.net. POP over SSL is supported.

3. Using fetchmail. Here's what I do in ~/.fetchmailrc:

poll mail.comcast.net proto pop3
  user "remote-me", with password "pAsSwOrD", is "local-me" here,
  ssl,
  sslfingerprint "86:4B:ED:3A:64:CE:70:D4:56:C1:DE:57:C6:92:AC:19"

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From svanhoosen at yahoo.com  Mon Jun 30 11:05:02 2003
From: svanhoosen at yahoo.com (Scott Van Hoosen)
Date: Mon Jun 30 11:05:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux memory usage
In-Reply-To: <1056984276.13803.5.camel@sparticus>
Message-ID: <20030630180335.2983.qmail@web40806.mail.yahoo.com>

I'm curious as to how to interpret free memory in
Linux. It seems as though memory gradually gets used
up more and more each day, until free memory gets very
small. I know this is not what is actually happening,
because even when only a small amount of memory is
free, I can open several programs, like OpenOffice,
Mozilla, Evolution, etc, and the swap file will not be
used.

Does Linux somehow keep old programs and/or data in
memory after they are closed, only removing it from
memory when it is needed?

How can I know how much memory is actually available?

I have attached the output from /proc/meminfo on one
server, which has 2 gigs of RAM and very little
running (Samba and Apache). I have watched memory
utilization grow slowly from ~10% to ~90% in a few
weeks.

cat /proc/meminfo
      total:    used:    free:  shared: buffers: 
cached:
Mem:  2113421312 2008666112 104755200        0
121565184 1619886080
Swap: 1990057984  2867200 1987190784
MemTotal:      2063888 kB
MemFree:        102300 kB
MemShared:           0 kB
Buffers:        118716 kB
Cached:        1579148 kB
SwapCached:       2772 kB
Active:        1088316 kB
ActiveAnon:     104904 kB
ActiveCache:    983412 kB
Inact_dirty:     22476 kB
Inact_laundry:  678372 kB
Inact_clean:     37448 kB
Inact_target:   365320 kB
HighTotal:     1179072 kB
HighFree:        20376 kB
LowTotal:       884816 kB
LowFree:         81924 kB
SwapTotal:     1943416 kB
SwapFree:      1940616 kB

Thanks,

-Scott

From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Mon Jun 30 11:20:02 2003
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Mon Jun 30 11:20:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] 802.11b Antenna cheap or wireless card router preferen
	ces
Message-ID: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A0559C607@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

  I use a Linksys WAP11 at home.  I used to use a Linksys WPC11 PCMCIA card
in my laptop.  I had a lot of trouble keeping a good signal level, and had
occasional driver hangs under RH 8.0.  (The same WPC11 card works fine in my
NT 2000 laptop.)

  I switched to an Orinoco Silver PCMCIA.  The chipset is well supported and
the card has an external antenna jack.  The Orinoco has worked fine running
earlier RH 9.0.  I've recently started seeing some driver problems on the
latest RH kernel.  Signal levels have been good.  I haven't needed to use an
external antenna.  

Steve D...

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Mon Jun 30 11:29:01 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor Pikus)
Date: Mon Jun 30 11:29:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux memory usage
In-Reply-To: <20030630180335.2983.qmail@web40806.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0306301124300.2542-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

You need a tool which will show you not just free memory, but what the
memory is used for: most of the memory which appears "used" but then
magically becomes available when you start another application is
used for disk caches. Linux will consume all available memory pretty
quickly if there is any disk I/O, and won't release any until it's needed
for something else (i.e. the pages are not marked as free but rather as
available for freeing if needed).

On Mon, 30 Jun 2003, Scott Van Hoosen wrote:
> I'm curious as to how to interpret free memory in
> Linux. It seems as though memory gradually gets used
> up more and more each day, until free memory gets very
> small. I know this is not what is actually happening,
> because even when only a small amount of memory is
> free, I can open several programs, like OpenOffice,
> Mozilla, Evolution, etc, and the swap file will not be
> used.
>
> Does Linux somehow keep old programs and/or data in
> memory after they are closed, only removing it from
> memory when it is needed?
>
> How can I know how much memory is actually available?
>
> I have attached the output from /proc/meminfo on one
> server, which has 2 gigs of RAM and very little
> running (Samba and Apache). I have watched memory
> utilization grow slowly from ~10% to ~90% in a few
> weeks.
>
> cat /proc/meminfo
>       total:    used:    free:  shared: buffers:
> cached:
> Mem:  2113421312 2008666112 104755200        0
> 121565184 1619886080
> Swap: 1990057984  2867200 1987190784
> MemTotal:      2063888 kB
> MemFree:        102300 kB
> MemShared:           0 kB
> Buffers:        118716 kB
> Cached:        1579148 kB
> SwapCached:       2772 kB
> Active:        1088316 kB
> ActiveAnon:     104904 kB
> ActiveCache:    983412 kB
> Inact_dirty:     22476 kB
> Inact_laundry:  678372 kB
> Inact_clean:     37448 kB
> Inact_target:   365320 kB
> HighTotal:     1179072 kB
> HighFree:        20376 kB
> LowTotal:       884816 kB
> LowFree:         81924 kB
> SwapTotal:     1943416 kB
> SwapFree:      1940616 kB
>
> Thanks,
>
> -Scott
>

> http://sbc.yahoo.com

Brent Rieck wrote:

>I know little to nothing about cable access other than I've found some

>systems?  And if so, when will your show be broadcast?

Hi Brent,

Local cable access is only available in the community that is served by 
a given cable company.  That being the case, the show will ( initially ) 
only be broadcast in McMinnville, and possibly in Salem.  I can make a 
tape available to anyone who wants to go through the process of airing 
it in Portland and can step anyone who is interested through the process 
of getting the show aired in their community.

Regards,

Salvador Peralta

From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Jun 30 11:42:03 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon Jun 30 11:42:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux memory usage
In-Reply-To: <20030630180335.2983.qmail@web40806.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030630180335.2983.qmail@web40806.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0306301126420.20139@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 30 Jun 2003, Scott Van Hoosen wrote:

> I'm curious as to how to interpret free memory in Linux. It seems as
> though memory gradually gets used up more and more each day, until
> free memory gets very small. I know this is not what is actually
> happening, because even when only a small amount of memory is free,
> I can open several programs, like OpenOffice, Mozilla, Evolution,
> etc, and the swap file will not be used.
>
> Does Linux somehow keep old programs and/or data in memory after
> they are closed, only removing it from memory when it is needed?
>
> How can I know how much memory is actually available?

Linux is pretty aggressive about using RAM to buffer data from disk.
Try using the 'free' command; it "displays the total amount of free
and used physical memory and swap space in the system, as well as the
buffers and cache consumed by the kernel" (the free(1) man page).

For example, my workstation at work has a half-gig of memory.
According to free, nearly 300 (293) megabytes of RAM is just cached
files. The stuff in cache can be flushed if the kernel should
suddenly need to allocate a big hunk of memory to a new process.

[heinlein at glenfiddich heinlein]$ free -m
             total       used       free     shared    buffers     cached
Mem:           501        492          9          0         86        293
-/+ buffers/cache:        112        388
Swap:          996         26        969

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>



From robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com  Mon Jun 30 11:50:02 2003
From: robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com (robinsoq )
Date: Mon Jun 30 11:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Onstream bankruptcy, what can I do?
Message-ID: <200306301149.AA219152640@opusnet.com>

I got an onstream DI30 drive off of ebay but would you 
know it, the company is bankrupt.  I've tried getting 
Verbatim cartridges through E-Bay but they were not 
new or at least they're faulty.  Since it's an auction 
I'm stuck with them, the moral is, I don't want to 
waste more money on bad media.  I picked up one good 
cartridge through issi business solutions where this 
company won't sell media for the drive anymore because 
of the bamkruptcy.  Is there a place to trade this drive 
in for credit towards another Linux compatible tape 
drive?  Maybe I should try to sell it at this point.
If I can't pick up at least three good cartridges for
close to or under $100 there's not a whole lot I can 
do with it.

I look at buy.com and they have media for the 25/50 units
but I don't think you can put those cartridges into an 
older drive.

I tried to go to dirt cheap drives to look at buying hard
drives instead of tapes but there site is down for 
"corporate restructuring."

I wonder about all media drive business as IBM has abandoned
their ATA hard drive line and people are telling me that
drives are not profitable enough.  I wonder what's going to
happen considering that no server works without some kind
of nonvolatile memory ( O.K. you can network boot a server
but you still have to have at least one that has nonvolatile memory ). 

     --  Michael C. Robinson 



From holger at selover.net  Mon Jun 30 11:52:01 2003
From: holger at selover.net (Holger Stephan)
Date: Mon Jun 30 11:52:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Disk Spanning for NFS directory
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0306301126420.20139@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
References: <20030630180335.2983.qmail@web40806.mail.yahoo.com> 
	<Pine.LNX.4.56.0306301126420.20139@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <1056999117.16376.745.camel@halo>

How can I combine two disks to a single (NFS) directory? Is this done
with RAID? Is there a tutorial available? I have a box with two hard
drives. Another box can be configured to use a NFS mount as an expansion
storage, but only one mount (it's a network appliance). 

Thanks!

Holger





From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Jun 30 12:00:03 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon Jun 30 12:00:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Disk Spanning for NFS directory
In-Reply-To: <1056999117.16376.745.camel@halo>
References: <20030630180335.2983.qmail@web40806.mail.yahoo.com> 
 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0306301126420.20139@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
 <1056999117.16376.745.camel@halo>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0306301155250.20139@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 30 Jun 2003, Holger Stephan wrote:

> How can I combine two disks to a single (NFS) directory? Is this
> done with RAID? Is there a tutorial available? I have a box with two
> hard drives. Another box can be configured to use a NFS mount as an
> expansion storage, but only one mount (it's a network appliance).

Holger,

Look at the LVM stuff:

  http://tldp.org/HOWTO/LVM-HOWTO/

Red Hat includes all the LVM functionality, so you won't have to
rebuild a kernel or anything. Sadly, however, you'll have to backup
your disk data, do some LVM hand waving, reformat your drives, and
then restore your data.

It works pretty well, however. I've got an 860GB LVM partition
(formatted with XFS) at work, and it works pretty well for both NFS
mounts and Samba shares.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>



From holger at selover.net  Mon Jun 30 12:11:02 2003
From: holger at selover.net (Holger Stephan)
Date: Mon Jun 30 12:11:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Disk Spanning for NFS directory
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0306301155250.20139@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
References: <20030630180335.2983.qmail@web40806.mail.yahoo.com>

	<Pine.LNX.4.56.0306301155250.20139@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <1057000224.16378.770.camel@halo>

Excellent! Thank you so much Paul!

It's a fresh install so the reformatting is not a problem. 

Holger

From guy1656 at ados.com  Mon Jun 30 12:37:01 2003

Subject: [PLUG] OT - Spoof Plural?
Message-ID: <200306301233.48952.guy1656@ados.com>

Although it is accepted that techie-types get to mangulate grammar and 
orthography with supposedly a bit more license than most folks are usually 
allowed to get away with, I was talking to a friend about spoofing, and I'd 
like to put a question out to this forum:

Would the plural of (n.) 'spoof,' like as for roof and hoof, be 'spooves?'

-GLL

From holger at selover.net  Mon Jun 30 13:54:01 2003
From: holger at selover.net (Holger Stephan)

Quoting Anthony Schlemmer <aschlemm at comcast.net>:

> I'm not in the Portland area but I did have to transition from attbi.com 
> to comcast.net. The mail server names for POP and SMTP have been 
> changed and everyone gets the "comcast.net" domain on their userids. My 
> user ID stayed the same and everything appears to be working normally 
> for email. It's a pain though since I subscribe to a number mailing 
> lists. At least Comcast is nice enough to keep forwarding email to our 
> new addresses even if people use our old attbi.com domain. 
> 
> I'm assuming everyone will use the following email servers no matter 
> where they are located geographically:
> 
> incoming (POP) server: mail.comcast.net
> outgoing (SMTP) server: smtp.comcast.net

> Tony

On Mon, 30 Jun 2003, Billy Dimaculangan wrote:

> I found this strange things going on in our server maillog.  upon reviewing
> the the daily mail delivery report, if found out that "from=<>"  was
> included in top 10 Senders by message count and top 10 Senders by message
> size. This "from=<>" also exist in our maillog and sending out mails to
> other domain. we are currently running postfix in our mail server.  i'm
> wondering if any one can clear things for me regarding this matter. i hope
> someone could help me with this one..
> 
> TIA

I think this is either the reverse look up fail (ip to name) or there was 
no domain name given from the sending server.   Spammer or misconfigured 
mta.  or both.

From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Mon Jun 30 15:17:01 2003
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)
Date: Mon Jun 30 15:17:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] It Worked! (Was: Re: [lug] Apache Reverse Proxy)
In-Reply-To: <1056946897.1496.124.camel@sparticus>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306301533120.16996-100000@antares.mpcu.com>

On 29 Jun 2003, Cooper Stevenson wrote:

> Robert,
> 
> Just exactly "something along those lines!!"
> 
> Here's what did the trick:
> 
> <VirtualHost *:80>
>      ServerName hostb.domain.com
>      ProxyPass        / http://<ip address of host b>/
> </VirtualHost>
> 


and the forwarding is based on the URL (hostname, I guess) passed to 
hosta.domain.com?

From edasher at javelin.net  Mon Jun 30 15:21:02 2003
From: edasher at javelin.net (Erik Dasher)
Date: Mon Jun 30 15:21:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] mp3 players -- separate from the system
Message-ID: <B6FBC8135B7CAD4FB9C85A61DB40B519028D0F@linden.javelin.net>

Rich,
I can't recommend a specific mp3 player, but I recommend the below criteria:

1. Requires no software, appears to your operating system (be it linux mac or windows) as a new file system (Best) OR at least has software for linux.
2. Expandable.
3. Intuitive interface.
4. "Drop" survivable.
5. Uses a generic USB cable.

Just some ideas.

-EcD

I've noticed that 98SE's fdisk and Ranish partition manager
both doing something strange with partitioning.  Under Redhat
7.x and 8 disk druid picks up an extra partition before
each partition created with Ranish or 98 fdisk and Linux
fdisk will give errors about partitions not being on a 
cylinder boundary.  Why does Windows 98 partition 
differently than Linux?  Why do Ranish and Windows 
create a partition that is same cylinder to same cylinder 
before every partition according to Disk Druid?  Ranish 
can create Linux partitions, is this what an XOSL user 
should use to create Linux's partitions?  Can xosl allow 
booting from extended partitions and/or partitions over 
the 1024 cylinder boundary, I thought it could but I 
couldn't get any of this to work.

From m at pdxlug.org  Mon Jun 30 15:26:24 2003

I just bought the Creative Nomad MuVo and I'm very happy with it.  It's
small enough to fit on my keychain and also doubles as a 128MB USB drive. 
There's no software or drivers to worry about.  You just plug it into your
Windows or Linux box, mount the USB drive, copy your files over, and any
MP3 or WMA files will be playable.

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Mon Jun 30 15:54:01 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Mon Jun 30 15:54:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] mp3 players -- separate from the system
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306301506270.9980-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306301506270.9980-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20030630225356.GA24616@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

On Mon, Jun 30, 2003 at 03:07:48PM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Can anyone recommend an mp3 player to which music can be transferred from
> the workstation? The digital music equivalent of the Walkman, I presume.

I've been pretty happy with the new iPod. The default interface is
firewire, which works great for me (using a SIIG 3-port pci firewire
card, with the standard kernel module). gtkpod provides a useable,
albiet buggy interface(it crashes once in a while), there are a few
others, but I haven't looked into them.

The thing I dislike the most is the heavy reliance on id3 tags, I'm
not sure which version of id3, but I'm having a few issues with that.

Overall though, I'm extremely pleased. Battery life is great (haven't
measured it yet, but probably 8 hours+) it's very tiny, and holds more
than one CD of music, which is my main gripe with the solid state
players.

-Rogan

From m at pdxlug.org  Mon Jun 30 16:29:02 2003
From: m at pdxlug.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Mon Jun 30 16:29:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Unicode, HTML, and Perl
In-Reply-To: <32959.68.107.223.201.1057010534.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
References: <32959.68.107.223.201.1057010534.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <33000.68.107.223.201.1057015693.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>

Matt Alexander said:
> I'm parsing an HTML document and I'd like to save the actual unicode
> characters to a text file.  For example, an HTML file might contain a name
> like this:  L&#243;pez
> I would like my Perl script to convert the &#243; to the correct unicode
> character and save it in a text file.
> Any suggestions on how to do this?
> Thanks,
> ~M

I figured it out.  Browsers use decimal for unicode.  So I would convert
243 in decimal to F3 in hex and then I can print the character:

perl -e 'print "\x{F3}\n"

> disable the bell under cygwin?

configuration"--take the case off and remove the connector to the
speaker.

From danh at fork.com  Mon Jun 30 18:32:03 2003
From: danh at fork.com (Dan Haskell)
Date: Mon Jun 30 18:32:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [PDXLUG July 01, 2003 Meeting Announcement]
In-Reply-To: <2632.192.168.1.251.1056951931.squirrel@webmail.tearitalldown.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0306301734070.13475-100000@cohiba.fork.com>

On Sun, 29 Jun 2003, Robby Russell wrote:

> PDXLUG (Portland Linux User Group) presents:
[snip]
> Portland Linux User Group
> http://www.pdxlug.org/

Robby, would you guys PLEASE re-think the naming of your group? First you
pick our old group name (PLUG went by Portland Linux Users Group until
sometime around 1995), then you pick a *really* similar domain name
(pdxlug.org versus pdxlinux.org), and lastly you schedule meetings for the
same time as ours (I appreciate that the current one isn't).

As time goes by, and your stuff gets indexed in the search engines, this
is going to cause major confusion. Imagine someone searching for your
group on the web and coming up with our URL, our mailing list archive, or
meeting schedule - how do they know which is which? The fact that you're
posting meeting announcements on our mailing list will make things all the
more confusing.

It's not hard to come up with alternatives. Here's the result of 10
minutes of thought and a little web browsing:

Portland Linux Enthusiasts
Portland Linux Mafia
PDX Linux Group
Puddle City Linux Group
Stumptown Linux Users Group
NW Oregon Linux Users Group

How about it?

Dan




From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Jun 30 18:35:03 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Mon Jun 30 18:35:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] mp3 players -- separate from the system
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306301506270.9980-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306301506270.9980-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1057023256.14824.27.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Mon, 2003-06-30 at 15:07, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Can anyone recommend an mp3 player to which music can be transferred from
> the workstation? The digital music equivalent of the Walkman, I presume.

A Discman or other portable CD player.  Most will play MP3s from an
ISO9660 CD these days, at a fraction of the cost of memory-based
players.  None of them do Ogg yet, so I'm still SOL.

Wil
--

From robby at planetargon.com  Mon Jun 30 19:40:02 2003
From: robby at planetargon.com (Robby Russell)
Date: Mon Jun 30 19:40:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [PDXLUG July 01, 2003 Meeting Announcement]
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0306301734070.13475-100000@cohiba.fork.com>
References: 
     <2632.192.168.1.251.1056951931.squirrel@webmail.tearitalldown.com> 
     <Pine.LNX.4.21.0306301734070.13475-100000@cohiba.fork.com>
Message-ID: 
     <1252.192.168.1.251.1057027090.squirrel@webmail.tearitalldown.com>

<?echo Dan Haskell managed to take the time to type out the following:

>
> On Sun, 29 Jun 2003, Robby Russell wrote:
>
>> PDXLUG (Portland Linux User Group) presents:
> [snip]
>> Portland Linux User Group
>> http://www.pdxlug.org/
>
> Robby, would you guys PLEASE re-think the naming of your group? First you
> pick our old group name (PLUG went by Portland Linux Users Group until
> sometime around 1995), then you pick a *really* similar domain name
> (pdxlug.org versus pdxlinux.org), and lastly you schedule meetings for the
> same time as ours (I appreciate that the current one isn't).

Why? Feel free to join the list and bring up that suggestion...but I doubt
that it'll hold much ground.

We changed our meetings to be the first tuesday of the month after our
first meeting which conflicted with PLUGs. It was a group vote to do so,
out of courtesy of those who are involved in both groups.

We've been in existance for about 6 months now, have about 100
subscribers, several sponsors, print material, our own bootable distro, a
large media library, our highly active irc channel, etc, etc...

Why doesn't PLUG change it's name?

Are you implying that the average person who looks up Portland Linux User
Group shouldn't see our name towards the top of the list as well?

If Linux has taught me/us one thing about our world...it's choice. Give
people a choice.

We're not trying to take away PLUG subscribers...and this isn't a
competition. Is it wrong to have more than 1 group in town? Is it wrong to
have more than 3 in town? Who cares.


>
> As time goes by, and your stuff gets indexed in the search engines, this
> is going to cause major confusion. Imagine someone searching for your
> group on the web and coming up with our URL, our mailing list archive, or
> meeting schedule - how do they know which is which? The fact that you're
> posting meeting announcements on our mailing list will make things all the
> more confusing.
>
> It's not hard to come up with alternatives. Here's the result of 10
> minutes of thought and a little web browsing:
>
> Portland Linux Enthusiasts
> Portland Linux Mafia
> PDX Linux Group
> Puddle City Linux Group
> Stumptown Linux Users Group
> NW Oregon Linux Users Group

Can I suggest that you change your linux/Unix group to :
The REAL Portland Linux/Unix Group

>
> How about it?
>
> Dan

How about it?

Bobby and Dan,

Why don't you guys both come on my show and talk about both of your groups
this Thursday?  You can promote your installfests, get a copy of the
tape to air in Portland, and tell people about your success stories and
your experiences.  

One of my  guests fell through, but I am not ruling out the
possibility of having beers or dinner with one of the speakers at OSCON
after we tape.

This is a great opportunity for you guys to promote Linux and your LUGs on
a show with a highly agreeable host.


---
Salvador Peralta
http://www.willamette.edu/~speralta
Man is an indifferent egoist.  Even the cleverest thinks his habit more
important than his advantage.

From auto22879 at yahoo.com  Mon Jun 30 20:38:01 2003
From: auto22879 at yahoo.com (Don Baldwin)
Date: Mon Jun 30 20:38:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Red Hat 9.0 and Open Office
Message-ID: <20030701033743.6174.qmail@web10505.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi

I upgraded my 7.3 Red Hat Machine to 9.0.

Open Office worked fine

For some reason the x-windows server started acting
oddly so I reinstalled RH 9.0.  

Now the wheel mouse finally works fine, but the Menu
choices for Open Office Applications are about 4
inches high on the screen.  I use an ATI 32 Mb card
for video.

Has anyone else had a similar problem and what did you
do to fix it?

Thanks

Don

From aschlemm at comcast.net  Mon Jun 30 23:22:02 2003
From: aschlemm at comcast.net (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Mon Jun 30 23:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] attbi -> comcast switch..
In-Reply-To: <CAENLEIHEHPLANCLMFKMIEMKDGAA.mwlist@planetwills.com>
References: <CAENLEIHEHPLANCLMFKMIEMKDGAA.mwlist@planetwills.com>
Message-ID: <200306302320.52043.aschlemm@comcast.net>

I was using port 995 for POP ever since the change from @Home to ATTBI 
occurred back in 2001. I use KMail and when I setup the account I had 
it check what sort of security was supported and used to most secure 
method available to me.

Tony

On Monday 30 June 2003 09:45 am, Mark Wills wrote:
> I have opened the transition pages - with difficulty after many
> refreshes! I suspect the servers are slammed.
> Anthony has the servers right. In addition add netnews.comcast.net
> for News Server
> They also support ssl connection to the POP server (port 995)
> All of my mail was waiting at the new servers. I couldn't get any
> from the old.
> The forwarding seems to work. mail sent to attbi.com or comcast.net
> comes though to the new mail boxes.
> I avoided having to change email addresses by getting my own domain
> name from domainforte.com with email forwarding for $12.95/yr.
>
> Mark
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
> > [mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org]On Behalf Of Anthony
> > Schlemmer Sent: Monday, June 30, 2003 7:38 AM
> > To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
> > Subject: Re: [PLUG] attbi -> comcast switch..
> >
> >
> > I'm not in the Portland area but I did have to transition from
> > attbi.com to comcast.net. The mail server names for POP and SMTP
> > have been changed and everyone gets the "comcast.net" domain on
> > their userids. My user ID stayed the same and everything appears to
> > be working normally for email. It's a pain though since I subscribe
> > to a number mailing lists. At least Comcast is nice enough to keep
> > forwarding email to our new addresses even if people use our old
> > attbi.com domain.
> >
> > I'm assuming everyone will use the following email servers no
> > matter where they are located geographically:
> >
> > incoming (POP) server: mail.comcast.net
> > outgoing (SMTP) server: smtp.comcast.net
> >
> > Tony
> >
> > On Monday 30 June 2003 07:04 am, Brent Rieck wrote:
> > > Hello,
> > >   Has anybody seen the manual switch instructions yet?
> > > connect.comcast.net bounces me to a non-existent server
> > > (online.comcast.net).
> > >
> > > thanks,
> > > Brent

On Mon, 30 Jun 2003, Wil Cooley wrote:
> On Mon, 2003-06-30 at 15:07, Rich Shepard wrote:
> >   Can anyone recommend an mp3 player to which music can be transferred from
> > the workstation? The digital music equivalent of the Walkman, I presume.
>
> A Discman or other portable CD player.  Most will play MP3s from an
> ISO9660 CD these days, at a fraction of the cost of memory-based
> players.  None of them do Ogg yet, so I'm still SOL.

Not to mention the fragility and wastefullness of those (kinda) big
plastic disks.  (Not that I think Rich thinks twice about disposable
anything.)

And many of them have odd limitations like 256 tracks per directory and so
on.

Does anyone make a keychain-sized thing that is ID3-aware and has an LCD?

Ideally, I'd like something that understood m3u playlists.  That'd be the
bizormb.

J.
